data.title: Here's the tea: The first ever Seattle Boba Fest is happening in the U District this weekend
data.description:
Bubble Tea is a drink that folks either love or hate. But here in Seattle, plenty of people are fans of the sweet and satisfying drink. That’s evident in the sheer number of boba shops our city has and also makes sense as to why the first-ever Seattle Boba Fest is happening this weekend! Seattle Boba Fest is happening in the U District with the event page stating that the “U District is fast becoming the heart of the boba scene in Seattle.” It is also a celebration of National Bubble Tea Day which happens to be April 30th. Recent Posts:
You can celebrate an authentic medieval Mayday at Camlann Village this weekend
Maris Farms Baby Animals and Blooms Days kick off this weekend & here’s what to expect  Festival attendees will be able to enjoy 16 unique boba drinks like cream strawberry, white rabbit candy milk tea, TieGuanYin latte, and more. There are also 2 unique boba-centric desserts being offered including vanilla soft serve with brown sugar boba and milk tea ice cream with boba topping. Talk about yummy! This event is only happening for one day only so be sure to mark your calendars. There’s no festival admission, all you have to do is show up to one or a few of the participating boba shops and enjoy. Psst, the festival has a handy map that you can find on their website.

data.title: This Capitol Hill wine shop offers a monthly natural wine club subscription
data.description:
Picking the perfect bottle can be hard, really hard. Wouldn’t it be great if someone could just do it for you? Well, it turns out they can, Capitol Hill’s La Dive has a wine club perfect for folks looking to explore. Here’s how it works. Each month, La Dive select’s their favorite natural wines for their club members. That means when you sign up you can choose between three different subscription options. The first option is two bottles a month for $42, then four bottles a month for $84, or six bottles a month for $120. Recent Posts:
The chef behind Bainbridge Island’s Hitchcock is opening a new resto next month
Washington State Ferries bringing beer, popcorn & more back this month  On the first Monday of each month, you’ll be able to head over to the shop to pick up your order and start your month on a high note! And if you end up finding a new favorite bottle, you’re in luck because you get a 10% off coupon for your next purchase in shop. Pretty great deal huh? Beyond the wine club, La Dive has a full bottle list and drink & eats menu. So start your wine exploration at home and visit the shop for a night out on the town. You’ll probably discover that you’ve found the new perfect spot to meet friends. Enjoy!

data.title: The chef behind Bainbridge Island's Hitchcock is opening a new resto next month
data.description:
Bainbridge Island is already worth the visit but now foodies are going to have an extra reason to ride the ferry. Brendan McGill of Hitchcock is opening Seabird, a brand new restaurant in the former Hitchcock space. Here’s what you can expect. Seabird is set to be a seafood and vegetable-focused restaurant that will open on May 26th. It’s a revitalization of the old Hitchcock space with a sharper menu and complete kitchen renovation and dining room refresh. Expect an overall PNW beach vibe with nautical-themed works of art. Recent Posts:
Lucky Envelope Brewing is hosting a series of tasty pop ups this May & you don’t want to miss out
10 of the best places to go glamping in Washington  So what can you expect to see on the menu? You’ll be able to find an iced shellfish section with a “rotating selection of local oysters, and other gems from the sea like spot prawns, geoduck, and green sea urchin.” Additionally, you’ll be able to find small plates like albacore tartare, octopus salad, chinook salmon Crudo, and more. There will also of course also be large plates like wood-fired halibut with summer squash, black garlic mole, and squash blossom, as well as seared sturgeon with potato fondant, kumquat kosho beurre blanc, and roasted little gems among others. And yes, there’s a thirst-quenching wine and cocktail program that will also accompany the menu. Until Seabird opens you can keep up with updates on their Instagram.  Enjoy!
data.when: 133 Winslow Way East #100, Bainbridge Island, WA

data.title: Lucky Envelope Brewing is hosting a series of tasty pop ups this May & you don't want to miss out
data.description:
May is Asian American, Native Hawaiian, and Pacific Islander Heritage Month aka AANHPI! In order to celebrate Lucky Envelope Brewing will be serving up limited-edition beers and tasty pop-ups that you don’t want to miss out on. Let’s get into the details. The event kicks off on Friday, May 6th with the Tasting Room releasing weekly limited availability beers. They’ll also be hosting AANHPI-owned food vendors twice weekly. Some of those vendors include Mike’s Shave Ice, Kathmandu MoMoCha Food, Panda Dim Sum, and more. Recent Posts:
Three Washington cities just ranked among the most physically active in the US
The Station is hosting a night market this Friday and you don’t want to miss it  While this month of food pop-ups and limited edition brews is already a must-visit, you can feel good knowing that your purchases are giving back. A portion of all May Tasting Room beer sales will be donated to the Asian American Journalist Association’s Seattle Chapter and also to the Very Asian Foundation. Cheers to that! If that wasn’t enough for you, there will also be journalist spotlights throughout the month. These spotlights feature both past and current members of the journalism industry. The spotlights are meant to educate the public on why diversity and inclusion are important in the industry. Keep up with all of the tasty deets at Lucky Envelope Brewing’s Instagram. Enjoy!

data.title: Money Frog is Capitol Hill's newest spot for pan-Asian eats & it opens tomorrow
data.description:
It looks like Seattle’s restaurant scene is only getting better and better, with yet another new addition from the folks behind Taurus Ox and Hangry Panda. The new spot is called Money Frog, continuing on with the theme of cute animal names. It serves up pan-Asian cuisine in the former location of Capitol Hill’s Vios. If you ever dined at Vios in the past then you’ll know there’s plenty of room while still remaining cozy. That being said, Money Frog is looking like a great place to enjoy meals with a group of pals. Especially when you see all the delicious items on the menu. Recent Posts:
Foodie Fest is bringing together 13 of Seattle’s most popular pop ups this April
Seattle Restaurant Week is back and on now with over 200 participants  You can dine on items like condensed milk peanut prawns, soft shell chilli crab, and green beans. You’ll also find menu items like fried frog legs, cacio e pepe with yakisoba noodles and curry ketchup fried rice. Our mouths are already watering. If you’re ready to give them a try you’re in luck because Money Frog’s grand opening is tomorrow, April 13th. You’ll be able to get a first taste at the menu as well as drinks. Why not have a hump day celebration? Happy eating!
data.where: : Grand opening April 13th, Wednesday-Sunday 4 pm-9 pm

data.title: Foodie Fest is bringing together 13 of Seattle's most popular pop ups this April
data.description:
This spring is full of food festivals and now its time to add one more to your list of events to check out. Foodie Fest is being put on by locally owned restaurant group Heigh Connects and is bringing together 13 of the most popular Seattle pop ups for you to enjoy. Let’s get into the tasty details. Foodie Fest I taking place later this April at The Stone House Cafe. You’ll find a mix of food, retail and even live sets from local DJs. Food will be available outside from individual vendors and drinks  will be available inside Stone House. Recent Posts:
Seattle Restaurant Week is back and on now with over 200 participants
See more than 80 life size dinosaurs at this new immersive exhibit in Seattle  The participating food vendors include Sea Sandwich, Your Kuyas, Puffy Pandy, Ramen Ramen, Grayseas Pies, Mike’s Shave Ice, Laina’s Handcrafted Ice Cream, Jay Blue Thai, and Half Lion Brewing. Best of all there are no tickets for this event, you simply have to show up and enjoy the eats. That being said, as is the case with most pop ups, items will probably only be available while supplies last so be sure to be early if there’s a certain pop up you’re really craving. Enjoy foodies!

data.title: Seattle Restaurant Week is back and on now with over 200 participants
data.description:
The tastiest bi-annual event of the year is on now! That’s right folks, Seattle Restaurant Week is back until April 16th with over 200 participating restaurants. It’s one of the best ways to satisfy your taste buds and also support Seattle’s culinary community. If you’ve never attended Seattle Restaurant Week before, featured restaurants offer a prix fixe dining promotion meaning you get a chance to try all sorts of great food. You can choose between $20 lunches and/or $35, $50 or $65 dinners. What’s more, you can choose between takeout or onsite dining, and this year, give meal options, as well as pop-ups, have been added. Recent Posts:
West Seattle could soon have it’s own transit gondola from the Junction to SODO
The Seattle plane building is nearing it’s final stages, here’s what’s new  No matter where you live, you should be able to participate as there are over 45 neighborhoods and cities in the Greater Seattle area represented. That means it’s almost guaranteed that a restaurant near you is participating. If you’re looking for something in particular the event’s website has an easy-to-use search tool that can help you break down your search by cuisine, neighborhood, cost, and more. Some of the notable participating restaurants this year include Monsoon, Nue, Rione XIII, and many more. Don’t miss out!

data.title: The Fairmont Olympic's stunning new restaurant officially opens today
data.description:
Happy Monday Seattle! We know it’s not everyone’s favorite day of the week but today there’s a reason to celebrate. Why, you ask? Well because The Fairmont Olympic’s new restaurant, The George is finally opening after a much anticipated wait. The opening marks the end of the hotels $25 million dollar restoration project that began in January 2020. The restoration also included another notable spot, The Founders Club which opened earlier this year. That means you have more than one reason to check out the new and improved Fairmont. Recent Posts:
5 hidden bars & speakeasies that you can visit in Seattle
MariPili is Seattle’s newest Galician spot and is opening next month  The George will be run by newly appointed Restaurant Executive Chef Thomas Cullen. Chef Cullen will set the new restaurant apart with a brasserie-inspired menu. Expect a showcase of PNW seafood, dry-aged meats, produce, sustainably foraged items, and more. Some of the signature dishes include a traditional French bouillabaisse, The George seafood tower featuring a plethora of the sea’s best offerings, and Painted Hills bone-in short rib with heirloom carrots and natural jus. Of course, the menu will also be accompanied by an extensive bar program with hand-crafted signature cocktails created by Jesse Cyr, the hotel’s award-winning Beverage Curator. To fully package the experience, guests will be able to dine in a stunning interior by Spanish design studio Lázaro Rosa Violán (LRV). The new space balances the hotel’s classic elements while adding modern flair and is sure to end up on your Instagram feed. So what are you waiting for? Book yourself a reservation today. Enjoy!
data.where: : Opening April 4th, Tuesday-Thursday 5 pm–9:30 pm, Friday & Saturday 5 pm–10:30 pm

data.title: Seattle's newest Korean restaurant just opened in Ballard
data.description:
Nothing quite like a new restaurant to help us all end our weekend on a high note! Ballard’s gastropub, The Gerald has a whole new identity thanks to chef Wes Yoo who has just opened WeRo earlier this March. The new restaurant is a Korean spot centered on comfort. Yoo decided to open the restaurant after seeing the effect the pandemic had on the city of Seattle. A brave choice as many long-standing restaurants closed for good. Nonetheless, Yoo believed that he could help bring comfort to the city through Korean food which he found so soothing throughout his early life. Recent Posts:
12 amazing Seattle patios with great views of the city
Here are 12 of the tastiest spots to grab sushi in Seattle  The restaurant’s goal is to show Seattle the different types of Korean cuisine, authentically reflecting the diversity of delicacies available on the peninsula. Some of the menu items you can enjoy include YookHweh (Korean style beef tartare with prime tenderloin), Salmon Jorim (king salmon seared and poached in spicy and sweet broth with daikon served with rice), and much more. WeRo also has a full bar including Korean drinks like soju and makgeolli so treat yourself this weekend and try something new or enjoy an old favorite!

data.title: Final Call: This is your last month ever to grab a brew at Hale's Ales
data.description:
All good things must come to an end, including Hale’s Ales, one of the Northwest’s oldest and longest-running independently-owned breweries. While it is sad news, now is the perfect time to stop by grab a brew and celebrate. After all, it’s your last chance. Hale’s Ales was started in 1983 by Mike Hale and built a reputation over the years for full-flavored ales crafted using traditional English brewing methods. What’s more, Hale’s was the “first craft brewery to introduce Seasonal, Cask Conditioned, and Nitrogen Conditioned ales to the region.” That’s a pretty big deal! Recent Posts:
Cheers to this: A look at Seattle’s newest breweries
Hi Life is Bainbridge Island’s newest poke spot & is worth the ferry ride  Not only is Hale’s known for their brews but they’re also known for hosting the Moisture Festival, which by the way is happening right now. The brewery will be sorely missed by its many fans who have had a brew or two over Hales 39 year history. Especially because at this time it appears that Hales closure includes its production. Like many other businesses during the pandemic, Hale’s had a hard few years and owner Mike Hale is ready for retirement. So add a few more memories to this classic Seattle spot, you have until April 9th to grab a brew. Bring your friends, your SO, or maybe even your coworkers!
data.where: : Monday-Friday 3 pm-9 pm and Saturdays 12 pm-9 pm, Closing April 9th

data.title: Wolf and Woman & chef Tiffany Ran are collabing for an unforgettable pop up this April
data.description:
There are tons of foodie centric events to look forward to in the coming months. Between food festivals and new farmers markets, your eating calendar is probably looking pretty full. But be sure to leave room on April 11th because Wolf and Woman and chef Tiffany Ran are collaborating for a pop up thats sure to be out of this world. Wolf and Woman opened in Seattle in 2017 with a focus on Malaysian Tamil cuisine and while the cuisine remains the same these days, they’re now based in San Diego. Chef Tiffany Ran is known for her uber popular pop up Ba Ba Lio Taiwanese which can often be found at Fair Isle Brewing. While both are equally delicious on their own, the collaboration of the two is sure to be a taste you won’t soon forget. Recent Posts:
Hi Life is Bainbridge Island’s newest poke spot & is worth the ferry ride
10 of the best cafes to work remotely from in Seattle  The pop up dinner will take place at Lottie’s Lounge in Columbia City on April 11th and will have six dishes that blend  elements of Malaysian and Taiwanese cuisine. It’ll cost $55 per person. Here’s the deal, as both the resto and pop up are extremely popular, reservations are currently sold out. The good news is that you can join the waitlist which is probably worth doing considering the event is a month out and someone is bound to cancel. In the meantime you can always enjoy Ba Ba Lio and who knows, maybe just maybe, another seating will be added to this tasty event.

data.title: Hi Life is Bainbridge Island's newest poke spot & is worth the ferry ride
data.description:
In need of an excuse to get on island time? The owner of Rondo and Tamari Bar, Makoto Kimoto has you covered. Earlier this month he opened Hi Life, a new poke spot right next to the Bainbridge Island Ferry Terminal. The new spot is on the casual side with a main focus on poke. Customers can enjoy 12 types of poke bowls with classic garnishes like seaweed salad, imitation crab, tobiko and more. Some of the protein choices include multiple flavors of salmon, scallop, octopus among others. If you’re in the mood for a little bit of everything, there’s a bento style poke box to ensure you can experience it all. Recent Posts:
Here are 12 of the tastiest spots to grab sushi in Seattle
The Seattle-Tacoma International Airport is about to get a major facelift  Beyond poke you’ll also be able to pick up Japanese curry as well as the famous Pike Place Chowder clam chowder topped with the addition of Hi Life’s house Japanese chilli oil. Additionally, you’ll also be able to pick up highballs, which only makes sense considering the drink is the restaurants name sake and will be the focus of the restaurants drink menu. So whether you’re looking for an excuse for a road trip, live on Bainbridge or already have a trip in the works, be sure to stop by Hi Life. As they are brand new hours are bound to change and fluctuate so be sure to check their Insta before making your trip. Enjoy folks!

data.title: Kamino Sushi and More is Seattle's only Burmese resto & you can visit it in Uptown
data.description:
Seattle has its fair share of diverse eats but not every cuisine is represented. For many years Seattleites have been missing out on Burmese cuisine, until now. Uptown’s Kamino Sushi and More is quietly serving up some of the country’s most popular dishes and you can try them. The restaurant describes itself as serving up “traditional sushi recipes blended with modern, mind blowing flavours.” What’s more, the restaurant has partnered with Master Chef Tin Tin Oo, the Season One winner of Master Chef of Myanmar in 2018-19. Her 12 years of experience in the art of Japanese Burmese cuisine inform the dishes that Kamino serves.  Recent Posts:
Seattle is the most desired post-graduation destination for college students
10 of the best cafes to work remotely from in Seattle Alongside a wide sushi menu, the restaurant offers three Burmese dishes. The star of the Burmese side of the menu is the Tea Leaf Salad aka Laphet Thoke. It’s made from fermented young tea leaf salad, shredded cabbage, slice tomato, fried dried bean, peanut, garlic, chili, sesame seed, and sesame oil. As Kamino Sushi and More is still relatively new on the scene they don’t have a big social media presence. So in order to get an idea of the dishes you’ll have to visit them yourself. Think of it as a unique new activity to add to your week, enjoy folks!
data.where: : Monday-Saturday 1 pm-10 pm, Sunday 1 pm-5 pm

data.title: Seattle's Lark restaurant has returned after a two year hiatus, here's what's new
data.description:
Openings, closings, restrictions, liftings, delays, all the joys of living through several years of a pandemic. Ready for some good and tasty news? We’ve got you. Seattle’s Lark restaurant is open once again after a two-year hiatus during the pandemic. If you’re unfamiliar with Lark, the restaurant is known for serving up the best of the Pacific Northwest’s bounty. They work with local farmers, ranchers, fisheries, and foragers to serve the best of each season, creating delicious and truly seasonal dishes for diners to enjoy. If you’re all about farm to table, this is your spot. Recent Posts:
Did you know? The history of Seattle’s Fremont Troll
10 rocking concerts coming to Seattle this March  For their return Lark is serving up a four-course dinner menu that changes monthly and features locally-produced and organic cheeses, charcuterie, vegetables, grains, fish, and meats. These dishes are all prepared with the restaurant’s signature focus on flavor and quality. Some menu items include Palmer Ranch wagyu steak tartare, Squid ink spaghetti, Wild black cod, and Butterscotch budino among many. The dinner costs $120 per person and you can also add a $70 wine pairing should you choose. If you’ve been looking for an excuse to dine out, let this be it.

data.title: The Ellensburg Winterhop Brewfest kicks off next weekend
data.description:
Looking to enjoy some brews this month? You’re in luck because the 18th Annual Ellensburg Winterhop Brewfest is on February 26th, 2022. It’s your chance to visit downtown Ellensburg and experience craft beer from local breweries, live music, shopping, and more. So what does this event entail? A $45 ticket to Winterhop Brewfest will include general admission into the event, a commemorative tasting glass, and 5 beer Sscrips. A $60 ticket includes early access to the event starting at 11:30 am, a commemorative tasing glass, 5 Beer Scrips, and a swag bag. Recent Posts:
Downtown Seattle streets are actually brick & here’s why that’s cool
You can watch people race motorcycles on ice later this month in Washington  This year’s event features 21 breweries, 4 cider and/or seltzers, and 5 venues. Some names include Wander Hob, Blewett, Moonshot, and more. You’ll also be able to tune into performers like Jayleigh and The Lost Boys, Micah J, Spiced Rye, and more. Tickets are on sale now and considering that this event takes place next weekend we’d recommend purchasing those tickets ASAP. You can grab tickets and learn more at the Winterhop Brewfest website. Enjoy folks!

data.title: Here's a first look inside The George, The Fairmont Olympic's new restaurant
data.description:
In case you didn’t know, The Fairmont Olympic has been under a $25 million dollar restoration project since January 2020. And now all of that hard work is coming to a close with the opening of the hotel’s newest signature restaurant – The George. It’s an experience that both long-time and new Fairmont guests will enjoy. The George will be run by newly appointed Restaurant Executive Chef Thomas Cullen. Chef Cullen will set the new restaurant apart with a brasserie-inspired menu. What’s more, it will be a showcase of the PNW’s best offering, seafood. Patrons will be able to dine on the freshest seafood straight from local waters as well as dry-aged meats sourced from farms across the PNW. Recent Posts:
Check out these tasty pop ups in Seattle this week
Fremont’s newest vegan bakery serves beautifully decorated cakes That’s not all though, you can expect to find artisan cheeses, PNW produce, sustainably foraged items, and more. Some of the signature dishes include a traditional French bouillabaisse, The George seafood tower featuring a plethora of the sea’s best offerings, and Painted Hills bone-in short rib with heirloom carrots and natural jus. Of course, the menu will also be accompanied by an extensive bar program with hand-crafted signature cocktails created by Jesse Cyr, the hotel’s award-winning Beverage Curator. And all of this will happen in a fresh new interior by Spanish design studio Lázaro Rosa Violán (LRV). They’ve created a space that balances the hotel’s classic elements while adding modern flair. While we know you’re probably chomping at the bit to grab a reservation, you’ll have to wait until the restaurant’s opening on April 4th. But you can plan ahead and place your reservations as early as March 7th.

data.title: Fremont's newest vegan bakery serves beautifully decorated cakes
data.description:
A new addition to Seattle’s food scene is always a reason to celebrate, even more so when that addition is purpose-driven. Lazy Cow Bakery in Fremont has opened its doors after years of planning and is serving up plant-based treats as well as acting as a community space. If it sounds cool, it is so let’s get into some details. Lazy Cow Bakery is owned by Lara de la Rosa who has been serving up her delicious treats at the West Seattle Market. With the new permanent location, customers will be able to find a pastry menu with items like croissants, meringue tarts, flan, and much more. Additionally, customers will be able to order eye-catching hand-decorated cakes for all of their celebration needs. Recent Posts:
15 of the most romantic Airbnbs you can find near Seattle
Here’s a look at the world’s first NFT Museum in Seattle & it’s next show  That being said, de la Rosa wants to do more than just serve up delicious baked goods. So Lazy Cow Bakery is associated with the social justice organization, La Casa Del Xoloitzcuintle. It’s a “Latinx mutual aid organization that responds to the needs of the community.” The bakery comes into play here because it has a free community fridge & food pantry and donations are welcome anytime during the bakery’s normal business hours. So you can eat your cake and give it too. For now, Lazy Cow is offering beautiful Valentine’s Day boxes one for $25 that comes with a slice of red velvet cake topped with a chocolate strawberry and an almond croissant. And another in partnership with Frelard Tamales for $124 that comes with 15 mini tamales, flowers, vegan candles, and a taster box of Lazy Cow’s goodies. If you’re not in the market for a Valentine’s Day box your best bet is to keep up with Lazy Cow on social media as they’ll be having a grand opening later this month.

data.title: Dough Joy just opened its first permanent location on Capitol Hill
data.description:
In May 2021, Seattle was blessed with a brand new vegan donut food truck, Dough Joy. It was sorely needed in a city that has fewer vegan options than one may expect. Understandably, it’s taken off and as a result of its popularity now has a permanent home on Seattle’s Capitol Hill. Dough Joy’s Capitol Hill store opened its doors just last week to a perfectly pink interior with a minimalistic design so that you can focus on choosing your donut. Because when there are so many options, it’s hard to choose. You’ll find all your old favorite donut flavors, as well as some new ones. Recent Posts:
Onigiri pop-up Sankaku just opened a permanent location on Capitol Hill
6 Lunar New Year events and eats to check out in Seattle this year  According to the store’s Instagram, Birthday Cake was the most popular new flavor. Keep in mind that they regularly rotate and create new flavors, so you might just find a new fave each time you visit. And while the store works out all of its newnesses, they will be open until sold out each day and keep the food truck closed for the time being. So treat yourself this week, head over to Capitol Hill, and nosh on a delicious plant-based donut. Psst if you grab a coffee, be sure to ask to have your drink topped with the pink plant-based whip, yes it’s a real thing. Enjoy!

data.title: Seattle's Life on Mars just released a hemp-based, non-alcoholic drink menu
data.description:
Want to head to the bar without the buzz? Then a trip to Mars is in order, well, Capitol Hill’s Life on Mars that is. The bar is more than a bar, it’s also a record shop and restaurant. And now they’re adding non-alcoholic drinks to their line up of things to be known for. Last weekend, Life on Mars released a special menu featuring 9 non-alcoholic cocktails just in time for Dry January. These 9 drinks feature Pathfinder, a “fermented and distilled hemp-based liquid with the intense flavor and aromatic characteristics of a spirit.” That means you can get the taste of alcohol with out the harmful effects. Recent Posts:
Onigiri pop-up Sankaku just opened a permanent location on Capitol Hill
Here are 5 unique heated patios worth visiting in Seattle this month Some of those drinks include a Pathfinder Spritz made with Pathfinder N/A Amaro, Citrus, Soda and the N/Americano made with Pathfinder, Giffard Aperitif and Soda. All of the drinks have inventive names and flavours with something for everyone. Its a great way to try non alcoholic cocktails if you’ve been curious and also if you want to go out and hit the bar with your friends in a sober friendly way. According to Eater Seattle, on the 26th of January even more non-alcoholic cocktails will be released. This release is part of Life on Mars’ “N/A in the Mix”, a special evening of non alcoholic drinks on the last Wednesday of every month. So get out there and treat yourself to this unique limited time beverage menu while you can.
data.where: : Tuesday & Wednesday 4 pm-11 pm, Thursday 4 pm-12 am, Friday 4 pm-2 am, Saturday 10 am-2 am, Sunday 10 am-11 pm

data.title: Onigiri pop-up Sankaku just opened a permanent location on Capitol Hill
data.description:
Love hole in the wall spots? Well, Seattle’s beloved Sankuku pop-up just opened its first permanent location inside of Melrose Market. It’s not exactly a hole in the wall but it’s tucked away and if you didn’t know where to look you might just miss it. Let’s check it out. Sankaku opened its doors right next to Butter Home inside of Melrose Market in early January. Their spot is small, minimal and features a white and bright decor. They’ve started off slow and steady with a small menu full of delicious items. You can score onigiri with fillings like ume, salmon basil, tuna mayo, and more. Recent Posts:
Here are 5 new restaurants in and around Seattle to check out now
Here are 5 unique heated patios worth visiting in Seattle this month  They also serve up side dishes like a cabbage salad, sesame cucumbers, and hijiki nimono, a salad with mixed veggies and hijiki seaweed. That’s not all though, they also serve up sake, bubbles, and some soft drinks as well. So stop by for lunch or head over after work for a bite and a drink. Be sure to check Sankaku’s Instagram for current hours as they appear to change regularly. That being said if you’re in the area it’s well worth swinging back to see if they’re open treat yourself to an onigiri.

data.title: Field to Table returns next month with over 20 menus to choose from
data.description:
The first-ever dining series on a professional sports field returns to Seattle this February. Field to Table is your chance to dine on eats from some of the city’s best chefs in an intimate dining experience on the turf. It’s 20 days of tasty goodness that you don’t want to miss out on. Field to Table takes place throughout February with a new menu every single day. Some of the featured chefs include Mel Miranda of Musang, Kristi Brown of Communion, and Maximillian Petty of Eden Hill. Menu items’ ingredients are diverse, ranging from foraged mushrooms to wagyu beef to heirloom citrus. Recent Posts:
These are Seattle Public Library’s most popular books of 2021
Here are 5 new Seattle restaurants to check out this January  Like last year’s event, diners will be seated in a tent on the field. The experience lasts between 1.5-2 hours and you will be able to purchase drinks. That means everyone attending must be 21 or older. As with last year’s event, reservations are going quickly so book yours ASAP. In order to attend, you will need to provide proof of COVID-19 vaccination or a negative COVID-19 test result taken within 72 hours prior to the event. As the event is taking place inside of Lumen Field, a clear bag policy is in place.

data.title: Seattle's newest cafe is all about being low waste & sourcing locally
data.description:
We all love a good cafe, especially a brand new one! Bake Shop is Seattle’s newest cafe and venture from Hot Cakes former director of operations Krista Nelson and London Plane alum Madeline McDonald. What sets this new cafe apart is its dedication to staying low waste. Bake Shop believes that “a responsible business takes care of the planet.” That’s why they work to reduce waste through sourcing in bulk, working with local farms, and not using single-use plastic in their kitchen. They also encourage customers to bring their own mugs and to-go containers, offering $.25 off when you bring your own cup. Recent Posts:
Wunderground has opened its first cafe in Seattle with a full drink & eats menu
Cirque du Soleil returns to Seattle next week with a brand new show  Bake Shop is an all-day café meaning you’ll find a menu full of options like house-made baked goods, sourdough bread, as well as a small savory menu with toasts, sandwiches, and salads. Additionally, you can sip on coffee, loose leaf teas, beer, and wine. Give them a visit for breakfast, lunch, or before the next show at Climate Pledge Arena. Or you can always order online for pick up if you’d rather enjoy your eats at home. Be sure to double-check Bake Shop’s socials for hours before you head out. Enjoy folks!
data.where: : Tuesday-Friday 7 am-7 pm, Saturday & Sunday 8 am-7 pm

data.title: This Seattle pop-up serves a new hyper-local & organic menu every 2 weeks
data.description:
It’s no secret that Seattle has a great, ever-evolving food scene. Throughout the pandemic, we’ve watched as dining standards have completely changed. From upscale dine-in experiences to pop-up and takeout dining models. And if you consider yourself a local foodie, we have a pop-up with a hyper-local focus that you might just want to try. Three Sacks Full is a pop-up from Chef Michael Tsai and Sommelier Matthew Curtis. Together the duo has created a pop-up with a focus on organic vegetables, grains, and locally sourced ingredients as well as wines to accompany them. What makes this pop-up extra cool is that they grow the majority of ingredients on their very own Snoqualmie Valley farm. Recent Posts:
A new bookshop that pairs unique reads and natural wine is opening in Seattle
You can take a real class called “Calling Bullsh*t” at the University of Washington  Because of their dedication to their craft and hyper locality, you’re not only getting delicious and wholesome meals, but you’re also supporting the regional food loop that keeps Washington thriving. What’s more, this pop-up releases a new menu every two weeks, so you can try seasonal produce and maybe even get inspired to cook up your own meals using ingredients from the PNW. Some past menu items have included wild yellow foot chanterelle and heirloom bean stew, pasture-raised chicken stew with violet queen turnips, and grilled sourdough flatbread to name just a few items. The menus feed 1-2 people making it a great choice for switching up your weekly dinner menu or sharing with a friend or SO. The next pop-up menu goes live on January 15th and you’ll be able to pick up your meal on either Tuesday, January 18th, or Wednesday, January 19th. If you’d like to learn more or sign up for pop-up updates you can click below.
data.where: : Tuesday pick up at Ebb & Co. 3404 NE 55th St, Wednesday pick up at La Medusa 4857 Rainier Ave S

data.title: Dick's Drive-In is finally opening it's new Bellevue location this week
data.description:
It sure has been a year for Dick’s Drive-In. From their recently announced temporary Capitol Hill closure to food trucks, the fast-food chain has been busy. So busy that you might have forgotten about the promised, permanent Bellevue location which by the way officially opens this week! Last February, the fast-food chain announced it was looking to open a Bellvue location and ultimately decided on a spot at Bellevue’s Crossroads Mall. It will be the chain’s 8th location and is a welcome relief to eastside burger fans. But regardless of whether or not you live on the east side, you’ll probably want to check out the grand opening. Recent Posts:
Seattle just ranked as the most caffeinated city in the nation
3 Washington cities just ranked among the most generous cities in the country  The grand opening celebration will take place on Thursday, December 16th, and will be full of fun. Visitors can enjoy a pop-up apparel shop for your holiday shopping needs, and a DJ playing some rocking tunes. Additionally, there will be performances from the local Sammamish High School Band and Bellevue High School Band and Cheer Team. So get out there, check out the ribbon-cutting ceremony, tunes, and more as you become one of the first to purchase burgers on the Eastside. You can click below to learn more. Enjoy folks!

data.title: There's a new speakeasy hidden in a bookcase at Seattle's Fairmont Olympic Hotel
data.description:
You may or may not remember but earlier this year, the Fairmont Olympic Hotel’s bar got a massive facelift. And part of that fancy-schmancy series of renovations included a hidden speakeasy. If you’re looking for an unforgettable night of drinks, history, and design, a trip to the Founders Club may be in order. Upon entering The Olympic Bar, you’ll be surrounded by almost a century of history. Expect to see beautiful heritage details as well as fresh modern accents for a completely unique space. To make things even more unique, the bookcase lining the wall is more than it seems, it’s the entrance to The Founders Club, a hidden speakeasy. Recent Posts:
Seattle has a retro Christmas pop-up hidden in an auto-garage
Seattle’s iconic venue The Crocodile reopens in a big new home this December  The intimate space seats only 30 people and is inspired by 1920’s speakeasy culture. The look is defined by deep, rich wood tones and the soft glow of polished brass. Expect something moody and warm with plenty of gravitas and mysterious energy. Not only is it a beautiful space, but it also features an exquisite spirit collection hand-selected by Fairmont Olympic’s award-winning Beverage Curator, Jesse Cyr. On the menu, you’ll find innovative cocktails unique to the Founders Club like the Cafe Racer with Camus VSOP Cognac, Le Verger, Lemon, Yuzu and Grapefruit Bitters. So what are you waiting for? Treat yourself to a night of original drinks in one of Seattle’s coolest hidden bars. Click below to learn more and make reservations.

data.title: Sippin Santa returns to Seattle as a holiday pop-up bar this month
data.description:
On Wednesday, November 24th, curious sippers will be able to get a sneak peek at this kitschy and thirst-quenching event. Then starting on Friday, November 26th, Sippin Santa will be in full swing daily from 4 pm-11 pm for festivities. So dust off those Christmas sweaters and get ready to have a drink or two. Seattle Center’s Winterfest is back next month with its classic train, ice sculpting & more
GeekCraft Expo is coming to Seattle this month with over 100 ‘nerdy’ vendors  You can expect holiday-themed drinks in perfectly kitschy cups surrounded by decor like twinkling lights, ornaments, and tinsel. It’ll feel as if you’ve stepped into a Christmas tree in the best way possible. Who knows, you might just end up with some inspo for your own holiday parties. You’ll soon be able to book your reservations so grab your friends and find the perfect day to visit. Keep in mind that you will need to provide proof of vaccination in order to attend. If you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: The 'World's Most Unusual Vending Machine' pops up in Portland this weekend
data.description:
Atlas Obscura is bringing something unusual to Portland, OR. To celebrate the launch of their book Gastro Obscura: A Food Adventurer’s Guide, they built the World’s Most Unusual Vending Machine. So grab your keys and let’s get into some details as we make the 3-hour drive. Folks sampling the machine’s goodies will get to taste a curated selection of unique foods and beverages. From taste bud-bending miracle berries to color-changing edible flowers, they’ve compiled a selection of curious items from around the world into one simple vending machine. And while it’s touring the country, Portland is as close to Seattle as the machine is getting. Recent Posts:
Gobble Up is returning to Seattle this month with 100+ vendors & its FREE to attend
10 of the tastiest spots for dim sum in Seattle  The vending machine is making its debut on Saturday, November 13th at the Portland Art Museum’s sculpture garden. And if you choose to attend the main event you’ll also be able to partake in a meet & greet with co-author Cecily Wong from 2-5 pm. Additionally, you can eat from tasting stations featuring local items like oysters, wagashi, fermented goods, and even hard cider. To make things even more unique you’ll be able to tune into a special fruit and vegetable synth performance. So if you’re looking to take a trip this weekend and get your hands on some eats, a trip to Portland might not be such a bad idea. You can learn more about the vending machine by clicking below and if you choose to go be sure to reserve your free tickets online ahead of time as the machine can only accommodate 1000 people. Enjoy folks!
data.where: : Portland Art Museum Sculpture Garden, 1219 SW Park Ave, Portland, OR

data.title: Gobble Up is returning to Seattle this month with 100+ vendors & its FREE to attend
data.description:
Thanksgiving is a great excuse to treat yourself to your favorite dishes. But just wait until you hear about all of the delicious goodies you can enjoy the weekend before at Gobble Up Seattle. Urban Craft Uprising’s premier food show is back for an in-person event later this month that you don’t want to miss. Gobble Up features over 100 of the best craft food and beverage makers in the PNW and it’s totally free to attend. You can walk around sampling food, discover new products and ingredients and even partake in chances to win free raffle prizes. Seriously, why not attend? Recent Posts:
Here are 11 places to enjoy Thanksgiving dinner in Seattle this year
Wunderground has opened its first cafe in Seattle with a full drink & eats menu   Expect to find locally crafted treats like artisan sauces, chutneys, CBD chocolates, and more. You can also find new and beautiful kitchenware like handmade potholders, cutting boards, and unique ceramics. Plus if all that sampling is making you hungry you can stop by a number of food trucks and purchase items like fresh seared scallops, paella, sushi burritos, and Ethiopian dishes. Whether you simply want to sample and browse, stock up on unique ingredients or shop for the perfect gift for the foodie in your life, Gobble Up is well worth attending. While attending is free you do need to register online ahead of time and you will also need to provide proof of vaccination when attending. You can learn more and register by clicking below.

data.title: Wunderground has opened its first cafe in Seattle with a full drink & eats menu
data.description:
Earlier this year a unique, mushroom-centric coffee brand popped up in Seattle. And now Wunderground is making things permanent with its first cafe on Capitol Hill. They’re serving up all your favorite caffeinated drinks with the added benefit of the adaptogenic powers of mushrooms. If you haven’t heard of Wunderground yet they’re woman and LGBTQ+ owned. They’re all about providing consumers with a drink that gives you a creative buzz while also giving you the health benefits of each mushroom. And to make them even cooler, they make sure that 75% of the premium price goes back to the smallholder coffee farmers that they work with. Recent Posts:
Seattle is now the largest US city to decriminalize mushrooms & other psychedelics
11 of the best free and cheap things to do in Seattle this November  Now back to the cafe. The focus of the cafe is the coffee beverages featuring mushrooms like Chaga, lions mane, reishi, and cordyceps but you’ll also be able to snag some tasty food items. Some of those items include grain bowls, bone broth, pastries, and sandwiches on fresh-made bread. That means you get the best of both worlds, tasty flavors, and healthy eats. So if you’re in the mood to try something new this week, a visit to Wunderground can’t hurt. Who knows, it might just become your new favorite coffee shop. If you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: Ba Bar is opening a vegan walk-up window at its SLU location next week
data.description:
Pho enthusiasts and vegans can rejoice in a brand new offering from the beloved Seattle Vietnamese restaurant Ba Bar. The local restaurant group’s South Lake Union location just opened a walk-up window geared towards vegans. It’s called Ba Bar Green and you’ll be able to get your hands on the menu starting November 12th. According to an interview with Eater Seattle, owner Eric Bahn said the new addition comes with diners changing preferences. He stated “many are moving away from eating meat and are more curious about plant-based eating” and also mentioned “flexitarians” aka folks who are conscious about their meat consumption. And now those folks can follow their dining preferences and needs at a dedicated vegan outpost. Recent Posts:
Here are 5 new restaurants in and around Seattle to check out now
A new bookshop that pairs unique reads and natural wine is opening in Seattle  The new walk-up window will have both grab-and-go and made-to-order items for diners to choose from. Some of the menu items will include kabocha and sweet potato malay laksa, Singapore noodles, veggies, and JUST Egg as well as dan dan noodles with Beyond Meat. You’ll also be able to grab banh mi with options like soyrizo or braised tofu. We know it’s going to be an inpatient week for many of you plant-based eaters out there but in the meantime, you can enjoy vegetarian options at Ba Bar’s other locations. If you’d like to learn more about the new walk-up window you can click below. Enjoy folks!

data.title: The Wandering Goose has officially reopened on Washington's Olympic Coast
data.description:
We all know that the pandemic hit many restaurants hard and led to the closure of some of Seattle’s OG favorites like The Wandering Goose. But now that things are steadily picking up again it’s time for new beginnings. Get excited, because The Wandering Goose is back in a new and very unique home. The beloved Capitol Hill establishment that served up some of Seattle’s favorite southern dishes has found a new home at the old Tokeland Hotel. Now where the heck is that? Good question. The Tokeland Hotel is located on Washington’s scenic Olympic Coast and it happens to be the oldest hotel in the state. So that means it might just be time to book a little vacation. Recent Posts:
The 41st Seattle International Comedy Competition is back this year with 33 comedians
Seattle is being scouted by FIFA as a potential host for the 2026 World Cup  Best of all you don’t have to wait for a grand opening because as of Monday, November 1st, The Wandering Goose is open. When you visit you’ll be able to nosh on your old faves as well as seasonal specialties that highlight the hidden coast of Tokeland. Some of the listed menu items include Eggs Benedict, Fried Rockfish Sandwich, Chicken Fried Pork Chop, and many other delicious items. Plus you can expect some of the old restaurant’s charm thanks to the fact that the Tokeland Hotel is from the Victorian Era. If you’re looking for an excuse to drive out to the coast, let this be it. Also, keep in mind that next week you’ll be able to get free National Park admission so feed two birds with one scone and have an adventure while eating some of your old favorites. You can learn more by clicking below.
data.where: : Breakfast & Lunch 8 am-2 pm, Supper 4 pm-8 pm

data.title: Seattle just got the nation's first Hokkaido-style soft-serve spot & it's time to try it
data.description:
Sure it’s fall but we’re always in the mood for ice cream. Especially now that Wallingford gem Yoroshiku is serving a delicious kind of soft serve that might not be available anywhere else in the nation. We’re talking about Hokkaido-style soft-serve. Yoroshiku’s owner Keisuke Kobayashi has tried a lot of soft serve. But none of them have been quite like the delicious soft serve that he’s used to in his home of Japan. So he decided to open Indigo Cow and show us all just what we’re missing. Recent Posts:
You can now score Seattle Kraken branded Filson gear at select team stores
10 of the best free or cheap things to do in and around Seattle this October Now you don’t have to go far to get your hands on this delicious treat because the soft serve shop is actually inside Yoroshiku. Right now, the shop serves just one flavor and that is Hokkaido milk. It’s what gives this soft serve its delicious flavor and Kobayashi wanted to make sure folks got to taste it in all its glory. Now if you’re a fan of flavors, get excited because rotating monthly special flavors are on their way. You can soon expect to see flavors like matcha, black sesame, and yuzu. But here’s the deal, due to demand, there are only 300 servings available daily so you might have to wait a bit to try. Either way, get out there and give it a go and if you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: Seattle's Miracle Christmas pop-up bar is returning this year as festive as ever
data.description:
Well folks now that it’s October, people like to forget that November exists and look straight ahead to everyone’s favorite holiday of the year. You know, Christmas? If you’re already looking for ways to get in the holiday spirit, we might just have the event for you. In fact, you could even call it a Miracle… The wildly popular Christmas-themed Miracle bar is returning to Seattle in the form of a pop-up cocktail bar. It’s the ultimate spot to snag holiday cocktails in a festive setting. You’ll feel just like papa Noel yourself as you sip professionally-developed cocktails surrounded by kitschy holiday décor. Recent Posts:
You can visit the real-life Halloweentown and it’s just 3 hours from Seattle
Bella Swan’s house from Twilight is an Airbnb and you can stay in it (PHOTOS)  If you’ve felt a little grinchy this past year, you definitely need to treat yourself to a visit to the Miracle Seattle pop-up this winter. Of course, be sure to wear your best Christmas fits because you might as well be as over the top as the decor itself. Now while the exact dates have yet to be released, we do know that this year’s pop-up is taking place at Rob Roy. And if things are at all like last year’s pop-up, it will likely start in late November and run until late December. With all that in mind, be sure to look for more info on Rob Roy’s Instagram here. And if you want to see where else this pop-up is happening or grab more details you can click below. Enjoy folks and don’t miss out on the best opportunity to get in the holiday spirit.

data.title: This elevated Seattle steak & sushi place is one of the best to grab an after work happy hour
data.description: A couple of years ago when the 31st floor of the Lincoln Square South in Bellevue became home to the Ascend Prime Steak & Sushi, there was some buzz. The buzz doubled up when they opened doors to the public, courtesy of their upscale decor, the exquisite views of Lake Washington and the city set against a mountainous backdrop, the mind-blowingly delicious food and the craft cocktails. From being recognized as the most romantic restaurant to the best fine dining establishment to that of one having award-winning desserts, Ascend Prime earned itself quite a few acclaimed titles.  Three years later, we are still raving about its elevated (literally and figuratively) dining and lounge experience. Alright Seattle, now imagine this: You’ve put in a long hard day at work. You drag your tired self all the way up to the 31st floor of the Lincoln Square South with your friends/ work buds to unwind. Amidst views that last for days and an ambience that could lift large boulders, let alone your mood, you dig into a heaven-in-your-mouth delicious steak prepared from olive-fed beef. As you eat and chit-chat your way to de-stress city, you also enjoy a smooth, craft cocktail. Are you imagining it all? Good! Now, imagine reveling in this surreal sky-high dining experience minus the sky-high prices. Yes, wow indeed! The steakhouse and sushi bar recently relaunched its enticing Happy Hour menu. As if we needed any more reason to love this architectural gourmet gem. The Happy Hour goes on from 3 pm to 6 pm and then again from 9 pm onwards. With a long list of cocktails & wines, $6 draft beers, and delicious appies and snacks, we just can’t get enough. You can check out the full Happy Hour menu right here.  Don’t know about you but we sure are ready for this mile-high gastronomical rendezvous.
data.when: Lincoln Square South- 10400 NE 4th St Ste 3100, Bellevue, WA

data.title: Seattle Restaurant Week returns with over 200 participating spots later this month
data.description:
The tastiest bi-annual event of the year is returning later this month. That’s right folks, Seattle Restaurant Week is back between October 24th and November 6th with over 200 participating restaurants. It’s the best way to satisfy your taste buds and also support Seattle’s culinary community. If you’re unfamiliar with this event, featured restaurants offer a prix fixe dining promotion that gives you a unique chance to try all sorts of great food. You can choose between $20 lunches and/or $35 or $50 dinners. What’s more, you can choose between takeout, delivery, or on-site dining. Recent Posts:
10 of the best bakeries in Seattle to grab a fall pastry
Both Washington state and Seattle just ranked as the most neighborly places in the US  This event is pretty hard to miss as it takes place at venues in over 45 neighborhoods and cities in the Greater Seattle area. So that means it’s almost guaranteed that a restaurant near you is participating. If you’re looking for something in particular the event’s website has an easy to use search tool that can help you break down your search by cuisine, neighborhood, cost and more. Some of the participating restaurants that we’re excited about are Nue, Rione XIII, Shiro’s Sushi and many many more. You can click here to learn more and also check out the full list of participating restaurants.

data.title: You can drink beer out of a massive pumpkin at this October Seattle festival
data.description:
Pumpkin carving is one thing but sipping beer out of a giant pumpkin is a whole other deal. If that sounds like an absolute blast to you, get excited because the 17th annual Great Pumpkin Beer Festival is back and better than ever this October. Let’s get into some deets. A giant, several-hundred-pound pumpkin is the centerpiece of this Seattle Center festival. The pumpkin in question is scooped, scorched, filled with pumpkin beer, sealed, conditioned, and then tapped at the fest for all to enjoy. It’s unlike anything you’ve experienced before and a great way to welcome in fall if you’re a beer lover. Recent Posts:
10 of the best u-pick pumpkin patches in and around Seattle
You can visit the real-life Halloweentown and it’s just 3 hours from Seattle  Now not only will you be able to sip beer out of a massive pumpkin but you’ll also be able to enjoy over 80 pumpkin and seasonal beers from both near and far. It’s also worth mentioning that 20 of those beers come straight from Elysian so expect the best of the best. After all, what could be better than pumpkin beer? Oh, what’s that? All 100% of the proceeds will benefit The Vera Project. Yep, this thirst-quenching festival helps keep one of Seattle’s OG youth-driven music and art venues alive. You don’t want to miss out on this super fun festival and if you want to grab tickets or learn more you can click below.

data.title: A boozy Alice in Wonderland-style tea party is coming to Seattle this winter
data.description:
Have you ever wanted to fall down the rabbit hole without all the complications that ensue from the Alice in Wonderland multiverse? Well lucky you because a brand new, immersive tea party experience is coming to Seattle this November. Get ready to eat, drink and play like never before. The folks behind pop-ups The Wizard’s Den and Beyond Cinema are bringing Seattle a magical journey that you don’t want to miss! The Wonderland-themed concept bar will pop up at Knee High Stocking Co in Seattle beginning November 24th for a limited time only. It has all the aspects of the classic Brothers Grimm fairytale that will have you wondering if you’ve really stepped out of this world. Recent Posts:
A terrifying haunted house returns to the site of Seattle’s most gruesome unsolved crime
You can visit the real-life Halloweentown and it’s just 3 hours from Seattle Guests will be able to create their own liquid concoctions under the watchful eye of The Mad Hatter. You can expect things to get more and more curious as the night goes on. Dive into Wonderland with a game of flamingo croquet, paint the roses red, and devour ‘Eat Me’ cake. Don’t forget to solve riddles and challenges so that you can unlock all the ingredients to create your own enchanted teapot cocktails. Come and experience Alice’s adventure in the heart of Seattle at the tea party to end all tea parties! The 90-minute alternate reality experience in Wonderland includes 2 bespoke cocktails and an ‘Eat Me’ cupcake. We have a feeling that tickets will go fast so be sure to click below to learn more and purchase them. Enjoy your journey folks!

data.title: Kobuta & Ookami is Capitol Hill's newest spot for delicious katsu-style dishes
data.description:
If you’re looking to eat something new this week you’re in luck because a brand new Japanese restaurant opened its doors this month. Kobuta & Ookami is a Japanese katsu and sake house on Capitol Hill. It’s pretty much the perfect fall spot. The new restaurant’s menu revolves around katsu-style dishes made with both meat and veggies. You can score various pork cuts, chicken, prawn, and even multiple styles like classic katsu, miso katsu, and katsu nabe which is a Japanese-Korean fusion dish served in a clay pot. Recent Posts: 
Enjoy some of Seattle’s most diverse eats at this food festival happening now
9 German restaurants in Seattle where you can celebrate Oktoberfest anytime  One of the more unique menu options is the tomato and cheese dishes. They come with tomato miso sauce, grated Parmesan, rice, miso soup, shredded cabbage, and pickles. But if you want to keep it to what you’re comfortable with, you can go wrong with a classic katsu don or katsu curry. Now as the name suggests, the restaurant also has tons of sake for you to choose from. Between the tons of options and a wide menu, Kobuta & Ookami is definitely worth adding to your fall eats list. If you’d like to learn more you can click below. Enjoy folks!
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 11 am-3 pm & 5 pm-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 11 am-3 pm & 5 pm-9:30 pm, Sunday 12 pm-3 pm & 5 pm-9 pm

data.title: A new Seattle restaurant from a local star chef is already booked months in advance
data.description:
Seattle’s dining scene has had quite the year from openings and closings to chefs moving and more. One of the most notable moves was that of Canlis’ head chef Brady Williams. As you might remember he left Canlis to open his own restaurant, Tomo which debuted only a couple weeks ago. The new, highly anticipated restaurant seats 28 and serves two 5-course tasting menus for a price of $68, and also offers a weekend lunch. Menu items are inspired by a combination of Williams’ Japanese heritage and chef de cuisine Diana Mata Garcia’s Venezuelan heritage. Their creations utilize Pacific Northwest ingredients, resulting in a truly unique fusion menu. Recent Posts:
10 of the best things to do in & around Seattle this week (September 13-17)
Seattle just got super strict with food delivery apps & here’s what to know  What perhaps sets Tomo apart the most is the exceptional fine dining experience free of formality and also at a relatively affordable price. The restaurant’s ethos really does live up to its namesake which is Japanese for “pal” or “friend.” So consider treating yourself and a friend or two to dinner at White Center’s newest restaurant. Now keep in mind, Tomo is booked through October but a waitlist is open. If you’d like to enjoy a full dining experience you’ll need to plan ahead and make room in your November calendar. But if you’re impatient and want to try your luck, you can snag walk-in bar seating and a limited à la carte menu Thursday–Sunday. With that enjoy and if you’d like to learn more you can click below.
data.where: : Thursday & Friday 5 pm-9 pm, Saturday & Sunday 11 am-2 pm, 5 pm– 9:00 PM

data.title: Enjoy some of Seattle's most diverse eats at this food festival happening now
data.description:
If you’re looking to eat your way around Seattle this weekend then you need to check out Plate of Nations. This festival is the signature event of the MLK Business Association and promotes independently-owned restaurants in the MLK community aka Rainier Valley. For the next 10 days, you can join in on these restaurants traditions and try some of the most diverse food in the city. This year you can dine at 15 southeast Seattle restaurants that are taking part in Plate of Nations. Cuisines range from BBQ to Ethiopian to Hawaiian and more. What’s extra great about this festival is the fact that you can do it on your own time and pick and choose just which restaurants you’d like to visit. And you can enjoy menus crafted perfectly for tasting a bit of everything priced affordably at $20-$30. Recent Posts:
9 German restaurants in Seattle where you can celebrate Oktoberfest anytime
A Seattle brewery just won one of the nation’s most prestigious beer awards  If you end up going big and visiting multiple restaurants you’ll want to download the Plate of Nations Passport. This passport allows you to log which restaurants you visit during the festival and how many times you visit. And the top 6 individuals with the most PON stamps will receive prizes, so be sure to fill yours out. Some of those prices include a $40-$100 PON gift card to a participating restaurant of your choice and PON swag. So treat yourself to some delicious eats and maybe even a prize. If you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: A Seattle brewery just won one of the nation’s most prestigious beer awards
data.description:
Well folks it looks like Seattle is about to get put on the map for something more than tech and coffee. Seattle’s Cloudburst Brewing has won the “The Brewery and Brewer of the Year” at the prestigious Great American Beer Festival in Denver. Looks like it might just be time to grab a pint. The Seattle brewery won the award for the small brewery category which is defined as brewing 1,001 to 2,000 barrels yearly. Cloudburst definitely lives up to the small brewery identity as they only have 7 full-time employees according to the Seattle Times. So you can imagine what a shock and also honor this was for the folks at Cloudburst. Recent Posts:
Fremont Oktoberfest returns this month as Seattle’s largest beer fest & tix are on sale now
Here are 7 boozy brunch spots to hit up in Seattle this weekend  But it’s probably not too much of a shock to Seattleites as this brewery is well-loved. They’re known for creating unique brews and owner and head brewer Steve Luke was a 2020 James Beard semifinalist for “Outstanding Wine, Beer or Spirits Producer”. So clearly the folks at Cloudburst know a thing or two about making good beer. That being said, they weren’t the only local brewery to win at the Great American Beer Festival. In fact, 21 other medals went to breweries both in Seattle and across the state. If you’d like to check out all of the winners of the Great American Beer Festival you can click here. And if you’re looking to grab a drink this week, a visit to Cloudburst Brewing is definitely in order. Not to mention some tasty new IPAs will be hitting the taproom soon. You can click below to find out more.

data.title: Seattle is getting a week-long Negroni event this month & tons of spots are participating
data.description:
Wish you could sip cocktails all week long? Well, you’re about to have the perfect opportunity to do just that. Negroni Week is kicking off in Seattle this coming Monday, September 13th, and tons of bars and restaurants all over the city are serving up the tasty Campari-based cocktail for a good cause. From September 13th-19th, you’ll have the opportunity to drink your way across the city and taste different takes on the Negroni. If you’re unfamiliar with the drink it’s classically made with gin, vermouth Rosso, Campari, and an orange peel for garnish. If it sounds tasty, trust us it gets even better because a portion of the sales going to one of Negroni Week’s charity partners. Recent Posts:
This delicious $29 sandwich from a local spot has Seattleites obsessed
10 Seattle restaurants with big dishes perfect for sharing with friends  Featured charity partners range from COVID-19 relief to food insecurity to homelessness to animal welfare. That means you can enjoy your drink even more, knowing that the money you’re spending on it is going to a good cause. And in case you didn’t know, this event is kind of a big deal. Negroni Week takes place in over 12,000 cities worldwide and raises a collective $3 million for charitable causes. There are 28 spots participating in Negroni Week around Seattle, including Lady Jaye, Navy Strength, Rob Roy, Roquette, Spinasse, and more. Registration is still open for more bars and restaurants to sign up. You can see a complete list of them here. If you’re ready to get your drink on you find out more about the event by clicking below. Have fun and drink responsibly.

data.title: This delicious $29 sandwich from a local spot has Seattleites obsessed
data.description:
If you keep up to date with Seattle foodie Instagram’s then there’s a sandwich that you’ve probably seen gracing your feed quite a bit. Well, it’s not exactly a sandwich…rather it’s a lobster roll. A big one. Can you see it yet? It’s the $29 sandwich from Edmonds spot The Market that has had folks obsessing across the city. A $29 sandwich might sound like quite the price to pay for a relatively small amount of food. But the key ingredient here is the lobster. It’s fresh, straight from the Gulf of Maine. The crustacean’s freshness along with a Macrina warm toasted roll, house aioli, celery, gherkins, arugula, brown butter, and fries make this sandwich unforgettable. Recent Posts:
Fremont Oktoberfest returns this month as Seattle’s largest beer fest & tix are on sale now
Here are 7 boozy brunch spots to hit up in Seattle this weekend  While the Connecticut-style lobster roll is the star here, the menu has plenty of other items. You can grab other delicious seafood items like fish & chips, chowder, crab, oysters, shrimp, and more. Whatever you choose you’re probably going to love it and if you’re balking at the sandwich price, it’s definitely a treat yourself item. Now we know that Edmonds is a bit far for some of your homebodies but there is good news. According to an article from The Stranger, it looks like a location of The Market will be opening at Seattle Art Museum next month. So you can either wait for that opening or head to Edmonds in the meantime to get your hands on this tasty sandwich.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 11 am-9 pm, Saturday & Sunday 10 am-9 pm

data.title: Volunteer Park Cafe has opened after 8 months with new ownership and a new look
data.description:
Tucked away on Capitol Hill’s 17th Ave E is one of the neighborhood’s favorite and maybe oldest haunts. You might have already guessed but we’re talking about Volunteer Park Cafe. The business sold last November and has been in the reinvention process since. After 8 months, things are finally back in business with new owners and a new identity. Volunteer Park Cafe quietly reopened earlier this August and remains a local favorite for coffee, pastries, and good old hangs with friends. Now with new ownership comes some change. The new owner James DeSarno is a local architect and co-owner of Freehand Cellars, so he’s made some aesthetic changes while keeping favorite elements like the original counter and vintage “groceries” sign. Related posts:
Here are 7 boozy brunch spots to hit up in Seattle this weekend
10 of the best things to do in & around Seattle this week (August 23-27)  Because of Desarno’s wine background, the new Volunteer Park Cafe also has more of a focus on wine. That means you can visit the cafe later in the day for a drink after work. But the cafe will still keep its main focus which is breakfast, coffee, and pastries. And in order to make sure their offerings are the best of the best, the cafe has brought on pastry chef Crystal Chiu and manager Melissa Johnson. Both Chiu and Johnson are former Canlis alums so you can expect all sorts of goodness. If you’re looking for somewhere new to try this week stop at Volunteer Park Cafe and show them some love. It’s been a constant in the North Capitol Hill neighborhood for decades and its return is very welcome. You can learn more by clicking below. Enjoy folks!

data.title: The Spheres' mysterious 'Deep Dive' bar has finally reopened after over a year
data.description:
The Amazon Spheres are an undeniably eye-catching landmark in Seattle. But what lies inside them might be even cooler. We’re not talking about the indoor garden, rather we’re talking about Deep Dive. It’s the bar that’s tucked away in the spheres and it just reopened after being closed for over a year. If you haven’t visited Deep Dive before it’s part of Renee Erickson’s Sea Creatures Group. It’s a great place to grab eats and drinks in a truly unforgettable environment. And as the name suggests, the restaurant’s interior truly feels like you’re doing a deep dive, it’s dark and mysterious, full of velvet, antiques, and curiosities. You’ll definitely snap a few pics while you’re here. Related posts:
Here are 7 boozy brunch spots to hit up in Seattle this weekend
Here’s how Climate Pledge Arena is preparing for the Seattle Kraken  As with most reopenings and restaurants these days there are some new rules in place. Those rules include providing proof of vaccination and ID upon entry, however, the bar has stated that a photo of your vaccination card will suffice. You can also dine and drink here if you have a negative COVID test that was administered within 48 hours of visiting. Of course, masks must be worn until seated as well which is now mandatory statewide. Best of all, you can cap this week with a visit to Deep Dive as the bar is open from Thursday until Saturday. An online waitlist is available from 5 pm-8 pm so we recommend putting your name on the list when you visit as this spot is quite popular. With that, enjoy!
data.where: : Thursday, 4 pm-10 pm, Friday & Saturday, 4 pm-11 pm

data.title: This former fine dining resto is downtown's newest lunch spot
data.description:
Dining has definitely changed quite a bit in the past year. From sit down to take out to patios and back to dine in, it’s hard to keep up with how quickly things change. So in order to get with the times, the W Seattle has transformed their former fine-dining restaurant TRACE into TRACE Market. TRACE Market is open for breakfast and lunch and serves up artisanal, fast, local, and earth-friendly eats. You can expect dishes inspired by the PNW’s regional bounty and you can enjoy these dishes with dine-in, take-out, and grab-and-go options. So if you live or work downtown you might just want to check out the menu. Related posts:
The 10 most relaxing places you can find in Seattle for when you need a chill day
The 2021-2022 Seattle Arts & Lectures lineup just went live and you don’t want to miss out   For a little menu preview, you can expect to see items like avocado toast, a bagel sandwich, salads, and more! The menu is small but that means it’s just easier to pick when you’re busy on the go. But if you want to spend a little bit more time at TRACE Market you can also stop in for hand-crafted cocktails, local liquor, and both local and international wines. If you’re wondering, they do have a happy hour so you can make this your after work pit stop. On Fridays & Saturdays, you can score $5 beers and $6 house wines by the glass, as well as bites between $6-$9 and entrees under $16. So keep them in mind next time you’re downtown. You can learn more by clicking below.
data.where: : Breakfast: Daily 7 am-11 am, Lunch: Daily 11 am-2 pm, Happy Hour: Friday & Saturday 5 pm-11 pm

data.title: You can enjoy seafood-centric sandwiches at this local burger joint all month long
data.description:
Love Lil Woody’s burger month? Just wait until you hear about their Seattle Seafood Month happening right now! You can enjoy delicious seafood-centric sandwiches made by the beloved burger joint and 4 local chefs. Best of all, you have the opportunity to try a new sandwich each week. As we’re already halfway through August somehow, there are only two sandwich rotations left in Seattle Seafood Month. This week you can snag the “Lil Local Burger” by Chef Victor Steinbrueck of Local Tide. The burger has rockfish, a pork and shrimp patty with sweet mayo, chili garlic oil, cabbage slaw with sesame vinaigrette on a Lil Woody’s bun. We know what you’re having for lunch today. Related posts:
The 2021-2022 Seattle Arts & Lectures lineup just went live and you don’t want to miss out
10 of the best things to do in & around Seattle this week (August 16-20)  If you happen to be a fan of McDonald’s you’ll be excited to know that next week’s burger is the “Lil Woody’s Fillet-O-Fish”. It was created by Chef Brian Miyamoto of Lil Woody’s. The fish sandwich has beer-battered Alaskan pollock, pickle-ly tartar sauce, shredded lettuce, and American cheese on a Lil Woody’s bun. It’s sure to become a new favorite of yours. If you’d like to try one of these delicious sandwiches all you have to do is head to a Lil Woody’s location. This week’s sandwich is available until the 23rd and next week’s sandwich will be available until the 30th. So get out there and enjoy a seafood sandwich this week, you can learn more by clicking below.

data.title: This beloved American restaurant is hosting it's first annual BBQ competition in Washington this month
data.description:
What’s more American than BBQ? Probably only the flag itself. Well, if you yourself happen to be a huge BBQ fan then you’re going to need to check out the 1st Annual Famous Dave’s Washington BBQ Competition. Whew, that’s a mouthful! It’s happening later this month in Everrett and is probably going to be one of the tastiest events of summer. To help you have a great late summer, Everett’s Famous Dave’s BBQ has teamed up with the Pacific Northwest Barbecue Association to host this new annual BBQ competition. And best of all, it’s happening in a family-friendly and safe parking lot party format. That means you can go solo, bring friends and of course, the fam. Related posts:
Looking for new Seattle restaurants? Here are 6 to try this August
31 things you have to do in and around Seattle before summer is over Attendees will be able to watch as almost 30 teams compete to smoke the best meat. Teams will cook off in different categories including chicken, pork ribs, and brisket. Each of which will be judged by KCBS-certified BBQ judges. And to make things even more unique, Famous Dave’s will be providing the meats for the teams so that judges can really tell who knows how to smoke the best meat. Teams are competing for a prize purse of $5,000 as well as a chance to land a team’s name on the menu at select Famous Dave’s locations. The biggest of all though is the chance to compete at the Daniel’s World Championship Invitational BBQ Competition and The World Food Championship. Who knew there were that many BBQ competitions? Beyond the competition, attendees will also be able to nosh on Famous Dave’s BBQ, enjoy kids’ activities, yard games, music from radio personality B-Dub and 98.9 The Bull, and relax at a 21+ drink garden. Because you’re probably wondering, admission is free but you will have to purchase food and drinks. So end your summer on a high note and treat yourself to watching the tastiest competition in town. You can learn more by clicking below.
data.when: 1402 SE Everett Mall Way, Everett, WA

data.title: Bellevue's brand new spot is an international sensation & serves 'sea salt' soft-serve
data.description:
Looks like it’s going to be another hot weekend in the PNW and you know what the means. We’re all going to be looking for ways to cool down. By far the tastiest option is treating yourself to some ice cream, so why not check out Aqua S, a brand new Australian soft-serve spot that serves up extravagant cones. Aqua S began in Sydney, Australia with a goal to be the best soft serve spot around. Judging by the fact that even though they only launched in 2015, they now have stores in Australia, the US, China, and Singapore, it looks like they’re doing a pretty great job. It’s hard not to love a soft-serve spot that rotates flavors bi-monthly and has over 100 flavors in its history. Related posts:
Looking for new Seattle restaurants? Here are 6 to try this August
This interactive map shows the places in Seattle that make people the happiest  While all the flavors and flavor combos are delicious, the signature sea salt ice cream is what has folks coming back time and time again. It’s described on the Aqua S website as ‘sweet and creamy with a hint of saltiness’ and hails originally from soft-serve in Okinawa, Japan. It’s vibrant blue color that you’ll see all over the shop’s Instagram page is also hard to miss. Along with the soft-serve flavors, Aqua S offers toppings like cotton candy clouds, toasted marshmallows, and more. If you’ve been looking to go big with soft-serve then it looks like it’s time for you to head over to Bellevue and give Aqua S a try. They’re still pretty new as they only opened in July so be sure to show them some love. Of course, tag us in the tastiest pics you take. Enjoy folks!

data.title: Dick's food truck is popping up at Hello Em with a star chef from TikTok this month
data.description:
This month you’ll be able to enjoy a triple whammy of delicious local eats from Dick’s Drive-In, Hello Em, and Matt Broussard. The trio is popping up for a one-time Dick’s food truck event with proceeds going to Friends of Little Saigon. It’s your best chance to support local chefs and a great cause this month. On August 10th you’ll be able to try Viet-Poutine Fries by Tik-Tok’s favorite chef Matt Broussard. To make things even better you’ll also be able to try Pho Bac Pate Gravy by chef Yenvy Pham of Hello Em/Pho Bac and you can have it as a topper for your fries or deluxe! But this is only happening once so you don’t want to miss it. Related posts:
Seattle could break its all time ‘days without rain’ record this week
A brand new Topgolf venue just broke ground in the Seattle area  Ready to secure your spot? Your $75 reservation includes fries and gravy for 2, $20 in Dick’s Gift Certificates, a Retro Fanny Pack, and Retro Sunglasses. Additionally, it includes a $55 donation to Friends of Little Saigon to invest in the Little Saigon community in Seattle’s CID. When you think about the cost breakdown and everything you get, it’s pretty dang affordable. Right now there are still 6 different time slots available for purchase between 11:30 am and 2 pm. Now because this is a pop-up with so many local faves we recommend getting on purchasing those tickets ASAP. If you’d like to do so or learn more you can click below.

data.title: You can catch live music & food events every Friday on Pier 62 until September
data.description:
If you’re looking for the perfect way to unwind after work on Fridays, we have just the solution for you.
