That is KEXP’s Beats & Eats series which allows you to enjoy food and music between the city and Puget Sound. Each week you’ll be able to hear from different KEXP DJs as they spin live. This unique music and food series happens every Friday from 4:30 pm to 7:30 pm on Pier 62’s waterfront park. When you arrive you can grab a bite or two to eat from the local onsite food trucks and sit back to watch the DJs spin. Best of all, the series runs until September 3rd so you still have plenty of time to check it out. Related posts:
This beloved plant-based Seattle restaurant just opened a stunning rooftop patio
This Seattle waterfront restaurant has a floating dining area and urban market  You can head over this Friday to hear Mike Ramos or check out Brit Hansen, Lace Cadence, Kennady Quille,  DJ Sharlese, and DJ Riz each Friday in August. Check out one set or start going every Friday and make it part of your weekend plans. After all, chilling out on the sound with local food and tunes kinda seems like the dream. If you’d like to learn more about Beats & Eats you can click below. Just remember you can always bring your friends, your SO, or just go solo. It’s a great way to wind down after the week and also to support both Seattle’s music and food scene. Enjoy folks!

data.title: A wildly popular boozy brunch fest returns to Seattle in August & you can still get tix
data.description:
Seatle is chock full of brunch fanatics and if you count yourself as one then you need to check out Bacon Eggs & Kegs. This wildly popular, brunch festival is back for another year this August at Lumen Field, and tickets are on sale now! You can snack and drink to your heart’s content all while socializing with fellow brunch lovers. This year you can enjoy eats from 12 different restaurants including local faves like Where Ya At Matt, Watson’s Counter, Wich Came First, and more. Additionally, you’ll be able to sip on brews and drinks from tons of local breweries which have yet to be announced. It’s one of the few events where day drinking is acceptable and even encouraged. Related posts:
This beloved plant-based Seattle restaurant just opened a stunning rooftop patio
Seattle is getting its first permanent outdoor hair salon at the end of this summer  Beyond enjoying an array of eats and drinks you’ll also be able to partake in all sorts of games. You can play games like giant beer pong, giant Jenga, cornhole, and more. And if you’re feeling musically inclined you can also rock out to dueling pianos on the Bacon Eggs & Kegs main stage. Who knows what all those drinks will bring out in you. If you’d like to grab tickets we recommend doing so ASAP as August 14th is already sold out. If you purchase tickets for August 15th, your ticket will include 12 drink tokens and access to the event. When it comes to food you’ll have to purchase it separately but hey it’s worth it. Now it’s also worth mentioning that the event benefits SCM Medical Missions. It’s a nonprofit focused on “bringing relief and aid to people affected by conflict and natural disaster within the Middle East and North Africa”. So you can really feel good about all the fun you’re having. You can learn more about the event by clicking below. Have fun out there folks!

data.title: Ballard's wizard-themed bar is opening soon after a three year build out
data.description:
After a long year, Ballard could definitely use a touch of magic. And that’s exactly what it’s about to get as it looks like the wizard-themed bar by the name of Splintered Wand will open at the end of July. Now, this bar has been in the works since 2018 and it’s set to be a truly magical experience that will you transport you out of the city and maybe even this world. The Splintered Wand takes up several floors in Ballard’s historic Flatiron Building which was built in 1896. The reason why the bar is so expansive is because it’s also going to have a wand shop and event space. Visitors can make custom wands based on their astrological signs in workshops taught on the second floor. Or they can rent out the third floor’s private event space. Plus it looks like some magic and spell classes might be taught here in the future. Related posts:
This beloved plant-based Seattle restaurant just opened a stunning rooftop patio
10 of the best things to do in & around Seattle this week (July 26-30)  Already sounds pretty cool right? Well get this, the Splintered Wand is really all about the experience. So when you visit you’ll be greeted in character by all of the witches and wizards that will serve you up the bar’s thirst-quenching selection of boozy potions. It also looks like you’ll be able to snack on some British pub-influenced foods but a menu has not been released yet. Now with that in mind, the bar will be 21+ but you can opt to have drinks made without booze. It feels pretty safe to say that a visit here is almost like a show as you’re getting a lot more than just a drink and meal. Now because this is something Seattle doesn’t really have yet, it’s probably going to be pretty dang popular. For that reason, reservations will only be available online to start. So if you’re looking to have a magical experience we recommend clicking below to keep up with the opening and we might just see you there. Enjoy folks!

data.title: This beloved plant-based Seattle restaurant just opened a stunning rooftop patio
data.description:
It’s the best time of the year and patio dining is in full swing in Seattle. If you happen to be a fan of patio dining, you’re going to be pumped to know that the Flora Bakehouse now has a stunning rooftop patio. That’s right, it looks like it’s time for you to take a trip over to Beacon Hill. If you’re unfamiliar, the Flora Bakehouse is from the people behind the long-time local fave, Cafe Flora. The Bakehouse describes itself as the “perfect connection between Cafe Flora and Floret”. It’s one of the best spots in Beacon Hill to snag both sweet and savory baked goods ranging from croissants to quiches and more. Of course, they also have tons of vegan options. Related posts:
You can get ‘mushroom coffee’ from this local pop-up this weekend in Seattle
Seattle is getting its first permanent outdoor hair salon at the end of this summer  The new rooftop patio or deck as they call it is a new space to enjoy your favorite goodies. You can soak in views of Mount Rainier and even sip on a glass of wine or two. In the above Instagram post, the Bakehouse mentions that they’re introducing a curated wine and beer selection for patio goers to enjoy. And it looks like you’ll be able to purchase by the bottle as well. So start your Monday off right and treat yourself this week to a delicious pastry and some PNW views on the Flora Bakehouse’s new patio. We can’t wait to see what they do with the space and love to see local spots continuing to grow. Enjoy folks!
data.where: : Monday-Tuesday 7 am-2 pm, Wednesday-Sunday 7 am-8 pm

data.title: Fulfill your sandwich craving with one of these massive chicken sammies
data.description:
You know us, we’re always looking for new and unique eats in Seattle. And we just found a spot that you’re definitely going to want to check out. It’s called Yummy Meats & Deli and they have some truly massive sandwiches that will fulfill all of your wildest sandwich dreams. We always love a spot that’s straight to the point with the menu. Yummy Meats & Deli is exactly that, offering you a choice between sandwiches, noodles, or Nashville hot fried chicken. And while the whole menu sounds yummy, we’re mostly interested in those sandwiches and the chicken. Specifically the chicken sandwich with a whole slab of meat in it. Related posts:
It looks like patio dining in Seattle might be here to stay
Capitol Hill has a new plant-based restaurant focusing on seasonal PNW cuisine  We feel like this sandwich is probably best for two or some for now and some for later. And there’s nothing wrong with that in our books, it just means more food to savor. Now if chicken isn’t your thing, you can also enjoy a variety of pork sandwiches. Honestly, it’s probably worth it to try them all. Now, this restaurant is a bit out of the way because it’s in Renton. But the good news is that they do delivery with both Grubhub and Doordash. Regardless, it’s pretty much a pick-up/takeout only spot so if you can, definitely consider picking it up yourself to save the restaurant some money. With that, enjoy and if you’d like to learn more you can click below!
data.when: 509 S 3rd St., Unit B Renton, WA

data.title: The newest member of one of Seattle's top restaurant groups opens in Phinney Ridge today
data.description:
New restaurant alert, new restaurant alert! It feels like it’s been a little bit since we’ve heard about a new Seattle spot. But that’s all changing because the newest member of the General Harvest Restaurant team is coming to Phinney Ridge. Give it up for Autumn Seattle! Autumn “focuses on a simple approach to pasta, seafood & vegetables”. If you ask us, that sounds like prime PNW cuisine. Due to Chef Brian Clevenger’s love for local seafood and produce we’ll bet that the menu has at least a few locally sourced ingredients. We don’t know about you guys but it definitely seems worth a try. Related posts:
You can’t miss this weekly food truck festival right here in Seattle
Seattle’s own Spice Waala is releasing delicious soft serve flavours this summer  What’s best of all is that Autumn actually opens today! That means you can hop online and snag a reservation for today or sometime this week. Now there are limited timeslots left so if you’re dying to try we recommend hopping online ASAP. Because you don’t want to miss out on tasty eats do you? If you’d like to learn more about Autumn you can click below. As always, if you make it there before we do be sure to let us know what you think and snap some tasty pics. Enjoy folks and we might just see you out there!
data.where: : Dinner: Monday–Sunday 5 pm-10 pm, Happy Hour: Monday-Friday 5 pm–6 pm

data.title: An immersive floral-filled dining experience is arriving in Seattle this July
data.description:
We’re all about limited-time dining experiences. They’re a great way to try inventive, fresh, and often in-season eats from amazing local and international chefs. That’s why we’re super excited about Cafe Nordo’s Bloom! dining experience. The menu is full of amazing local and in-season ingredients with a beautiful setting. Nordo’s Bloom! menu was of course created by Chef Erin Brindley and was “inspired by the undeniably hopeful feeling of new growth and transformation in the air after an impossibly difficult year”. The menu is a multi-course pre-fixe dinner and even includes live music. All of the dishes feature amazing ingredients full of the Pacific Northwest’s early summer bounty. Not only are they tasty but they’re also beautiful. Related posts:
Seattle’s oldest Japanese restaurant is back after a massive makeover
Seattle’s favorite bread pop-up is going permanent this fall  This isn’t your regular old dining experience, no, Cafe Nordo went all out and created three stunning Escher-esque rooms. They’re each full of their own unique blooms and were uniquely designed by designers and artists complete with specialized lighting. This means you can either opt for the per head dining experience or rent out the whole room for up to eight people if you feel like going big. Now you’re probably curious about what exactly is on the menu. Some of the dishes include things like the “Chrysalis” a dish inspired by the Monarch Butterfly. It’s a fresh roll cocoon filled with black garlic, sesame, mango, radish, cucumber,
and butterfly pea noodles served with a mint sauce. See? Pretty dang amazing. If you’d like to learn more or get your hands on reservations you can click below. You really don’t want to miss this one.

data.title: Seattle's oldest Japanese restaurant is back after a massive makeover
data.description:
If you need something to end your week on a high note, this is it. Seattle’s oldest restaurant is back after winning a makeover and surviving the pandemic. Have any guesses as to which spot we’re talking about? Of course, we’re talking about Chinatown’s beloved Maneki. Maneki has been in business for 116 years making it one of Seattle’s oldest restaurants and maybe even one of the oldest on the West Coast. They, like many other restaurants, were hit extremely hard by the pandemic and relied on takeout to keep things going. But in an amazing turn of events, they ended up being one of the winners of Evening’s Small Business Energy Efficiency Makeover Contest, sponsored by Puget Sound Energy. Related posts:
46 pools, spray parks & cooling centres in Seattle that’ll help you beat this heat wave
This Seattle waterfront restaurant has a floating dining area and urban market Winning this award has allowed the restaurant to undergo $45k worth of upgrades and renovations. Some of those things include new lighting, appliances, and organization for the restaurant’s decor. All the stuff that helps the restaurant function and adds to your overall experience of the place, ya know? Honestly, we can’t think of many places that deserve this award more than Maneki. We love all of the city’s restaurants but losing this gem might just mean the end of Seattle. And on that note, now is as good a time as any to stop in and give them a visit. That being said, they’re still operating on a takeout basis. If you’d like to learn more about Maneki’s makeover from Puget Sound Energy you can click here. We will definitely be giving them a visit when they reopen for dine-in as a dinner at Maneki is one of the best dining experiences in the city. Have a great weekend folks!

data.title: Seattle's favorite bread pop-up is going permanent this fall
data.description:
The pop-up to permanent news just keeps getting better and better. Yet another Seattle fave is joining the ranks of new restaurants in the city. After six years of beloved pop-ups, Ben’s Bread from duo breadmakers Ben and Megan Campbell will open a new bakery in Phinney Ridge. This new place of bready goodness is set to open this fall. Of course, you’ll be able to score your favorites loaves and also a whole lot more. You will also be able to get your hands on things like doughnuts, biscuits, breakfast sandwiches, and grain bowls. But it doesn’t stop there because you’ll also be able to grab drinks like espresso, beer, and wine. Related posts:
Here are 10 of the trendiest brunch spots to hit up in Seattle
10 can’t-miss Washington wineries to visit this summer  We have a feeling that the new location will quickly become a popular spot in the neighborhood. Ben’s Bread will do more than just sell their goods, they’ll also host dinners with local chefs and have baking classes. That means you’ll be able to have your bread and make it too. Not to mention, there’s going to be an outdoor patio with views into the bakery so you can check out just how it’s made. Pretty cool right? In the meantime, Ben’s Bread will continue with their pop-ups so you still have plenty of opportunities to enjoy their doughy goodness. If you’d like to check them out further or keep up with their socials you can click below. We can’t wait to see what they do with their new space and we’ll definitely be lining up to get our hands on some bread when the big day comes.

data.title: This Seattle waterfront restaurant has a floating dining area and urban market
data.description:
We all love good waterfront dining but what about dining on the water? If you’ve ever wanted to have a floating dining experience it turns out that you can actually do that at Dock & Drink. This local spot is pretty much the ultimate summer dining destination. Dock & Drink is part of Hyatt Regency Lake Washington at Seattle’s Southport. It’s a boardwalk-style set up with a floating dock to enjoy meals and drinks on. You can enjoy multiple menus with items ranging from sandwiches to tacos and more. When it comes to drinks you can enjoy cocktails, brews, and spirits. Oh, and they have live music every once in a while too. Related posts:
Seattle may hit 100-degree temperatures & be hotter than Miami this weekend
25 amazing things to add to your 2021 Seattle summer bucket list  It’s a great place to reset by the water or wind down after a long work week. But what we find extra cool about Dock & Drink is that they are also the location of the Renton Urban Market which happens every Saturday & Sunday. That being said, this market is only happening until the end of June meaning the 26th and 27th are the last days for you to check it out. If you didn’t have weekend plans, now you do. Considering how hot it will be this weekend we think a trip to Renton is in order. After all, you can head to a nearby beach or swim spot before and make a whole day out of it. If you’d like to learn more about Dock & Drink you can click below. As always if you end up checking them out be sure to let us know what you think and send some pics our way. Have a great weekend folks!
data.when: 1053 Lake Washington Blvd N, Renton WA 98056

data.title: This beloved local pizza pop-up just got a permanent home in Capitol Hill
data.description:
Pop-ups gone permanent, Seattle has seen a bunch of them this year. While we love them all, we’re particularly excited about this one. Blotto, the highly coveted naturally leavened sourdough pizza spot is no longer a roving vendor. As of last week, they’re the newest restaurant in Capitol Hill. Blotto is known for its thin-crust New York and Neapolitan-style pizza which took Broadway Alley by storm. Like many other local pop-up spots, they were often sold out within hours. With a focus on quality over quantity and use of local ingredients, that’s not too surprising. Related posts:
Here are 10 of the trendiest brunch spots to hit up in Seattle
Here are 12 of the most delicious ice cream spots to try in Seattle  We’re happy that they’ve made the transition to a permanent spot because it means more pizza for all of us. But it’s also worth noting that the new Blotto also has a great selection of market items from both local and far away purveyors. You can grab coffee, sauces, bottles, brews, and more. Basically, your favorite artisanal pizza spot just got a whole lot better. We recommend getting over to Blotto ASAP because well, they do still sell out. So get out there, treat yourself to a delicious pie, and if you’re feeling generous consider bringing us a slice. If you’d like to learn more or check out their socials you can click below.

data.title: You can soak in the sun and support multiple local businesses at this SLU patio
data.description:
If you’re trying to figure out how to spend this week right, we recommend heading over to 9th & Thomas. Because they have a massive outdoor patio perfect for chilling or kicking back with a few friends. What’s best of all is that this patio will actually be up until October 2021 as street closures are here to stay for a bit. The patio at 9th & Thomas is a unique opportunity to support multiple businesses as it’s a community gathering place. You can score drinks and food from Elm Coffee Roasters,  Jacks BBQ, Gold Bar, and Evoke Espresso. So whether you’re looking to wind down with a drink or get boosted with a coffee, 9th & Thomas has you covered. Related posts:
Seattle is now the most vaccinated major city in the nation
Seattle may want to decriminalize psychedelics — Here’s what to know  Now that you’re aware of this patio be sure to get out there this weekend and treat yourself to some time in the sun. That being said, if you can’t make it this weekend remember that you’ll be able to check out the patio until October of this year. So either way, you have plenty of time. If you’d like to learn more about 9th & Thomas you can click below. If you end up paying them a visit be sure to let us know what you think and tag us in any photos that you snap. Have a great weekend Seattle!

data.title: Chef Eduardo Jordan is closing his first restaurant and reopening a Ravenna favorite
data.description:
Over the past few years, Chef Eduardo Jordan has taken Seattle by storm. He started with his beloved Ravenna spot, Salare, and moved on to JuneBaby as well as several chef features across the city. And this month marks an intense time for the chef as one chapter is closing and another is beginning. Sadly, Salare is another victim of the COVID-19 pandemic and will be closing permanently on July 3rd. As we all know, restaurants and their owners have been hit quite hard by the pandemic. So continuing to run this beloved spot is no longer feasible. But the good news is that after a year, JuneBaby is starting up indoor dining on June 16th. Related posts:
Here are 12 of the most delicious ice cream spots to try in Seattle
One of Seattle’s most popular pho spots is opening a downtown location  While this news is bittersweet, it’s yet another reminder to continue to support local restaurants when you can. After all, we love the food and they depend on our business. So use this news as an excuse to treat yourself and look back on the fond memories that you have of Salare. When JuneBaby returns you can expect to see a few differences including a merger of neighbor Lucinda Grain Bar. Additionally, seating will be half capacity and walk-in only. So if you decide to dine-in this month be sure to get there early as this restaurant is popular. If you’d like to learn more you can click here or check out JuneBaby’s info below.
data.where: : Reopening June 16th: Wednesday-Sunday from 5 pm-10 pm

data.title: This iconic Roosevelt Way art and music bar is returning in a new home
data.description:
It was a very sad day when we learned that Cafe Racer was closing its doors for good. After all, this cafe has been a spot of joy, immense tragedy, resilience, arts, music, food, and more. It was and is truly a Seattle staple which is why we are overjoyed that it is returning to the scene. That’s right folks, Cafe Racer is returning but this time to Capitol Hill. After a long search for a U District space, owners Jeff Ramsey and Cindy Anne have found one on the hill. You’ll be able to find the beloved music venue and cafe in the former location of Barca on 11th Ave. Related posts:
Here are 12 of the most delicious ice cream spots to try in Seattle
One of Seattle’s most popular pho spots is opening a downtown location  Not only is this exciting to see a gem return but it’s also great for Capitol Hill’s live music scene. After all, venues have been shuttered for months and there will be no Capitol Hill Block Party for the second year in a row. We’re hoping that Cafe Racer and neighboring venues like Neumos and Chop Suey can look forward to a year of amazing shows. Because they need it and we need it too. While we know the wait for this one is going to be very hard, it looks like things should be open by September of this year. In the meantime, Ramsey and Anne will be prepping the space to give it some of the charms of the old location. We absolutely can’t wait to see what they do and if you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: One of Seattle's most popular pho spots is opening a downtown location
data.description:
Pho is one of our all-time favorite foods and we think that’s a pretty common sentiment in Seattle. Which is why we’re super pumped that Pho Bac is opening a new location in the heart of downtown! You can expect your favorite noodle soups and some new menu additions including Banh Mi! The new spot will hopefully open by mid-June. You can also expect a cool speakeasy-style cocktail bar upstairs called Phocific Standard Time to open in late August or September. We have a feeling that this new spot will become a popular hangout as Pho Bac’s other locations are city-wide faves. Related posts:
Here are 5 to-go cocktails to enjoy in Seattle this weekend
10 of the best places to hang near the water in Seattle this summer  Phocific Standard Time will take a bit longer to open as the team is working on creating some seriously unique Vietnamese-influenced cocktails. You’ll also be able to snag both bottled and canned beer. We have to say we can’t wait to see what they come up with because we know it’ll be amazing. This new addition is Pho Bac’s fifth location and we love to see local restaurants thrive like this. While we all impatiently wait for the new location, you can enjoy food at The Sup Shop and Pho Bac Rainier Valley. If you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: One of Seattle's favourite sandwich spots is opening a huge Central District location
data.description:
Sandwiches are good year-round and Seattle happens to be lucky with many amazing spots to snag them. But HoneyHole Sandwiches is perhaps one of the best between its funky decor and two decades of sandwich-making experience. It’s a dining experience that will soon be coming to Seattle’s Central District as the shop is finally expanding. For the first time ever in HoneyHole’s history, they’re getting bigger! The brand spanking new shop opens May 31st on East Jefferson Street in the CD. Now the new space will obviously need some breaking in to get the good old spot vibes. But the new owners are doing their best to recreate the funky interior with vintage posters, colored lights, and the old sign. Related posts:
This minimalist pet brand is having a limited-time pop-up in Seattle this weekend
13 of the best burgers you can find in Seattle  What makes the new spot particularly special is that it’s massive, three times the size of the old space. And if that isn’t enough for you, they also have an awesome patio and outdoor bar so you can enjoy the sun while eating your favorite sammy. We have a feeling it’s going to be an amazing spot to enjoy this summer (and year-round of course). If you’re wondering, you’ll be able to find all of your old fav sandwiches and also some drinks as well. We hope that you guys get out there and show them some love on their opening. And if you’re really jonesing for a sandwich you can always head to the old faithful Capitol Hill location in the meantime.

data.title: The stunning dining experience on Lumen Field returns this June
data.description:
Dining has gotten a lot more creative in the past year. At this point, outdoor and patio dining is pretty much the new norm but what about dining on Lumen Field? Yes, that’s where the Seahawks play and it turns out you don’t need to be a football star to step foot on the field. Field To Table is back this June with an amazing lineup of chefs. If you haven’t heard of Field To Table, they focus on providing diners with an unforgettable experience while highlighting the best of Seattle’s diverse restaurant culture. They do this by transforming Lumen Field into a massive open-air dining room making it super COVID-19 safe. And to make things even better, they support Big Table, an organization that assists hospitality workers in need. Related posts:
25 of the best things to do in Seattle this June
The Seattle Aquarium just turned 44 – here’s a look at its crazy history  Plus it’s the first-ever dining series on a professional sports field which definitely gives you some bragging rights. If you’re wondering a reservation includes free parking, a four-course meal, complimentary Topo Chico, photo ops with physical & digital prints, and field access for exploration, photos, and more. As you can see it’s a lot more than sitting down for a delicious meal. For the time being, there are reservations available for all dates, however, tickets will go quickly and we recommend purchasing ASAP. Because you don’t want to miss out on meals made by chefs like Mel Miranda, Kristi Brown, Matt Lewis, and 11 others. Learn more and grab tickets by clicking below.

data.title: One of Seattle's oldest restaurants is up for sale in Ballard
data.description:
During the pandemic, we’ve all heard of a lot of restaurants closing their doors for good. But in a positive change, one of Seattle’s oldest restaurants is looking for a new owner instead. Owner Pam Hanson is looking for someone to continue the fish and chips legacy of Ballard’s Lockspot Cafe. The Lockspot Cafe has been a local fish and chips destination for over 90 years. They’ve served up Ballard’s OG fisherman, Seattleites, tourists, and many others. Instead of changing to reflect the hip nature of Ballard these days, the cafe has stayed true to its roots making it a beloved spot. Related posts:
Seattle’s last family-owned video store is saying goodbye after 30 years
10 socially-distant things to do in Seattle this week (May 24-28)
 It also happens to be located right next to the Ballard Locks making it a prime place for visitors to stop. We have to say, it really is one of Seattle’s last OG restaurants and we hope the new owner keeps it as authentic as possible. With that in mind, it might be time to pay them a visit because who can say no to delicious fish and chips? If you happen to be interested in becoming a restauranteur you can contact Ozzie Kvithammer at (206) 719-6866. Either way, we’re happy to know that this historic spot will be getting a new lease on life instead of shuttered doors. With that, have a great week and treat yourself to some delicious local fish and chips.

data.title: Washington Wines is having an auction this month that you don't want to miss
data.description:
If you happen to have a taste for fine wine you’re going to want to hop online this month. Because you’ll be able to enjoy and shop the Auction of Washington Wines, Wine & Music Week. It’s a week of celebration that you certainly don’t want to miss. Let’s get into the details. The auction takes place over the course of three days and features more than 100 lots. Lots include things like special wines and collections as well as regional wine and travel packages. And because this particular auction has a musical element you can also bid on music-themed experiences. Fun right? Related posts:
Enjoy the city’s best wine and art with Bon Vivant Wine Tours Art & Wine Tour
It looks like patio dining in Seattle might be here to stay While the auction is the main focus, the other event days will give you the opportunity to hear talks from winemakers as well as music from local musicians. Some of the musicians include Glen Phillips of Toad the Wet Sprocket, LeRoy Bell, and Stephanie Ann Johnson. Plus it’s worth mentioning that each night you watch over Zoom, you will be eligible to win two tickets to a concert at the Chateau Ste Michelle 2022 Summer Concert Series! So whether it’s for wine or music, the Auction of Washington Wines, Wine & Music Week is well worth your time. You’ll probably end up with at least a few bottles and maybe even a post-pandemic travel experience. But you’ll have to attend to see just what you can snag. If you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: A Black-owned Seattle spot lands on list of Best New Restaurants in the World
data.description:
We all know that Seattle has a pretty spectacular culinary scene. Despite the pandemic, restaurants in the city have seemed to get better and better. This has landed Communion a spot on Conde Nast’s “Best New Restaurants in the World: 2021 Hot List“. Looks like it’s time to give them a try. If you’re unfamiliar with Communion it’s a relatively new spot in the Seattle scene. The restaurant opened in November 2020 and has already shot to worldwide recognition. And that’s because of owner Chef Kristi Brown’s amazing culinary sense and work. Beyond her new restaurant, you probably know from her decades of catering in Seattle and “That Brown Girl Cooks!“. Related posts:
It looks like patio dining in Seattle might be here to stay
Capitol Hill has a new plant-based restaurant focusing on seasonal PNW cuisine  What sets Communion apart is its mission which is “to foster community through the cultivation of fresh food and fine cooking”. The menu not only brings people together through the act of eating but also through culture by honoring Black, Asian, and East African dishes and culinary traditions. This blend has created a unique and delicious menu that has secured Communion a spot in Seattle’s list of culinary geniuses. It’s also worth mentioning the physical significance of the restaurant. As a Black-owned business, the restaurant is located on the former site of the PNW’s first Black-owned bank as well being in the historically Black Central District neighborhood. And this honor is a huge win for the spot after a tumultuous year. If you haven’t tried Communion yet now is the time. Show them some love and treat yourself to some amazing food. You can find out more by clicking below.

data.title: The Olympic Bar at The Fairmont just got a multi-million dollar facelift
data.description:
Remember when going out to bars was a weekly occurrence? Us too, but now when we get to enjoy them, the experience is even more special. And we’re thinking a visit to the Fairmont Olympic Hotel Olympic Bar is in order this weekend. Because it just got a revamp and you’ll want to see it. The nearly century-old Fairmont Olympic Hotel got a multi-million dollar restoration this year and part of that included the Olympic Bar. The new lobby bar serves up daily breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Plus they have afternoon tea on Saturdays and Sundays for those of you needing a midday pick-me-up experience. Related posts:
Seattle rent prices have dropped significantly compared to 2020
It looks like patio dining in Seattle might be here to stay  This new bar is just the start of new dining experiences at the Fairmont. And for now, we’re super excited to try out their menu which is described as “approachable American cuisine”. Plus we think a picture or two with the stunning new interior wouldn’t hurt our Instagram feed. What’s best of all is that you can visit the Olympic Bar right now and you don’t even have to make a reservation. Seating is all on a first come first serve basis and if you’re wondering the bar and hotel are going to extensive measures to ensure the safety of patrons. If you’d like to learn more or visit the bar you can click below.

data.title: Capitol Hill has a new plant-based restaurant focusing on seasonal PNW cuisine
data.description:
Capitol Hill is without a doubt one of the best places in the city to snag delicious food and it just got even better thanks to a new spot that’s all about using natural and locally sourced ingredients from the PNW. If you’re looking for a new spot to dine this week, Finch & Pine should be your first stop. Finch & Pine opened this past weekend in the former home of Cafe Barjot. If you’ve visited the former then you know it’s a sweet spot on Bellevue Ave E. And while we’ll miss it we’re super excited about what Finch & Pine has to offer. You can dine on menu items like mushroom pate, seasonal gazpacho, confit tuna, and more. Related posts:
12 of the best spots to enjoy delicious pasta in Seattle
Here are some fantastic spots to eat & drink in Seattle this weekend  If you just want to stop in for drinks you can grab espresso-based drinks as well as seasonal drinks like a cinnamon latte. But it doesn’t stop there because you can also enjoy libations like wine including white, bubbles and red. You might just find yourself coming here at all times of the day. This new spot is yet another win for plant-based eaters in the city as the menu is quite veg-heavy. And personally, we can’t wait to try it. As always, if you get there before us, be sure to give them some love and let us know what you think. If you’d like to learn more you can click below. Enjoy folks!

data.title: Seattle Beer Week has kicked off with 45 participating venues you can visit
data.description:
Ready to get your drink on? Well, you chose the perfect time because it just so happens to be Seattle Beer Week. This beloved fermented festival is back with a COVID-19 safe format that still allows you to get out there and enjoy your fave brews. Keep on reading to find out what you can expect from this year’s festival. This year Seattle Beer Week is happening at tons of different venues across the city in nearly every direction. So no matter where you are in the city you can participate. But one of the best ways to participate is by grabbing a pint of the SBW12 Collaboration Ale at one of the 45 venues offering it on tap. Related posts:
10 socially distant things to do in Seattle this weekend (May 7-9)
A brand new kombucha taproom just opened in Seattle  You can also check out daily events like the Stout and Sour Fest at Brouwer’s Cafe or the Bodacious Beverages event featuring rare beers at Beveridge Place Pub. Trust us, no matter what kind of beer you like, one of the venues will have something perfect for you. So don’t miss out on this thirst-quenching week. If you’d like to learn more about Seattle Beer Week you can click below. And as always please be prepared to follow individual restaurant and venue guidelines for COVID and other safety precautions. With that, get out there, have some fun and please drink responsibly.

data.title: This Seattle spot makes mouthwatering handmade 'bread boats'
data.description:
Bread could really be its whole own food group and during the pandemic, it’s only grown in popularity. And that’s why we’re so intrigued with Skalka and their mouthwatering handmade ‘bread boats’. Just imagine doughy goodness filled with your favorite foods. Skalka is a Georgian bakery and dumpling house that serves up unique menu items right on Seattle’s stunning waterfront. And while their whole menu looks amazing we’re most intrigued by the bread boats or Khachapuri. The boats are eaten by tearing off the edges and dipping them in the center of the boat. Some of the filling ingredients include items like cheese, chicken, vegetables, and more. It’s like a bread bowl but way better. Related posts:
A brand new kombucha taproom just opened in Seattle
These world-famous Mille Crêpes cakes just became available in Seattle  And best of all, they’re each made to order so you’ll get them hot and straight out of the oven. Plus if you’re feeling really adventurous you can try a sweet boat with items like cheese, dried fruit, walnuts, and vanilla. It’ll be unlike anything you’ve had before. If you’d like to learn more about Skalka you can click below. And if you end up visiting be sure to let us know what you think because we’re pretty dang curious. Who knows, you might just see us there this weekend. Enjoy folks!

data.title: A brand new kombucha taproom just opened in Seattle
data.description:
Sometimes it’s nice to be able to go out for drinks without the booze factor. Because let’s face it, not everyone likes to drink and we can always use a break. So that’s why we’re super excited to welcome a new taproom to our city that focuses solely on kombucha and other fermented. Let’s take a look at Seeking Kombucha. Seeking Kombucha is a small batch, locally and women-owned business that brews up over 40 creative flavors. And at their taproom, you can enjoy 12 different flavors on tap. But what really sets this spot apart is their kombucha mocktails. That’s right, you can get all the fanciness of your favorite cocktails without the hangover factor. Related posts:
Canlis’ new executive chef is making history for the restaurant
This Seattle business will help you create your dream picnic  That being said, you can actually still grab booze here. So this is a great place to check out if you’re with a group of people with different drinking preferences. And beyond drinks Seeking Kombucha also has pop-ups which we hope to see more of in the future. Because this taproom looks like a seriously promising spot for hard-core foodies. If you’re looking to grab a drink this weekend consider supporting this new spot. Because you can never go wrong with a delicious kombucha or mocktail. Who knows, you might just end up going home with a growler or two. If you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: You need to try this delicious new bakery in Portage Bay
data.description:
Seattle’s bakery news has been pretty sweet lately (no pun intended). It turns out that Portage Bay has a brand spanking new bakery in the nearly century-old Jensen Motor Boat Company building.  This new spot is called Saint Bread and it might just become your new go-to bakery. Not only are you guaranteed to find delicious pastries like cardamon knots and melonpan, but you’ll also find one of the most beautiful interiors. And that’s because it was done by Graham Baba Architects. They’ve worked on other restaurant concepts like Mezcaleria Oaxaca, Chophouse Row, and Melrose Market. So if you’re not too distracted by the delicious pastries, you might snag a few insta pics too. Related posts:
Seattle has a brand new bakery from a local acclaimed coffee roasting company
A Seattle mother went viral after accidentally naming her baby ‘Korn’  Beyond pastries, you’ll also be able to find delicious menu items like bratwurst, sandwiches, and much more. and we have a feeling in the future you’ll be able to nosh on all sorts of amazing dishes as this kitchen is definitely a creative one. Plus it’s looking like it’s going to be one of the best community spaces in the neighborhood. Can you tell we’re excited? But what’s best of all is that Saint Bread is open now so you don’t have to wait to pay them a visit. Start your weekend off right and enjoy a great coffee and bite to eat while supporting a brand new local spot. If you’d like to learn more about Saint Bread you can click below. Enjoy folks!

data.title: Seattle has a brand new bakery from a local acclaimed coffee roasting company
data.description:
We can always get behind a new bakery. Especially when it comes from acclaimed local coffee roasting company Olympia Coffee Roasting Co. So get ready to add the roasting companies sibling Moonrise Bakery to your rotation of coffee shops and bakeries. The new Moonrise Bakery is located in Queen Anne in the former Le Reve bakery. And Olympia actually took over Le Reve last summer after the coffee company’s longtime pastry supplier closed down during the pandemic. So it’s a new foray for the roasting company and a great addition to the neighborhood. Related posts:
24 socially distant things to do in Seattle this May
Seattle just ranked as one of the best cities for…naked gardening  On the back end, Moonrise will provide baked goods for Olympia’s six other retail locations across the state. But for Seattleites, it’s a brand new spot to grab pastries, coffee, and a curated selection of vibrant natural wines. And while Le Reve was a longtime beloved spot, we think that Moonrise Bakery will quickly become a mainstay in the neighborhood. We’ll definitely be giving them a try because who can say no to a new haunt? Who knows, maybe we’ll see a Moonrise 2.0 in the future if it becomes Seattle’s next “it” bakery. If you’d like to learn more or find out the location and hours you can click below. Enjoy folks!

data.title: A brand new vegan donut truck is rolling into town this May
data.description:
Vegans and sweet tooths alike should be excited because a new vegan food truck is rolling into Seattle this May. Dough Joy is a new doughnut spot on wheels that makes its sweet goods sans dairy products. And if that isn’t exciting enough, this new venture comes from Christopher Ballard and Sean Willis of Outbound Herbivore. If you ask us, another food truck makes a lot of sense. After all, dining will probably continue to have a takeout or grab-and-go focus for quite a while due to the pandemic. And let’s face it, you don’t really need a whole sit-down joint for a donut spot. Especially because Dough Joy is focused on quality over quantity and they have a pretty small kitchen being in a truck and all that. Related posts:
Explore Fishermen’s Terminal breweries on a Seattle Brewery Walking Tour
10 socially distant things to do in Seattle this weekend (April 23-25)  So while the operation is small, we have a feeling that these donuts will pack a flavorful punch. Dough Joy will serve up donuts with creative names and flavors like the Petal To The Metal (rose-flavored) and the Faconator (maple icing with “bacon”) to name a few. And alongside your donuts, you’ll also be able to grab entirely plant-based drinks like lattes, mochas, and more. If you’d like to learn more about Dough Joy you can click below. We’ll definitely have to give this spot a go because we can never say no to a donut. And now is the time to support local restaurants so be sure to check them out and satisfy that sweet tooth of yours.

data.title: Seattle's brand new waterfront pub is on track to open in June 2021
data.description:
You might remember earlier this year when we reported on Here Today Brewery & Kitchen. The massive undertaking definitely seemed a little crazy during a time when many of the city’s infallible restaurants were closing. But what’s exciting is that the new brewery is on track to open in June 2021. The seemingly Vaporwave-themed brewery has raised over $1 million to open. And that means right now they’re busy working on all those key, behind-the-scenes details. So we’ll impatiently wait for a new spot to enjoy brews on Seattle’s stunning waterfront. Related posts:
10 Of The Best Places To Go For A Bike Ride In Seattle  Not only are we excited for this new spot but we’re also excited for the location. Because obviously it’s by the water but it’s also by the Olympic Sculpture Park. This makes it the perfect spot to come after a walk downtown. Not to mention, we’re super excited to have yet another amazing local beer to love. If you’d like to learn more about Here Today Brewery & Kitchen you can click below. What kind of beers are you hoping to see from this new spot? We’ll assume that whatever they make will be pretty legendary considering they have such a talented team. Can you tell we’re excited?

data.title: This Seattle lounge is 500 feet in the air and is reopening this Friday
data.description:
If you’re looking for a unique dining experience with perhaps one of the best views in the city you can’t go wrong with The Loupe Lounge. Sound familiar? It should because it’s the lounge inside the Space Needle and it just so happens to be reopening this week! As you might have guessed, things will look a little different at The Loupe Lounge but don’t worry, you’ll still be 500 feet in the air. But what is different is the meal pricetag. In order to dine at the iconic building, you’ll have to pay a $200 ticket price. However, this includes admission, a 2-hour table reservation, food, drinks, and parking. And when you think about it, that’s actually a pretty good deal. Related posts: 
10 amazing Seattle patios with great views of the city
This local ramen food truck is one of the only of its kind in the United States  Now visiting the lounge at the needle is usually more about the drink menu. But don’t worry you can also grab some high-touch snacks with ingredients like wagyu beef and local seafood. So if you’re looking to celebrate or simply treat yourself, a trip to the Space Needle might just be in order. The lounge will be reopening on April 9th aka this Friday. And we’re going to assume that reservations will go pretty quickly. So if you’d like to learn more about Loupe Lounge you can click here.

data.title: Seattle Restaurant Week is back for all of April and you don't want to miss it
data.description:
Seattle foodies get excited because Seattle Restaurant Week is back. But this time it’s here to stay for the entire month of April. That’s right, you can score amazing deals and meals at some of Seattle’s best restaurants. Due to the pandemic, all events are looking different this year and Seattle Restaurant Week is no different. So that means this year you can enjoy takeout, ready-to-heat, delivery, and meal boxes. Plus you can also participate in indoor and outdoor dining. Of course, this is subject to change if Washington state dining guidelines change. Related posts:
Here’s what to know about fans returning to T-Mobile Park
A drive-thru version of the Washington State Spring Fair happens this month!  However, the special prix fixe menu prices are the same as years past. So that means you can still snag a $20 lunch and $35 and $50 dinner options. Now you’ll probably have a hard time choosing where to eat because there are so many amazing restaurants participating. That being said, this is a great way to show your support for local restaurants. So if you’d like to learn more about Seattle’s tastiest event you can click below. Plus it’s also worth mentioning that this year, a buy one, give one option has been added via a $10 donation. So if you end up ordering yourself a meal, consider treating someone in need to one as well through this option.

data.title: SeaTac Airport just got America's first pop-up bar that only serves shots
data.description:
We know that not many of you are flying right now. But when you are, SeaTac airport has a brand new bar that’s pretty unique. Shot Bar as it’s called, is a bar that simply serves shots. And if you’re a nervous flyer this might just be your new favorite spot. Shot Bar is a concept From local chef Kathy Casey and is part of Relish Burger Lounge. And what makes the concept even better is the fact that all shots are served in mini plastic red solo cups. So you’ll feel like you’re at a good old party. Related posts:
You can soon dine in a secret garden at one of Seattle’s favourite restaurants
This iconic Seattle bakery is closing after 100 years  But you’ll really have to throw the shots back because you can only consume them at the counter. That being said, we’re sure you’ll enjoy whatever you have as the bar has vodka, tequila, bourbon, and more. And since it’s the airport, shots are pretty expensive at $7 for a single and $10 for a double. But if you hate flying this might just calm your nerves. Considering restauranteurs have had it harder and harder throughout the pandemic we’re happy to see this unique new concept. And if you find yourself at SeaTac soon be sure to give Shot Bar a try and let us know what you think. Because we might just have to stop by next time we’re flying.

data.title: You can soon dine in a secret garden at one of Seattle's favourite restaurants
data.description:
Now that we’re in Phase 3, the dining options across the city are getting better and better. Plus many restaurants that took a break during the winter are now back including some old favorites. So that’s why we’re reminding you about Oddfellows’ secret garden. This Capitol Hill institution is a beloved spot for breakfast, lunch, brunch, and dinner. Seriously, they do it all, and very well might we add. And beyond the delicious food, they also have a beautifully curated interior that happens to be quite large and perfect for social distancing. But the very best table is actually located in the back. Related posts:
This iconic bakery is closing after 100 years
Washington enters Phase 3 today, here’s what you need to know  That table is in the secret garden which is a small back patio space that’s perfect for intimate outdoor dining. And good news! Oddfellows just revealed that they’ll be opening reservations for it very soon. You’re going to have to move quickly, though, because this place is a hot commodity. If you’d like to learn more about Oddfellows and their secret garden you can click below. If you end up giving them a try be sure to let us know what you think. But really, we think you’ll love this spot. Enjoy folks!

data.title: This iconic Seattle bakery is closing after 100 years
data.description:
We’re all pretty used to restaurant and business closures these days. But it hurts a bit extra when it’s spots that are backbones of the city. Unfortunately, Seattle’s iconic Borracchini’s Bakery is closed permanently. Borracchini’s Bakery made the announcement via Facebook citing that the lack of parties meant no businesses. After all, this spot was known for its sheet cakes. And while people are still celebrating, it’s not enough to keep them going in the way things were before. Related posts:
12 food events in Seattle to look forward to this spring
This popular Seattle sourdough spot is coming to Capitol Hill  So after 100 years, this spot will be no more. Beyond a loss of options for cake, it’s sad to see Seattle lose a centennial business. Because at this point, the city has relatively few, especially in the food industry. So let this be a reminder to continue supporting those businesses that you love. If you’d like to learn more about the bakery and its closure you can click here. We wish the Borracchini family the best and will miss this spot dearly. Have a great week, and hit up your favourite food and drink spots if you can.

data.title: Musang's sibling spot has a pop up happening today!
data.description:
In the past few years, Seattle has had a few superstar newcomers to the restaurant scene. And one of the most beloved has to be Musang which is Beacon Hill’s spot for Filipinx dishes. So while we’re big fans of their restaurant we also do miss the old days of their pop-ups. But psst, Musangtino’s is back in town. If you’re unfamiliar with Musangtino’s, it’s the more snack-centric sibling of Musang. It’s a collaboration between Melissa Miranda and her long-time friend Jeff Santos. And due to its pop-up nature, you can expect things to be a little different each time. Plus if you’re a fan of the restaurant you’re pretty much guaranteed to be a fan of the pop-up. Related posts:
This wildly popular Vietnamese coffee shop is opening a second location!
Open & coming soon – 12 new Seattle restaurants to try this spring  You can snag dishes like the boMburger which features a potato bun, ⁣Painted Hills patty, American cheddar⁣, pickled zucchini, ⁣diced onions⁣ , and magic mayo. It’s a take on a classic snack food that you won’t soon forget. And the best part about all this is that you don’t have to wait to try it because the first pop-up is actually today! Musangtino’s will be located at Fair Isle Brewing from 4-7 pm today. And we certainly hope that this is the first of many pop-ups from this local fave. Plus it’s worth mentioning that you can also snag Kryse Ice Cream today. So if you plan on going be prepared because, in the past, these pop-ups have sold out quickly!

data.title: People are going crazy for these limited ‘egg-bottles’ from a Seattle coffee shop
data.description:
Spring is just around the corner and that means Easter! So with that in mind, one local coffee shop has some pretty unique coffee cups that you should check out. Coffeeholic House is serving up iced drinks inside of massive eggs. Yes, massive eggs. Now before you get too excited or scared, these are plastic reusable cups shaped like cracked eggs. Although we have to say, a drink out of something like an Ostrich egg would be pretty cool. But anyway, in order to score one of these cups you need to purchase it and a drink. Related posts:
This popular Vietnamese coffee shop is now serving Cinnamon Toast Crunch Lattes
Seattle has a trendy new magazine shop with over 250 unique reads  If these have caught your attention, we’d recommend getting on it because the cups are limited edition and Coffeeholic House just released them today! So head down to Columbia City and treat yourself to one of their delicious drinks. Some of their offerings include Vietnamese coffee, Ube Latte, and much more. And if you’re to food pics then you’ll have to take a picture with your new egg cup. Plus, just imagine the next time you take it to a coffee shop for a refill. We’ll bet the barista will be pretty dang surprised. If you’d like to learn more you can click above or below.

data.title: A beloved Seattle vegan food truck is getting a permanent home
data.description:
If you’re a vegan in Seattle then you’re well aware of your options. And while our city isn’t perfect, we’re happy to see it gaining more and more vegan spots. So now you congratulate Cycle Dogs on getting a permanent location. Woo hoo! In case you haven’t heard of them, Cycle Dogs is a vegan hot dog shop. Because let’s face it, even plant-based folks need their comfort food too. In a bittersweet twist, this beloved food truck is taking over the old location of the equally beloved No Bones Beach Club. But hey, we all know the pandemic got a lot of local restaurants. Related posts:
Dick’s Drive-In is finally opening a permanent Bellevue location!
Dough Zone is opening it’s brand new Bellevue flagship tomorrow!  Now the permanent location will have an expanded version of the food truck menu. And while you’ll still be able to grab all your plant-based hot dogs and burgers, the owners plan on moving the menu towards more restaurant-centric food. So we’re excited to see what unfolds in the new chapter of this restaurant’s life. Now for the time being there aren’t many details. But we do know that Cycle Dogs will be creating a Kickstarter campaign to help with expansion costs. So click above to check out their social media and here to keep up with them. In the meantime, you can still enjoy all your favorites from their food truck.

data.title: Dough Zone is opening its brand new Bellevue flagship tomorrow!
data.description:
Eastside foodies get excited because one of Seattle’s beloved soup dumpling spots is coming to the eastside. That’s right folks, Dough Zone is opening its Bellevue flagship tomorrow aka February 25th! So if you’re in need of some dumplings you’ll have to give them a try and show them some love on their first day open. As we mentioned above, Dough Zone is one of the most popular spots for soup dumplings in Seattle. But you can also score other delicious menu items like dan dan noodles, various kinds of bao, and other amazing dishes. And for opening, the spot will be offering some special menu items which is even more of a reason to give them a try. Related posts:
A beloved Japanese BBQ spot has just reopened on Capitol Hill
Seattle restaurant group hosting two pop-ups in March featuring global chefs  So if you’re in a treat yourself this weekend, Dough Zone is always a good choice. And in case you didn’t know, the classic Crossroads location has closed so this will be your new go-to. Plus, you can enjoy takeout and delivery from third-party services. On that note, dine-in will be available but at 25% capacity. If you’d like to learn more you can click below. As always if you end up giving them a try, be sure to let us know what you think. And we’re curious to see just what special new items will be added to the menu in honor of their new opening. Enjoy folks!

data.title: One of Seattle's most beloved rooftop bars is reopening in just a few weeks
data.description:
We know it’s technically still winter but spring is definitely in the air. And on that note, one of Seattle’s favorite rooftop bars will be reopening quite soon. That’s right, you can welcome Mbar back on March 10th. Mbar has been closed for a while due to the pandemic. But now that state regulations have lightened up, they’re reopening for outdoor dining. And at this point, you’ve probably already guessed but the seatings are for parties of six or less. Not to mention, overall reduced capacity. Related posts:
A beloved Japanese BBQ spot has just reopened on Capitol Hill
Here are 10 new restaurants in Seattle worth trying this week  We’re going to assume that the menu will be just as delicious as before. You can grab tasty bites as well as some amazing cocktails all while overlooking the city. So if you’ve missed dining with a view, soon you’ll have a spot to enjoy. If you like to learn more about Mbar and its reopening you can click below. Be sure to be patient with restaurants as they reopen. After all, the pandemic has been extra hard on restaurants and this isn’t easy for anyone.
data.when: Sunday-Thursday 4 pm-10 pm, Friday & Saturday 4 pm-11 pm

data.title: A beloved Japanese BBQ spot has just reopened on Capitol Hill
data.description:
Well, Seattle food is there’s yet another new spot for you to try. Although the ‘new’ spot used to be in Bellevue and has now moved to Capitol Hill, it’s still got that fresh resto smell to it. So if you’re in the mood for some Japanese barbeque you have to try Ishoni Yakiniku. Ishoni Yakiniku opened earlier in February and has a menu full of items like curry, udon, sides, and more! Plus we love that they focus on using high-quality meats for their delicious barbecue. And right now you can either opt for take out or dine in, the choice is yours. Related posts:
Here are 10 new restaurants in Seattle worth trying this week
Seattle restaurant group hosting two pop-ups in March featuring global chefs  But we have to say that we think this would be a great dine-in spot to hit up with friends. After all, Japanese barbecue is pretty fun since you get to cook it right at your table. So if you’ve been meaning to take a friend out to dinner, now you know where to go. If you’d like to learn more about Ishoni Yakiniku you can click above or below. Their menu is viewable via QR reader on Insta so be sure to check it out. And of course, make reservations and be prepared to follow any and all Covid-19 rules when you go. Enjoy!

data.title: You can dine on Lumen Field at Seattle's coolest new pop-up series
data.description:
If you consider yourself a foodie you definitely don’t want to miss out on this new dining experience. Right now, you can enjoy covered, open-air dining on Seattle’s very own Lumen Field. This dining experience is called Field to Table. Haha, get it? Field to Table works with local award-winning chefs to bring you amazing meals on Lumen Field. So not only is this incredibly cool and unique but it allows for tons of space for socially distanced dining. And each meal comes with four courses and is priced at $100 a person, which for the experience and the food is not bad at all! Also, reservations are currently available for groups of 2 to 6 people. Related posts:
Bok a Bok fried chicken is opening a new location on the East side!
QFC is closing two Seattle locations in response to hazard pay  So if this sounds like something you’re into just a few of the participating chefs include Matt Lewis, Liz Kenyon, and Trey Lamont. But in total there are 11 different chefs participating so you’ll get to try a diverse and delicious assortment of food. If you’d like to learn more you can click below. And as always if you end up making a reservation and checking it out, be sure to let us know what you think. After all, this experience definitely seems worth checking out.

data.title: Flavortown is coming to Seattle thanks to a new ghost kitchen from Guy Fieri
data.description:
Yet another ghost kitchen is about to hit our city’s streets, and his time around it’ll be featuring eats from an iconic Food Network host. Yep, Guy Fieri is bringing Flavortown to Seattle.  Get ready to order items like burgers, sandwiches, and more Flavortown-inspired foods as soon as next Wednesday, February 17. Guy Fieri’s Flavortown Kitchen will be operating out of the Buca di Beppo in South Lake Union. And you might remember a similar ghost kitchen happening around Christmas that centered on Mariah Carey’s cookies. Well, it just so happens that both pop-ups are being put on by Virtual Dining Concepts. So that means we could see more celebrity centric ghost kitchens in the future. Related posts:
McDonald’s is bringing back it’s famous orange drink after nearly 4 years
A Seattle healthcare worker just won her first home from HGTV  The menu includes food items like Buffalo Wings, Real Cheezy Burger, Chicken Parm-eroni, and more. But pretty much everything on this menu looks like it’s guaranteed to put you in a massive food coma. So eater beware, but honestly, what did you expect from Guy Fieri? If you’d like to check out the menu or learn more you can click below. As we’re always curious about food and especially ghost kitchens be sure to let us know what you think if you give it a try. Enjoy Flavourtown Folks!

data.title: A brand new pop-up serving seafood-centric sandos is arriving in Seattle
data.description:
It’s no secret that Seattle is a foodie city so we love to see it when local restaurants come together. And that’s why we’re pumped that Sam Choy’s Poke To The Max and Ramen Ramen are coming together for the ultimate pop-up. You don’t want to miss Sea Sandwich. As the name suggests, this pop-up is all about sandwiches and focuses on seafood. So it’s really the best of both worlds if you ask us. After all, you can never go wrong with a tasty sandwich and Seattle is one of the best places to be for seafood. But you can also grab some other tasty items like lobster tots, fish & chips, and chowder. Related posts:
Here are 11 Seattle spots to get great takeout for Super Bowl Sunday
You can dine 175-feet in the air on The Great Wheel at Seattle’s iconic waterfront  So if you have a hankering for seafood (or anything delicious) this month you definitely can’t go wrong with Sea Sandwich. The pop-up dates are February 19th and 20th and prices range between $13.95 to $25.95. But be sure to place your pre-orders ahead of time. Because it would suck to miss out on this since it’s a limited time thing. If you’d like to learn more about Sea Sandwiches you can click here. And if you end up ordering be sure to let us know what you think. But we might just have to try this one for ourselves. Enjoy folks!

data.title: The Soul of Seattle returns this month with 4 different tasty events to check out
data.description:
At this point, you’re probably aware that February is Black History Month and that means there are tons of amazing events happening. But one of the best is the Soul of Seattle event which is happening for the second year in a row. So not only is this a great way to try new food but it’s an excellent way to support local Black culinarians. Throughout February Soul of Seattle will put on 4 different events. They range from cooking demos to dance parties and if we could, we would attend every single one. The first event kicks off tomorrow and features a live cooking demo from Dre Neely and Sabrina Tinsley. Plus if you’re really feeling it you can even snag a 3-course meal from either Gravy or La Spiga. Related posts:
10 great ways to celebrate Black History Month in Seattle
12 spots in Seattle offering romantic Valentine’s Day dinner & specials  And if you can’t make it to tomorrow’s event that’s no problem because there are events also happening on February 12th,19th, and 26th. In the next events, you can expect to see Edouardo Jordan, Kristi Brown, and even Questlove. So clearly these are not ones you want to miss! If you’d like to learn more about Soul of Seattle or snag tickets you can click here. As always if you check out one of the events, let us know what you think. We’ll probably be checking out at least one of these events. Have a great weekend Seattle!

data.title: Seattle has a new spot serving mochi donuts, Korean corndogs & more!
data.description:
Seattle’s food scene just keeps getting better and more unique. And honestly, we’re surprised that so many new restaurants have opened during the pandemic but we’re happy to see it. So now you can welcome Mochinut Seattle to the scene. Mochinut serves up Japanese mochi donut and Korean style corndog making it a super niche spot. However, for those of us who are into unique food items, this is an immediate must-try spot. After all, how can you go wrong with donut flavors like churro, raspberry drizzle, ube, Nutella almond, taro pebbles, and mango. Related posts:
This popular Vietnamese coffee shop is now serving Cinnamon Toast Crunch Lattes
Here are 10 grocery stores & farmers’ markets offering delivery in Seattle  But beyond the amazing flavors of these donuts, we’re super into the shape. The almost honeycomb or flower shape means you can break off pieces for bite-sized chunks. So if you find the donuts to be overpowering, you can always save some for later. If you’d like to learn more about Mochinut you can click here. And be sure to be patient with them as they work out hours. After all, opening a new business is hard, especially in the middle of a pandemic. With that, get out there and treat yourself to a unique donut!

data.title: This beloved Capitol Hill dining spot is finally returning next month
data.description:
We probably all have favorite restaurants that have either closed for good or are on hiatus. It’s been a devastating 12 months for the hospitality industry, but we have a little good news on the return of a beloved Seattle restaurant. Thanks to a huge new mural it looks like Oddfellows Cafe will be returning sooner rather than later. The Capitol Hill dining spot which serves breakfast and lunch as well as a host of alcoholic and caffeinated beverages has been a long-time favorite in the neighborhood. But sadly it closed this winter due to the pandemic which makes sense. But thanks to a big new sign and an Instagram post, it looks like they’ll be back next month. Related posts:
This 110-year-old Seattle home for sale comes with stunning views of Mount Rainier
Seattle’s Sub Pop Records just opened a new flagship store in the city   So we’ll take this as some good news as well as a reminder that summer weather and sun is coming. And we could certainly use both of those things right now. After all, Seattle winter can really get to you. With that, we’re pumped that we can expect to see Oddfellows Cafe back up and running in February or March. If you’re a fan of the cafe and want to stay updated you can follow their Insta here. Or you can learn more at their website here. Have a great week, Seattle!

data.title: This popular Vietnamese coffee shop is now serving Cinnamon Toast Crunch Lattes
data.description:
We all know that Seattle has about a billion options for coffee. But coffee shops are starting to get more and more creative with their drinks which we love to see. So if you want to spice up your coffee you need to try the Cinnamon Toast Crunch Latte from Coffeeholic House. In case you don’t know, Coffeeholic House is a Vietnamese inspired coffee shop tucked away in Columbia City. And we have to say, their entire menu is unique. So with that in mind, whatever you try is sure to be something new. Plus we love their focus on Vietnamese coffee and all of the different takes that they have on it. Related posts:
You can’t miss this new-ish Vietnamese coffee shop in the International District 
A new Vietnamese cafe and roastery is opening in Little Saigon  So get out of your coffee comfort zone this week and try out a new shop. Plus you can even order ahead of time for a quick and seamless pick-up. And doesn’t a Cinnamon Toast Crunch Latte sound good? You can have it hot, iced, or even blended depending on your mood. If you’d like to learn more about Coffeeholic House you can click here. And as always if you end up checking them out be sure to let us know what you think. With that, get out there and treat yourself to a coffee!

data.title: West Seattle has a brand new Detroit-style pizza spot opening today!
data.description:
West Seattle’s very own ‘Up’ house is about to get a whole new lease on life. Because now it’s home to Moto, a brand new pizza spot offering Detroit style pies. So if you need somewhere new to eat this weekend, this is one more spot to add to your list. If you’re unfamiliar with Detroit-style pizza it’s basically deep dish but square-shaped. And what’s sets Moto apart is the fact that they’ll be using sourdough. So you can expect delicious, deep pies that will fulfill all of your pizza cravings. Not to mention, they’ll also have soft-serve ice cream in very ornate handmade cones. Which is perfect if you happen to have a sweet tooth. Related posts:
This Seattle spot makes wildly delicious donut ice cream sandwiches 
This nearby spot is home to the original ‘boba donuts’ & they’re absolutely worth trying  So if you live in West Seattle and need some comfort food Moto is your go-to. And it’s also worth mentioning that they’ll serve coffee as well. So no matter what time of day you can find something delicious here. If you’d like to learn more about Moto you can click below. They open today so be sure to show them some love if you’ll be in the area. And if you give them a try and be sure to let us know what you think.
data.when: 4 pm to 9 pm Wednesdays through Sundays

data.title: This Seattle spot makes wildly delicious donut ice cream sandwiches
data.description:
It may be winter but ice cream is good year-round if you ask us. Especially when that ice cream is in a donut sandwich from Donut Factory. Yes, there is such thing as a magical donut sandwich which probably tastes just as good as it sounds. Donut Factory crafts mouthwatering ice cream donut sandos that are sure to satisfy the sweet tooth in your life. Because you can choose from toppings like bacon, sprinkles, Ferrero Rocher, and more. Not to mention there are tons of flavor and filling options if you decide to opt for other kinds of donuts. Related posts:
10 new restaurants in Seattle that are definitely worth checking out
Seattle’s oldest bar is officially back in business after it closed in 2020  But the options are pretty much endless here because you can also have custom character donuts made for an additional cost. So whether you want a simple message or a few characters, Donut Factory is here to give you the ultimate donut experience. Plus you can even order normal donuts through third-party delivery services. And as always if you end up trying them out be sure to let us know what you think. Because we might have to order these donuts for our next big celebration.

data.title: This nearby spot is home to the original 'boba donuts' & they're absolutely worth trying
data.description:
If you’re a fan of bubble tea then you absolutely can’t miss Bobae. If you haven’t heard of it yet, this spot offers boba donuts among many other unique and delicious menu items. So if you’re in the mood to try something new this week we’d recommend this. Bobae claims to be the first to make nitro bubble tea and that they also have a “farm to straw” cafe experience. But what’s best of all about this spot is that their goal is to show the world and specifically Washington how good bubble tea can be. Because if you’re a fan of this drink you’ll know that not all bubble tea shops are created equally. Related posts:
10 new restaurants in Seattle that are definitely worth checking out
This online tool lets you know when you can expect to get a COVID-19 vaccine  Now as for the boba donuts, they are pretty much exactly what they sound like. So you can expect a filled donut stuffed with boba and whatever flavor combo you chose. Some of the combos listed include Brown Sugar Boba Donuts and Organic Japanese Matcha Cream Donuts. All of which are handmade in house. As far as wacky food combos go, this is definitely one that we want to check out. So as always, if you beat us to it, be sure to let us know what you think.

data.title: Seattle's oldest bar is officially back in business after it closed in 2020
data.description:
At this point, we’re all quite used to the news of restaurant closures. But what about when they come back from the dead? That’s right folks Seattle’s oldest bar, Jules Maes Saloon is back. We don’t know about you guys but this is the good news we needed to start the weekend on a high note. Raché Hemmelgarn had her first date with her husband here and now she owns the business. Understandably she couldn’t let this amazing and historic space disappear. After all, it’s closure was truly a huge loss to the city in 2020. So she made the brave and risky choice to save it and for that, we are extremely thankful. Related posts:
West Seattle’s Stone Cottage needs your help to save it from demolition
Guide: 10 essential ramen spots with takeout & delivery to try in Seattle  Now Hemmelgarn is ready to do what it takes and wants to rejuvenate the business. So with that in mind, she’s hired a talented chef and spiffed up the restaurant. And as you might’ve guessed she is currently operating the restaurant on a takeout, delivery, and curbside pick-up basis. If you’d like to learn more about the new Jules Maes Saloon you can click here. And if you feel like giving back to the restaurant community this weekend consider ordering a take-out order from them. After all, it’s always great to try new restaurants especially ones that are over a century old.

data.title: After nearly 40 years, Seattle's aviation-themed diner is closing its doors
data.description:
For nearly 40 years, Randy’s Restaurant in Tukwila has been a staple of the Seattle-area diner scene. Now, along with many other iconic restaurants and small businesses in the area, it’s announced that it will have to close its doors. The flight-themed diner sits close to the Museum of Flight and has thrilled and satisfied hungry aviation enthusiasts and food lovers alike for decades. The proximity to the Museum was a major source of business as Museum visitors and workers would venture to Randy’s for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Recent Posts:
A very unique virtual dance festival kicks off in Seattle next week
One of the Elephant Super Car Wash signs is being donated to Amazon Now, with the Museum having been closed during the pandemic and people going out to eat less and less, Randy’s Restaurant has to say goodbye. It’s a harsh reality of the current times, but, at the very least, we’ll have the memories of places like Randy’s to keep us looking forward to better times ahead. Randy’s Restaurant will be open until November 15th, so be sure to head over for one last diner classic!
data.where: Last day of operation is November 

data.title: Ballard has a brand new cafe in the old Bastille space
data.description:
Well folks Seattle has yet another brand new spot to check out. And this time it’s Sabine Cafe & Market, a brand new spot in Ballard. It also just so happens to be located in the old Bastille space. So if you want to try a new coffee spot this weekend you might want to stop by. Sabine Cafe & Market is the reinvention of the old Bastille restaurant. And it honestly makes a fair amount of sense, after all the space was huge and with few people dining in a cafe seems much more appropriate. So now you can snag some homemade creations along with a cup of joe. Related posts:
Krispy Kreme is giving away free donuts to voters on election day
This new Capitol Hill spot has naturally-leavened pizza  And it looks like they’ll also be offering some light lunch fare including sandwiches and salads. Not to mention chicken and also cocktails for those of you needing something more than a coffee. So if you want a place that does it all, Sabine might just tick all your boxes. If you’d like to learn more you can click below. And if you end up checking it out let us know what you think. After all, we’re always curious to see how restaurants are continuing to evolve. Have a great day Seattle!

data.title: This new Capitol Hill spot has naturally-leavened pizza
data.description:
Well, Seattle if you’re looking to start your November with some new eats we have a spot for you to check out. And that is Cornelly, a brand new Italian spot with handmade pasta, naturally leavened pizza, and local veggies. So don’t miss out! Cornelly opened last week and is located on Capitol Hill.
