data.title: Shoreline's highly-anticipated Black Coffee Northwest is finally open
data.description:
Well folks it’s been an eventful past few weeks for Shoreline’s new spot Black Coffee Northwest. After an arson fire at the end of September, this new cafe is finally open. And, this coffee shop is certainly more than meets the eye. That’s because this new coffee shop has a community and social justice focus. So beyond coffee, they are planning on rolling out several youth programs. And just a few include a barista training program, an after-school study hour, and more! Related posts:
Fremont has a brand new must-try pizza spot for all your cravings
This swoon-worthy bakery is opening soon in Seattle!  But when it comes to coffee you can find a whole host of roasts from the Black-owned Renton company Boona Boona. And we recommend checking out the menu because it truly has some of the best drink names we’ve ever seen. Not to mention, you can also grab some tasty treats from Zuri’s Donutz and Salmonberry. And if you’re planning on heading over to Shoreline or live in the area, we highly recommend that you stop by and show them some love. Because we’ll be doing so as well!

data.title: This swoon worthy bakery is opening soon in Seattle!
data.description:
If you’re serious about your pastry game, you’ll want to hear about this new bakery coming to Seattle. It’s called Temple Pastries and you may be familiar with the name as they’ve done a few pop-ups. But regardless we promise you’ll want to try their treats. Temple Pastries doesn’t have an exact open date yet but it could be as soon as this week! So with that in mind, if you’re feeling really excited, we recommend keeping up with their Instagram. Because we too want to be first in line to try some of their goodies. Related posts:

You have to check out this bagel delivery service that sells out every week  Not to mention, it looks like their space is beautiful. And while dine-in isn’t everyone’s first choice at the moment we will certainly look forward to sitting down here in the future. But we guarantee you’ll want to snap a few pics upon seeing it. So we’re super excited to welcome Temple Pastries to Seattle. Because we always need an excellent pastry to accompany one of our cities’ many excellent cups of coffee. And if you end up checking them out please let us know what you think.

data.title: Seattle’s first Japanese Yakitori restaurant just opened!
data.description:
We all love a new restaurant. And Shinya Shokudo is pretty dang new on the block. In fact, they opened early September. So now is a great time to check them out as they’ve had a bit of time to get in the swing of things. But what’s even better is that Shinya Shokudo is Seattle’s first Japanese Yakitori Restaurant. And they’re here to give you an authentic Izakaya dining experience. So we don’t know about you guys but this is a must-try in our books. Related posts:
School is in session at the very unique Canlis Community College starting today
8 things to do in Seattle this week (October 5-9)  Not to mention, their clean and minimalistic space is pretty dang Instagramable. So you can enjoy some tasty eats and snap a few pics while you’re at it. Because showing restaurants some love on your socials is a great way to help bring more people to their tables. We’ll definitely be trying this place and hope that you do too. But if you get there before us, be sure to let us know how it is. And we’ll see you guys there!
data.when: Sunday to Thursday, 12 PM-10 PM and Friday/Saturday, 12 PM-12 AM

data.title: This new Seattle restaurant in a historic spot has a disco hallway
data.description:
It’s been a while since Seattle has gotten a truly unique restaurant. But it looks like that’s changing with a new spot in Fremont called Dreamland Bar and Diner. And as the name suggests, this spot might just have you feeling a little dreamy. Dreamland Bar and Diner is taking over the historic Red Door bar space. And we have to say that we think this restaurant will be a great new chapter of history for the building. After all, they’re serving up all-day breakfast with an incredibly unique interior and menu. Related posts:
8 things to do at home and around Seattle this weekend (July 14-16)
Optimism Brewing is the first Seattle restaurant to receive a street closure permit  And while you can find some classics on the menu you can also find some very unique items like guava mules and ‘tigers blood’ margs. So while you eat your all-day breakfast and sip your drinks you can enjoy a beautiful garden and disco ball hallway. And we’re thinking there are some pretty great Insta pic opportunities here. And as this restaurant has opened during the pandemic they’re following all state guidelines to give you a safe dining experience. So you might just have to stop by for some new eats.

data.title: A crazy Korean corn dog chain just opened up in Seattle
data.description:
We don’t know much, but we do know that Korean corn dogs in Seattle are a good idea. The international chain Chung Chun opened a location here this past weekend. Here’s why you need to check it out. You can toss aside your idea of what a corn dog is when you visit Chung Chun. Instead of corn batter, these guys use a rice flour batter that results in a chewy, almost sticky consistency. Might sound weird, but trust us here. Related Posts:
8 things to do in Seattle this week (December 9-13)
8 of the best New Year’s Eve parties & events in Seattle  Then, their menu introduces some truly foreign options. Try a corn dog with potato chunks, ramen noodles or even a squid ink batter. However, the one thing we think is a must here is the cheese. Instead of being drizzled on top, this corn dog features a layer of cheddar cheese between the dog and the batter. Or, for the purists out there, there’s also what is essentially a massive mozzarella stick. It does sound pretty tempting, full disclosure.

data.title: Add this gorgeous garden tea ceremony to your summer bucket list
data.description:
Ok, so now is the time for you to experience everything that Seattle has to offer in the summer. And, one of those things is equal parts beautiful and educational. That’s right, we’re talking about the tea ceremonies at the Seattle Japanese Garden. First off, the garden itself is absolutely stunning. A full-fledged, 3.5-acre space filled with walking paths and flora. Enjoy a leisurely stroll through it, making sure to take in the tranquility of the space. When a garden survives for over 5 decades (it opened in 1960), you know that there’s something special going on. And while we can easily say that the garden does more than prove that, there’s another draw here. Related Posts:
Glossier Seattle has just opened its pop-up location
Guide: 7 of the best spas in Seattle  Chanoya, aka a tea ceremony, is an opportunity to look into chado, or the ‘way of tea’. Why would you want to learn the way of tea? Well, we’re sure you can find a reason. As for us, we see it as a ritual that calms one a little bit. Maybe even a gateway to meditation. Don’t get too hung up on form- just appreciate your surroundings and sip on a little tea. It is just an introduction, after all. You’re not going to be tested after the ceremony is over, thankfully.
data.when: Weekly, the upcoming events page for the next one

data.title: A look inside Seattle's first bubble tea food truck
data.description:
Let’s face it, food trucks are amazing. Food trucks serving up incredible bubble tea? That’s downright dreamy. Good thing that this truck is called Dreamy Drinks! (Otherwise we would have to call them out for false advertising.)  The pastel pink van offers all sorts of sips. If you’re feeling coffee, they’ve got you. Milk tea craving? They’ve got you. This truck has even got slushies! So, swing by and treat yourself to a little something, you’ve earned it. Related Posts:
RGB’s tasty new soft-serve is a Seattle first
Find Seattle’s top Southern dishes at this low-key spot  We’re big fans of the strawberry matcha latte. It tastes fruity, but comes with a little kick of energy. Plus, it’s filled with milk, green tea and strawberries. (AKA, a match made in heaven.) You can trust us on this, we don’t mess around.  For the hotter days, go for the Grapefruit Jasmine Slushy instead. Think of it as a slurpee on steroids. Probably healthier than a slurpee, too. We think. It’s better for your soul, at least.  After you visit, make sure to toss them a follow them on Instagram. That way, the next time they’re nearby you can make a beeline over there. Think of Dreamy Drinks as the adult ice cream truck. Except instead of a fun song to alert us, we’ve got social media. How times have changed…

data.title: A look inside Canon, one of best bars in America
data.description: Before we get started today, we should mention that we are in no way qualified to provide a whiskey connoisseurs rundown of Canon. But! We do really like drinking and know a good spot when we see it.  Which is why taking a look inside Canon was an easy choice for us. As one of the best bars in America, this low-key bar has certainly made the nation’s canon (haha, nice).  We will start things off with their food menu. Small plates dominate, allowing for guests to nibble away as they try drink after delicious drink. They’ve got a few larger options too, like skirt steak and duck cassoulet. You know, just in case your dinner wasn’t up to par.  Moving on, their cocktail menu reflects an intense dedication to both past and present. Manhattans, mules and sharing drinks rest beside international concoctions and house creations. Frankly, it’s a long list and one that would take the average person months to get through.  Of course, you’re not going to find a better cocktail in the city, so we think that you should get a move on.  Canon also has the largest selection of spirits in the Western Hemisphere, sitting at a whopping 4,000 bottles and counting. The 192-page (good lord) menu has everything from $7 shots of tequila to things you have never seen before.  And we mean that- there are bottles at Canon from the late 1800s, often costing over $800 a pour. Might as well make ours a double, right?

data.title: An exclusive look inside a Capitol Hill treasure
data.description:
Whenever we feel the need to escape the gloominess of Seattle, we head over to Stateside for a quick bite to eat. Not that we don’t love the rain, but sometimes it’s nice to be transported to a tropical oasis.  This French-Vietnamese fusion spot is bright and airy and complete with tropical plants on the wallpaper. Whether you’re at a table or posting up at the bar, Stateside will make you forget what the weather is like outside. Related Posts:
Guide: 7 of the Best Spas in Seattle
Take a sneak peek inside of a Seattle speakeasy  We think you should start with some of their crispy duck fresh rolls and a cocktail or two. The light yet flavorful dish is the perfect way to warm up the palate for your meal. Also, who doesn’t love a little duck? Vegetarians, probably, so fair.  Next, grab some of their signature Hunan-style Chili Cumin Pork Ribs. You’ve got two options for these- a bit spicy or extra spicy. Personally, we only recommend extra spicy if you’re a spice lord or a little bit of a masochist. Hey, you do you, no judgment here.  Even if you don’t grab a large plate or a side, make sure you end your meal with their incredible creamsicles. You can choose between Thai-Iced Tea, Cherry Coconut or Vietnamese coffee. Take our word for it and grab the Vietnamese Iced Coffee, especially if you walk next door to Foreign National afterward.

data.title: Take a sneak peek inside of a Seattle speakeasy
data.description:
Ah, the classic bar within a bar idea. A time-honored tradition, and one done extremely well at Needle and Thread. This speakeasy located above the already popular Tavern Law is a great late night date spot. Here’s a quick look at what to do at one of Seattle’s most low-key speakeasies. Related Posts:
The Pink Door is Seattle’s best dinner and a show
5 New Seattle Restaurants You’ve Gotta Check Out  First things first, let’s get into the bar. You’re not going to be able to enjoy Needle and Thread if you can’t thread your own needle into the place. The only real strategy is to make reservations ahead of time on their website. Then, put on your best late-night duds. Men, wax your mustaches (if you’ve got one). Ladies, plump those eyelashes (if you’ve got two). When you’re ready, head to the back of Tavern Law, pick up the telephone, provide the password (from your reservation) and enter through a bank vault.  Once you’re in, you might be surprised to find out that there’s no menu. Instead, the bartender will figure out your taste preferences and craft one for you from memory. A great approach, just so long as you know what you’re feeling for that night. If you don’t want to fully pretend like it’s the prohibition, then you can always just grab something from Tavern Law instead. An extensive cocktail list and great American food mean you can’t go wrong either way.

data.title: This Milk Truck Espresso is a Seattle Staple
data.description:
We’re just goofing, but it is true that you can find an amazing espresso drink that is served out of an old milk truck. Celesto Espresso has been around since 2013, offering some of the best coffee in the city from a convenient location. Now at King Street Station, this is the second street cart/truck created by owner Celeste Clark. Her first venture started way back in 1991, with a cart in South Lake Union. Related Posts:
The Pink Door is Seattle’s best dinner and a show
5 New Seattle Restaurants You’ve Gotta Check Out  After five years of running it, Celeste got out of that game and spent time at such staples as Vashon Roasters and Zoka, as well as the now-defunct Tully’s. Anyway, she found her milk truck, named it Annie, and returned to serving delicious coffee on the street. Now, you can either grab an incredible mocha or a really nice chai. Feeling peckish? There’s also a rotating selection of baked goods and snacks. Next time you find yourself in Pioneer Square, make sure you keep Celesto Espresso in mind.
data.when: Monday to Friday and occasional weekends, 6:30AM-12PM

data.title: The Pink Door is Seattle's best dinner and a show
data.description: Quite literally a hole in the wall spot, The Pink Door has been a Seattle staple for over three decades. If you’ve not had a chance to check out this local gem, then here are a few reasons to do so. First and foremost, their menu is delicious- unpretentious Italian-American food done well and at a reasonable price. While their lasagna is arguably the best choice, you’ll probably be craving a bit more. So, grab the arancini as a starter or the meatballs as a side. If you’re really hungry, try their cioppino dish with clams, mussels, prawns and calamari. Related Posts:    But as an added bonus, the Pink Door has nightly entertainment. To start, they host great jazz shows Tuesday through Friday. Alternatively, you can opt for something a little more risqué. On Saturdays, they have one of the best burlesque shows in the city. Meanwhile, Sundays and Mondays are reserved for ‘aerialist’ performances. For these events, get a reservation and make sure you remember their dress code. It’s clear that The Pink Door offers an equally delicious and interesting dining experience. Duck into it the next time you decide to eat out.
data.when: Monday to Thursday, 11:30AM-11:30PM, Friday/Saturday, 11:30AM-1AM and Sunday, 4PM-10PM

data.title: Analog
data.description: Analog is a modern American coffee shop located in Seattle’s hip Capitol Hill neighborhood. You’ll find a rotating cast of exceptional local roasters and Fresh Breeze Organic dairy. You’ll love the attention to detail and vintage feel of the interior.

data.title: Union Coffee & Wine
data.description: Union is a great place to snag a cup of joe and also a bottle or two. The coffee shop also sells natural wine so you can swing by in the morning for a pick me up and back in the afternoon for a wind down.
data.when: 2407 E Union St Suite B, Seattle, WA

data.title: General Porpoise
data.description: If you want to enjoy a space that is beautifully curated and serves up delicious coffee paired with the city’s best donuts then you need to head to General Porpoise. Be prepared to leave with two donuts because you’ll probably be craving another after your first.

data.title: Hood Famous Bakeshop
data.description: Not only is Hood Famous super cute but they also have one of the most unique menus in the city. This bakeshop and coffee spot focuses on Philippine cuisine and flavors. So you can grab a coffee and an amazing snack.
data.where: : Wednesday-Friday 8 am-4 pm, Saturday & Sunday 9 am-4 pm

data.title: Zeitgeist Coffee
data.description:
This Pioneer Square spot is a classic coffee destination for Seattleites. The wood filled interior is unique, homey and also happens to be full of art which rotates regularly. Might as well stroll the neighborhood after for the full experience. Recent Posts:
10 of the best cafes to work remotely from in Seattle
Great local bakeries to score delicious Easter treats in Seattle this year

data.title: Ada’s Technical Books and Cafe
data.description: Ada’s has it all, a book store full of amazing technical, science and downright interesting reads as well as a vegetarian cafe. So you can grab your coffee, a snack and browse their selection of great reads.

data.title: Elm Coffee Roasters
data.description: Minimalists, Elm is for you. The uncomplicated, white walled interior is the perfect distraction free place to enjoy a delicious cup of coffee. That being said, you will still have to contend with the normal hustle and bustle of a popular cafe.

data.title: Moonrise Bakery
data.description: You can grab pastries, coffee, and a curated selection of vibrant natural wines at Moonrise. If you’re looking for a place that has a little bit of everything, this Queen Anne spot might just become your new haunt.

data.title: Temple Pastries
data.description: If you’re looking for great coffee and perfect pastries its time to head to Temple. Between their delicious goodies and attention to detail you’ll be coming back time and time again. Right now you can find some super cute spring treats.

data.title: Bake Shop
data.description: Love coffee and sustainability? You’ll love Bake Shop! This relative new comer to the Seattle coffee scene is all about staying low waste and sourcing locally. Enjoy your coffee Seattle!
data.where: : Tuesday-Friday 7 am-7 pm, Saturday & Sunday 8 am-7 pm

data.title: Needle & Thread
data.description: Inside of Tavern Law is a prohibition-style speakeasy. You won’t find a menu here, rather the staff will ask you what you enjoy and craft a custom cocktail, a drink you’ll only get to experience once. Keep in mind reservations are required.
data.where: : Tuesday-Saturday 5 pm-12 am, Sundays 5 pm-11 pm

data.title: Bathtub Gin & Co.
data.description: A bar tucked away in the basement of an old hotel? If it were anywhere but Bathtub Gin & Co we might be a little sketched out. It’s a prohibition-style cocktail bar with liquors from around the world

data.title: Knee High Stocking Co.
data.description: Knee-High is a speakeasy-themed, craft cocktail bar that also serves up Filipino eats. So if you’re looking for something that deviates a bit from the classic speakeasy bar, this might just be for you.
data.where: : Thursday 6 pm-11 pm, Friday & Saturday 6 am-12 am

data.title: Foreign National
data.description: Foreign National is a cocktail and drinking snacks destination created by the Stateside Team. It’s directly next door and has a dark and intimate environment perfect for enjoying a drink or two.

data.title: The Founders Club
data.description: Definitely the newest spot on the list, The Founders Club is an “intimate spirit drinker’s enclave.” It’s inspired by 1920s speakeasy culture which you’ll find reflected in the space’s decor and secret nature. Psst by the way you have to go through a bookcase to get to this one. Enjoy Seattle!

data.title: Macrina
data.description: You can always count on Macrina to have some perfectly cute seasonal goodies. This year they have birds nest cupcakes, carrot cake and we’ll bet they’ll unveil some new frosted cookies soon.

data.title: Temple Pastries
data.description: If you’re looking for perfect pastries its time to head to Temple. Between their delicious goodies and attention to detail you’ll be coming back time and time again. Right now they have some beautiful first come first serve cakes, cronuts and more!

data.title: Coyle’s Bakeshop
data.description: Did someone say hot cross buns? Coyle’s is kind of the place to get them. In fact, they sell out every year so if you’re in need of some for your Easter brunch be sure to order ASAP.

data.title: Bakery Nouveau
data.description: On the topic of hot cross buns, Bakery Nouveau also happens to make some pretty mean buns. So grab. a few or check out some of their other beautifully decorated and delicious spring themed goodies.

data.title: Fran’s Chocolates
data.description: Need some chocolate bunnies to fill out your Easter baskets? Fran’s has you covered with a few different options. Grab chocolate bunnies, chocolate eggs, or customize a chocolate bunny of your choice by adding a chocolate name to it.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 7:30 am-5 pm, Sunday 8:30 am-5 pm

data.title: Trophy Cupcakes
data.description: Need expertly decorated cupcakes to take your Easter celebrations to the next level? Trophy is where it’s at. The cupcake shop has tons of bright, spring themed sweets to help you have the best Easter yet. Happy Easter, Seattle!

data.title: Westward
data.description: For lakefront views, you have to visit Westward. Not only is the patio perfect for outdoor dining but it also happens to be a Renee Erickson restaurant. So that means you’ll get an amazing menu and experience to match those stunning views.
data.where: : Dinner Monday-Thursday 4 pm-9 pm, Friday & Sunday 4 pm-9 pm, Happy Hour Monday-Thursday 4 pm-5 pm, Friday Lunch 12 pm-2 pm, Brunch Saturday & Sunday 10 am-2 pm, Limited Bar Menu Friday-Sunday 2 pm-4 pm

data.title: Patio Cielo at Mezcaleria Oaxaca
data.description: This is our favorite spot for authentic Oaxacan eats. They also just so happen to have one of Seattle’s best patios. It’s a great spot to catch the sunset, enjoy a drink and look over Pine Street. Check it out if you’re looking for some great eats, drinks, and of course a covered patio with a lively atmosphere.

data.title: Old Stove Brewing
data.description: Having drinks and eats is already cool as is but how about a view? Old Stove Brewing has a great indoor and outdoor patio that overlooks Elliott Bay as well as a stretch of Seattle’s waterfront.
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 11 am-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 11 am-10 pm

data.title: The Mountaineering Club
data.description: You really can’t beat the panoramic views provided by the 16th floor of the Graduate Hotel Seattle. The Mountaineering Club boasts views of Mount Rainier, downtown Seattle, and Puget Sound. It’s so nice up there you might forget to even eat and drink.

data.title: mbar
data.description: Impressive views combined with a club-like ambiance make mbar one of the best rooftop patios in Seattle. Obviously, the rooftop is great, but even the indoor seating provides a top-notch atmosphere and sights.
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 4 pm-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 4 pm-10 pm

data.title: Fog Room
data.description:
Perched above 2nd Avenue in downtown Seattle, this is more of a unique terrace than a traditional rooftop patio. That being said, it’s hard to deny Fog Room from earning a spot on this list. The modern-chic decor is gorgeous, the downtown views are stunning, and the food and drink menus are insanely good. Enjoy! Related posts:
12 of the best waterfront patios you can find in & around Seattle
Sky High: Scenic flight tours you can take in & around Seattle this spring

data.title: Smith Tower Observatory & Bar
data.description: If you’re looking for an unforgettable view then you have to visit the Smith Tower Observatory. Not only can you check out the deck but you can also enjoy a drink at the bar. If you want to treat yourself to a drink and a little piece of Seattle history the Smith Tower is the spot for you.

data.title: The Nest
data.description: Get a little boujee and hit the top shelf of Seattle rooftop bars/patios with a visit to The Nest. Come for the views, stay for the cocktails, and leave because you’re broke (like us), or stay a little longer ‘cuz you’re flush with cash. Either way, you’ll enjoy the delicious menu and the stunning views.
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 5 pm-10 pm, Friday & Saturday 3 pm-11 pm, Sunday 5 pm-10 pm

data.title: Agua Verde
data.description: This spot is unique for a few reasons. Firstly it’s right on the water and has a great outdoor patio.  Secondly, you can actually rent kayaks and paddleboards here. So grab some eats and drinks and hit the lake afterward. It’ll be a fun and tasty experience you won’t soon forget.
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 9 am-8 pm, Friday & Saturday 9 am-9 pm

data.title: Brimmer and Heeltap
data.description: This Ballard spot has a beautiful back patio and garden area that just so happens to be covered. So if you’re looking to enjoy a delicious menu with PNW ingredients this spot is a great choice. And while it might not be the kind of view you’d normally associate with patios, you can’t beat garden dining.

data.title: Captain Blacks
data.description: With two outdoor decks, some wicked deals, and an unbeatable atmosphere, it’s hard to deny that Captian Blacks is one of Seattle’s favorite spots. Heck, throw in the Southern-inspired dishes and you’ve practically encountered heaven on earth.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 4-10 pm, Friday, Saturday & Sunday 2-10 pm

data.title: Salty’s on Alki
data.description: On the topic of Alki, we can’t not mention Salty’s. The classic spot is known for its waterfront views and menu which is chock full of seafood. Seafood by the sea err bay sounds pretty great, doesn’t it? That’s what we have for you when it comes to patios with views in Seattle. Enjoy!
data.where: : Monday-Friday 5 pm-9 pm, Saturday & Sunday 10 am-9 pm

data.title: Agua Verde
data.description: This spot is unique for a few reasons. Firstly, it’s right on the water and has a great outdoor patio.  Secondly, you can actually rent kayaks and paddleboards here. So grab some eats and drinks and hit the lake afterward. It’ll be a fun and tasty experience you won’t soon forget.
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 9 am-8 pm, Friday & Saturday 9 am-9 pm

data.title: Ivar’s Fish Bar
data.description: There aren’t many restaurants in Seattle let alone the world where you can arrive via boat. Ivar’s Salmon House has to be one of our favorite spots for casual dining. You can enjoy delicious fish and chips on the floating barge outside which is pretty dang unique.
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 11:30 am-8 pm, Friday & Saturday 11:30 am-9 pm

data.title: Salty’s
data.description: If you happen to be over in West Seattle then you probably already know about Salty’s. This classic is considered one of the most scenic restaurants in the whole nation. So if you want to enjoy some delicious seafood you should head to Salty’s.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 5 pm-9 pm, Saturday & Sunday 10 am-9 pm

data.title: Little Water Cantina
data.description: If you want to kick back and relax with some tacos on Lake union you can always head to Little Water Cantina. This waterfront spot has tacos, margs, and more for you to enjoy in a beautiful setting.
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 11:30 am-9 pm and Friday & Saturday 11:30 am-11 pm

data.title: The White Swan Public House
data.description: You’ll find a wide menu of both eats and drinks at The White Swan. Of course, you’ll also find a great outdoor patio perfect for soaking in the sun.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 3 pm-10 pm, Saturday 10 am-10 pm, Sunday 10 am-2 pm

data.title: Westward
data.description:
For lakefront views, you have to visit Westward. Not only is the patio perfect for outdoor dining but it also happens to be a Renee Erickson restaurant. So that means you’ll get an amazing menu and experience to match those stunning views. Related posts:
Sky High: Scenic flight tours you can take in & around Seattle this spring
The Seattle Public Library just added 5 new partners to it’s Museum Pass program
data.where: : Dinner Monday-Thursday 4 pm-9 pm, Friday & Sunday 4 pm-9 pm, Happy Hour Monday-Thursday 4 pm-5 pm, Friday Lunch 12 pm-2 pm, Brunch Saturday & Sunday 10 am-2 pm, Limited Bar Menu Friday-Sunday 2 pm-4 pm

data.title: Un Bien
data.description: Technically this spot doesn’t have a waterfront patio but it’s directly across the street from Shilshole Pocket Beach and down the road from Golden Gardens. And for proximity to a beach, you really can’t beat that. So treat yourself to a delicious sandwich and watch a picture-perfect sunset at Golden Gardens.
data.where: : Wednesday-Saturday 11 am-9 pm, Sunday 11 am-8 pm

data.title: Elliott’s Oyster House
data.description: If you’re looking for Oysters on the water you can’t really go wrong with Elliott’s. This spot is appropriately located on Elliott Bay and has a menu full of seafood and of course, drinks. So if you’ll be downtown, give them a go.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 3 pm-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 12 pm-10 pm, Sunday 12 pm -9 pm

data.title: Ray’s Cafe
data.description: If you’re looking for a spot to grab drinks and fish and chips, Ray’s is a great spot to head to. The Ballard classic has a great waterfront patio that makes a great spot to spend the afternoon. Just don’t forget your sunscreen.

data.title: Marination Ma Kai
data.description: This unique Hawaiian-Korean fusion spot is located right on Alki. It’s a perfect spot for some seriously delicious eats like tacos, sandwiches, and more. They have a sun drenched patio or you can just take your meal to go and enjoy it on the beach.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 11 am-8 pm, Friday & Saturday 9 am-9 pm, Sunday 9 am-8 pm

data.title: West Seattle Brewing Co.
data.description: Want a few brews and an exquisite view? Head over to West Seattle to enjoy a spot that’s right on Alki. If you happen to get peckish you can also grab some pizza. And when you’re ready for something more you can head down to the beach.

data.title: The Fisherman’s Restaurant & Bar
data.description: If you’re looking for fresh from the sea delicacies you should check out The Fisherman’s Restaurant. It’s a waterfront classic and a great spot to nosh on local seafood. Those are our picks for waterfront patios in and around Seattle. We hope that you get out there and enjoy some fresh, outdoor dining.

data.title: Maneki
data.description: It’s Seattle’s oldest restaurant so it has to be good right? Well, it is, and Maneki not only serves up delicious sushi but you can also have an unforgettable dining experience in one of their tatami rooms. That being said, they are still operating on a takeout-only basis.

data.title: Taneda
data.description: If you’re looking for traditional counter-service style sushi then you need to check out Taneda, it’s tucked away in Capitol Hill’s Broadway Alley. Choosing your dishes here is easy as chef Hideaki Taneda only serves up course meals aka omakase. Definitely on the higher end but well worth it for a treat yourself kind of meal.

data.title: Fremont Bowl
data.description: Okay, so it’s not technically sushi, but Fremont Bowl has some of the best if not the best rice bowls in the city. You can get a delicious chirashi don or opt for a single fish don like salmon. Not to mention their prices are killer and the fish is always fresh. Their bowls are perfect for taking to the park to enjoy your eats with a view.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 11:30 am-2 pm, Saturday & Sunday 11:30am – 2:30pm, Monday- Sunday 4:30 pm-9 pm

data.title: Kisaku Sushi
data.description: This Tangletown spot has a menu complete with rolls, sashimi, nigiri, and a whole host of lunch specials. If you want to go a bit bigger they also offer two different omakase menus. So go for a roll or two, or enjoy a whole omakase with friends, whatever you chose you won’t be disappointed.
data.where: : Monday-Saturday 11:30 am-2 pm, Sunday-Thursday 5 pm-8 pm, Friday & Saturday 4:30 pm- 8 pm

data.title: Musashi’s
data.description: This Wallingford spot is definitely considered a classic at this point as they’ve been in the sushi game a long time. This has made them one of Seattle’s best spots to grab rolls and bowls. In fact, they’re pretty well recognized as having one of the best Chirashi dons in the city.
data.where: : Tuesday-Friday 11:30 am-2:30 pm & 5 pm-9 pm, Saturday 5 pm-9 pm

data.title: Nishino
data.description:
This Madison Park spot is definitely on the higher end of sushi spots but it’s a great spot for a special occasion or date night. You can enjoy signature rolls, small plates and of course their wildly popular omakase that has folks coming back time and time again. They’ve been at it for over 20 years so you can expect to have an unforgettable experience. Recent Posts:
Here are which Seattle Farmers Markets you can visit now & when more open
Kamino Sushi and More is Seattle’s only Burmese resto & you can visit it in Uptown
data.where: : Wednesday-Saturday 5 pm-8:45 pm, Sunday 4:30 pm-8:15 pm

data.title: Tamari Bar
data.description: Tamari Bar is a great place to get sushi as well as a full Japanese menu full of items like appys, noodles and bao. When it comes to sushi you can nosh on rolls, chirashi and sashimi. This spot is also known for it’s highballs if you’re looking to imbibe a bit.

data.title: Mashiko
data.description: Not only is Mashiko tasty but they’re also committed to sustainability which not every restaurant can say. In this day and age, sustainability is super important as we need fish to enjoy sushi! The resulting dishes are high quality, delicious, and sure to have you coming back for more.
data.where: : Monday, Tuesday & Wednesday, Sunday 5:30 pm-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 5:30 pm-10 pm

data.title: Aburiya Bento House
data.description: As the name suggests, Aburiya is all about bento boxes making their meals one of the most Instagrammable on the list. Beyond the food’s incredibly photogenic nature it’s also delicious and conveniently located near Pike Place. So enjoy your eats and wander around the waterfront after.
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 11:30 am-2:30 pm, 4:30 pm-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 11:30 am-3 pm, 5 pm-9:30 pm

data.title: Sushi Kappo Tamura
data.description: 2018 James Beard Award semifinalist chef Taichi Kitamura runs this delicious spot on Eastlake. He serves up a mix of rolls, nigiri, sashimi, sushi combos, and omakase. A dinner or lunch here is a sure win and a great spot to enjoy with friends or for a big night out.
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 5 pm-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 5 pm-9:30 pm

data.title: Wataru
data.description: This spot is known for its omakase but like other local restos made some adaptations during the pandemic. Currently you can enjoy weekend dine in service (which is limited so plan your rest in advance) or you can pick up some amazing take out to enjoy at home.
data.where: : Friday, Saturday and Sunday from 7 pm

data.title: Shiro’s
data.description: Shiro’s has long been known as one of the best spots in Seattle to score delicious, authentic, high quality sushi. That hasn’t changed, it’s a great spot to enjoy “Edomae”, essentially traditional sushi made from Pacific Northwest ingredients. We can all get behind that! Those are our picks for the tastiest places to grab sushi in Seattle. Get out there and treat yourself!

data.title: Starbucks Seattle Roastery
data.description: An intuitive choice perhaps, Starbucks Capitol Hill Roastery is big, busy and bright. If you need the hustle and bustle of people walking by, background noise, a reliable menu and plenty of table options, this is a great choice.

data.title: Ada’s Technical Books and Cafe
data.description: Ada’s has it all, a book store full of amazing technical, science and downright interesting reads as well as a vegetarian cafe. What’s more is that they’ve actually built part of their space around coworking so you can have the best possible remote working experience.

data.title: Zeitgeist Coffee
data.description: This Pioneer Square spot is a classic coffee destination for Seattleites. The wood filled interior is unique, homey and also happens to be full of art which rotates regularly. So grab a coffee, get your work day flowing and hop out early since they have shorter hours.

data.title: Lost Lake
data.description: Looking to do breakfast or brunch and work? Or maybe even bring a friend along? Capitol Hill’s Lost Lake is definitely worth checking out. You have a full menu of classic, delicious diner fare items and a retro interior to get your work done.
data.where: : Thursday-Saturday until 2 am, Sunday-Wednesday until 12 am

data.title: Cafe Vita
data.description:
Need space, light, coffee, tables and some other humans to make your remote workday a little more enjoyable? Cafe Vita is another great option for Capitol Hill folks. You can go alone or invite your fellow WFH buddies to join you. Recent Posts:
10 of the best bookstores in Seattle for finding your perfect read
10 of the most scenic restaurants to visit in Seattle

data.title: Top Pot Doughnuts
data.description: If you love doughnuts look no further than Top Pot. The Capitol Hill location has an incredibly cool interior complete with tables for you to get your hard work done. They of course also have some of the city’s best doughnuts and coffee.

data.title: Elm Coffee Roasters
data.description: Minimalists, Elm is for you. The uncomplicated, white walled interior is the perfect distraction free place to get a few hours of work done. That being said, you will still have to contend with the normal hustle and bustle of a popular cafe.

data.title: General Porpoise
data.description: Another doughnut spot? Sign us up! General Porpoise is known for its delicious filled doughnuts and they also happen to serve up some great coffee. Not only that, but their seating area is perfectly minimal and full of tons of light for a great switch up from your normal workday.

data.title: Victrola Coffee and Art
data.description: Coffee, art, tables, Victrola has it all. It’s also conveniently located on Capitol Hill for a central Seattle spot perfect for meeting up with friends and coworkers.

data.title: Union Coffee
data.description: Working a little later in the day? Union is a great place to head because after your work hours you can enjoy a drink and some snacks. Of course, you can also head over earlier in the day and enjoy the coffee shop atmosphere. Enjoy your WFH grind, Seattle!
data.where: : Saturday-Tuesday 8 am-4 pm, Wednesday-Friday 8 am-8 pm

data.title: Westward
data.description: You can’t say no to a waterfront patio. Westward’s is a step above the rest as it sits right on Lake Union. You’ll get to enjoy waterfront views, amazing hospitality, and some of the city’s best food so you really can’t go wrong here.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 4 pm-9 pm, Friday & Sunday 2 pm-9 pm

data.title: Lowell’s Restaurant
data.description: Need another excuse to visit Pike Place? Lowell’s is the perfect reason. The casual diner-style restaurant which describes itself as “almost classy” has three levels with stunning views. We recommend going early in the morning to enjoy a cup of coffee and some breakfast while looking over Elliott Bay.
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 8 am-4 pm, Friday & Saturday 8 am-4 pm

data.title: Ivar’s Acres of Clams
data.description: A walk on downtown Seattle’s waterfront is always a great idea. An even better idea is to stop by Ivar’s Acres of Clams. You can pick up your favorite fish & chips dishes, some fries and feed the seagulls that fly by while you sit on the restaurant’s outdoor side patio with views of Elliott Bay, the ferries, and more.

data.title: The Pink Door
data.description: The Pink Door has been bringing joy to Seattleites and visitors since 1981. The restaurant is a unique mix of Italian-American dining, eclectic entertainment and views. The delicious, uncomplicated Italian dishes are as much a draw as the beautiful and romantic atmosphere making it a great date or special occasion spot.

data.title: mbar
data.description:
Impressive views combined with a club-like ambiance make mbar one of the most impressive rooftop patios in Seattle. Obviously, the rooftop is great, but even the indoor seating provides a top-notch atmosphere and sights. Recent Posts:
Seattle’s Lark restaurant has returned after a two year hiatus, here’s what’s new
6 nurseries to buy seeds & plants for you spring garden in & around Seattle
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 4 pm-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 4 pm-10 pm

data.title: Bay Cafe
data.description: If you’re looking for a new place to enjoy breakfast or lunch check out the Bay Cafe. It’s not new, it’s been around for decades but it’s tucked away in Fisherman’s Terminal making it a bit of an if you know, you know spot. You’ll enjoy the classic eats and waterfront views.

data.title: Agua Verde
data.description: Waterfront tacos anyone? This spot is unique for a few reasons. Firstly, it’s right on the water and has a great outdoor patio.  Secondly, you can actually rent kayaks and paddleboards here. So grab some eats and drinks and hit the lake afterward. It’ll be a fun and tasty experience you won’t soon forget.
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 9 am-8 pm, Friday & Saturday 9 am-9 pm

data.title: Canlis
data.description: Canlis isn’t just one of Seattle’s premier fine dining spots, it also has stunning views. For your next special occasion head here to enjoy over 70 years of history and expertly crafted dishes and drinks all while looking out over Seattle.

data.title: Il Nido
data.description: Alki Beach, a historic homestead, freshly made pasta, need we say more? Il Nido might not immediately spring to mind when it comes to view spots but it’s located inside of a historic building and right off Alki Beach. So enjoy your meal and a long stroll on the beach afterward.

data.title: Salty’s on Alki
data.description: On the topic of Alki, we can’t not mention Salty’s. The classic spot is known for its waterfront views and menu which is chock full of seafood. Seafood by the sea err bay sounds pretty great doesn’t it? Enjoy your eats with a view!
data.where: : Monday-Friday 5 pm-9 pm, Saturday & Sunday 10 am-9 pm

data.title: A La Mode Pies
data.description: A La Mode is one of the city’s few solely pie dedicated joints. You’ll find sweet and savory pies as well as vegan options. So pick your poison and celebrate the day with your favorite pie.

data.title: Pie Bar
data.description:
Sweet, savory, whatever you’re looking for, Pie Bar has it. You’ll be able to snag a variety of pies at both of their locations this Pi(e) Day. Recent Posts:
5 fun events to celebrate Saint Patrick’s Day in Seattle this year
10 rocking concerts coming to Seattle this March

data.title: Pagliacci Pizza
data.description: Want a pie and a sweet deal. If you purchase an 11-inch pizza, the folks at Pagliacci will throw in a second 11-inch pie for only $3.14 on Pi Day. Looks like the perfect excuse to have a little pizza party with your friends.

data.title: Macrina Bakery
data.description: On Monday aka Pi(e) Day, you’ll be able to choose from four of Macrina’s favorite pies at all of their locations. Seems like a great way to treat yourself and add something extra sweet to the start of your week.

data.title: Bakery Nouveau
data.description: If you want to choose from a selection of rotating seasonal pies, Bakery Nouveau might just be for you. Beyond pies, you can also find an assortment of tarts and other delicious sweet treats that are sure to help you have a great week. Happy Pi Day, Seattle! Enjoy those pies.

data.title: Lass & Lad Brewing
data.where: : Wednesday-Friday 3 pm-9 pm, Saturday 2 pm-9 pm, Sunday 2 pm-8 pm

data.title: Wheelie Pop Brewing
data.where: : Wednesday-Thursday 3 pm-10 pm, Friday & Saturday 12 pm-10 pm, Sunday 12 pm-9 pm

data.title: Lazy Cow
data.description: Lazy Cow Bakery is not exactly open but you can place cake orders for now. It’s owned by Lara de la Rosa who has been serving up her delicious treats at the West Seattle Market. At the new permanent location, customers will be able to find a pastry menu with items like croissants, meringue tarts, flan, and much more. It also has an associated social justice organization called La Casa Del Xoloitzcuintle.

data.title: Dough Joy
data.description:
Dough Joy‘s Capitol Hill store opened its doors in January to a perfectly pink interior with a minimalistic design so that you can focus on choosing your donut. Because when there are so many options, it’s hard to choose. You’ll find all your old favorite donut flavors, as well as some new ones. Recent Posts:
‘Top Chef’ star Shota Nakajima is opening a new teriyaki spot outside Seattle
Check out these tasty pop ups in Seattle this week

data.title: Bake Shop
data.description: Bake Shop is an all-day café meaning you’ll find a menu full of options like house-made baked goods, sourdough bread, as well as a small savory menu with toasts, sandwiches, and salads. Additionally, you can sip on coffee, loose leaf teas, beer, and wine. Give them a visit for breakfast, lunch, or before the next show at Climate Pledge Arena.
data.where: : Tuesday-Friday 7 am-7 pm, Saturday & Sunday 8 am-7 pm

data.title: Cookies with Tiffany
data.description: Looking for cookies fresh out of the oven? Cookies with Tiffany most certainly has you covered, owner Tiffany Lewis has been selling her delicious cookies at the Ballard Farmers Market for the past year and a half and now you can visit her brick and mortar location. You’ll find classic flavors like chocolate chip, peanut butter, s’more, and more! Enjoy Seattle!

data.title: EKÉKO
data.description: The team behind Garzon has a delicious pop-up called EKÉKO that you can find at The Growler Guys this weekend. You’ll find a menu full of Latin American eats like Cuban Frita, Sweet Potato Foldies, and Ají Papas Fritas. You might just find your new favorite dish.

data.title: Haru
data.description:
Haru is a Seattle artisan bakery with a Korean touch. If you’re looking for pastries that are equally as beautiful as how good they taste then you’ll definitely want to check out Haru. They’ll be popping up at Tougo Coffee this weekend with an assortment of treats perfect for Valentine’s Day. That being said be sure to place your order ahead of time. Recent Posts:
10 of the best places to watch Super Bowl LVI in Seattle
28 of the best things to do in Seattle this February 2022

data.title: Lazy Cow Bakery
data.description: Not a pop-up per se but Lazy Cow Bakery is offering beautiful Valentine’s Day boxes. One for $25 that comes with a slice of red velvet cake topped with a chocolate strawberry and an almond croissant. And another in partnership with Frelard Tamales for $124 that comes with 15 mini tamales, flowers, vegan candles, and a taster box of Lazy Cow’s goodies.

data.title: Situ Tacos
data.description: If you’re looking to get your hands on tasty eats ASAP then you’ll want to try Situ Tacos. They’re actually available daily now and you can enjoy quesadillas, tacos, rolled tacos, and more. Can you say tasty?

data.title: Three Sacks Full
data.description: Three Sacks Full is a pop-up from Chef Michael Tsai and Sommelier Matthew Curtis. Together the duo has created a pop-up with a focus on organic vegetables, grains, and locally sourced ingredients as well as wines to accompany them. What makes this pop-up extra cool is that they grow the majority of ingredients on their very own Snoqualmie Valley farm. See? No shortage of eats. Have a great week Seattle!
data.where: : 3404 NE 55th St or 4857 Rainier Ave S

data.title: Queen Anne Beerhall
data.description: If you’re looking for an authentic beer hall experience to celebrate Superbowl, then you should head to Queen Anne Beerhall. You’ll find 25 premium draft brews, beerhall & PNW eats, and of course, screens to keep your eyes on the score.
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 11 am- 12 am, Friday & Saturday 11 am- 2 am

data.title: LTD Bar & Grill
data.description: This Fremont spot is unique in that it’s both a Seahawks & Packer Bar. That means you’ll find multiple screens, eats, and a wide drink menu.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 4 pm-2 am, Saturday 12 pm-2 am, Sunday 12 pm-2 am

data.title: Madison Pub
data.description: Capitol Hill’s gay sports bar Madison Pub is another great option for game watching. Expect screens, pool, darts, a jukebox, and plenty of fun!

data.title: Trade Winds Tavern
data.description: This Belltown spot describes itself as “corner pub meets supper club”. They have a classic wood-filled tavern interior with some retro decoration flair as well as a menu full of appetizers, plates, and of course drinks. You’ll also find screens as well as some games.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 3 pm-12 am, Saturday & Sunday 10 am-12 am

data.title: Buckley’s in Belltown
data.description:
Buckley’s is a pub with plenty of everything, eats, drinks screens and cheer. You’ll feel right at home in the classic pub atmosphere amongst plenty of other football fans. Recent Posts:
2 Seattle spots made the Most Romantic Restaurants in America 2022 list
The 10 most popular movies set in Washington state according to IMDb
data.where: : Monday-Friday 11:30 am-1 pm, Saturday 9 am–2 am, Sunday 9 am–1 am

data.title: Rookies Sports Bar and Grill
data.description: At Rookies, you can expect a comfortable neighborhood atmosphere, great eats, and plenty of drinks. As they’re a sports bar, you’re in the perfect setting to watch the Superbowl on one of the grill’s screens.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 11 am-10 pm, Saturday & Sunday 9 am-10 pm

data.title: The Westy
data.description: The Westy prides itself on being a sports bar without the sports bar feel. You’ll find all the sports-watching amenities accompanied by a great eat and drinks menu with a selection of beer, cider, and whisky.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 4 pm- 12 am, Saturday & Sunday 9 am-12 am

data.title: Fuel Sports Grill
data.description: Ballard’s Fuel Sports Grill has a family-friendly energy and plenty of eats and drinks to enjoy while watching the big game. Not only that but they have 25 flatscreen TVs, a huge projector and state-of-the-art sound.
data.where: :  Monday 3 pm–10 pm, Tuesday-Thursday 3 pm–11 pm, Friday 3 pm–Midnight, Saturday 9 am–Midnight, Sunday 9 am–10 pm

data.title: Tony T’s Sports
data.description: Considering that Tony’s is located in SODO, across from T Mobile Field, it’s easy to see how it’s a popular spot. They also have 20 large screen TVs and plenty of space to relish your eats and drinks while watching the game.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 11 am-11 pm, Friday 11 am-12 am, Saturday 9 am-12 am, Sunday 9 am-11 pm

data.title: Garage Billiards & Bowl
data.description: A bowling alley for football? Don’t knock it till you try it… Garage may predominantly be a billiards and bowling spot but they also have a sports bar perfect for watching the big game. Snack, drink, and play games while you root for your favorite team. Enjoy the Super Bowl, happy game watching and may your favorite team win.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 5 pm-11 pm, Friday-Sunday 3 pm-11 pm

data.title: Chachi’s
data.description: Popular pizza, burger & burrito pop-up Chachi’s is heading over to Capitol Hill’s La Dive this weekend. On Sunday, you’ll be able to snag an assortment of slices in a walk-up-only format so be sure to be early.

data.title: Hamdi
data.description:
Duo Chef Berk Güldal and Katrina Schulttraditional cook up delicious traditional Turkish dishes at their pop-up Hamdi. You can find them at Fair Isle Brewing each Sunday until food sells out. Recent Posts:
Wa Na Wari’s free community meals offer a taste of African diasporic food this month
Here are the best places to enjoy afternoon tea in & around Seattle

data.title: Kryse
data.description: In the mood for ice cream? There’s a pop-up for that, Kryse is on its 69th flavor of ice cream (rosemary, olive oil, chocolate chip) and you can place an order now for pick up this weekend. Act fast because these flavors go quick!
data.when: Pre-order online for pick up February 6th

data.title: Lenox
data.description: For those of you down south, you need to give Lenox a try. They’re posted up at White Center’s Future Primitive Brewing and serve a mix of Afro Latin Soul, Cuban & Puerto Rican as well as comfort food.

data.title: Selva Central Goods
data.description: Here’s another perfectly tasty option for those of you with a sweet tooth. Selva serves up Central American pan dulces of all kinds and flavors. You can find them at El Mercadito Farmers Market this Saturday and pre-orders are available.

data.title: Queen Mary Tea Room
data.description: If you’re in Seattle you can’t beat the Queen Mary Tea Room. It’s an intimate tea room with eye-catching decor and a wide menu of teas to choose from as well as an all-day afternoon tea. Expect your favorite mini sandwiches, fruit, mini pastries, and more.
data.where: : Wednesday-Saturday 9 am-4 pm, Sunday 9 am-4:30 pm

data.title: Afternoon Tea at The Fairmont
data.description:
In years past, The Fairmont has been one of the premier destinations in Seattle for fancy-schmancy afternoon tea. While that likely hasn’t changed the website currently says that details on 2022’s afternoon tea will be released “soon”. So check back, and we’ll be sure to keep you posted! Recent Posts:
Yuan Spa just opened a brand new 8,000 sq ft spa in Kirkland
27 of the best things to do in Seattle this February 2022

data.title: The Secret Garden Tea Room
data.description: If you live in south Seattle, consider a drive down to Sumner to check out The Secret Garden Tea Room. It’s situated inside of a Victorian mansion and has all those cozy vibes you crave in a tea room. They even have a little gift shop that you can check out.

data.title: Graham’s RoyalTea
data.description: This super cute Bothell spot has several high tea menus that you can choose from. Whether you want tea and a simple scone or the full deal, they have you covered. You can also grab “Teamosas” if you want something a little boozier. Enjoy your tea, Seattle!

data.title: Brimmer and Heeltap
data.description: Not only does this Ballard spot serve up a delicious menu full of local ingredients, but they also have a garden patio. It’s a beautiful spot to enjoy your morning coffee at if you happen to be in the neighborhood. Keep in mind this patio is only open in the morning, but that’s part of what makes it so special.

data.title: The Walrus and the Carpenter
data.description:
If you’re in the mood for oysters then you have to go to The Walrus and the Carpenter. This spot has been a long time city wide favorite for small plates, seafood, drinks and more. Their covered and heated patio will make you feel like you’re in a cottage porch in the best way possible. Recent Posts:
Here are 5 new restaurants in and around Seattle to check out now
6 natural hot springs in Washington state that will melt your winter blues

data.title: Harry’s Fine Foods
data.description: This patio brings the indoors out. You’ll get to have a chandelier lit dining experience while surrounded by classic metal patio tables as well as plants. Choose between small plates and larger plates full of local ingredients or head in on the weekend for brunch.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 4 pm-9 pm,  Friday 4 pm-10 pm, Saturday 9 am-10 pm, Sunday 9 am-3 pm

data.title: Stoup Brewing
data.description: Stoup is unique in that your only seating option is outdoors. The brewery has a variety of tents, pods, firepits, and tables with heaters for you to choose from. There’s even a greenhouse that you and five of your friends can book if you feel like you want something more private.
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 12 pm–9 pm, Friday–Saturday 12 pm–10 pm

data.title: Westward
data.description: You can’t say no to a waterfront patio. Westward’s is a step above the rest as it sits right on Lake Union. You’ll get to enjoy waterfront views and fresh air all while being covered and heated. plus you’re dining on some of the city’s best food so you really can’t go wrong here. There’s something to love about each of these patios so be sure to treat yourself this month. And remember that while these patios are outdoors restaurants still require mask use and proof of vaccination or a negative COVID-19 test for entry.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 4 pm-9 pm, Friday & Sunday 2 pm-9 pm

data.title: Persephone
data.description: Persephone is the newest part of Columbia City’s La Medusa. Its a bar rather than a restaurant and what makes it even more unique is that it also has a retail component. So you can stop by for drinks and light eats and also pick up pantry and locally made items as well as wine.
data.when: Next door to La Medusa located at which is located at 4857 Rainier Ave S

data.title: Bake Shop
data.description:
Bake Shop is an all-day café meaning you’ll find a menu full of options like house-made baked goods, sourdough bread, as well as a small savory menu with toasts, sandwiches, and salads. Additionally, you can sip on coffee, loose leaf teas, beer, and wine. Give them a visit for breakfast, lunch, or before the next show at Climate Pledge Arena. Recent Posts:
30 of the absolute best things to do in & around Seattle this January
The coziest pub crawl of the year returns to Seattle later this month
data.where: : Tuesday-Friday 7 am-7 pm, Saturday & Sunday 8 am-7 pm

data.title: Señor Carbón
data.description: If you’re looking to try Peruvian food you’re in luck. Señor Carbón just opened in Pioneer Square and serves both traditional Peruvian eats and Nikkei cuisine, a Peruvian and Japanese fusion. So far diners have been raving about the dishes so it might be time to head down to Pioneer Square.
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 11 am-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 11 am-10 pm

data.title: Jackalope
data.description: Like Tex-Mex? Then you have yet another spot to visit in Columbia City. Jackalope comes from the Jacks’s BBQ Family of Restaurants and serves up smoked meats in all sorts of different dishes. You can nosh on tacos, fajitas, enchiladas and more.
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 11 am-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 11 am-10 pm, Sunday 11 am-8 pm

data.title: Little Neon Taco
data.description: West Seattleites rejoice, Neon Taco is joining the west’s food scene. The heritage driven taqueria serves up delicious menu items like posole, tortas and of course tacos. It’s well worth making the trek out to West Seattle for. Well Seattle, we hope you’re hungry. Get out there and enjoy these new spots.

data.title: Spinasse
data.description: This Italian resto serves up cuisine inspired by Piemonte. That means they have a hyper-focus on crafting delicious handmade pasta. You can snag multiple kinds of pasta with ingredients like seafood, veal sauce, beef and much more.

data.title: The Pink Door
data.description: The Pink Door has been bringing joy to Seattleites and visitors since 1981. The restaurant is a unique mix of Italian-American dining and eclectic entertainment. The delicious, uncomplicated Italian dishes are as much a draw as the beautiful and romantic atmosphere making it a great date or special occasion spot.

data.title: Cornelly
data.description: Despite being a relative newcomer to the Seattle food, scene Cornelly has proved to be a delicious spot to grab fresh pasta, naturally leavened pizza and much more. Choose between spaghetti, rigatoni and Cacio e Pepe. While you’re there you might as well pick up a bottle or two as well.
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday, Sunday 5 pm-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 5 pm-10 pm

data.title: San Fermo
data.description: While they may not boast the largest menu, San Fermo is certainly a spot to visit for pasta and more. To make things even more unique, the menu changes daily so expect a deliciously different visit every time. That being said you can find pastas ranging from risotto, bolognese and much more.

data.title: Il Terazzo Carmine
data.description:
Since 1984 Il Terazzo Carmine has been considered a bastion of soulful and authentic Italian cuisine. They serve both lunch and dinner with a wide menu of items to choose from. Items range from antipasti to pasta to zuppe and much more. Recent Posts:
10 of the tastiest spots for dim sum in Seattle
Here are 10 of the best spots to get a bowl of pho in Seattle
data.where: : Lunch: Monday-Friday 11:30 am-3 pm, Dinner: Monday-Saturday 5 pm-10 pm

data.title: Osteria La Spiga
data.description: This spot has a focus on northern Italian cuisine and all of the pasta is made fresh, in-house. Expect to find Italian ingredients combined with the freshest seasonal ingredients from local markets. You’ll find a wide array of pasta options sure to fulfill your desire for pasta.

data.title: Carrello
data.description: This is the sister restaurant of upscale Altura. While Altura is certainly excellent, Carrello is a bit more affordable and still has amazing quality. They have a number of delicious pasta for you to choose from with ingredients like duck, foraged mushrooms, oxtail and much more. If you’re looking to switch up from your normal pasta spot, this is an excellent choice.

data.title: Pasta Casalinga
data.description: Pasta Casalinga has a whopping 14 different kinds of pasta with 5 different options for you to choose from. You can snag tasty lasagna, squid ink spaghetti, wild boar ragu and more. Plus you can opt for dine-in or take-out.

data.title: Bizzaro Italian Cafe
data.description: If you’re looking to enjoy your pasta in a unique atmosphere, Bizzaro is probably the place for you. Expect an atmosphere full of unique decorations and of course some delicious pasta dishes. One of the more unique items is Elk Bolognese and yes they do have less bizarre options as well (pun intended).
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 5 pm-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 5 pm-10 pm

data.title: Ristorante Machiavelli
data.description: This long-standing Capitol Hill spot has been serving up pasta and more for almost 30 years! By that fact alone, Machiavelli definitely knows what it’s doing. You’ll find a wide array of pasta options from penne to fettuccine and much more. Clearly, there’s no shortage of pasta in Seattle. So, why not simply try them all? Enjoy folks!
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 5 pm-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 4 pm-10 pm

data.title: Harbor City
data.description: Harbor City is a longtime Seattle favorite oftentimes has big lines and wait times. That being said, it’s well worth the wait to get your hands…err mouth on items like dumplings, buns, shumai and much more. If you’re not a fan of waiting you can always order to-go as well.

data.title: Dim Sum King
data.description: This spot is affordable and their classic offerings are tasty and well loved. That being said, many diners have noted the value of checking out the delicious a la carte menu items as well. Keep in mind they’re still operating on a takeout format so you can walk and eat or take it home to enjoy.

data.title: Honey Court Seafood Restaurant
data.description: An OG spot for late night dim sum, it’s hard to go wrong with Honey Court. You can select all your dim sum favourites in a family-style format perfect for sharing. You’ll leave in a food coma in the best way possible.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 9 am-2 am, Friday & Saturday 9 am-3:30 am, Sunday 9 am-1:30 am

data.title: Jade Garden
data.description: Jade Garden is yet another wildly popular spot for dim sum in Seattle’s CID. They have all of your favorite dim sum classics and more. It’s usually packed so be prepared to wait but the eats you get to devour are well worth the patience.

data.title: Ocean Star
data.description:
This is a great classic dim sum spot in the CID. It has more of a dining room feel and food comes quickly, so come hungry! It’s a go-to spot for many Seattleites and if you visit it might just become one of yours as well. Recent Posts:
Here are 10 of the best spots to get a bowl of pho in Seattle
A new bookshop that pairs unique reads and natural wine is opening in Seattle

data.title: Hong Kong Bistro
data.description: Want dim sum late at night? Look no further than Hong Kong Bistro. This spot is tasty at any time of day but particularly caters to late-night crowds. Dim sum is made all day and fresh to order meaning you’ll get the best whenever you’re in the mood.

data.title: Foo Lam
data.description: If you live further south in Seattle you can grab some super tasty dim sum at Foo Lam in the Rainier Valley area. Expect all your dim sum favourites as well as an all-day menu with items like soup, hot pot, egg noodle and much more.
data.when: 7101 Martin Luther King Jr Way S Ste 111
data.where: : Dim sum available Monday-Friday 11 am-3 pm, Saturday & Sunday 10 am-3 pm

data.title: Homestyle Dim Sum Restaurant
data.description: You have multiple options at Homestyle. On one side you can grab Chinese pastries and on the other, you’ll find a dine-in area perfect for enjoying their delicious dim sum menu. Enjoy and then grab some of your fave pastries to go.

data.title: China Harbor Restaurant
data.description: Want dim sum with a view? China Harbor is a great choice. It has a relatively newly launched dim sum menu for you to munch on. You can additionally find a wide menu for lunch and dinner if you’re feeling extra peckish.
data.where: : Daily, lunch 11:30 am-2:30 pm, dinner 4:30 pm-10 pm

data.title: Mee Sum Pastry
data.description: For folks heading to Pike Place, you need to stop by Mee Sum. It’s truly a Seattle classic where you can grab buns, pastries & other Chinese eats. The food is good and the prices are affordable making it a no brainer stop. The noshing never ends when it comes to dim sum in Seattle. We hope that you see an old favorite on this list or find a new one. Either way, enjoy and don’t get yourself in too much of a food coma.

data.title: Dine In
data.description: Ben Paris You can enjoy a three-course Thanksgiving dinner just steps from Pike Place Market. Ben Paris is serving up a menu with items like honey nut squash soup, roasted turkey, sweet potato gratin, and more. It’s a great choice if you want to experience wandering downtown afterward. Cafe Flora  This year is Cafe Flora’s 30th annual Thanksgiving dinner and it’s in person! Expect a plant-based 4-course meal and you can choose between either indoor or outdoor dining.  If you’ve dined at Flora before you know it’ll be good and we recommend making your reservations ASAP as spots will go quickly. Goldfinch Tavern     A post shared by Four Seasons Hotel Seattle (@fsseattle)  Enjoy a 3 course Thanksgiving brunch made just for you at Goldfinch Tavern. The menu includes options like oysters, carrot cake overnight oats, slow-roasted turkey, wild PNW mushroom hash, pumpkin creme brûlée, and much more. Be sure to make reservations as this will be popular. Hotel Sorrento Hotel Sorrento’s Stella is going big this year with an homage to 112 years of Thanksgiving. You’ll be able to dine on a scrumptious menu with items like burrata & wild mushroom bruschetta, cream of brussel sprouts, fancy roast turkey, and many more items. Plus you get to experience it all in the historic atmosphere of this grand hotel. Samara  This Sunset Hill bistro is wood-fueled and has not one but three ways for you to enjoy Thanksgiving this year. The first option is dine-in which is complete with a snack platter, veggies of your choosing, and entrees like turkey, pork, or salmon. You can also opt for a take and bake menu which can feed 2-4 people depending on what you choose as well as a turkey pick-up. The Lakehouse If you’re looking for farm-to-table dining on the eastside, consider a Thanksgiving dinner at The Lakehouse. This year they’re serving up a menu with items like roast turkey, fennel sausage stuffing, pumpkin pie, and more. You can also opt for a takeout version for 2 as well. 13 Coins This beloved local chain is serving up Thanksgiving at all 3 of its locations. You can snag a menu with items like butternut squash soup, roasted turkey with sage stuffing, Yukon gold mashed potatoes, and more. You can also opt for a take-out option that can serve between 4-8 people depending on your needs.

data.title: Take Out
data.description: Plum Bistro  This NYT-approved vegan restaurant is offering a massive take-home feast this year. You can choose from a $150 feast for 4 that includes a seitan roast, cornbread stuffing, mac and “yease” and more. But if you just want a few items you can do that too and choose from pies and sides. Blue Ribbon Cooking If you’re looking for an array of options consider Blue Ribbon. You can choose dishes to feed between 2-8 and people. Some of the featured dishes include a whole turkey, ginger maple smashed yams, butternut squash bisque, and more. It’s sure to be delicious no matter what you pick. Wilmott’s Ghost If you’re planning a big dinner, Thanksgiving from Wilmott’s Ghost might just be your best bet. The menu serves 8-10 and features an organic dry brined turkey ready to roast at home along with a bountiful assortment of the restaurant’s favorite dishes. There’s nothing like a Renee Erickson thanksgiving! Eden Hill Restaurant  If you want to enjoy Thanksgiving in the comfort of your own home without all the cooking, consider ordering from Eden Hill. This year they’re offering a 4 person take-home meal with items like 1/2 a turkey, stuffing, creamed kale, pumpkin basque cheesecake, and more. It will be a truly seasonal meal from the restaurant that does seasonal eats best. You have no shortage of options when it comes to Thanksgiving dinner in Seattle this year. Now that being said, reservations are going quickly at many of these restos so we recommend placing your orders and bookings resos ASAP. With that, enjoy and happy Thanksgiving!
data.where: : 2209 Queen Anne Ave N, Seattle, WA

data.title: Wunderground
data.description: Earlier this year a unique, mushroom-centric coffee brand popped up in Seattle. And now Wunderground is making things permanent with its first cafe on Capitol Hill. They’re serving up all your favorite caffeinated drinks with the added benefit of the adaptogenic powers of mushrooms. Plus they have tasty food items like grain bowls, bone broth, pastries, and more.

data.title: Maiz
data.description:
Maiz is a brand new spot from the owners of Mexican restaurant Sazon. At Maiz, they serve fresh tortillas and antojitos made from heirloom corn for a truly hot off-the-grill experience. And it’s right in the market so you can wander the area after enjoying your eats. Recent Posts:
10 of the best concerts coming to Seattle this November
11 of the best free and cheap things to do in Seattle this November

data.title: Indigo Cow
data.description: The nation’s first Hokkaido-style soft-serve spot has opened inside of Wallingford’s Yoroshiku. You can soon expect to see flavors like matcha, black sesame, yuzu, and always the classic Hokkaido milk flavor. But here’s the deal, due to demand, there are only 300 servings available daily so you might have to wait a bit to try.

data.title: The Wandering Goose
data.description: The beloved Capitol Hill establishment that served up some of Seattle’s favorite southern dishes has found a new home at the Tokeland Hotel. When you visit you’ll be able to nosh on your old faves as well as seasonal specialties that highlight the hidden coast of Tokeland. Some of the listed menu items include Eggs Benedict, Fried Rockfish Sandwich, Chicken Fried Pork Chop, and many other delicious items.
data.where: : Breakfast & Lunch 8 am-2 pm, Supper 4 pm-8 pm

data.title: Kobuta & Ookami
data.description: One of Capitol Hill’s newest restaurants revolves around katsu-style dishes made with both meat and veggies. You can score various pork cuts, chicken, prawn, and even multiple styles like classic katsu, miso katsu, and katsu nabe which is a Japanese-Korean fusion dish served in a clay pot. It’s a great choice if you’re looking for some warming and delicious fall eats.
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 11 am-3 pm & 5 pm-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 11 am-3 pm & 5 pm-9:30 pm, Sunday 12 pm-3 pm & 5 pm-9 pm

data.title: Dong Thap Noodles
data.description: Dong Thap takes going big to the next level. This spot is known for its massive 13-pound bowl of pho that claims to be the world’s largest. While that’s fun and all, this spot also serves quality pho with delicious flavours that will have you coming back time and time again.

data.title: Pho Bac Súp Shop
data.description: It’s hip, it’s delicious and you can really never go wrong with it. Pho Bac has been a family business since 1982 and has been satisfying Seattleites’ food cravings ever since. Grab classic bowls of pho or opt for something more unique like the beef rib pho.

data.title: Ba Bar
data.description: With several locations, Ba Bar is a local favorite. This Vietnamese restaurant serves up a delicious assortment of pho and other dishes that hit the spot every time. If you’ve never been before be sure to try the duck leg confit pho.

data.title: Pho Viet Anh
data.description: This lower Queen Anne spot calls itself the “home of the 24-hour slow cook beef broth.” It’s a neighborhood gem and has a menu chock full of delicious pho offerings. Plus their interior is cozy and you’ll feel right at home here on a chilly day.

data.title: Phở Ba
data.description:
This is one of those posts where if you know, you know. It has an unpretentious atmosphere and is tucked away in the ID. If you’re looking for simple but good pho and are in the area you might as well stop in. Recent Posts:
The New York Times just dropped its 2021 Restaurant List & 3 Seattle spots made it
Shaq is opening a new outpost of his fried chicken chain in Climate Pledge Arena

data.title: Local Pho
data.description: This spot is known for its tasty beefy broth but they also offer veggie and vegan options for those of you that are plant based. So if you’re looking to enjoy a bowl of pho with friends who have dietary preferences and needs, this could be your go to. Plus it’s super affordable.

data.title: Vinason Pho Kitchen
data.description: This local Vietnamese chain focuses on using fresh, local, and sustainable ingredients to create delicious bowls of pho. Their broth is a 24 hour cooked bone broth giving the pho a nice rich flavour. And if you’re really hungry you can also snag vermicelli bowls, banh mi and more.

data.title: Green Leaf Vietnamese
data.description: Green Leaf is a Chinatown staple that has a wide menu full of Vietnamese eats. The big draw for the purpose of this list is of course the pho. Be sure to give it a go but make sure to look at the hours before going as they’re pretty limited these days.

data.title: Pho Than Brothers
data.description: Simply put, this local chain goes in. If you want something simple and consistent you can’t beat Than Brothers. Plus everyone loves the little pastries that come with your pho. Give it a go even if you’ve had it a million times before.
data.where: : Daily 10 am/11 am-9 pm depending on location

data.title: Meekong Bar
data.description: This spot is pretty unique in that you can find both pho and burgers. Keep it simple or try something a little more unique like the beef satay pho or mala pho. Give it a go if you’re in the area! We almost have a food coma just from thinking about all the delicious bowls of pho to be enjoyed across the city. So get out there and treat yourself. Let us know what your favorite ends up being.

data.title: Temple Pastries
data.description: The Central District’s Temple Pastries is a great spot to check out any time of year. But right now they have some deletable fall treats that you should definitely try. Choose from a salted caramel cronut, apple danish, and more.

data.title: The Flora Bakehouse
data.description: Beacon Hill’s extension of the popular Cafe Flora is another spot well worth visiting daily. You can snag pumpkin teacake or a new danish with pear, ginger, and honey. Whatever you choose, it’s almost guaranteed to be delicious.

data.title: Coyle’s Bakeshop
data.description: Boy oh boy do we love Coyle’s, this Seattle bakeshop is a local favorite because of its attention to quality, detail, and flavor. Its fall offerings are no different. Right now you can snag a seasonal fruit croissant, an apple olive oil bundt cake, seasonal fruit galette, and more.

data.title: General Porpoise Donuts
data.description: Seattle’s OG filled donut spot is adding some seasonal faves back into its menu. For now, you can grab Tiramisu Cream and Italian Plum Jam for a limited time. Walk, don’t run folks, and be sure to try some of their delicious classic flavors while you’re at it.

data.title: Cafe Besalu
data.description:
Cafe Besalu is a long-time Ballard fave and they’re not slowing down this fall. You can snag a delicious seasonal fruit danish, a cardamom twist, fall spice angel food cake, and more. Honestly, you can’t go wrong with any of their pastries so you might as well grab an assortment. Recent Posts:
10 of the best u-pick pumpkin patches in and around Seattle
10 of the best vintage shops in Seattle to refresh your fall wardrobe

data.title: Columbia City Bakery
data.description: You can get pastries, bread, and more at Evan Andre’s beloved local bakery. Enjoy a classic pistachio snail or opt for a seasonal fruit galette. Whatever you choose we recommend getting a few of them because you’ll definitely want seconds.

data.title: Macrina
data.description: Maybe Seattle’s favorite bakery chain, Macrina always has something delicious to offer. This fall they’re serving up some cute ghost cupcakes, a mini autumn spice cake, a pumpkin pie bar, and more. Don’t miss out on these limited-time goodies from a Seattle fave.

data.title: Byen Bakeri
data.description: Why not make your fall sweet treat a little more unique? Byen Bakeri is an authentic Scanadanvian bakery and they have all sorts of goodies for you to try. Right now you can grab things like an apple walnut danish,   semla, almond horn, and more.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 6 am-5 pm, Saturday 6:30 am-5 pm, Sunday 7 am-4 pm

data.title: Sea Wolf
data.description: This local bakery is known for delicious baked creations both savory and sweet and while they haven’t been super vocal about fall offerings we’re sure that there are at least a few. Think seasonal fruit, veggies, and more. You’ll have to visit for yourself to find out.

data.title: Nuflours
data.description: Now this list wouldn’t be complete without a spot that offers gluten-free goodies. We know baked goods aren’t always the most accessible treat for folks with dietary needs or restrictions but Nuflours has you covered. Score some tasty pumpkin bread, pumpkin cinnamon cake, cinnamon rolls, and more. What are you waiting for? Get out there and enjoy a fall pastry from one of the best bakeries in Seattle. You certainly won’t regret it.

data.title: Rhein Haus
data.description: A classic loved by Seattleites and sports fans alike, Rhein Haus is a great spot to grab pretzels, sausage, and of course beer. You can simply eat and drink, watch a game or even play on one of the restaurants Bocce courts.
data.when: Monday–Thursday 4 pm-close, Friday & Saturday 4 pm–2 am, Sunday 12 pm-close

data.title: Altstadt Bierhalle & Brathaus
