data.description: This Northwest-inspired German Bierhalle & Brathaus downtown is a great spot to grab brews and of course German eats. Feast on pretzels, meats, and more while simply enjoy your food or watching a game.

data.title: Prost!
data.description: This Phinney Ridge spot claims to be Seattle’s, OG German pub. They’ve been at it for almost two decades and definitely know a thing or two about German beer and cuisine. So swing by, grab a stool or share a table and raise a glass with them.
data.when: Monday-Thursday 3 pm-10 pm, Friday 3 pm-12 am, Saturday 1 pm-12 am, Sunday 1 pm-10 pm

data.title: Die Bierstube
data.description: For those of you living in northeast Seattle, Die Bierstube is your spot! They have fifteen German biers on tap which taste great with menu items like a curried bockwurst or tangy sauerkraut. Dig in!
data.when: Tuesday-Thursday 3 pm-10 pm, Friday 3 pm-1 am, Saturday 1 pm-1 am, Sunday 1 pm-10 pm

data.title: Kaffeeklatsch Seattle
data.description:
Now, this spot is unique in that it’s not a place to grab brews. Rather it centers on a unique German tradition that involves women gathering to share coffee in homes when it was illegal for them to gather in public coffeehouses in the 1990s. So if you’re looking to celebrate sans alcohol, be sure to head in and grab a cup of joe and a tasty pastry. Recent Posts:
A Seattle brewery just won one of the nation’s most prestigious beer awards
Seattle Kraken is looking for 32 local bars to be the best hockey-watching spots

data.title: Brouwer’s Cafe
data.description: So this spot is technically Belgian-inspired but we’re going to throw it in because why not. Brouwers has 64 craft beers on draft, a selection of over 400 bottles from both the US and abroad, an exceptional selection of Scotch and American Whisk(e)ys, and a full-service bar, and Belgian-inspired cuisine.
data.when: Wednesday-Friday 4 pm-10 pm, Saturday 12 pm–10 pm, Sunday 12 pm-8 pm

data.title: George’s Sausage and Delicatessen
data.description: While technically a Polish spot, George’s offers all sorts of European specialty foods. It’s a deli-style shop where you can grab generously portioned sandwiches, Polish meats, and more for your own take-home celebration.
data.when: Monday-Friday 9 am-4 pm, Saturday 10 am-3 pm

data.title: Queen Anne Beer Hall
data.description: If you’re looking for an authentic beer hall experience then it’s time to head over to Queen Anne. You can enjoy local brews as well as beers from around the world and unique cocktails made with in-house prepared syrups and shrubs. Not to mention classic beer hall eats.
data.when: Monday-Thursday 11:30 am-12 am, Friday 11:30 am-2 am, Saturday 11 am-2 am, Sunday 11 am-12 am

data.title: Sebi’s Bistro
data.description: Sebi’s is also technically a Polish bistro but they do have a German section of their menu so you know we had to include them. Some of the tasty items you can grab include chicken schnitzel, blood sausage, and dumplings. Of course, you can also grab beers and spirits. There you have it, folks, there are plenty of German restaurants in Seattle where you can get your Oktoberfest on year-round. We hope that you get out there and treat yourself. Please be sure to follow all posted restaurant rules and of course be respectful.
data.when: Monday & Tuesday 5 pm-9 pm, Thursday-Saturday 5 pm-9 pm

data.title: Victrola Coffee Roasters
data.description: A long-time Capitol Hill fave, Victrola has been in the business for 21 years! You can grab coffee, pastries, beans, and even get a coffee subscription through them if you’re really into coffee. Their Pike St location is a perfect stop if you’re on a walk towards downtown.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 6:30 am-8 pm, Saturday & Sunday 7:30 am-8 pm

data.title: Volunteer Park Cafe
data.description: Newly reopened and reinvented, Volunteer Park Cafe is back! This cafe has been serving the north Capitol Hill neighborhood for decades. You can grab a coffee, wine, pastries, and more here. It’s pretty much the perfect spot to come after wandering through Volunteer Park.
data.where: : Wednesday-Saturday 8 am-7 pm, Sunday 8 am-5 pm

data.title: Ghost Note Coffee
data.description: Ghost Note has a core menu of expertly roasted and prepared single-origin coffees. You’ll also find house-made ingredients, rotating seasonal drinks, unique teas, pastries, and toasts. If you fall in love with a particular kind of coffee you can grab a bag because they also happen to sell beans.
data.where: : Monday, Wednesday-Friday 8 am-5 pm, Tuesday 8 am-3 pm, Saturday & Sunday 8 am-6 pm

data.title: Ada’s Technical Books and Cafe
data.description: Ada’s is one of the most unique places to grab a coffee on this list. That’s because they also happen to double as a bookstore. So you can grab a coffee, pastry and you’ll probably end up taking a few books home too.
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 8 am-3 pm, Friday-Sunday 8 am-8 pm

data.title: Fuel Coffee
data.description:
Fuel is a great place to grab your favorite coffee drinks and also beans. It’s also worth noting that Fuel has a pretty interesting no-tipping policy as they pay their employees living wages and also offer benefits. So feel good about your coffee. They also have a few other locations in the city. Recent Posts:
10 of the best autumn hikes with amazing views you can find near Seattle
You can get ‘mushroom coffee’ from this local pop-up this weekend in Seattle

data.title: Realfine Coffee
data.description: Realfine is locally owned and operated meaning you’re getting a real cup of Seattle Joe. It’s a great spot to pop in for a high-quality coffee from talented baristas. Oh and you can grab an assortment of tasty pastries as well.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 7 am-4 pm, Saturday-Sunday 8 am-4 pm

data.title: Analog Coffee
data.description: This Capitol Hill favorite serves a rotating cast of exceptional local roasters and Fresh Breeze Organic dairy. You can also enjoy delicious bites from b~side foods from 8 am-2 pm daily. You’ll also probably leave Analog with a few Insta pics.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 7 am-6 pm, Saturday & Sunday 8 am-4 pm

data.title: Wunderground
data.description: This brand definitely offers the most unique coffee on this list. Wunderground is a local coffee company serving up delicious adaptogenic mushroom coffee. Right now you can visit a pop-up in Capitol Hill’s Chophouse Row for the foreseeable future and try a coffee or two. Of course, you can also take some beans home as well.

data.title: Espresso Vivace
data.description: Capitol Hill has one of the last walk-up coffee bars in the city which has been around since the 80s. Vivace is a staple in the neighborhood and pretty much the perfect grab-and-go spot. Plus they have long enough hours to grab a coffee both before and after work.

data.title: Caffe Vita
data.description: This spot is another independent & locally-owned cafe that has been around since 1995! Caffe Vita now has locations across the nation and all of their beans are imported directly from the farm and roasted on-site. During non-pandemic times they offer a free brewing class held on third Sundays at their roasting facility on Capitol Hill. Looks like you’re going to have to do a DIY coffee tour of Capitol Hill now huh? Well, this list will definitely help you out and we hope that you discover a new favorite place. Be sure to keep your eyes peeled as we explore more neighborhoods.

data.title: The Maple Pub
data.description: If you’re looking for classic dishes with a few contemporary additions head to The Maple Pub. Their weekend brunch menu has items like eggs benedict, chicken & waffles, and avocado toast. To add to your tasty meal you might as well throw in an $8 mimosa pint.

data.title: Super Six
data.description: If you looking to try something different than your go-to brunch dishes, a visit to Super Six is in order. They focus on Asian flavors, American comfort food, and Pacific Northwest staples which result in some unique dishes like Filipino bacon & eggs. Plus you can snag $29 POG Mimosas for two!

data.title: Skillet Capitol Hill
data.description:
Skillet is a Seattle fave for many reasons but a big reason is that they offer brunch all day every day. You can nosh on your fave sweet and savory breakfast and brunch goods whenever you like. Part of the brunch magic here definitely includes a $30 mimosa pitcher so be sure to add it to your order. Related posts:
12 of the most relaxing spas in Seattle perfect for a treat yourself day
Looking for new Seattle restaurants? Here are 6 to try this August

data.title: Goldfinch Tavern
data.description: If you’re looking to elevate your bunch experience you can always head over to the Goldfinch Tavern. They have a $59 three-course brunch menu with a selection of dishes to choose from. And best of all, that price comes with bottomless mimosas.

data.title: Nue
data.description: Nue is a unique spot all around because they offer dishes from cultures around the world. Plus they have a weekday and weekend brunch menu with different options to help your taste buds diversify. Of course, your tasty brunch isn’t complete until you throw in a $28 carafe of their “Mo’ Mosa”.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 11 am-10 pm, Friday 11 am-11 pm, Saturday 10 am-11 pm, Sunday 10 am-10 pm

data.title: Mission Cantina
data.description: Folks in West Seattle can enjoy pan-Latin weekend brunch at Mission Cantina. Enjoy classics like huevos rancheros, chilaquiles, sweet papa hash, and more. Now to make your brunch boozy you can throw in bottomless(ish) mimosas for $14 and $1 per 8 oz refill. Keep in mind they have 16 flavors so you might as well try a few.

data.title: Lost Lake
data.description: While no longer a 24-hour restaurant, Lost Lake is conveniently located on the hill and still open pretty dang late. And that means you can enjoy brunch pretty much whenever. Not only do they have a large menu but they also have $35 mimosa pitchers. We bet your mouth is already watering and we don’t blame you. With that, have a great weekend, and be sure to drink responsibly. Enjoy folks!
data.where: : Thursday-Saturday 6 am-2 am and Sunday-Wednesday 6 am-12 am

data.title: LTD Edition Sushi
data.description: Just last week we made a list of some of the best sushi spots in Seattle to check out and it looks like LTD Edition Sushi could be added soon. This new sushi spot serves up limited numbers of traditional Japanese omakase boxes daily. That means you not only get a beautiful meal but the freshest food possible.

data.title: Jackson’s Catfish Corner
data.description: During the pandemic, we all saw way too many good restaurants close which is why we’re super excited that Jackson’s Catfish Corner is back with a new spot in the Central District. They reopened in June but you can never go wrong with their tasty menu. You can score items like fried catfish, burgers, chicken sandwiches, and more.
data.where: : Tuesday-Saturday 11 am-9 pm, Sunday 12 pm-6 pm

data.title: Autumn
data.description:
Pasta lover rejoice, Autumn “focuses on a simple approach to pasta, seafood & vegetables”. It’s pretty much prime PNW cuisine. Due to Chef Brian Clevenger’s love for local seafood and produce you can find tons of locally sourced ingredients on the menu. Time to treat yourself to a pasta dish or two! Related posts:
The author of Seattle Walk Report just released a new book of the city’s secret spots
10 of the best things to do in & around Seattle this week (August 9-13)

data.title: Karachi Cowboys
data.description: The highly anticipated opening of this wildly popular Indian/Pakistani pop-up‘s brick-and-mortar location is finally here. You can now visit the new permanent location to grab your favorite, snacks, drinks, and mains. If you haven’t tried them yet you’ll definitely want to this week.

data.title: Seatango Argentine Bakery & Cafe
data.description: If you’ve been looking for or wanting to try Argentinian cuisine then you need to check out Seatango. It started as a spot in Tukwila’s Spice Bridge and now has its own space on Lake City Way. You can score tasty sweet and savory pastries like empanadas, crepes, sandwiches and more.
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 8 am-4 pm, Friday 8 am-7 pm, Saturday 10 am-5 pm

data.title: Blotto
data.description: Yet another pop-up that went permanent this summer, Blotto has quickly become a Seattle fave thanks to its naturally leavened sourdough pizzas. Now you don’t have to worry about missing their pop-ups because you can head to their permanent Capitol Hill spot. Plus they have new pizzas to try all the time so you’ll never get bored. See? Lot’s to try this month so get out there and treat yourself if you’re in the mood. Enjoy your eats and please be sure to follow all rules posted by each restaurant.
data.where: : Pizza: Thursday-Saturday 5 pm- 9 pm, Shop/Bar: Thursday-Saturday 3 pm-9 pm, Sunday 12 pm-5 pm

data.title: Flowers
data.description: Sequim Lavender  Looking to pick something other than food? Well believe it or not you can actually pick your very own lavender in Sequim. If you’re really feeling it you can also check out farm tours or just buy direct from farmers. So while you can’t enjoy the normal lavender festival this year we highly recommend that you try picking your own!
data.when: Click above to see our picks

data.title: Berries (July-September)
data.description:
Bybee Farms This farm has been in operation since the 40s and offers 6 strands of Blueberries for pickers to choose from. And they are Stanley, Dixi, Pemberton, Jersey, Blue Ray, and Blue Crop. Did you even know there were that many different kinds of Blueberries? Oh, and they use organic agricultural methods. Larsen Lake Blueberry Farms This is probably one of the closest Blueberry Farms to Seattle which as you may have guessed also means it’ll be busy. But that being said, people have rave reviews about Larsen Lake Blueberry Farms and its location is accessible. Biringer Farms  This farm has strawberries, blackberries, raspberries, and even tayberries (a mix between raspberries and blackberries). It’s a great farm to visit if you’re looking for more than one kind of berry. Plus you can also check out the farm stand if that’s something you’re into. Mountainview Blueberry Farm This spot is big. Mountainview has 9 acres of land and 7 different varieties of berries that you can pick. However, Mountainview’s berries are conventionally farmed using IPM. That being said, it’s still one of the more popular spots near Seattle. Charlotte’s Blueberry Park And for those of you situated in South Seattle, heading down to Tacoma might be your best bet. So if that’s you, you can try checking out Charlotte’s Blueberry Park which is run by Metro Parks Tacoma. And it’s huge at over 3,300 bushes! Olalla U-Pick Blueberry Farm Gotta love organic. Olalla is another great spot for those of you looking for specifically organic Blueberry farms. And during the pandemic, they are operating on time slots so be sure to book ahead for your preferred timeslot. Blue Dot Farm On the topic of appointments, Blue Dot is also running on a by appointment picking schedule during the pandemic. And while blue Dot is a small family-run farm, they have 9 primary varieties of Blueberries and 7 other varieties. Which is pretty dang good. Related posts:
12 of the most romantic Airbnbs you can find near Seattle
10 of the best live concerts that you can see in Washington this summer Bow Hill Blueberries  Bow Hill also likes to keep things organic and they happen to be one of the oldest if not the oldest family-run blueberry farm in the Skagit Valley. So you can be sure that they know their stuff. Not to mention, they’re the perfect stop on a day trip in the Skagit Valley. Broers Farms Inc. And if you want certified organic then Broers is the place for you. Not to mention they also have multiple other berry varieties. So you can snag blueberries, raspberries, blackberries, and marionberries. Because variety is key. Bryant Blueberries If you want more variety in berries, Bryant has you covered. Not only do they have blueberries but they also have a hybrid of raspberries and blackberries known as tayberries. And they also have boysenberries and currents. So you could say they’re one of the most unique blueberry farms near Seattle. Blue Dog Farm Blue Dog is another farm that takes its organic practices very seriously. They also offer a unique membership program for dedicated u-pickers. So if you want the ability to pick at any time, consider a membership. You’ll still have to pay by the pound but hey that flexibility sure sounds worth it to us.
data.when: Members can pick daily from sunrise to sundown
data.where: : 7125 W. Snoqualmie Valley Rd, Carnation, WA

data.title: Apples (August-October)
data.description: Swans Trail Farms  This Snohomish Farm has 5 acres of delicious Honeycrisp and Jonagold apples for you to pick while supplies last. And during apple season we recommend getting out there sooner rather than later because you’ll want to have the best selection of available apples. Jones Creek Farm Now if you want to go really crazy, this farm has over 50 varieties of u-pick apples. Yes 50, so you can truly try them all if that’s something you’re into. But be sure to check their harvest calendar here before you go in case you’re looking for a specific variety. Curran Apple Orchard Surprise folks, this Tacoma orchard is actually free! But for that reason, you can expect it to get over picked. However, it’s still worth checking out if you’re going to be in the area. Because who doesn’t love free fruit?? West Valley U-Pick And if you’re into all things natural, you might want to make the drive to Yakima for West Valley U-Pick. Because they have u-pick available for apples and a ton of other produce options as well. So if you want to go big, go here. Bellewood Farms  And finally, we have to cap the list with one of the largest apple orchards in western Washington. If you’re wondering, you’ll be looking at about 25,000 trees. So you’ll have a whole lot of tasty trees to pick from. We hope that you get out there and check out these amazing u pick farms. Again please double-check hours before you head out in order to avoid disappointment. Be sure to tag us in any picking photos that you get!

data.title: Golden Apricot-Glazed Turkey Breast
data.description: Of course, turkey is a big one here, this bird quickly became a popular protein of American settlers. So while you might normally save this bird for Thanksgiving consider cooking it up this 4th. You can honestly probably throw this one on the barbecue if you really really want to fire it up.

data.title: Waldorf Salad
data.description: This unique salad is one that you might have actually had before. Waldorf Salad consists of finely chopped apples, celery, and mayo dressing. What’s extra cool about this recipe is that it calls for reusing the apple itself as a serving dish for the salad. Talk about reduce, reuse, recycle.

data.title: Buttermilk Pound Cake
data.description: Sweet tooths this one is for you. OG American cake recipes were pretty simple usually only using about 4 ingredients but this recipe throws a few more in to ensure you’ll have the best cake to date. We also recommend finding a fun cake pan to create an unforgettable cake.

data.title: Cherry Sandwiches
data.description: This wild-sounding dish is indeed a real thing and it comes from the first cookbook that was solely focused on sandwiches. The 1912 recipe calls for finely chopped cherries and crackers. So it’s almost like cherry tapenade on a cracker. Kinda interesting right?

data.title: Sweet Potato Pudding
data.description:
Pudding can be made from all sorts of things including sweet potatoes! This recipe calls for sweet potatoes, sugar, lemon, nutmeg, and some butter. It’s a pretty classic dish and if you haven’t had it before this 4th might just be the time to make it. Related posts:
The first modern UFO sighting happened this week in Washington in 1947
10 can’t-miss Washington wineries to visit this summer

data.title: Sausage Johnnycake
data.description: When wheat wouldn’t grow early settlers had to get creative. Instead, they turned to cornmeal so you can enjoy a different take on cornbread. And to make things more interesting this recipe includes sausage for a bit of extra flavor and protein.

data.title: Pickles
data.description: You either love them or hate them. Pickles and pickling things, in general, were some of the easiest ways for early settlers to preserve foods. So make some pickles, eat them alone or have them as a side dish. Chances are that once you figure out pickling you’ll never stop.

data.title: Escaloped Eggs
data.description: A truly vintage recipe straight out of the 1890s, this unique recipe calls for hard boiling eggs and then breading and baking them. It’s sure to be one of the more unique things you’ve made in a while and you’ll be kind of freestyling since the OG recipe isn’t exactly detailed with measurements. Whatever, it’s a culinary adventure.

data.title: Custard Ice Cream
data.description: Forget heading to the grocery store to buy ice cream when you can make your own straight out of 1933. This might just be the richest ice cream recipe that you have tasted because it’s made from custard. Hey, we all have to satisfy a sweet tooth sometimes though right?

data.title: Sweet and Sour Cabbage
data.description: You still have to get those greens in but you might as well have them with some flavor. Sweet and Sour Cabbage is straight out of 1936 and calls for ingredients like sour apples, vinegar, and brown sugar. Give it a try and see if you like it more than the other cabbage classic, coleslaw. That’s what we have for you when it comes to historically American dishes for the 4th of July. We hope you enjoy these recipes and if you end up cooking some up be sure to let us know. Of course, tag us in any pics you snap because we’re pretty dang curious.

data.title: Wilridge Winery
data.description: In the past few years, organic and biodynamic wines have become all the rage. If that’s something you’re into then you need to head to Wilridge Winery, Washington’s very first organic and biodynamic winery. If that isn’t enough for you they also have Seattle’s oldest winery so clearly, they know what they’re doing. Head to Yakima or check out their Madrona tasting room.
data.when: Estate Vineyard & Tasting Room: 250 Ehler Rd Yakima, WA, Madrona Winery: 1416 34th Ave Seattle, WA

data.title: Spoiled Dog Winery
data.description: If you’ve been meaning to take a trip to the islands, this is your sign. Spoiled Dog Winery is located on Whidbey Island and has an outdoor patio for tastings making it the perfect spot to enjoy views of the vineyard and surrounding forest. You might as well spend a day or two on the island because well, you’ll probably be on island time.
data.when: Spoiled Dog Winery: 5881 Maxwelton Rd, Langley, WA
data.where: : Wednesday-Friday 2 pm-5 pm, Saturday & Sunday 12 pm-5 pm

data.title: Frichette Winery
data.description: Frichette is Washington’s only Black-owned winery and owner Shae Frichette focuses mostly on Bordeaux-style wines. All of her grapes come from the Red Mountain AVA and she has a few different experiences that you can enjoy at the winery. Go for a private concierge tasting & tour or bring your own chair and enjoy the views of Red Mountain with a glass (or bottle) in hand.
data.when: 39412 N Sunset Road Benton City, WA

data.title: Hedges Family Estate
data.description: This winery is yet another amazing spot to enjoy Red Mountain AVA wine. The Hedges Family Estate uses a “blend of biodynamic farming and time-honored winemaking techniques” to create their delicious wines. They describe it as an “ear to the earth and a voice to the vines”. Sounds worth it to check it out if you ask us.
data.where: : 53511 N Sunset Rd, Benton City, WA

data.title: Woodward Canyon
data.description:
Who can say no to award-winning wines? It’s a stunning winery built on a canyon and a great place to visit if you’re looking for both delicious wines and ambiance. You’ll find cabernet sauvignons, Bordeaux-style blends, merlots, chardonnays, and more. Might as well take a few bottles home. Related posts:
This cliffside Airbnb in Washington has a glass sunroom overlooking a rushing river
Washington’s oldest winery has amazing summer concert series you can’t miss

data.title: L’Ecole No 41
data.description: If you want a bit of heritage then you have to check out L’Ecole No 41. This winery’s tasting room is located inside of a schoolhouse from 1915! You can enjoy their award-winning wines through both tastings and tours. You can also head into Walla Walla for a tasting experience in the Marcus Whitman Hotel if that’s more your speed.

data.title: Cairdeas Winery
data.description: If you’ve meaning to head to Chelan, you might as well head to Caideas Winery. This beloved winery pours Rhône-inspired wines which are of course crafted right in Lake Chelan. Just imagine sipping on a glass or two while overlooking the lake. Sounds pretty idyllic huh?

data.title: Basel Cellars
data.description: This winery is slowly transforming itself into a destination resort for all things wine. So if you’re looking for more than a day of tasting, Basel Cellars is the place to head. You can enjoy the inside of the American Lodge-inspired estate or relax outdoors. The choice is yours.
data.when: 2901 Old Milton Hwy Walla Walla, WA

data.title: Chateau Ste Michelle
data.description: Washington’s oldest winery is a classic fave of many. They’re great to visit year-round but especially in summer for their concert series. Or if you want to keep things simple, you can just head in to enjoy a tasting. Regardless of what you choose, we’re sure you’ll love it.

data.title: Maryhill Winery
data.description: Visiting Maryhill Winery is a great way to enjoy the best of both worlds, thirst-quenching wine, and the Gorge. You also can’t go wrong with this spot as it’s one of Washington’s largest and most visited, wineries. They produce 80,000 cases annually so you know you’ll be getting some consistent goodness. It looks like you have your summer travel plans cut out for you. And if you take a bottle or two home from each winery you’ll be set through the winter months. Enjoy and as always, if you end up checking a spot or two out, let us know what you think.
data.where: : Sunday-Friday 11 am-6 pm, Saturday 11 am-8 pm

data.title: Geraldine’s Counter
data.description: It doesn’t get more classic or delicious than Columbia City’s Geraldine’s Counter. This hip and happening spot is known for serving up some of the best french toast in town and the atmosphere is super cozy. Plus they support small, local vendors in their commitment to using the finest and freshest ingredients.

data.title: Bounty Kitchen
data.description:
A post shared by Bounty Kitchen (@bounty_kitchen) 
If you want to enjoy a delicious brunch and are looking for something health conscious then we recommend heading to Bounty Kitchen. This restaurant is dedicated to quality food in both flavor and harvest. You can expect to see lots of salads and bowls with lots of ferments, pickled and grilled items.

data.title: Olmstead
data.description: This Capitol Hill spot still feels new to us even though they opened early on during the pandemic. That being said, the spot has held its own between its comforting dishes and light-filled interior. Not to mention, they serve brunch every single day so you don’t have to wait until the weekend to have a great time.
data.where: : Wednesday & Thursday 11:30 am-10 pm, Friday 11:30 am-11 pm, Saturday 10 am-11 pm, Sunday 10 am-9 pm

data.title: Cafe Flora
data.description: This vegetarian spot is an all-time favorite of ours. If you happen to be plant-based or just want to try something new then you need to check it out. Besides their tasty menu chock full of greens, they also have a beautiful interior that is full of light and tons of plants.

data.title: Cafe Presse
data.description:
Want to kick our brunch up a notch? Head to Cafe Presse for authentic French fare. In our books, they have one of the best breakfast and brunch menus in the city. Think Croque Madame, light salads, and classic egg dishes. Not to mention you can snag some great reads here as well thanks to their magazine section. Related posts:
Seattle just ranked as one of the best cities for LGBTQ+ singles
Here’s how you can get a Discover Pass for FREE in Seattle

data.title: The Fat Hen
data.description: This trendy spot is a Seattle brunch favorite for a good reason. The tiny cafe serves up some seriously amazing brunch and breakfast foods. But because of its popularity and size, we highly recommend that you make a reservation. Otherwise, you could find yourself waiting for hours.

data.title: Cafe Pettirosso
data.description: If you’re looking for a fulfilling and egg-centric brunch, Cafe Pettirosso is a sure win in our books. This cute Capitol Hill spot has a menu ranging from classic dishes to more adventurous ones like a duck confit hash. Whatever you choose, it’s sure to be delicious.
data.when: Sunday & Monday 10 am-5 pm, Tuesday-Sat 10 am – 9 pm

data.title: The London Plane
data.description: Undoubtedly one of Seattle’s most aesthetically pleasing spots, The London Plane is the place to be in Pioneer Square. They’re a long-time brunch fave and throughout the pandemic have had an added emphasis on their market, cafe, and flowers. If you’re in the area definitely try them out.

data.title: Parish NW
data.description: This unique spot serves up southern fare using PNW ingredients. They’re all about farm-to-table and providing you with the best eats possible. Nosh on shrimp & grits, beignets, salads, and more. If you’re about a bit of fusion, this will definitely hit the spot.

data.title: Finch & Pine Cafe
data.description: Have dietary needs ot prefernces? Finch & Pine is a great place to try as they offer a mostly plant based menu with some pescatrian options. Snag dishes like mushroom pate, mixed greens salads, house mad granola and more. It’s a great place to grab a few plates and share. That’s what we have when it comes to out current trendy brunch spots to hit up in Seattle. We hope that you get out there and check out a few, we’re sure you’ll love them.

data.title: Full Tilt Ice Cream
data.description: For some of the city’s best and most original flavors, you have to stop by Full Tilt. If you don’t want to stop at one of their four locations you can also find their pints at select grocers around Seattle. Trust us, a visit to their store is very worth it because they don’t disappoint.

data.title: Molly Moon’s
data.description: This spot is an OG option for ice cream in Seattle and one of the first to become wildly popular. Molly Moon’s started with its Wallingford location and has expanded to add eight more. You can score ice cream made from locally sourced ingredients for wholesome goodness you won’t soon forget.

data.title: Frankie & Jo’s
data.description: This ice cream shop has a lot of wins, it’s plant-based, gluten-free, and owned by women. So by those factors alone you gotta check them out. Their ice cream happens to be some of the best in the city. So don’t worry about the lack of milk. You won’t be able to tell the difference.

data.title: Hello Robin
data.description: A post shared by Hello Robin (@hellorobincookies)  We can almost guarantee that you know this spot for their delicious cookies. But you can also score amazing ice cream sandwiches here made from freshly baked cookies and delicious Molly Moon’s ice cream. It’s the ultimate sugar rush and an excellent way to cap a day.

data.title: Whidbey Island Ice Cream Co.
data.description: If you’re all about quality then you need to try a pint from Whidbey Island Ice Cream Co. They source their milk from local farms and you can absolutely taste the difference in their delicious, rich ice creams. Not to mention they’re available in many local grocery stores or you can head to the scoop shop on Whidbey Island.

data.title: Salt & Straw
data.description:
Normally when we do specific lists like this one we try to keep it pretty local. Salt & Straw is technically from Portland but we know that they’re a beloved spot to grab a scoop so we had to include them. Plus you can score some seriously unique rotating flavors. Related posts:
10 of the best places to hang near the water in Seattle this summer
Hot new restaurants you should check out this June in Seattle

data.title: D’Ambrosio Gelato
data.description: If you’re a fan of high-quality gelato, D’Ambrosio is the place for you. Owner “Enzo D’Ambrosio has been creating small-batch, authentic Italian gelato for decades”. If that’s not enough for you, he has a “degree and numerous accreditations as a Gelato Maestro in Rome”. All of their flavors are amazing and worth trying.

data.title: Fainting Goat
data.description: They have a funny name but amazing Gelato. Plus it’s all organic and you absolutely can’t go wrong with that. Be sure to stop by this North Seattle gem to try one of its many delicious flavors. If you really end up loving it, grab a pint because we know you’ll probably want another scoop as soon as you get home.

data.title: Sweet Alchemy Ice Creamery
data.description: Here’s another ice cream shop that’s all about all things organic. Sweet Alchemy definitely lives up to its name and serves up delicious flavors. Not to mention they work hard to reduce their food waste and pasteurize their milk daily. So no waste here folks.
data.when: Monday-Friday 2 pm-10 pm, Saturday & Sunday 1 pm-10 pm

data.title: Husky Deli
data.description: For those of you on the island that is West Seattle, you can’t forget Husky Deli. This Seattle classic has been at it a long time and serves up some great classic ice cream flavors. Be sure to stop by to support this great small business and get your ice cream fix.
data.when: Sunday-Thursday 7 am-7 pm, Friday-Saturday 7 am-9 pm

data.title: Bluebird Ice Cream
data.description: If you happen to live in North Seattle and are in the mood for a scoop, then you have to check out Bluebird Ice Cream. You can find an array of delicious flavors at their shop and you can also find them at select farmer’s markets around the city.

data.title: Nutty Squirrel Gelato
data.description: Finally, we’re capping our list with another great gelato spot. Nutty Squirrel is only open for curbside pick up and delivery so be sure to hop online before going. They are well known in the city for their quality and tasty frozen goodness. So be sure to give them a try. That’s our round-up of the best and craziest spots for ice cream in Seattle! We hope this helps you find your new favorite spot to grab a scoop. Enjoy folks!

data.title: Mezcaleria Oaxaca
data.description: Mezcaleria’s margs are to die for. We’re huge fans of the Classic Margarita and the Mezcal Margarita. Grab one or two to go and a few tacos and you’re all set for an amazing weekend. Plus we love that you don’t have to be a crazy mixologist since these are pre-mixed for you.
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 4 pm-10 pm, Friday-Saturday 4 pm- Midnight

data.title: Linda’s Tavern
data.description:
This Capitol Hill classic is one of our fave places to grab a drink with friends. And we love that you can also grab a few drinks to go. Grab a bottled Old Fashioned, Boulevardier, or even a boozy slushie with rotating flavors. You really can’t go wrong here. Related posts:
Hot new restaurants you should check out this June in Seattle
Here are 10 places with some of the best donuts in Seattle

data.title: Rose Temple
data.description: If you want a to-go cocktail that’s a bit more adventurous, Rose Temple is a great spot to check out. They have drinks like alcoholic slushies, trash can cocktails, and even jello shots. Grabbing a drink from here will probably be the most fun you’ve had in a while.

data.title: Lady Jaye
data.description: Lady Jaye is a West Seattle classic for smoked meat and amazing cocktails. They have a wide range of to-go cocktail kits and drinks for you to choose from. You can choose from drinks like a Wagyu Old Fashioned, Gingja’ Turtle, Guns N’ Rosemary.
data.where: : Wednesday-Saturday 4 pm-7:30 pm, Sunday 2:15 pm-6 pm

data.title: Bottlehouse
data.description: We’ll cap with Bottlehouse. This spot is obviously a great place to grab bottles but they also have some cocktails that you can snag to go. Choose from wine spritzers, frose, fete de las fleur, and more. We love the lightness of these cocktails and think they’re the perfect way to end a long week. With that, we hope that you treat yourself to some to-go cocktails in Seattle this weekend. If you end up snagging one be sure to tag us in any pics that you take. Have a great weekend!

data.title: Dough Joy
data.description: If you’re plant-based and like donuts, there’s a brand new spot that you need to check out. Dough Joy is a queer-owned donut truck that serves up yeast-raised plant-based donuts. They sell out pretty quickly so you may have to try a few times before you can get your hands on these delicious donuts.
data.where: : Varies, check Instagram for upcoming dates

data.title: Taku
data.description: If you’re a fan of fried chicken then Taku should be your next dining destination. This new restaurant serves up delicious Japanese fried chicken. You can also grab dishes like rice bowls, and a karaage burger. We love that this spot has a small menu so that your choosing process is smooth.

data.title: Dat Creole Soul
data.description:
This one is a bit out of the way but still absolutely worth visiting. Dat Creole Soul serves up comfort food influenced by New Orleans flavors. You can find items like gumbo, gator on a stick, fried catfish, beignets, and more. Oh, and they also have a wide selection of drinks. Related posts:
One of Seattle’s favorite sandwich spots is opening a huge Central District location
This minimalist pet brand is having a limited-time pop-up in Seattle this weekend
data.when: Marine View Dr S, Des Moines, WA
data.where: : Thursday-Saturday 5 pm-11:30 pm, Sunday 11 am-6 pm

data.title: Finch and Pine
data.description: Another win for plant-based eaters in the city. Finch and Pine is the newest plant-based spot to grace Capitol Hill focusing on natural and locally sourced ingredients from the PNW. You can dine on menu items like mushroom pate, seasonal gazpacho, confit tuna, and more.
data.where: : Wednesday-Friday 8:30 am-3 pm, Saturday 9 am-3 pm, Sunday Brunch 10 am-3 pm

data.title: Seeking Kombucha
data.description: Ever wanted to hit the bar without the booze? Well, the taproom at Seeking Kombucha allows you to do just that and more. Because you can actually still snag alcoholic drinks here but it’s a unique way to experience multiple kinds of drinks.

data.title: Cycle Dogs
data.description: We’ll cap with this long-awaited permanent location from the beloved vegan hot dog purveyor, Cycle Dogs. The new Ballard location has a menu full of your old favorites and also some new menu items to spice things up a bit. So if you’re in the mood for plant-based comfort food, head here. Those are our picks when it comes to new restaurants in Seattle. We hope that you get out there and treat yourself to some delicious food and support these new spots. Have a great weekend folks!
data.where: : Wednesday-Friday 4 pm-8 pm, Saturday 11 am-8 pm, Sunday 11 am-6 pm

data.title: Mighty-O Donuts
data.description: Mighty-O is a local institution for donuts. What we love about them is that they bake organic goods and are vegan-friendly. Plus they have several locations around the city making them extremely accessible no matter where you are. And they have flavors that range from plain glazed to exciting flavors like french toast.

data.title: Dochi
data.description: If you want to get out of your donut comfort zone and try something new then we recommend Dochi. This ID spot serves up mochi-donuts that deliciously chewy and might just become your new favorite treat. You can snag flavors like ube, strawberry pocky, matcha smores, and more.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 11 am-5 pm, Saturday & Sunday 11 am-6 pm

data.title: Donut Factory
data.description: If you want to go all out with the perfect donut for your Instagram feed, Donut Factory is the spot for you. In fact, you’ve probably already seen their crazy donuts all over your feed if you’re into local foodie accounts. Try a Ferrero Rocher, Smore’s, Ube doughnut, and more.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 5 am-9 pm, Saturday & Sunday 6:30 am-9 pm

data.title: Raised Doughnuts
data.description: We always love to see pop-ups succeed and Raised Doughnuts is a prime example of one that was so popular it became permanent. Right now they’re takeout only but it’s well worth checking out for the amazing flavors. Some of those flavors include tahini chocolate, nectarine, earl grey, and more.
data.where: : Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday 7 am-2 pm, Saturday & Sunday 9 am-2 pm

data.title: The Original Bakery
data.description:
Want a real oldie but goodie? The Original Bakery is just that as they have been open and making donuts since 1936. You can enjoy classic donuts and a whole lot more baked goodness at this local family-owned spot. Don’t sleep on this one folks. Related posts:
13 of the best burgers you can find in Seattle
One of Seattle’s favorite sandwich spots is opening a huge Central District location
data.where: : Tuesday-Friday 7 am-6 pm, Saturday 7 am-5 pm, Sunday 8 am-3 pm

data.title: Top Pot Doughnuts
data.description: Dare we say, THE spot for donuts? Top Pot has been at it a long time and is a local fave of many. They have over 40 different kinds of tasty baked goods and we can guarantee there’s something for everyone. In our books, it might even be as iconic as Starbucks (but better obviously).

data.title: Half and Half Doughnut Co.
data.description: On the topic of Top Pot, we have to talk about cofounder Michael Klebeck’s newer Cap Hill spot. Half and Half bakes its donuts using organic Pacific Northwest ingredients. Plus they have some seriously amazing rotating and limited-run flavors like market spice, Bimba caramelized pineapple, and more.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 6 am-2 pm, Friday-Sunday 6 am-3 pm

data.title: General Porpoise Coffee and Doughnuts
data.description: What can’t Renee Erickson do? Her amazing donuts are to die for and you can grab doughnuts with filling like fresh custard, sweet cream, and even homemade jam.  If that’s not enough from you, they’re made from locally sourced ingredients. And we can guarantee you’ll love the minimalistic interior.

data.title: The Flour Box
data.description: This delicious spot is another pop-up turned permanent. The Flour Box focuses on handmade filled brioche donuts with inventive flavors. A few recent flavors have included Thai milk tea, mango cream, and pistachio to name a few. Keep in mind they are only open for walk-up on the weekend so if you want to enjoy donuts during the week you’ll have to order ahead.
data.where: : Pre-order Thursday & Friday, Public walk-in Saturday & Sunday 11 am-2 pm

data.title: Daily Dozen
data.description: We’ll cap this list with a Pike Place Market favorite, Daily Dozen. You can enjoy mini donuts straight out of the fryer and covered in cinnamon sugar. They’re an old-time Seattle fave that always tastes good and is yet another excuse to head to the market. Well, now you have no excuse not to treat yourself to a donut. You have plenty of donuts to eat your way through our summer and we hope that you enjoy our picks. Of course, if you stop at one of these spots and have an amazing donut be sure to let us know.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 8 am-5 pm, Friday 9 am-3 pm, Saturday 9:30 am-3 pm, Sunday 8 am-5 pm

data.title: Dick’s Drive-In
data.description: An oldie but a goody, Dick’s has been in the burger game since the 1950s. They serve up no no-nonsense burgers in a fast-food format that’s tasty and reliable every time. Plus you can’t go wrong with the low price point and locations across the city.

data.title: Red Mill
data.description: Ooh, we sure do love a Redmill Burger. They’re always extremely fresh and topped with fresh lettuce and tomato making them one of the most mouth-watering burgers in the city. And they also happen to have some insane onion rings and milkshakes if that’s something you’re into. (It’s DEFINITELY something you should be into, by the way).
data.where: : Tuesday-Saturday 11 am-9 pm, Sunday 12 pm-8 pm

data.title: Loretta’s Northwesterner
data.description: We hear you folks, after lots of feedback, it’s been suggested that we add Loretta’s Northwesterner to the list. What we love is that this spot is straight to the point. They describe themselves as “A neighborhood outpost where drinking is a priority, but also happens to have a really good burger”. You can’t go wrong with that folks.

data.title: Eden Hill Provisions
data.description: This beloved Seattle spot has a mean selection of burgers available for you to enjoy via takeout. You can try burgers with add ons like molasses shoulder bacon, apple fennel jam, whipped chevre, and more. Eden Hill pulls out all the stops when it comes to burgers so you might just find your new fave.

data.title: Lil Woody’s
data.description: We love this spot year-round but especially during their burger month in March where they invite chefs to create delicious limited-run burgers. That being said, they do run some pretty crazy burger specials throughout the year. So go big with one of those or opt for one of their equally delicious classic burgers.

data.title: Two Doors Down
data.description: This family-friendly burger joint serves up regionally sourced, hormone and antibiotic-free beef burgers. Plus they also have vegan and gluten-free options for those of you who need or want them. To make things even better, they also happen to have twenty Northwestern brews on draft and growlers to go.

data.title: Mean Sandwich
data.description:
Boy oh boy are the sandys here mean but don’t worry the employees are perfectly pleasant. You can enjoy the delicious D.A.M Burger with toppings like cheese, mayo, house-made pickles and sauce, and more. Plus you can go big and try one of their other sandwiches if you’re really feeling it, Related posts:
One of Seattle’s oldest restaurants is up for sale in Ballard
This Seattle company has created a fully automated pizza-making machine
data.where: : Daily 11 am-7 pm, Till 8 pm Thursday-Saturday

data.title: Rain City Burgers
data.description: This family-friendly spot is a great place to head for consistently tasty burgers made from fresh and natural beef patties. It’s also a great place for local sports fans because RCB loves all our teams. That means you can enjoy themed burgers like the Huskies Burger, Mariners Burger, 12th Man Burger, and more.
data.where: : Monday-Saturday 11 am-9 pm, Sunday 11 am-8 pm

data.title: Sunny Hill
data.description: While not so much of a dedicated burger spot, Sunny Hill does serve up a delicious burger that’s worth trying. The Sunny Burger comes with umami ketchup, shredded lettuce, and frizzled onion. Of course, you can add bacon and cheese for an additional cost to create the tastiest burger of your dreams.
data.where: : Wednesday & Thursday 4 pm-8 pm, Friday 4 pm-9 pm, Saturday Brunch 10 am-2 pm, Dinner 4 pm-9 pm, Sunday Brunch 10 am-2 pm, Dinner 4 pm-8 pm

data.title: Zippy’s Giant Burgers
data.description: This White Center spot serves up classic and delicious burgers in a casual manner. You have tons of different burgers to choose from ranging from their take on cheeseburgers to chicken burgers and more. If you want a variety of options then Zippy’s is for you.

data.title: 8oz Burger and Co.
data.description: It’s pretty safe to say this spot is a Capitol Hill classic at this point. You can’t go wrong with their half-pound patties and their signature burger has delicious additions like arugula and truffle aioli. Or you can choose from their 8 other burgers, whatever floats your boat.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 4 pm-10 pm, Saturday & Sunday 12 pm-10 pm

data.title: Uneeda Burger
data.description: This Fremont institution uses all-natural meat for its delicious array of offerings. We love their classic burger offerings but also that they offering bison, lamb, and even elk burgers! If you’re looking to try a burger made with something other than beef, Uneeda is the spot to try.

data.title: Plum Bistro
data.description: Of course, we had to throw a plant-based option in because we know that not everyone is a fan of meat. With that in mind, Plum Bistro has some delicious veggie burger options for you to try. Plus owner Makini Howell was just recognized as a Top Chef Changing Food in America by The New York Times. Those are our picks when it comes to the best burger spots in Seattle. We hope that you all get out there and treat yourself to a delicious burger or two. With that, have a great National Hamburger Day!
data.where: : Monday-Wednesday 11 am-8 pm, Thursday & Friday 11 am-9 pm, Saturday 3 pm-9 pm, Sunday 3 pm-8 pm, Saturday & Sunday Brunch 10 am-3 pm

data.title: Finch & Pine
data.description: Finch & Pine is actually a brand new spot that has popped up in the previous home of Cafe Barjot on Capito Hill. Their plant-based menu uses natural and locally sourced ingredients from the PNW. So you can feel good knowing that you’re supporting local farmers, a small business, and cutting your animal product consumption.
data.where: : Wednesday-Friday 8:30 am-3 pm, Saturday 9 am-3 pm, Sunday Brunch 10 am-3 pm

data.title: Allyum
data.description: When it comes to vegan food, this West Seattle spot is pretty dang exciting. They have a rotating menu so chances are if you become a regular, you’ll get to try tons of amazing and different dishes. You can enjoy both brunch and dinner so be sure to give them a try next time you’re heading over to the west.
data.where: : Thursday & Friday 4 pm-8 pm, Saturday & Sunday 9 am-3 pm

data.title: Cafe Flora
data.description: It’s truly an oldie but goodie, this Madison Park spot is one of the cities premier plant-based dining destinations. You can never go wrong with one of their classic menu items or one of their rotating seasonal offerings. Plus we love the plant-filled interior, it really adds to the vibe.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 11:30 am–8 pm, Saturday & Sunday 8 am–2:30 pm & 5 pm–8 pm

data.title: Frankie & Jo’s
data.description: We can never say no to a scoop of ice cream, especially now that summer is basically here. We’re huge fans of Frankie & Jo’s delicious vegan ice cream flavors. Seriously, it’s so good, you probably won’t believe it’s plant-based. While you’re there you might as well grab a pint to take home.

data.title: Harvest Beat
data.description:
This higher-end vegan spot is the place to head if you’re looking for more of a tasting menu style dining experience. Right now they are offering a to-go market as well as limited indoor dining. So treat yourself and someone special to an unforgettable vegan tasting menu. Related posts:
A Black-owned Seattle spot lands on list of Best New Restaurants in the World
It looks like patio dining in Seattle might be here to stay
data.where: : ​Lunch seating: Friday-Saturday, 12 pm-4 pm & Sunday 1 pm-4 pm, Dinner seating: Thursday-Sunday 7 pm & Sunday 6:30 pm

data.title: Plum Bistro
data.description:
If you’re vegan chances are that you’ve heard of Plum bistro. But it is another must-try spot if you’re in the mood to treat yourself with plant-based offerings. Plus chef Makini Howell was just recognized as a Top Chef
Changing Food in America by the New York Times. So you’re definitely going to want to give them a go.
data.where: : Lunch & Dinner: Monday-Wednesday 11 am-8 pm, Thursday & Friday 11 am-9 pm, Saturday 3 pm-9 pm, Sunday 3 pm-8 pm, Brunch: Saturday & Sunday 10 am-3 pm

data.title: Wayward Vegan Cafe
data.description: If you’re in the mood for vegan comfort food then a trip to Wayward Vegan Cafe is definitely in order. It’s basically all your American diner faves but in a vegan format. So you can score all delicious breakfast and brunch food items you’re craving without the guilt.

data.title: Broadfork Cafe
data.description: This U District spot is all about truly healthy vegan options. That means you can find a menu full of locally-grown ingredients with an emphasis on all things organic. So if you’re looking to boost your veggie intake in a delicious way, Broadfork is a great place to check out.
data.where: : Tuesday-Friday 11 am-8 pm, Saturday & Sunday 11 am-5 pm

data.title: Pi Vegan Pizzeria
data.description: We’re actually huge fans of vegan pizza and we feel very lucky to have a spot in the city that’s completely dedicated to it. Pi Vegan Pizzeria is the spot to grab a pie and without all the dairy and meat. You can grab a wide selection of sides as well as salads. Be sure to give them a go next time you’re in the mood for pizza.
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 12 pm-10 pm, Friday & Saturday 12 pm-11 pm

data.title: Kati Vegan Thai
data.description: If you’re in the mood for Thai, Kati Vegan Thai is the perfect spot to try. You can feel comfortable knowing that you can enjoy a fully plant-based menu with all of your favorite items. Plus the menu is super authentic so it will be equally delicious and we’ll bet you’ll be back for more! See? You have plenty of delicious vegan options in Seattle. We hope that you get out there and give at least a few of these a try. And if you’re uncomfortable with heading indoors just remember that you can always opt for takeout or pick up. Enjoy folks!
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 11:30 am-2 pm & 4 pm-9 pm, Friday-Saturday 11:30 am-2 pm & 4 pm-9:30 pm, Sunday 11:30 am-2 pm & 4 pm-9 pm

data.title: Spinasse
data.description: This spot serves up delicious and high-quality pasta without a super pretentious air. You’ll enjoy the food and the atmosphere and we can almost guarantee you’ll be back time and time again after trying dishes like the tajarin with butter and sage. Talk about tasty!

data.title: The Pink Door
data.description: This restaurant is a Seattle classic loved by both locals and tourists alike, so you really can’t go wrong here. If you just so happen to be really picky about your pasta, The Pink Door has tons of options for you to choose from, including gluten-free options. Do the sensible thing and try them all.

data.title: Willmott’s Ghost
data.description: This is undeniably one of the most unique dining experiences in Seattle, as it’s located inside the Amazon Spheres. It also just so happens to be part of the Sea Creatures group which is locally owned and operated by James Beard Foundation Award-winning chef Renee Erickson and partners. So not only is the restaurant beautiful, but the food is amazing. It might just become your go-to pasta spot!
data.where: : Tuesday-Friday 12 pm-7:30 pm, Saturday 4 pm-7:30 pm

data.title: Carrello
data.description: This Capitol Hill spot is all about bringing seasonal and artisanal traditions of Italian dining to guests. The menu here is small but it’s all about quality over quantity so you’ll only be getting the best of the best. You can also enjoy a drink menu with libations like wine, beer, and cocktails.
data.where: : Wednesday-Sunday 4 pm-8:30 pm, Dining Room Opens at 5 pm

data.title: San Fermo
data.description: Firstly, San Fermo is beautiful. It has an old-world, intimate feel due to it being in a legit old house! It has a white wall, clean, and minimal aesthetic that fits perfectly in everyone’s Instagram feed. In fact, we’re sure you’ve seen people post pics from San Fermo before. Besides the restaurant’s aesthetics, they make great food. Just look at those parm piles!

data.title: Ristorante Picolinos
data.description:
Picolinos is the perfect spot to enjoy authentic regional Italian cuisine in a comfy and casual atmosphere. You can choose from several delicious kinds of pasta with ingredients ranging from veggies to seafood. It’s also worth mentioning that this spot also operates as an espresso counter during the day if you need a coffee or three. Related posts:
10 socially-distant things to do in Seattle this week (May 10-14)
Seattle Beer Week has kicked off with 45 participating venues you can visit

data.title: Pasta Casalinga
data.description: If you’re looking for a high-quality, more affordable option, Pasta Casalinga should be your first choice. It’s located in the heart of the Pike Place Market and serves up authentic Italian pasta with a Pacific Northwest influence. Definitely stop by!

data.title: Ristorante Machiavelli
data.description: A post shared by Ristorante Machiavelli (@ristorantemachiavelli)  This Capitol Hill classic has been around since the 80s so they definitely know a thing or two about making great pasta. And they have several different kinds of pasta for you to choose from as well as other Italian dishes like pizza and more. Be sure to give them a try whether you’re dining in or doing take-out.
data.where: : Take out only on Monday & Tuesday 4 pm- 8 pm, Wednesday-Saturday 4 pm-9 pm

data.title: GH Pasta Co
data.description: Here’s another affordable option for those of you trying to make the most of your carbs budget. GH Pasta Co has tons of tasty options and is quickly rising as a pasta star in Seattle. It’s the perfect grab-and-go pasta if you’re looking to gracefully inhale your food on the run!

data.title: Osteria la Spiga
data.description: La Spiga is another Capitol Hill classic that’s been serving up delicious northern Italian cuisine since the 90s. You can enjoy tasty and seasonal authentic dishes that use the finest Italian ingredients as well as many locally sourced items. It’s a great treat yourself spot.

data.title: La Medusa
data.description: If you’re looking for places to check out in Columbia City, La Medusa is the place to be. La Medusa is known for its southern Italian/Sicilian menu with Northwest ingredients. It’s a sweet little spot and you’ll be able to taste the difference in La Medusa’s dedication to the craft of pasta.

data.title: Bizzarro Italian Cafe
data.description: The name of this spot fits it perfectly and we mean that in the most loving way. Bizzaro is definitely one of the most unique spots on this list thanks to menu items like elk bolognese. And we have to say the quirky interior definitely adds to the experience. It’s well worth checking out if you’ve never been before. Clearly, Capitol Hill is kinda the spot for pasta but you really can’t go wrong with any of these spots. We hope that you treat yourself because chances are that you deserve it. Enjoy folks!

data.title: Saint Bread
data.description: If you’re looking for a new spot to check out, Saint Bread is the first on our list. This new restaurant is housed in a historic building reimagined by Graham Baba Architects and has an amazing menu. You can grab tasty coffee drinks and food ranging from pastries to bowls to sandwiches and more.

data.title: Moonrise Bakery
data.description:
If you’re looking for a new coffee spot then consider heading over to Moonrise Bakery which is a brand spanking new spot from Olympia Coffee Roasting Co. You can see how the former location of Le Reve has been reinvented and try some delicious new drinks and pastries. Plus you can enjoy a nice stroll in Queen Anne afterward. Related posts:
10 socially distant things to do in Seattle this weekend (May 7-9)
A brand new kombucha taproom just opened in Seattle

data.title: Aki Kushiyaki
data.description: This Japanese spot is a brand new player in the city. And in a unique move, they’re only offering indoor dining. So if you’re tired of takeout this is a great spot to visit for a high-touch kushiyaki experience. You can dine on a 13-course omakase menu with mouthwatering items like lamb and wagyu.

data.title: Cafe Presse
data.description: One of our all-time favorite Seattle spots is back for limited indoor dining capacity. You can nosh on a delicious authentically french breakfast, brunch, and dinner menu. Cafe Presse never disappoints and you might just see us there this weekend.

data.title: Geraldine’s Counter
data.description: This oldie but goodie institution is located in Columbia City. Geraldine’s is known for serving up some of the best french toast in town and the atmosphere is super cozy. Plus they support small, local vendors in their commitment to using the finest and freshest ingredients. Those are our picks for places to eat this weekend in Seattle. We hope that you treat yourself to a meal from one of these spots and if you do please let us know what you think. Have a great weekend folks!

data.title: Mezcaleria Oaxaca
data.description: Capitol Hill’s best spot for Oaxacan eats also happens to have one of the best rooftop patios in the city. This Cinco de Mayo you can enjoy delicious margaritas, mezcal, Mexican wine, tacos, and more at Patio Cielo. Plus there’s nowhere else in the city that you can dine from a rooftop taco truck. Of course, you can also take your food and drinks to go if that’s more your speed.
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 4 pm-10 pm, Friday-Saturday 4 pm- Midnight

data.title: El Paisano Rosticeria Y Cocina
data.description: This spot is probably off your radar unless you live in South Seattle. But it’s absolutely worth visiting because it’s the restaurant sister of a nearby butcher shop. And that means you can get great meat and of course you can enjoy it in food items like tacos. So grab your eats, drinks, and more from this combo local business.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 11 am-9 pm, Saturday 9 am-9 pm, Sunday 9 am-8 pm

data.title: Tacos Chukis
data.description: You can’t go wrong with Tacos Chukis simple and delicious taco menu that allows you to grab as many or as few tacos as you like. That means you can celebrate solo or grab tacos for yourself and all your friends. Or you can opt for other items like mulitas, baby burritos, tortas, and more. Don’t forget to grab one of their delicious horchatas as well.

data.title: Carnitas Michoacan
data.description: This Beacon Hill spot is another one that you may have never tried before. But trust us, it’s time to go give them a go! Carnitas Michoacan serves up tacos, carnitas, al pastor, carne asada, tamales and more. It’s the perfect food to grab and take home for whatever kind of Cinco de Mayo celebration you’re having.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 11 am-8 pm, Friday 11 am-9 pm, Saturday & Sunday 10 am-9 pm

data.title: Gracia
data.description:
If you want to go big this year you can treat yourself to Gracia. This higher-end Mexican spot focuses on fresh masa with imported heirloom corn from Oaxaca, Mexico. You can either enjoy a dine-in experience or opt for an equally delicious takeout menu. So snag yourself some tacos or another delicious entree, we bet you’ll love it. Related posts:
24 socially-distant things to do in Seattle this May
10 amazing Seattle patios with great views of the city
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 3 pm-10 pm, Friday 12 pm-11 pm, Saturday 12 pm-3 pm & 3 pm-11 pm, Sunday 12 pm-3 pm & 3 pm-6 pm

data.title: Fonda La Catrina
data.description: It doesn’t get much better than Georgetown in our books and part of that reason is Fonda La Catrina. This Mexican spot is one of our favorites in this super hip neighborhood. You can choose from a wide menu with items like tacos, sopas, carne asada, and much more. You can also choose from a dine-in or take-out celebration.
data.where: : Monday-Sunday 11 am-9 pm, Brunch Saturday-Sunday 11 am-3 pm

data.title: El Camion
data.description: Tacos, tacos galore! This multi-location food truck resto is another spot that always comes in handy when you just want simple tacos or a burrito. But it doesn’t stop there, they actually have a massive menu with items like gorditas, tostadas, and much more. So if you’re giving them a go this Cinco, be sure to check out the full menu.

data.title: La Carta de Oaxaca
data.description: It’s an oldie but definitely a goodie, this restaurant is a Ballard favorite and if you live in North Seattle it’s definitely one of your best options! You can enjoy a wide menu with items like molotes, pozole, tacos, and more. Of course, you can also snag some tasty cocktails and enjoy them in-house or to go.

data.title: D’ La Santa
data.description: This North Capitol Hill favorite is a unique spot to celebrate for a few reasons. Firstly some of their recipes date back to the 1800s, secondly, they serve up their eats in beautiful handmade clay dishes, and thirdly they have a tree in the middle of the restaurant. Cool right? Check it out if you haven’t yet, you won’t be disappointed.

data.title: Asadero
data.description: If you’re really into meat then you need to try Asadero. This spot specializes in Mexican ‘Norte’ cuisine which means you get to enjoy menu items with the restaurant’s signature steak and carne asada. You can choose from items like tacos, tortas, and of course asados. It’ll make for a delicious at-home feast perfect for your celebrations. Now you have no excuse not to celebrate. Our city is lucky to have so many authentic and family-owned Mexican restaurants so be sure to support them this week. Keep in mind that most restaurants are operating on a reservation-only basis or may require you to place a phone order. So be patient with them and be sure to follow all of their posted rules. With that, have a great Cinco de Mayo Seattle!

data.title: Shiro’s
data.description: There’s nothing quite like some deliciously fresh PNW seafood. And Shiro’s happens to be one of the best places in the city to grab just that. This Mother’s Day they’re offering a special platter with items like salmon, tuna, sea urchin, and more. Be sure to place your order ahead of time and don’t miss out!

data.title: Big Little News
data.description: It’s not exactly take out but it’s a super cool idea from a local business. We’ve loved seeing all the creative boxes that Big Little News has come up with for various holidays. This Mother’s Day you can snag a gift box with a bottle of rose, chocolate-covered potato chips, a journal, and much more. It’s definitely worth a look.

data.title: Bateau
data.description: One of Capitol Hill’s best restaurants is offering a unique gift basket for the mom in your life. Bateau’s baskets are curated by their team and have items like oysters, a floral arrangement, chocolate budino and meringues, and more! It’s definitely worth a go if you’re looking to keep the day light and also tasty!

data.title: Cafe Campagne
data.description: Pretend you’re in France with some delicious Mother’s Day brunch eats from Pike Place Market’s favorite, Cafe Campagne. This year their menu includes items like salmon rillettes, yellow potato salad, homemade sausages, and much more. Just be sure to place your order before May 2nd!

data.title: Cafe Flora
data.description: One of Seattle’s best plant-based restaurants is offering several delicious takeout brunch menus for two. They have options for vegetarians, vegans, kids, and even drink kits! Items range from fresh salads, quiche to polenta, and much more. So whatever you’re in the mood for, Cafe Flora definitely has you covered.

data.title: JuneBaby
data.description:
This beloved Ravenna restaurant is offering up a delicious brunch menu with items like Louisiana Gulf shrimp and Geechie Boy grits, smoked hot link sausage & house-cured bacon gravy, and much more. If you haven’t had the chance to try Chef Edouardo Jordan’s food, this is a great time. Be sure to order ahead of time! Related posts:
10 of the coolest things that were invented in Seattle
Your car will actually drive itself up this magnetic hill in Washington

data.title: London Plane
data.description: If you already have food covered for the day, you can always consider a Mother’s Day bouquet, flower crown, or a care package from the London Plane. Unfortunately, their special brunch is already sold out but their floral arrangements and gifts are sure to be a winner for the mom in your life. Check them out before they too, sell out.

data.title: Paragon
data.description: This Queen Anne spot is offering up a special Mother’s Day brunch centered on bake yourself Croque monsieurs. You’ll get all the ingredients, fresh-squeezed orange juice, and a bottle of the house’s natural sparkling wine. It’s a simple but delicious meal that’s great for two!

data.title: Monsoon
data.description: This beloved Capitol Hill spot is offering a few options this Mother’s Day. You can opt for takeout or dine-in and score some delicious items like duck potstickers, Alaskan king crab and pork noodle soup, and more. Don’t miss out on these limited-time menu items because they sound pretty dang tasty.

data.title: Ethan Stowell Restaurants
data.description: If you want a ton of options, Ethan Stowell Restaurants has you covered. Nine of the groups restaurants are offering special Mother’s Day menus with both takeout and dine-in options. Menu items range from seafood to pasta, to sweets, and much more. Seriously, whatever you’re craving, an Ethan Stowell Restaurant has it. But be sure to place your orders ahead of time.

data.title: Addo
data.description: Chef Eric Rivera is always up to something and of course, has multiple menus for this Mother’s Day. Some of the menu items include avocado toast, roasted duck leg, and Dungeness crab. And you can choose from either a 3 or 5-course meal or opt for the seafood menu. Plus menus are individually portioned, just be sure to order ahead of time!

data.title: Canlis
data.description: We’ll cap the list with one of Seattle’s most iconic restaurants. Canlis has a delicious Mother’s Day brunch menu with items like a frittata kit, cheesy hashbrown casserole, fresh strawberries, and more! Now we highly recommend placing your order asap because these will go quickly! That’s what we have for you when it comes to Mother’s Day takeout options in Seattle this year. In case you forgot, the actual holiday date is May 9th. And we’ll remind you again but be sure to place your orders ahead of time because you don’t want to be left without a plan last minute.

data.title: Glo’s
data.description: This spot is a Capitol Hill institution that has been around since the ’80s. And they make all of their delicious breakfasts from scratch plus they have one of the best benedicts in town. We also love that they have a community meal program where you can buy a hot meal for a person in need.

data.title: Geraldine’s Counter
data.description: This is another institution that’s located in Columbia City. Geraldine’s is known for serving up some of the best french toast in town and the atmosphere is super cozy. Plus they support small, local vendors in their commitment to using the finest and freshest ingredients.

data.title: Salmon Bay Cafe
data.description: This spot is a great old-school diner located right on the water. And you can enjoy “fisherman” sized plates while supporting a business that’s been around since the 70s. Who knows you might just become a regular here after trying it.

data.title: Lowell’s Restaurant
data.description: We love this spot that describes itself as “almost classy”. Not to mention they’ve been open since the 50s so they definitely know what they’re doing. And it just so happens to have the best dining views in town. So if you want a beautiful view and early morning breakfast this is the place to go.
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 9 am-4 pm, Friday-Sunday 8 am-5 pm

data.title: Luna Park Cafe
data.description: This West Seattle classic has some real 50s vibes if that’s what you’re looking for. They serve breakfast, lunch, and dinner and they even have a vegan menu as well. So don’t miss out on this spot that’s been a Seattle staple since the 80s!

data.title: The 5 Point Cafe
data.description:
This is a cafe with some serious history that’s been around since the 30s! Between prohibition, the great depression, and the grunge music scene, this cafe has been through a lot. And what’s best of all is that it’s stayed pretty authentic throughout the years. So if you haven’t visited before, now is the time. Related posts:
3 local spots make Yelp’s list of 100 places you have to eat in the U.S.
Guess what? Washington was just ranked the best state in the nation!

data.title: Burgermaster
data.description: Burgermaster is a unique local chain that’s been around since the 1950s. And all of their locations definitely feel retro in the best way possible. Plus we love that they use local ingredients including grass-fed beef. And not many fast food spots can say that.

data.title: Voula’s Offshore Cafe
data.description: If you’ve ever driven along the lake chances are that you’ve seen this spot or dined at it before. It’s truly one of Seattle’s classic diners. You can expect tasty diner food and comfort food that will make your weekend. So if you’re planning a day at the Fremont Market you might as well stop here before.
data.where: :  Monday-Friday 6 am-3 pm Saturday & Sunday 8 am-2 pm

data.title: Twedes Cafe
data.description: Well technically this isn’t in Seattle, it’s in North Bend. But this has to be one of Washington’s most iconic diners as it’s the Double R Diner in Twin Peaks. That’s right you can dine at the Twin Peaks diner. So if you haven’t been before it might be worth the drive.
data.when: 137 W North Bend Way, North Bend, WA

data.title: The Lockspot Cafe
data.description: This Ballard spot has been serving Seattle at the entrance to Hiram M. Chittenden Locks for over 90 years! So clearly they know a thing or two about serving up good food. And this spot is definitely what we’d call an oldie but a goody. So if you’re in Ballard be sure to give them a try.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 11 am-2 am, Saturday & Sunday 10 am-2 am

data.title: 14 Carrot Cafe
data.description: This spot is definitely retro and also somehow feels like you’re in your grandma’s house. The 14 Carrot Cafe is tucked away on Eastlake but is definitely worth checking out if you like diner food. They’ve been in business since the 70s
data.where: : Thursday & Friday 8 am-2 pm, Saturday & Sunday 8 am-3 pm, Monday 9 am-5 pm

data.title: Dick’s Drive-In
data.description: Now we know, this spot isn’t really a diner. But it pretty much embodies everything retro. After all, they’ve been open since the 50s and many of their restaurants haven’t changed much since then. And of course, you have the classic drive-up design. Not to mention, it’s one of Seattle’s best and also cheapest spots to get a tasty meal. Okay folks that’s what we have for you when it comes to retro diners in Seattle to check out. We hope that you get out there and try at least a few. After all, most of these spots have been family-owned for decades and we want to see them continue to thrive in our city. Have a great rest of the week!

data.title: Canlis
data.description: We’re tentatively putting this one here because surprise surprise, the Canlis Easter kit is all sold out. But the good news is that you can hop on the waitlist to enjoy items like ham, scalloped potatoes, and much much more. So let this be your reminder that the early bird definitely gets the worm here.
data.where: : Pick up from 2576 Aurora Avenue N

data.title: Archipelago
data.description: Perhaps one of the more unique offerings, Archipelago is offering a limited edition box featuring a 10 course Easter tasting menu. This menu is inspired by the book ‘Today’s Special’ in which one of their chefs is featured. So you can enjoy delicious Filipino food and even grab a copy of the book if you feel so inclined.

data.title: Fran’s Chocolates
data.description: It wouldn’t be a Seattle Easter without Fran’s. This beloved local chocolatier has plenty of themed chocolates to make this Easter the most festive one yet. You can grab bunny-shaped chocolates, chick-shaped chocolates, and mini eggs.

data.title: Omega Ouzeri
data.description: If Greek food is a favorite of yours, then you can score a delicious meal from Omega Ouzeri. You can enjoy roasted lamb shoulder, spanakopita, roasted beet salad, and much much more. Plus we like that you can make it a single meal if you’re dining solo.

data.title: Shiro’s
data.description:
Related posts:
Here are some great spots to to get sweet Easter treats in Seattle
10 socially-distant things to do in Seattle this week (March 29-April 2)

data.title: Macrina Bakery
data.description: Macrina is a beloved spot for many reasons. But one of the things we love most about them is their seasonal cupcakes. And right now they have very cute birds nest themed cupcakes that are the perfect spring and easter treat. Plus they’ll probably add more Easter-centric goodies as the day gets closer.

data.title: JOEY
data.description: JOEY has more or less become a modern classic option, and that extends to their holiday meals. This year, you’ll be treated to a turkey dinner for four to six people, complete with all the sides you could ask for and dessert afterward. Confession time- we’d be in for the dinner rolls alone.

data.title: Addo
data.description: Of course, Addo is up to something. And for Easter this year they’re asking you if you’re a good bunny or a bad bunny. What you choose will decide which menu you get so it’s sort of like a choose your own adventure and we like that. Some dishes include things like ham, rabbit pate, strawberry shortcake, and more.

data.title: Bakery Nouveau
data.description: This bakery is a go-to for holiday and themed pastries and treats. This year they’re taking easter eggs to the next level with their chocolate eggs in 3 different flavors. And they also have some very cute sheep chocolates as well as chick-shaped cakes. Plus you know they’ll be delicious.

data.title: Bramling Cross
data.description: This Ethan Stowell restaurant is offering an Easter feast with items like smoked salmon bruschetta, grilled asparagus, rack of lamb, and much more. You can also opt for a more seafood-centric meal if that’s more your speed. And this one is a dine-in pop-up experience so you can switch up your usual take-home holiday meals if you feel like it.

data.title: Spinasse
data.description: If Italian food is sounding like the move on Easter then you can’t go wrong with Spinasse. The Easter dinner kit comes with items like asparagus, rabbit ragu bianca lasagna, braised lamb shank, and more. It’ll definitely be a memorable meal and we know you’ll love it. Those are our picks for Seattle restaurants offering up Easter feasts and more. We hope that you all have a safe holiday and please remember to be as COVID-19 safe as possible. And don’t forget to place your pre-orders now for these restaurants because spots will go fast. Plus most restaurants will stop taking Easter orders on March 31st so the sooner, the better.

data.title: Bathtub Gin & Co.
data.description: If you’re into classic drinks then you can’t go wrong with Bathtub Gin & Co. The Belltown institution is known for serving up more gin than you could ever imagine (hence their name). And they also happen to have a super cool and intimate space. So treat yourself to a drink or two here this weekend.

data.title: Linda’s Tavern
data.description:
This Capitol Hill Spot is the perfect spot to grab drinks and some tasty food. You can grab a beer, cocktails, slushies, and even hot drinks. So if you want a reliable and fun spot to have a drink after work or on a weekend evening, head to Linda’s. Related posts:
All Washington adults will be eligible for the COVID-19 vaccine come May
New report shows the best areas near Seattle to buy a house

data.title: Chuck’s Hop Shop
