data.description: If you want to grab a beer to go or stay for one on the patio, Chuck’s Hop Shop is the place to go. They have pretty much any beer you could ever want or imagine and 2 locations. So check them out if you haven’t before because it’s a pretty special place and is one of the more unique places to drink in Seattle.
data.when: Tuesday-Saturday 11 am-10 pm, Sunday & Monday 11 am-8 pm

data.title: Nue
data.description: This spot is known for its super unique cocktails and delicious food. So if you’re looking to eat out and get some of the most unique drinks in the city, Nue is definitely for you. After all who can say no to drink ingredients like lychee, spicy salty licorice, and much much more.
data.when: Monday-Thursday 11 am-10 pm, Friday 11 am-11 pm, Saturday 10 am-11 pm, Sunday 10 am-10 pm

data.title: The 5 Point Cafe
data.description: We’ll cap the list with one of Seattle’s most classic dives. And if you want day drinks, this also happens to be one of our favorite spots to grab some breakfast or brunch. So if you haven’t visited before, now is the time. It’s definitely one of the most unique and authentic spots in the city. With that, we hope you all have a great weekend and are able to enjoy a few drinks. If you end up checking out any of these spots be sure to let us know what you think. Who knows, you might just see us out there.

data.title: Bakery Nouveau
data.description: This bakery is a go-to for holiday and themed pastries and treats. This year they’re taking easter eggs to the next level with their chocolate eggs in 3 different flavors. And they also have some very cute sheep chocolates as well as chick-shaped cakes. Plus you know they’ll be delicious.

data.title: Macrina Bakery
data.description:
Macrina is a beloved spot for many reasons. But one of the things we love most about them is their seasonal cupcakes. And right now they have very cute birds nest themed cupcakes that are the perfect spring and easter treat. Plus they’ll probably add more Easter-centric goodies as the day gets closer. Related posts:
You can soon dine in a secret garden at one of Seattle’s favourite restaurants
The Downtown Seattle Association releases heartwarming video to celebrate reopening

data.title: Fran’s Chocolates
data.description: It wouldn’t be a Seattle Easter without Fran’s. This beloved local chocolatier has plenty of themed chocolates to make this Easter the most festive one yet. You can grab bunny-shaped chocolates, chick-shaped chocolates, and mini eggs.

data.title: Theo Chocolate
data.description: On the topic of chocolate, we have to mention Theo. This local chocolatier has all sorts of simple and cute spring-themed chocolates. Options range from animal-shaped chocolates, spring tea flavored boxed chocolates, and more. Plus Theo’s unique chocolate flavor combos are always delicious.

data.title: Trophy Cupcakes
data.description: If you want a super cute cupcake you can also check out Trophy. This Easter they have a few different options. Our favorites are the spring flower cupcake and the easter basket cupcake. And we have a feeling they’ll be real crowd pleasers for folks of all ages. That’s what have when it comes to spots to grab Easter treats in Seattle. We hope that you give these spots a try because we know you’ll love their offerings. And remember to order these treats while you can as they’re all for a limited time only. With that, enjoy and have a happy Easter!

data.title: Hitchcock Guest Chef: Street Food Pop-Up Series
data.description: This pop-up has a few different events coming up. The first actually starts today and features food from Peruvian Chef Stefano Schiaffino. The next two will take place in April and will feature eats from other chefs around the globe. It’s a great opportunity to eat food you might not otherwise get to taste.

data.title: Puffy Jacket Pop Up Dining Series
data.description: If you’re ready to dine in again then you don’t want to miss out on this limited-time pop-up. The puffy Jacket Pop-Up is taking place at 12 different restaurants across the PNW and each spot has its own unique pop-up menu. So that means you can actually road trip to check out all that Columbia Hospitality has to offer.

data.title: Fresh Mozzarella and Ricotta
data.description: If you like cheese, why not learn how to make your own? This in-person class will teach you how to make your very own delicious mozzarella and ricotta. And you don’t have to have any experience plus the ingredients are all provided. We think this is well worth checking out.

data.title: Virtual Author Talk: Zoë Bakes Cakes by Zoë François
data.description: Eating food is great and all but sometimes it’s even better to hear from notable chefs to inspire you on your next culinary adventure. This talk is by pastry chef and author Zoë François who is known for creating some pretty spectacular cakes. So if you’re into all things baked goods, you definitely won’t want to miss out.

data.title: Harmony and Grain
data.description: If you love grain bowls then this pop-up was literally made for you. Gather Kitchen & Bar executive chef Ryan Donaldson has created a unique pop-up focusing on grain bowls with locally sourced ingredients. So while it’s super exciting, it’ll only be here until the end of March so don’t miss out!

data.title: Taste Washington
data.description:
Washington’s premier food and drink event is happening right now. So don’t miss out especially now that you can enjoy it all from home! You can either cook along thanks to recipes from Whole Foods or enjoy take-out from participating restaurants. Related posts:
12 amazing spring hikes to take near Seattle
15 romantic spring date ideas in and around Seattle

data.title: Everett Restaurant Month
data.description: You still have time to enjoy affordable eats from 21 different restaurants in Everett. And if you live up North this is a great way to treat yourself to some delicious eats and also support local restaurants. So don’t miss out on this tasty festival while you still have the chance!

data.title: Seattle Restaurant Week
data.description: Seattle restaurant week is actually a whole entire month which makes it that much better. You can grab meals from so many Seattle restaurants starting as low as $20. It’s an excellent opportunity to eat at places that otherwise might not. Be sure to check out the list of who’s participating!

data.title: French Macaron
data.description: Learning to make new food is always fun, especially when it’s something as unique as a macaron. So if you’ve been wanting to learn how to make pastries, this is a great place to start. Plus the class is in person and is COVID-19 safe thanks to mask-wearing, sanitizing, and social distancing.

data.title: Seattle Farmers Markets
data.description: This might seem like a no-brainer but you can visit our local farmer’s markets pretty much anytime. They’re a great resource for grabbing local, fresh, and high-quality produce. So if there’s a recipe you’ve been dying to try, treat yourself to the best and purchase from your closest farmers market.
data.when: Click above to find out more.

data.title: Better than Brunch! Because you are in a Beer Garden!
data.description: This is a food event that you can look forward to every single weekend! This Sichuan-inspired restaurant is located inside of a food truck that’s parked in the Cloudburst beer garden. And this one is great as you don’t really have to worry about accidentally missing it!

data.title: Wine Tasting with Frichette Winery and Marjorie
data.description: This wine tasting is by the only Black-owned winery in Washington and is paired with food by one of Seattle’s best restaurants, Marjorie. Plus this event is being put on by United Way so you’ll get to hear about issues impacting people in the community. You definitely don’t want to miss this! That’s what we have when it comes to food events in Seattle to look forward to this spring. We hope that you get out there and enjoy a few!! After all, it doesn’t get much better than tasty food and you really can’t go wrong with any of these events.

data.title: Musangtinos
data.description: If the name sounds familiar it’s because you’re thinking of Musang. And Musangtinos is a Filipinx comfort food pop-up by Melissa Miranda that’s been on a bit of a break. But now it’s back and you can catch it at Fair Isle brewing every 2nd and 4th Tuesday of the month!

data.title: Puffy Jacket Pop-Up Dining Series
data.description: Here’s another pop-up because why not? They are limited time only after all. This one is taking place at 12 different spots throughout the PNW. So that means you enjoy a unique menu at each of Columbia Hospitality’s participating restaurants. Don’t miss out!

data.title: Camp Canlis
data.description: Now obviously, Canlis isn’t new but Camp Canlis is. This is the restaurant’s last pop-up before resuming a relatively “normal” dining service. So whether you want to dine in the yurt village or tree house, you have some options. And they also have two other camp options coming up in May.

data.title: Harmony and Grain
data.description: If you love grain bowls then this pop-up was literally made for you. Gather Kitchen & Bar executive chef Ryan Donaldson has created a unique pop-up focusing on grain bowls with locally sourced ingredients. So while it’s super exciting, it’ll only be here until the end of March so don’t miss out!

data.title: Garzon
data.description: If you like pop-ups then you need to know about Garzon. This one offers some seriously tasty Latinx foods and you can catch them every Thursday at Faire Isle Brewing. So if you happen to live in Ballard be sure to give them a try.

data.title: Light Sleeper
data.description:
This spot is a new addition to Capitol Hill’s chophouse row. And what makes Light Sleeper unique is that it’s a wine bar highlighting natural and biodynamic wines. Plus you can also grab lunch items and bottles to go. Not to mention they also have a take-home meal box that features local items. Related posts:
This wildly popular Vietnamese coffee shop is opening a second location!
Here are some great places to get a drink at in Seattle this weekend
data.when: Tuesday-Saturday 12 pm-3 pm and 5 pm-8 pm

data.title: Phin
data.description: If you’ve been getting into Vietnamese coffee and roasts recently then you’ll definitely want to check out Phin. This relatively new coffee spot focuses on Vietnamese roasts and light desserts. So if you’re looking for a new coffee spot be sure to give Phin a try.

data.title: Aviv Shawarma Bar
data.description: This spot serves up Israeli shawarma in South Lake Union. And we have to say it’s pretty much the perfect lunch or dinner food. The menu ranges from pita to hummus bowls and much more. And of course, you can also get it delivered if you’re not spending much time in SLU.
data.when: Tuesday-Saturday 11 am-3 pm and 5 pm-8 pm

data.title: Communion
data.description: This new spot mixes Southern flavors with Asian and Ethiopian influences to create a truly unique restaurant. You can get dishes like wings, grilled okra, fried catfish po’mi, and more. If you’re looking for truly new flavors then you need to head to Communion, you won’t be disappointed.
data.when: Wednesday-Saturday 3 pm-8:30 pm, Sunday 1 pm-5:30 pm

data.title: BOCA Restobar and Grill
data.description: Who doesn’t love a good steak? BOCA Restobar and Grill is an Argentinian steak house that just took over the former Queen City space. So you can get steak, salmon, empanadas and much more. Not to mention they also have a great drink menu.
data.when: Monday-Saturday 5 pm-10 pm, Sunday 5 pm-9 pm

data.title: Itsumono
data.description: We have this spot thanks to an ownership change of the previous Kaname Izakaya. Itsumono is a gastropub with Japanese and Hawaiian influences. So you can snag items like a teri burger, coconut shrimp, eggplant donburi, and much more.

data.title: Tá Jóia
data.description: We’ll cap the list with this new spot which is not technically in Seattle but still worth checking out. Tá Jóia mixes Korean and Brazilian influences to create dishes that are full of flavor. You can grab items like grilled shrimp, poke, kalbi, and more. It’s delicious and you’ll definitely come back for more. That’s what we have for you when it comes to new restaurants in Seattle. We hope that you get out there and try a few. And if you do, be sure to let us know what you think. Have a great week Seattle!
data.where: : 22833 Bothell Everett Highway Ste 151, Bothell, WA

data.title: Roquette
data.description: If you want some French-inspired drinks this weekend then you have to try out Roquette. But they also have a wide selection of spirits and you can’t really go wrong with whatever cocktail you choose. Or you can always opt for a beer or some wine if that’s more your speed.

data.title: Bottlehouse
data.description:
If you’re into all things wine then you need to check out Bottlehouse. This Madrona spot is featuring women winemakers this March so if you want to support Women’s History Month and treat yourself to drink this is a great option. Plus they have some pretty tasty sides that you don’t want to miss. Related posts:
3 local spots make Yelp’s list of 100 places you have to eat in the U.S.
This locally-made browser tool helps you shop directly from local businesses

data.title: Rupee Bar
data.description: Rupee Bar has some amazing eats but they also happen to have some delicious and very unique drinks. If you want a cocktail with ingredients like ghee, turmeric, or East India sherry, then Rupee Bar has you covered. Just be aware, you might become a regular after giving them a try.

data.title: Hannyatou
data.description: If you’re looking to get into a spirit that you haven’t tried before then you should check out Hannyatou. This spot specializes in Sake and they also happen to have some delicious food. So we highly recommend checking them out and if you fall in love, you can always join their Namazake Club.

data.title: Herb & Bitter Public House
data.description: If you’re looking for a spot with a wide menu and array of options then Herb & Bitter has you covered. This public house not only has a mature drink menu but also a beautiful space. So it makes the perfect spot to wind down after a long week. Those are our picks for spots to get a drink in Seattle this weekend. We hope that you get out there and please make sure to follow all COVID-19 rules that each restaurant posts. Or you can always take items to go if reservations and tables are full!
data.where: : Thursday & Sunday 4 pm-10 pm, Friday & Saturday 4 pm-11 pm

data.title: Cafe Flora
data.description: This vegetarian spot is an all-time favorite of ours. So if you happen to be plant-based or just want to try something new then you need to check out Cafe Flora. And besides their tasty menu, they also have a beautiful interior that is full of greenery.

data.title: Olmstead
data.when: Wednesday-Friday 11:30 am-9 pm, Saturday & Sunday 10 am-9 pm

data.title: The Fat Hen
data.description: This classic spot is a Seattle brunch favorite for a good reason. And that’s because this tiny little cafe serves up some seriously amazing brunch and breakfast foods. But because of its popularity, it may take you a while to get a spot on the waitlist. However, the good news is that they’re only doing takeout, so you no longer have to deal with a crazy wait time.

data.title: Tilikum Place Cafe
data.description: Tilikum is a great choice for any of their menu items. But our favorite thing that they serve up is their delicious dutch babies. But you can also score more regular items like breakfast plates, baked eggs, and benedicts. We can confidently say you’ll love it regardless of what you choose.

data.title: Glo’s
data.description:
This spot is a Capitol Hill institution that has been around since the ’80s. And they make all of their delicious breakfasts from scratch plus they have one of the best benedicts in town. We also love that they have a community meal program where you can buy a hot meal for a person in need. Related posts:
Here’s everything to know about moving to phase 3 in Washington
3 local spots make Yelp’s list of 100 places you have to eat in the U.S.

data.title: The London Plane
data.description: And finally, we’ll throw this Pioneer Square classic on the list. Because they’re a long-time brunch fave but they’ve adapted to focus on their market, cafe, and flowers. So if you’re planning a walk through downtown we recommend stopping in for a coffee and pastry.

data.title: The 5 Point Cafe
data.description: This is a classic cafe with some serious history that’s been around since the 30s! Between prohibition, the great depression, and the grunge music scene, this cafe has been through a lot. And what’s best of all is that it’s stayed pretty authentic throughout the years. So if you haven’t visited before, now is the time. It’s definitely one of our favorite Seattle breakfast and brunch spots.

data.title: Cafe Presse
data.description: This Capitol Hill institution is one of Seattle’s best spots for authentic French fare. And they just so happen to have one of the best breakfast and brunch menus in the city. Not to mention you can snag some great reads here as well.

data.title: Portage Bay Cafe
data.description: It’s safe to say that Portage Bay Cafe is Seattle’s ultimate brunch spot. And if you’ve lived in Seattle for a while we can guarantee you know this place well. But with that in mind, you really can’t beat their huge menu and all-you-can-eat fruit bar.

data.title: Bounty Kitchen
data.description: For those of you that health forward but still want to enjoy a delicious brunch then you need to try Bounty Kitchen. This spot’s menu focuses on juices, scrambles, breakfast sandwiches, and more. Plus they offer delivery through third-party apps and also patio dining if that’s more your speed.

data.title: Geraldine’s Counter
data.description: This Columbia City spot is a must-try for classic and delicious breakfast and brunch foods. And you can also snag pick up or take out depending on what you’re feeling. Not to mention, you can take a stroll around Columbia City after your meal Those are our picks when it comes to some of our favorite brunch spots in Seattle. Between classic diners an elevated dining, we have you covered with these picks. We hope you try out a few and remember that most places are still doing takeout or delivery if you’re uncomfortable with dining in. Enjoy!

data.title: Off the Rez
data.description: This has to be one of the most unique food trucks, and our city is fortunate to have it. It’s Seattle’s first Native food truck and serves up items like frybread, tacos, burgers, and more. But of course, they have a twist and take influences from both owners Native background and upbringing.

data.title: Curbside
data.description: If you like Vietnamese food then chances are you know about Curbside. This food truck is a city-wide favorite for grabbing Vietnamese eats like banh mi, vermicelli bowls, pho, and more. Plus it has a permanent location so you don’t have to worry about hunting it down each week.

data.title: Cheese Wizards
data.description: As the name suggests, this food truck is all about cheese. But specifically grilled cheese sandwiches. So you can score a delicious classic sandwich inspired by some of film’s greatest wizards. Of course, you can also grab some tasty sides like soup, bacon, and salads.

data.title: El Camion
data.description: This is another spot that has been around for quite a while and they actually have multiple food truck locations. They have a wide menu with items like tacos, enchiladas, burritos, and much much more. So if you happen to be in North Seattle be sure to give them a try because most of their trucks are situated in that part of the city.

data.title: BeanFish
data.description:
Here’s a great spot to grab an incredibly unique dessert item. BeanFish serves up Taiyaki and they were the first to do it in a food truck in the USA. So you know they know what they’re doing. And we can confirm it’s just as tasty as you think. Related posts:
Dick’s Drive-In is finally opening a permanent Bellevue location!
Dough Zone is opening its brand new Bellevue flagship tomorrow!

data.title: Sam Choy’s Poke To The Max
data.description: If you want some seriously tasty poke, look no further than Sam Choy’s Poke To The Max. This place knows how to make a mean bowl of poke that will have you coming back for more. They go so far as to call themselves the “Godfathers” of poke, so you know they’ve gotta have offerings that you can’t refuse.

data.title: Where Ya At Matt
data.description: This food truck has been around for over 10 years so you know they know a thing or two about serving up fantastic food. You can score authentic Cajun and Creole dishes like jambalaya, po’boys, gumbo, and more. Plus this is the only way you can get your hands on Matt Lewis’s sought-after eats.

data.title: Kaosamai Thai
data.description: Thai food always hits the spot, and Kaosamai has been cooking up delicious eats since 2001. So between their restaurant and food truck, you’ll have plenty of delicious dishes to try. Plus they also have vegetarian and vegan options available!

data.title: Seoul Bowl
data.description: As you might have guessed by the name, this pot serves up Korean bowls. You get to choose protein and however many toppings you’d like. But if that’s not your thing you can also score Korean fried chicken, Korean-inspired fries, and more!

data.title: Theo’s Gyros
data.description: Of course, you can also never go wrong with a super tasty gyro and Theo’s serves up just that. You can snag their gyros with their signature halal lamb or switch it up with halal beef. Whatever you’re feeling, they’ve got it. There you have it, folks, those are just a few of the Seattle food trucks that you need to check out. Now keep in mind a lot of these food trucks move around quite regularly so be prepared to track them down. That being said, each truck’s socials should have all the details that you need.

data.title: Field to Table
data.description: This one is actually a pop-up but it’s pretty dang unique as it allows you to dine on Lumen Field! So this is a great way to taste food from acclaimed local chefs and check out an entirely new way of dining. Of course, it’s all socially distanced, and COVID-19 protocols are in place.

data.title: Hello Em
data.description: This very exciting new spot from the co-owner of Pho Bac Sup Shop, Yenvy Pham is officially open! SO if you’re looking to get your coffee fix and try something new, this is an excellent choice. You’ll also be able to score banh mi and other delicious treats.
data.where: : Monday-Friday: 7 am-4 pm, Saturday & Sunday 8 am-4 pm

data.title: Allyum
data.where: : Thursday & Friday 4 pm-8 pm, Saturday & Sunday 9 am-3 pm

data.title: Puffy Jacket Pop-Up Dining Series
data.description: Here’s another pop-up because why not? They are limited time only after all. This one is taking place at 12 different spots throughout the PNW. So that means you enjoy a unique menu at each of Columbia Hospitality’s participating restaurants. Don’t miss out!

data.title: Umami Kushi
data.description:
Related posts:
10 great spots for cheap eats in and around Seattle
Seattle food truck goes viral for sign about proper masking

data.title: Dantini
data.description: Surprise! Another pop-up, maybe pop-ups will just be the future of dining concepts, who knows. Anyway, Dantini is a takeout-only artisanal pizza pop-up with locally sourced ingredients. So that means you have new pizzas to try every single week. If you’re ready to try a new pizza spot, consider giving them a go.

data.title: Cookies Country Chicken
data.description: Yep, pop-ups are where it’s at this month. Cookies Country Chicken focuses on you guessed it, chicken. So you can snag tenders, a sandwich, or a combo. And honestly, we like that the menu is short and sweet because it means fewer hard decisions for us. Keep in mind that hours depend on food availability.
data.where: : Wednesday & Thursday 11:30 am-8 pm, Friday  11:30 am-9 pm, Saturday 12 pm-9 pm, Sunday 12 pm-5 pm

data.title: Salty Blue
data.description: If you need some fish & chips in your life, Salty Blue is offering an Aussie take on the classic dish. Right now they’re open for take-out and delivery so treat yourself to some fish tacos, fish & chips, or even a burger. That sounds pretty tasty, doesn’t it?
data.when: 601 South 3rd Street, Suite D, Renton, Washington
data.where: : Wednesday-Saturday 11 am-7 pm, Sunday 11 am-4 pm

data.title: Flavor Lao Bowl
data.description: While spring is on the horizon, it’s definitely still winter so we could use a bowl of nice warm soup. If you guys are feeling the same then you should check out this brand new hot pot spot. You can also enjoy different Laotian noodle dishes and amazing sides.
data.where: : Tuesday-Saturday 11 am-8 pm, Sunday 11 am-6 pm

data.title: Martino’s
data.description: That’s what we have for you when it comes to new restaurants in Seattle! We hope that you check a few out this week and if you do, let us know what you think. Have a great week Seattle.
data.where: : Thursday 3-8 pm, Friday & Saturday 11:30 am-8 pm, Sunday 10 am-4 pm

data.title: Dough Zone
data.description: Dough Zone has you covered when it comes to affordable dumplings and hum bao. Most menu items range from $5-$8 so you can score a few tasty dishes. Plus there are multiple locations around the city so you won’t have to go far to get your hands on these tasty dumplings!

data.title: FOB Poke Bar
data.description: If you like poke then you need to try FOB. It has to be one of the best and cheapest poke spots in the city. You can snag their regular size poke bowl for $12 and trust us, the regular is plenty of food with all the toppings they give. But if you really feeling it you can also snag a large for $15.

data.title: Ezell’s
data.description: If you’re in the mood for fried chicken, Ezell’s is an excellent choice. They have a menu with tons of different items, dips, and sides. But personally, we’re big fans of their tenders combo which is about $8. And for one person it’s plenty of food.

data.title: Pho Tan Brothers
data.description:
Seattle has a ton of fantastic pho spots but Pho Tan Brothers is definitely one of the OG’s. You can score delicious bowls of soup for under $10. Plus we love that they have so many locations as they’re accessible to pretty much everyone. Related posts:
Here are some great places to find Lunar New Year eats in Seattle
Here are 10 places to grab a slice in Seattle for National Pizza Day

data.title: Harbor City Restaurant
data.description: Harbor City is one of Seattle’s best Chinese restaurants and dim sum spots. And while we miss sitting down for dim sum we’re super happy to be able to take it to go. Not to mention, most of their dishes are under $5 each and are quite filling.

data.title: Dick’s Drive-In
data.description: This is one of those spots you probably take for granted but there’s no question that it’s a Seattle classic. So if you’re in the mood for a burger and fries you absolutely can’t beat dick’s. Plus your whole meal will probably cost you under $10 unless you decide to go big.

data.title: Spice Waala
data.description: This beloved Capitol Hill Indian spot just recently opened a new location in Ballard. So now you can enjoy all of the amazing menu items in North Seattle as well. But what’s best of all is that the menu items are all under $10. So be sure to give them a try!

data.title: Tacos Chuki’s
data.description: Tacos Chuki’s is a great spot for cheap tacos and they’ve slowly expanded across the city so you can snag their delicious tacos across the city. Plus we like that their tacos are individually priced so that you can get as many or as few as you’d like. On that note, pretty much every menu item is under $5. Okay folks that’s what we have when it comes to some of the best spots for cheap food in Seattle. We hope that you get out there and treat yourself to some tasty food this week. Just remember if you decide to order from a restaurant please opt for pick up to save restaurants from nasty third-party delivery fees. Have a great week Seattle!

data.title: Cafe Aloe
data.description: If you want the perfect Instagramable food item then you can’t go wrong with the super cute Ox buns from Cafe Aloe. Since this year is the year of the Ox, it’s only appropriate to celebrate with an Ox themed bun! Seriously, don’t miss out on these.

data.title: Chinese New Year at Lucky Envelope Brewing
data.description:
If you want to extend your Chinese New Year celebrations to drinks then you have to check out Lucky Envelope. This local brewery is releasing some delicious beers just in time for the holidays. Not to mention, you might just get lucky enough to score a red envelope. Related posts:
10 great ways to celebrate Black History Month in Seattle
This Seattle author has the cutest FREE Seattle-specific Valentine’s Day cards

data.title: Jade Garden
data.description: This is a classic, go-to spot for dim sum and is definitely known as one of the best spots in the city. So if you’re in the mood for consistently good dim sum, you absolutely can’t go wrong with Jade Garden. After all, they’ve been at it for over 15 years and you can even enjoy it at home thanks to delivery!

data.title: Lunar New Year Food Walk 2021
data.description: If you want to have a little bit of everything you can check out this walk which will give you the opportunity to score $3 dishes at participating eateries. And best of all, it’s safe and socially distant since it’s outside. So bring a friend and enjoy some amazing eats.
data.where: : Hing Hay Park, 423 Maynard Ave S

data.title: Dough Zone Dumpling House
data.description: There’s nothing quite like a delicious dumpling or hum bao to hit the spot. And Dough Zone certainly knows how to make some mean buns (hence their name). Plus they’re super accessible due to delivery and having multiple locations across the city. So if you’re having a dumpling fix, Dough Zone has you covered. Well folks that’s what we have for you when it comes to spots to celebrate the Chinese Lunar New Year in Seattle. And if you have a favorite local Chinese restaurant you can always celebrate by ordering a few of your favorite dishes. Happy Lunar New Year!

data.title: Delancy
data.description: This beautiful and minimal Seattle restaurant also happens to make a pretty tasty pizza. And while they have a smaller menu than some of the others on the list they are absolutely worth checking out. Because we all need artisanal pizza once and a while.
data.when: Monday-Friday 5 pm-9 pm, Saturday & Sunday 4:30 pm-9 pm

data.title: Dino’s Tomato Pie
data.description: From the people behind Delancey comes Dino’s. Serving up both New Jersey round pizza and Sicilian rectangular, Dino’s is the place to grab a little something if you’re in Capitol Hill. Plus they have one of the best websites we’ve seen in a while.
data.when: Sunday-Thursday 4 pm-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 4 pm-10 pm

data.title: Veraci Pizza
data.description: Veraci serves up a seriously mean wood-fired Neapolitan pie. And they have a wide selection of offerings or you can opt to build your own. So if you need some thin crust goodness, we definitely recommend stopping by Veraci.
data.where: : 500 NW Market St and 7320 35th Ave NE

data.title: Pagliacci
data.description: If you want guaranteed great pizza delivered to your home we definitely recommend Pagliacci. And they have a wide menu that includes sides and desserts like Gelato. Plus they have locations across the city so they’re accessible no matter where you’re located.
data.where: : 25 locations across Seattle and the Eastside

data.title: Proletariat
data.description:
Billed as ‘the pizza that made White Centre famous’, Proletariat makes the trip out here more than worth it. Grab something simple, like maybe the REAL Hawaiian made with SPAM, or test out a pizza like White Centre White, that foregoes tomato sauce. Related posts:
10 great ways to celebrate Black History Month in Seattle
You can now score Pegasus Pizza & Pasta from a second Seattle spot
data.when: Monday to Thursday, 4 PM-9 PM, Friday/Saturday, 12 PM-11 PM, and Sunday, 12 PM-9 PM

data.title: Ballard Pizza Company
data.description: Tasty, simple, and high quality is what comes to mind when thinking of Ballard Pizza Company. And we’re big fans of both their pizzas and salads so be sure to get one of each! Plus they deliver and you gotta love that.

data.title: Flying Squirrel Pizza
data.description: This pizza joint definitely gets the award for the best name. But beyond that Flying Squirrel has been known around the city for quite a while as one of the absolute best places to get a pie. And we’ll agree, they make excellent pizza and have a good range of options for you to choose from.
data.where: : 8310 5th Ave NE and 5701 Airport Way S

data.title: Cornelly
data.description: This Capitol Hill spot is still pretty new (they opened in November). And what we like about them is that they have naturally leavened pizza and handmade pasta. So if you’re looking for an amazing artisanal pie, you can’t go wrong with Cornelly.
data.when: Tuesday-Thursday 4 pm-8 pm, Friday & Saturday 4 pm-9 pm, Sunday 4 pm-8 pm

data.title: Moto Pizza
data.description: We’ll cap the list with another new edition to the city. Moto Pizza is a brand new pizza spot serving up Detroit style pies over in West Seattle. So if you happen to live over that way be sure to give them a try. Not to mention, they have some pretty crazy looking tasty desserts as well. Okay folks that’s what we have when it comes to places to grab a slice in Seattle for national pizza day. We hope that you get out there and treat yourself. And if not you can always come back to this list for some amazing pizza spots to check out when you’re in the mood.

data.title: Crawfish King
data.description: You can never go wrong with seafood. And this weekend you can snag an amazing seafood platter just for the big game. You can expect items like fried snow crab claws, fried crawfish fried scallops, popcorn shrimp, and more. Not to mention you can choose from a ton of sauces.

data.title: Addo
data.description: Surprise surprise, Addo has something for Superbowl Sunday! Addo is always cooking up something good and you can snag items like baby back ribs, 7 layer dip, wings, and more. So if you want classic game day food this is a great choice.

data.title: Lark
data.description: If you want to kick your gameday fair up a notch you can order from Lark. This weekend their special is all about classic game day foods. So you can snag items like cheese curds, buffalo wings, beef chili, and more! And this special can feed up to 4 people.

data.title: JOEY
data.description: JOEY has a gameday kit that is fit for the perfect Super Bowl party. You’ll get Sliders Royale, Truffle Parmesan Fries, Hot Wings, Japanese Gyoza, and a 6-Pack of Budweiser, all for a very reasonable price. Not satisfied? Check out their entire list of gameday options here.

data.title: Damoori Kitchen
data.description: This Lebanese spot has tons of amazing menu items perfect for snacking on during the big game. So if you want something different this year, this is a great choice. Damoori will have items all of their a la carte menu items available for you to choose from.

data.title: Dynamite Fried Chicken
data.description:
Does it get much better than fried chicken? Not really if you ask us. And this Saturday you can grab an amazing takeout meal! You can snag items like buttermilk fried chicken, collard greens, honey biscuits, and more! Related posts:
12 spots in Seattle offering romantic Valentine’s Day dinner & specials
Here’s what to know about Phase 2 of reopening in Seattle

data.title: London Plane
data.description: Everyone’s favorite Pioneer Square spot is offering a tasty game day kit for two. You can snag items like beef chili, cornbread, and all of the chili fixings you’ll need. Plus the London Plane has so many amazing other house-made items, you might as well stock up!

data.title: Serious Takeout
data.description: Tom Douglas is back at it again for another take out meal kit. And this time you can snag items like wings, nachos, pizza tots, and much more. So we have a feeling you’ll be everyone’s favorite host if you bust this out on the big game day.

data.title: Savor Seattle
data.description: If you want to go for a more DIY option you can grab the “Iconic Market Box – Big Game Day” from Savor Seattle. This box has items like gourmet pizza from Homegrown, chicken wings, and Cuban bean dip from homegrown. And this is a great option as it supports a lot of local businesses and vendors.

data.title: Trophy Cupcakes
data.description: If you’re covered for food but want a treat or two then consider Trophy cupcakes. They’re offering some super cute and tasty Superbowl themed cupcakes that are sure to be a winner. So don’t miss out on these limited-edition cupcakes!

data.title: Spinasse
data.description: To cap this list here’s one more unique spot that you don’t want to miss out on. Spinasse is offering a party pack full of tasty items like roasted hazelnuts, mini meatballs, beef and pork stuffed cipollini onions, and more. So enjoy your game day with a little flair! Okay folks that’s what we have when it comes to Super Bowl Sunday takeout options in Seattle. You won’t be disappointed by any of these options and if you end up trying one be sure to let us know what you think. Have a great game day!

data.title: Frans Chocolates
data.description: We’re starting with this because it’s one of the more unique options this Valentine’s Day. Frans is teaming up with TeaLeaves and the Pacific Northwest Ballet for a tea and cholate tasting. Plus you also get to watch PNB’s Romeo et Juliette. So we highly recommend this package if you’re looking for a great package.

data.title: Addo
data.description: This Ballard spot is always up to something with their pop-up dinners so it’s no surprise that they’re going all out for Valentine’s Day. You can expect a 6-course dinner for 2 to take home and reheat. Items include things like Delmonico steak, lobster tails, and more. Plus you can add a drink pairing.

data.title: Cafe Flora
data.description: If you or your SO happen to be plant-based, you can never go wrong with Cafe Flora. Seattle’s favorite vegetarian spot is offering a 4-course Valentine’s Day takeout meal for 2. You can expect items like kabocha squash, artichoke croquettes, and even a delicious dessert. And of course, you can also add on a drink pairing if that’s your thing.

data.title: Eden Hill
data.description: Here’s another fantastic take-home option for reheating. Eden Hill is offering a 5-course meal with dishes like Dungeness crab salad, spaetzle, and more! So if you want a delicious and seasonal Valentine’s meal this is a great choice!

data.title: Mamnoon
data.description: This delicious middle eastern restaurant is offering Valentine’s Day dinner with items like braised lamb shank, pink chicory salad, and many more delicious dishes. So if you’re looking for an unforgettable dinner, you can never go wrong with Mamnoon.

data.title: Trove
data.description:
If you haven’t heard of this subscription box you can click here to learn more. But if you are familiar you should get excited because Trove is offering a special Valentine’s Day box. This box will teach you how to make heart-shaped truffle ravioli and give you everything you need to enjoy this unique experience. Related posts:
Curiocity Introduces #RestoBingo to Encourage Seattle to Eat Local
You can watch another exclusive Pearl Jam concert this February!

data.title: Paragon
data.description: Paragon is another great option if you’re looking for a meal with entrainment. They’re offering a menu with a roast rack of lamb, delicate squash, and a decadent dark chocolate brownie. Not to mention, you’ll have access to a live-streamed burlesque show. So this sounds like a whole lot of delicious fun!

data.title: Westward
data.description: If you’re dedicated to having a truly PNW celebration then you can’t go wrong with Westward. This beloved spot is offering a unique dining experience on their amazing outdoor patio. You can enjoy a 4-course meal complete with a seafood tower! So if you want to dine-in, this is a great choice.

data.title: Sushi Kashiba
data.description: On the topic of seafood, you can also snag a true seafood lover’s dream from Sushi Kashiba. The Pike Place Market spot is offering a red and black Valentine’s Day box with an assortment of sashimi and nigiri. So you can expect a delicious meal with the highest quality fish.

data.title: Ba Bar
data.description: If you don’t want to go all out but want to enjoy a great dinner then you can’t go wrong with city-wide favorite Ba Bar. For Valentine’s Day, they are offering a wagyu pho and red bean mochi and that sounds pretty dang good if you ask us. Plus you can do take out or dine in on the heated patio!

data.title: Meesha
data.description: If you’re really set on dine-in, Meesha is another great spot to check out. This contemporary Indian cuisine spot is offering a 5-course meal on restaurants covered and heated back patio. So you can enjoy an amazing menu full of items like Dahi kebab, Squash thisri and much, much more.

data.title: Willmott’s Ghost
data.description: The amazing restaurant in the spheres is offering a 5-course meal for 2 with dishes that you definitely don’t want to miss out on. You can score items like lamb and salumi boards and a whole lot more! Plus this meal is extra special because you can add flowers, chocolate, wine or even a love note. That’s what we have for you folks when it comes to Valentine’s Day dinner in Seattle. You can’t go wrong with any of these options and we hope you give them a shot. If you do, be sure to let us know what you think. Happy Valentines Day!

data.title: PCC
data.description: We’re big fans of PCC, one of Seattle’s OG co-ops, and they just so happen to offer delivery. So if you’re in need of local, organic, or specific health foods, PCC is a great option. Plus you can get groceries delivered in as little as one hour!

data.title: Uwajimaya
data.description: This grocery store is great if you’re looking for specific ingredients. After all, they are Seattle’s premier destination for Asian ingredients and groceries. So while we miss shopping in person, we’re happy we can still get all of our favorite items at home.

data.title: Central Co-op
data.description: Probably our favorite spot, Central Co-op is another great choice for local, organic, and health forward products. So whether you need bulk items, snacks, produce, or meat, they have you covered. And if you don’t have a co-op membership, this one is absolutely worth joining.

data.title: Ballard Market
data.description: If you live in North Seattle, chances are that you’ve shopped at this Ballard staple. And luckily for you, you can now enjoy delivery directly from the store. So you can shop all your in-store favorites at home. But keep in mind that due to the pandemic, there might be shortages of certain items.

data.title: Pike Place Fish
data.description:
It’s no secret that Pike Place Market is one of the best spots to shop, especially now that the market isn’t crowded with tourists. But if you’re determined to stay at home you can still enjoy Pike Place Fish Market and its amazing products. So treat yourself to some seafood! Related posts:
10 socially-distant things to do in Seattle this week (January 25-29)
West Seattle has a brand new Detroit-style pizza spot opening today!

data.title: Seattle Farmers Markets
data.description: If you’re a regular Farmer’s Market attendee then you might as well order directly from vendors. However, this differs from other stores listed as it’s pick up only. So as long as you’re comfortable placing an order ahead of time and picking it up in person, this is another great option.

data.title: Metropolitan Market
data.description: If you want finer groceries then you probably know Metropolitan Market is your one-stop-shop. And luckily for you, they are indeed delivering. So whether your grocery lists are bougie or you need specific items, you can still get them from home.

data.title: DeLaurenti
data.description: On the topic of specialized items if you happen to be cooking Italian food then you have to order from DeLaurenti. Pike Place Market’s classic grocer has everything you need and more when it comes to Italian groceries and items. Plus they have a few treats that we’re sure you’ll want to check out.

data.title: Stockbox
data.description: This First Hill grocery store offers free delivery for people living within a 4 block radius. So if you happen to live in the area this is definitely worth checking out. Just be sure to place your order the day before. And if you work in the area, now you have one more spot to stop by on your break.

data.title: New Roots Organics
data.description: And finally, we’ll cap the list with a CSA box. Because who doesn’t love fresh, organic produce? New Roots Organics gives exactly that and sources locally whenever possible. Plus there are multiple box types to choose from! Okay folks that’s what we have for you when it comes to grocery stores in Seattle offering delivery. We hope that you check a few out if that’s something you’re into. Regardless have a great week and stay safe!

data.title: Betsutenjin
data.description: This small spot specializes in Hakata-style tonkotsu ramen. That means an incredibly rich pork broth, served with thin noodles and some chashu for good measure. Of course, if you ever get sick of that (you won’t), you could try their special offerings instead, like miso prawn ramen.

data.title: Menya Musashi
data.description: This International Japan-based chain is known for its tsukemen style ramen. So if you’re a noodle lover, Menya is a great option. Plus they have both ramen kits and ready to eat ramen. And we love options.
data.when: Sunday-Thursday 11:30 am-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 11:30 am-12 am

data.title: Yoroshiku
data.description: A full-service izakaya that serves up a variety of ramen, ranging from spicy miso to vegan options. Make sure you try the Fisherman Ramen, which includes clams, octopus, sockeye salmon, and scallops. And their new Lemongrass Pork Shoyu ramen also looks worth a try.
data.when: Daily 11 am-2 pm and 4 pm-8 pm

data.title: Rondo
data.description: Rondo happens to have a full menu full of amazing Japanese fare. And on top of that, they have some pretty tasty ramen. You can choose from options like classic shoyu or spicy hellz ramen. So we recommend ordering an array of items because you won’t be disappointed.

data.title: Ooink
data.description:
This delicious spot specializes in tonkotsu ramen, so the pork bone broth is the star of the show. We personally love the classic shoyu ramen, but those seeking heat can get the spicy ramen instead and choose a spice level of 1 to 4. Don’t say we didn’t warn you about just how hot things can get, though. Related posts:
This local subscription box allows you to travel the world right from Seattle
This new Seattle pop-up serves insane french fry stuffed burritos!
data.when: Thursday-Monday 11:30 am-2 pm and 4 pm-8 pm

data.title: Kizuki Ramen and Izakaya
data.description: You’ve probably heard of Kizuki before, it’s a favorite of Capitol Hill ramen diners. They offer 12 different kinds of ramen as well as an izakaya menu. So if you’re looking for variety and reliable flavors, this a great spot to check out.

data.title: Arashi
data.description: A staple spot that started in Tukwila and since expanded to the Ballard area, thank goodness. We really like the flavor profile of the Black Garlic ramen, but like every other spot on this list, you can order anything and walk away happy.

data.title: Hokkaido Ramen Santouka
data.description: This is the first free-standing outpost in America from the legendary Japanese chain. We’re going, to be honest, the Kara Miso ramen here is second to none when it comes to mixing heat with incredible flavor. But you also have 11 different ramens to choose from and you can’t go wrong with any of them.
data.when: Monday-Thursday 11 am-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 11 am-10 pm, Sunday 11 am-9 pm

data.title: Nuna Ramen
data.description: If you are vegetarian or vegan, Nuna should be your go-to. Plus they include locally sourced ingredients in their menu and also do have some options for carnivores. So if you’re looking for a wide range of options, Nuna has you covered.
data.when: Monday-Thursday 11 am-3 pm and 5 pm-9 pm, Friday 11 am-3 pm and 5 pm-10 pm, Saturday 11 am-10 pm, Sunday 12 pm -9 pm

data.title: Ramen Danbo
data.description: A straightforward outpost in Capitol Hill. Not only is the classic miso ramen an absolute treat, the extra scallions, sesame oil and sesame seeds in the negi-goma is something else too. Grab some of the chashu pork donburi on the side too, you won’t regret it. Okay folks that’s what we have for you when it comes to essential ramen restaurants in Seattle. We hope that you get out there and treat yourself this week. Just remember to opt for takeout/pick up whenever possible as it helps restaurants stay open. And of course, don’t forget to tip.

data.title: HeartBeet Organic Superfoods Cafe
data.description: The name says it all. HeartBeet has a wide selection of grain bowls, salads, smoothies, and more. And best of all, it’s all plant-based. So you can get all those healthy greens and proteins without the guilt. Not to mention, the menu is reasonably priced and they even have some healthy treats on there.

data.title: The Whale Wins
data.description: If you’re looking to elevate your at-home dining you can definitely do that with Renee Erickson’s The Whale Wins. This delicious restaurant has a menu full of seafood like oysters, salmon, and more. Plus you can also pick up some housemade goods along with their takeout and delivery menu.

data.title: Fremont Bowl
data.description: If you’re a fish lover, you have to try Fremont Bowl. This gem offers rice bowls topped with fresh and tasty varieties of fish. So you can opt for a single fish or you can get a little more adventurous with a poke bowl. It’s up to you!

data.title: Eve Fremont
data.description: Eve feels like a hidden gem in Seattle. It has an amazing menu that is full of local and organic ingredients and they happen to have some of the best bowls in town. So if you want a menu that is full of clean ingredients and delicious items you can’t go wrong here. But just be aware that they are closed until January 6th.

data.title: b~side foods
data.description:
Sometimes making breakfast is a pain but it’s still an extremely important meal to eat. And that’s why we love B-Side, they make some of the yummiest and healthiest breakfast in Seattle. You have options like bowls, toasts, sandwiches, and more! Related posts:
One of Capitol Hill’s most iconic breakfast spots has closed permanently
12 of the best free and cheap things to do in Seattle this January
data.where: ns: Takeout or text (206) 390-7670 to place orders ahead of time

data.title: Cafe Flora
data.description: Cafe Flora is pretty much the go-to spot for plant-based dining in Seatle. We’re huge fans of their constantly rotating menu and beautiful interior. And while we miss dining in, we’re pumped that we can enjoy their delicious food at home. Not to mention, they have a great brunch menu on the weekends.

data.title: Broadfork
data.description: This spot focuses on healthy and organic plant-based dishes full of greens and veggies. So if you’re trying to up your veggie intake this year while skipping out on the meat you definitely need to try Broadfork. After all, sometimes a green salad and smoothie just really hit the spot.

data.title: The London Plane
data.description: Now this one is interesting because The London Plane has pretty much shifted to a grocery type model. This means you can still get many of their housemade goods and select menu items. So if you’re looking for delicious green salads or unique housemade ingredients to add to your cooking you need to check out what they have to offer. Keep in mind they are closed until the 12th of January.

data.title: Bounty Kitchen
data.description: Bounty Kitchen has a menu that is chock full of healthy greens, vegetables, and more. But don’t let that fool you because the food here is really good and good for you. You can expect food influenced by the PNW with a focus on local and organic ingredients.
data.where: ns: Takeout from Denny Triangle location or delivery

data.title: Homegrown
data.description: We’re always in the mood for a grain bowl. And Homegrown makes some of our favorites that are both tasty and packed full of delicious fats and proteins. Not to mention, they also make a pretty mean sandwich. So you have options here and they’re all guaranteed to be good. That’s what we have when it comes to the best healthy takeout/delivery options in Seattle. And as a reminder, we always recommend picking up food directly from restaurants because this helps keep restaurants open. After all, restaurants already have a very low-profit margin and delivery services can drive restaurants out of business. And you could probably use a walk or quick drive.

data.title: Christmas Burger: $21
data.description: It’s a straight-up Christmas feast stuffed between two buns, you guys. You’ll get crispy chicken breast, melted white cheddar on a sausage patty, caramelized onion, bacon, cranberry sauce and crisp cabbage stacked on a bed of peppercorn gravy. Oh, it also comes with fries on the side (in case that didn’t sound like enough heavenly food already). Plus, it pairs perfectly with Guinness, the quintessential cozy-by-the-fire-beer that kicks up the Christmas spirit with every sip. Guinness’ roasted notes complement the Christmas Burger’s crispy chicken, sausage, bason, and white cheddar, while the natural bitterness of the beer contrasts the sweet caramelized onions, and it’s all brought together by the intensity of the cranberry sauce. Oh, and we haven’t even gotten to the best part yet. From December 7th to December 13th, you can get the Christmas Burger for only $12.25 through either DoorDash pick-up or delivery. No code necessary, easy as 1, 2, 3.

data.title: Christmas Cocktails: $12.25 each
data.description:
Rudolph: Absolut vodka, cranberry juice, Ribena Blackcurrant, orgeat (almond) & lime juice
The Grinch: Smirnoff Green Apple Vodka, melon, lime, organic cane syrup & stolen toys (/ gummy bears)
Milk & Cookies: Jameson, Kahlua, Disarrono Originale, chocolate milk & a cookie  So, what do you think, folks? Sounds like LOCAL Public Eatery has plenty of ways to make the last month of a wild 2020 wonderfully festive. Grab yourself a Christmas Burger, a 4-pack of Guinness, and thank us later for the tastiest night in all season. Happy holidays!

data.title: Next up, let’s check out the three different gift boxes they offer under $25!
data.description: Hoppy Holidays – $20 – Pilsner Urquell 4-Pack; a Pilsner Urquell Mug; Buttered Ranch Popcorn Kit Malty Christmas – $20 – Guinness 4-Pack; a Guinness Glass; Buttered Ranch Popcorn Kit A Very Bubbly Christmas – $25 – Bottle of Bubbles (750ml); Buttered Ranch Popcorn Kit

data.title: Next up, the gift boxes that are available for under $50!
data.description: It’s the Mule Wonderful Time of the Year – $30 – Moscow Mule Drink Kit with Absolut Vodka, Fever Tree Ginger Beer and fresh lime; Buttered Ranch Popcorn Kit It’s Bourbon to look a lot like Christmas – $36 – Bulleit Bourbon (375ml); 2 Bourbon Sugar Pies  Dreaming of a Rose Christmas – $50 – 3 bottles of Rose (750ml each); Buttered Ranch Popcorn Kit

data.title: Not bad at all, right? Finally, let’s take a look at the gift packages for under $100.
data.description: Bailey’s it’s Cold Outside – $60 – Bottle of Bailey’s; Cinnamon Sugar Donuts  All I Want for Christmas is Tequila – $70 – Margarita Drink Kit complete with Tequila, Cointreau, House-Made Margarita Mix, and a lime; Fresh Tortilla Chips & Dips  O Bubbly Night – $100 – Bottle of Moët (750ml); 2 Moët Glasses; Buttered Ranch Popcorn Kit; Popcorn Box Well, there you have it, folks! Some awesome gift packages you may not have expected from a place you know and love. Head on over to your nearest LOCAL Public Eatery or check these offers out on DoorDash. Cheers to some very happy holidays!

data.title: JuneBaby
data.description: At this point, you’ve probably heard of this spot. But have you actually tried it yet? If you haven’t, it should be next on your list because JuneBaby serves up some delicious Southern food. And we recommend planning ahead on when you want to order because this spot is popular.
data.where: : Thursday-Saturday 4 pm-7 pm, Sunday 3 pm-7 pm

data.title: Spice Waala
data.description: This Capitol Hill spot serves authentic Indian street food and is hidden on 15th ave in Capitol Hill. So if you’re looking to try a new Indian spot, let Spice Waala be it. Because this spot is seriously loved and guaranteed to satisfy your cravings.
data.where: : Tuesday 5 pm-9 pm, Wednesday-Saturday 11 am-2:30 pm & 5 pm-9 pm

data.title: Oriental Mart
data.description: You might have heard of this Pike Place spot after it won a James Beard Award. And let us tell you if you’re planning on heading by the market you should stop by here. They serve up delicious authentic Filipino food and also have a mini-mart.

data.title: Coyle’s Bakeshop
data.description: This bakeshop honestly has to be one of the best in the city and is tucked away in Greenwood. So you might be familiar if you happen to live in the area. But if you don’t, let us tell you, it is absolutely worth the journey to give them a try.

data.title: Mezcaleria Oaxaca
data.description:
This Capitol Hill gem has been serving up consistently delicious food in their discrete Pine street location. And they just so happen to have one of our favorite takeout experiences which is their taco window. So you can score tacos, churros, delicious drinks, and more. Related posts:
9th and Thomas has extended its outdoor space until December!
Seattle’s Miracle Holiday pop-up bar is returning this year

data.title: Delancy
data.description: If you’re a fan of high-quality pizza then you don’t want to miss out on this somewhat secretive Ballard spot. Delancy has been at it a while and serves up pizza made with fermented dough and local ingredients. So you can have a delicious pizza full of PNW flavor.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 5 pm-9 pm, Saturday & Sunday 4:30 pm-9 pm

data.title: Fremont Bowl
data.description: If you’re in the mood for some delicious seafood and want to be easy on your wallet then you need to check out Fremont Bowl. This spot is known for serving up delicious donburi bowls that are super affordable. It’s pretty much the perfect lunch option for takeout in Seattle if you ask us.
data.where: : Tuesday-Friday 11:30 am-2 pm & 4:30 pm-9 pm, Saturday & Sunday 11:30 am-2:30 pm & 4:30 pm-9 pm

data.title: Musashi’s
data.description: On the topic of Seafood, we’ll remind you of this tiny Seattle gem that has been well-loved for years. And chances are that you’ve dined here but if you haven’t recently we recommend that you consider stopping by for some takeout. After all, they do have one of the best Chirashi bowls in the city.
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 11:30 am-2:30 pm, Friday 11:30 am-2:30 pm & 5 pm-9 pm, Saturday 5:00 pm – 9:30 pm

data.title: Mi La Cay
data.description: This spot specializes in Chinese and Vietnamese noodles making it one of the best noodle spots in Seattle. And they happen to have a wide menu full of delicious items that will make you a regular customer. So be sure to give them a try if you’re heading to the central district.

data.title: Dim Sum House
data.description: And finally, we’ll cap the list with a delicious dim sum spot for the ultimate comfort food. Dim Sum House has been serving Beacon Hill for years and has all of your favorite dishes. So be sure to phone in a takeout order and try something new! Okay folks that’s what we have for our favorite hidden gems for takeout in Seattle. So with that in mind, please purchase directly from these restaurants so that they can continue to stay open. After all, we can all use a good drive or walk sometimes.
data.where: : Sunday-Tuesday 9 am-6 pm, Thursday-Saturday 9 am-6 pm

data.title: Oddfellows
data.where: : Monday-Thursday 10 am-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 9 am-9 pm, Sunday 9 am-3 pm

data.title: Patio Cielo at Mezcaleria Oaxaca
data.description: This our favorite spot for authentic Oaxacan eats. And they just so happen to have one of Seattle’s best patios. Not to mention we’re big fans of their delicious drinks. So head here if you’re looking for some great eats, drinks, and of course a covered patio.
data.where: : Tuesday-Thursday 5 pm-10 pm, Saturday & Sunday 5 pm-11 pm

data.title: Brimmer and Heeltap
data.description: This Ballard spot has a beautiful back patio and garden area that just so happens to be covered. So if you’re looking to enjoy a delicious menu with PNW ingredients this spot is a great choice. And you can’t beat garden dining.

data.title: Musang
data.description:
This newcomer has quickly become a favorite in Seattle. And now you can enjoy outdoor dining in a tent style patio space. Not to mention, you can also get a fleece blanket if you’re feeling really chilly. And don’t worry, they’re washed between uses. Related posts:
You can’t miss this crazy tres leches cake pop up this month in Seattle
This Ballard restaurant has just added ‘dining domes’ for safe eating
data.where: : Lunch Wednesday-Saturday 11 am-2 pm, Dinner Wednesday-Saturday 4 pm-9 pm

data.title: Rhein Haus
data.where: : Monday-Saturday 4 pm-11 pm, Sunday 9:30 am-11 pm

data.title: Bistro Shirlee
data.description: This newish spot from Renee Erickson is located along the Burke Gilman trail and has a fully enclosed and heated patio. Which makes it the perfect place to stop by if you’re on a bike ride or walk. Or if you happen to live in the area.

data.title: Meet The Moon
data.description: This spot has a delicious and diverse menu full of must-try dishes. And they just so happen to have a great patio area for all of your outdoor dining needs. So if you’re located in Leschi you need to stop by Meet The Moon.
data.where: : Monday-Friday 11 am-8:30 pm, Saturday & Sunday 10 am-8:30 pm

data.title: Ba Bar
data.description: This spot is a Seattle favorite for Vietnamese cuisine and specifically Pho. So if you’re in the mood you should check out their patio at U Village. Because you’ll be able to have a delicious bowl of soup on a great outdoor patio.
data.where: : Sunday-Thursday 11 am-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 11 am-10 pm

data.title: Bangrak Market
data.description: Well folks that’s what we have when it comes to heated patios in Seattle. And while a lot of these patios might not be your “normal” patios they will certainly provide a unique dining experience. After all, what is “normal” these days? Have fun out there Seattle!
data.where: : Lunch: Monday-Friday 11 am-3 pm, Dinner: Monday-Thursday 4 pm-12 am, Friday 4 pm-2 am, Saturday 12 pm- 2 am, Sunday 12 pm-11 pm

data.title: Bakery Nouveau
data.description: You can’t go wrong with Bakery Nouveau, after all, they truly know their stuff. And right now they have some pretty sweet 3” personal pies. So you can choose from pumpkin, pecan, chocolate pecan, dutch apple, chocolate creme, chocolate peanut butter, and coconut creme.

data.title: Macrina Bakery
data.description: Here’s another Seattle classic that we’re always down to check out. And right now they have some pretty spooky ghost cupcakes that are perfect for Halloween. So if you want a treat, you definitely need to give one of these a try.

data.title: Top Pot Doughnuts
data.description: If you want a simple doughnut to accompany your morning coffee then you need to check out Top Pot. Because they’re always good but right now they have some pretty creepy “bulls-eye” doughnuts. And we’re sure they’re delicious but you might think twice before taking a bite.

data.title: Cupcake Royale
data.description: This cupcake spot is always serving up some delicious sweets. And right now they have some pretty cute Halloween-themed cupcakes to ensure you have a very sweet holiday. So no tricks here, folks! Only treats.

data.title: Mighty-O
data.description:
If you want an organic and fall-centric treat then you can head over to Mighty-O. They currently (as per usual) have a delicious selection of doughnuts that won’t disappoint. And if you’re into all things pumpkin flavored, they definitely have you covered. Related posts:
8 things to do in Seattle this week (October 26-30)
The City of Seattle has extended free outdoor seating permits until next fall

data.title: Flying Apron
data.description: If you want a treat that’s both plant-based and gluten-free, you need to head to Flying Apron. They have you covered on dietary needs and they happen to have some pretty tasty fall treats. And that includes a pumpkin spice cupcake!
data.where: : Wednesday & Thursday 9:30 am-3 pm, Friday-Sunday 9:30 am-5 pm

data.title: Nuflours
data.description: And on the note of gluten-free, you can also check out Nuflours. This local bakery is offering some super tasty Halloween and fall treats that will definitely get you in the spooky season mood. And we’re thinking a pumpkin-shaped chocolate cake truffle is in order.

data.title: Piroshky Piroshky
data.description: If you aren’t done with the pumpkin-flavored treats then you need to try Piroshky Piroshky’s pumpkin toffee braids. Not only because that sounds pretty dang amazing,  but because this spot has been at it for years, so they clearly know their stuff.

data.title: Coyles Bakeshop
data.description: Now if you just want to enjoy the fall-themed treat of dreams you should head to Coyles Bakeshop. They’ve got a full list of all your pastry favorites and right now they just so happen to be serving up some delicious slices of pumpkin pie!

data.title: Fuji Bakery
data.description: And to cap this list we have to add everyone’s favorite ID bakery. This time of year, Fuji has some pretty cute but also spooky treats to help you celebrate Halloween. So whether you’re in the mood for a cookie sandwich, cupcake, or cake pop, they’ve got you covered. Okay, folks that’s what we have when it comes to Halloween and fall treats to eat in Seattle. So we hope that you get out there and treat yourself to at least a few items from this list. After all, Halloween is this weekend, so you might as well end your spooky season on a sweet note.
data.where: : Monday-Saturday 7:30 am-5 pm, Sunday 7:30 am-4 pm

data.title: Real Fine Coffee
data.description: Real Fine is actually exactly how we’d describe this Capitol Hill gem. You can expect great customer service and excellent coffee in a well-lit and welcoming environment that’ll persuade you into some repeat visits. Plus its the perfect stop if you’re on a stroll on the hill.

data.title: Fresh Flours Bakery
data.description: We love Fresh Flours because not only do they have great coffee but they also have some seriously amazing pastries. Not to mention, they have several locations around the city making them a great choice.

data.title: Elm Coffee Roasters
data.description:
Instagrammers, we’re looking at you! Elm Street coffee roasters will definitely give you some great photo ops.  And they also happen to roast some delicious, vibrant coffees and you really can’t go wrong with any of their drinks. Related Posts:
You can have the PNW adventure of a lifetime with Peace Van Rentals
Here are 5 tasty places to get takeout from in Seattle
data.where: : Monday-Saturday 8 am- 2 pm, Sunday 9 am-2 pm

data.title: Coyles Bakeshop
data.description: Here’s another bakery that has the best of both worlds. Coyles can serve you up an amazing cup of joe and a delicious pastry to match it. Not to mention their Greenwood location is perfect for those of you who live in North Seattle.

data.title: Analog Coffee
data.description: This place throws some serious OG Seattle hipster vibes and they make a mean coffee. And with that in mind, it has to be one of our favorite spots on the hill. After all, does it get much better than a perfect interior and tasty coffee?
data.where: : Monday-Friday 7 am-6 pm, Saturday & Sunday 8 am-4 pm

data.title: General Porpoise
data.description: Now if you want to enjoy a space that is beautifully curated and paired with the city’s best donuts you need to head to General Porpoise. This spot can give you a great coffee and a donut you’ll truly never forget. So with that in mind, get two.

data.title: Espresso Vivace Sidewalk Espresso Bar
data.description: Sure this place isn’t a sit-down establishment but we think walk-up coffee is pretty cute. And there aren’t many walk-up coffee shops left in the city. Not to mention, Espresso Vivace is the real Seattle OG (it’s older than Starbucks). So give them a try next time you’re strolling the hill.

data.title: Hood Famous Bakeshop
data.description: Not only is Hood Famous super cute but they also have one of the most unique menus in the city. This bakeshop and coffee spot focuses on Philippine cuisine and flavors. So you can grab a coffee and an amazing snack.

data.title: Zeitgeist
data.description: The cool older brother of coffee shops, Zeitgeist is another Seattle coffee shop that you don’t want to miss. And they also happen to have a gallery space where they feature different artists if you’d like some visuals with your coffee.

data.title: Moonshot Coffee
data.description: We have to cap this list with a tiny and super cute coffee shop tucked away in White Center. And while they’re currently only serving one person in the cafe at a time, it is absolutely worth the visit. You can get some seriously amazing coffee and see a cute new spot! And that’s our guide for cute and cozy coffee shops in Seattle to check out this fall! Now get out there and get caffeinated, folks!

data.title: Ezell’s
data.description: If you like fried chicken you can’t go wrong with Ezell’s. This long-standing Seattle favorite offers up some seriously tasty chicken combos and sides. So next time you’re looking for something fried be sure to check out Ezell’s.

data.title: Red Mill Burgers
data.description: We love Red Mill for several reasons but the main reason has to be that they have some of the best burgers in the city. And they make probably some of the best onion rings we’ve ever had. So if you’re in need of a burger be sure to stop by Red Mill.

data.title: Fremont Bowl
data.description: If you want comfort food that’s on the healthier side, Fremont Bowl is a great spot to checkout. They specialize in making super tasty donburi bowls and they never disappoint. So if you’re looking for some delicious seafood, try here.

data.title: The Crumpet Shop
data.description: If you’re looking for something unique we recommend checking out the Crumpet Shop. This Pike Place Market staple has plenty of options to choose from between savory and sweet. And you can always get multiple crumpets because chances are you’ll want more than one.

data.title: Pho Bac Sup Shop
data.description: We don’t know about you guys but pho always hits the spot when we need comfort food. And Pho Bac Sup Shop never disappoints. Plus you can also score some other delicious Vietnamese dishes and sides.

data.title: Mee Sum Pastry
data.description: If you guys haven’t had Hum Bao before it might just become your go-to comfort food. And when we’re in the mood we always head to Mee Sum Pastry in the market. Because their buns are affordable and always delicious.

data.title: Young Tea
data.description: This one might seem a little odd but bubble tea really hits the spot for us sometimes. And if you’re in the mood for something sweet but not too heavy we think that Young Tea is a great place to check out. After all, they have a wide menu full of super high-quality teas.

data.title: Tacos Chukis
data.description: If you’re in the mood for tacos and want something simple but tasty, you can’t go wrong with Tacos Chukis. Their no-nonsense menu is easy to order from and you can get as many or as few as you want!

data.title: Bangrak Market
data.description: If you’re in the mood for Thai we’re big fans of Bangrak Market. This spot in Belltown has a wide and very tasty menu that never disappoints. Not to mention they have a pretty cool interior if you take a peek inside.

data.title: Delancy
data.description: And finally, we have to cap this list with what might just be the best pizza in Seattle. Delancy knows how to make some seriously tasty Neapolitan style pizza and the pizzas are perfectly sized. So next time you’re in the mood for pizza try Delancy. Okay folks that’s what we have for you when it comes to the best comfort food in Seattle. And we hope that you guys try at least one of these spots the next time you’re in the mood for some tasty dishes. Because we promise you won’t be disappointed.

data.title: Mezcaleria Oaxaca
data.description: This delicious Oaxacan spot just started doing brunch at Patio Cielo (their spectacular rooftop). So if you want to enjoy some beautiful fresh air dining and a delicious new brunch and drink menu be sure to head here!

data.title: Le Pichet
data.description:
If you’re planning on heading to the market this weekend then stop by Le Pichet for breakfast. This authentically French spot never disappoints with their delicious menu. And you can grab takeout if you’d rather walk and eat. Related posts:
8 things to do in Seattle this weekend (September 11-13)
You can’t miss the Building Black Wealth Market this Saturday

data.title: Bakery Nouveau
data.description: On the topic of French-inspired foods, Bakery Nouveau is an excellent choice if you just want pastries and a coffee. And they’re running on a takeout basis. So you can grab your treats and enjoy a walk in Volunteer Park afterward.

data.title: The Dish
data.description: This is our favorite spot for a classic American breakfast. And it turns out they’ve expanded from Ballard/Fremont to Green Lake as well! So you can either dine-in or take your food to go. Either way, you won’t be disappointed.

data.title: The Crumpet Shop
data.description: This classic Seattle spot is another great stop if you’re heading to Pike Place. And with a huge menu, you’ll have plenty of both sweet and savory options to choose from. Plus they’re operating on a takeout basis so you can enjoy your crumpet while exploring the market. Alright, folks there you have it. Those are our picks for some of the most unique breakfast spots to try in Seattle. We hope you get out there and treat yourself to a delicious breakfast or brunch this weekend. And if you do, be sure to tag us in those pics!

data.title: Din Tai Fung
data.description: Well, you probably already know this one. But when was the last time you ordered some of their delicious dumplings? Or noodles, honestly we love the entire menu. But we also don’t love waiting to get a table during normal times. So we’re pretty dang happy to opt for takeout.

data.title: Mi La Cay
data.description: So Mi La Cay is technically a Vietnamese restaurant but their specialty is Chinese noodle soup. And for that reason, we think they deserve a spot on this list. Because trust us their entire menu is tasty but the noodle soup is particularly good. You need to try it.

data.title: Jade Garden Restaurant
data.description: This restaurant is a weekend hotspot in normal times. And whether you’re going for dim sum or just for some delicious traditional Chinese dishes, Jade Garden never disappoints. So we highly recommend that you try at least one of their menu items.

data.title: Mee Sum Pastry
data.description: If you’re heading down to the market you have to stop by this delicious spot. Mee Sum serves up authentic Taiwanese cuisine and is a well-loved market staple. We highly recommend that you try their buns as they’re some of the best in the city.

data.title: Biang Biang Noodles
data.description: This spot opened not too long ago but its already getting quite a bit of love. So if you’re in the mood for hand-pulled noodles you might as well swing by. After all, you can try something new and support a new restaurant. It doesn’t get much better than that.

data.title: Harbor City Restaurant
data.description: Harbor City is another one of Seattle’s best Chinese restaurants and dim sum spots. And while we miss sitting down for sim sum we’re super happy to be able to take it to go. Because let’s face it, waiting in line for an hour isn’t always the move.

data.title: Kau Kau Barbeque
data.description: If you want some of the best barbeque in the city then you need to check out Kau Kau. They have a large menu and they never disappoint. But if you need somewhere to start then go with the duck, we promise you’ll love it.
data.when: Monday-Friday 10 am-10 pm, Friday & Saturday 10 am-11 pm, Sunday 10 am-10 pm

data.title: Hue Ky Mi Gia
data.description: Here’s another sneaky Chinese fusion spot that’s worth checking out. Hue Ky Mi Gia combines Vietnamese and Chinese flavors for a unique food experience that you won’t soon forget. So we recommend checking out Hue Ky Mi Gia if you want the best of both worlds.

data.title: Dumpling the Noodle
data.description: This spot gets an award for the cutest name. But in all seriousness, Dumpling the Noodle serves up some very tasty food. Which of course includes dumplings as the name suggests. So if you’re in the mood for dumplings look no further than this spot.

data.title: King Noodle
data.description: And finally, we’ll cap this list off with one more place to snag some tasty noodles. Because let’s face it, you can never go wrong with noodles and they pretty much always sound good. So be sure to check out King Noodle and their selection of authentic Chinese noodle dishes. Okay, folks, we hope you enjoy this list of Chinese restaurants in Seattle offering takeout and delivery. Each restaurant has its own unique offerings and are all worth trying. So order yourself something tasty and have a great week!
data.when: Monday-Thursday 10 am-10 pm, Friday & Saturday 10 am-12 am, Sunday 10 am-10 pm

data.title: Mo Pockets
data.description: This food truck serves up authentic Chinese food with an American twist in the form of sandwiches. And best of all you can choose from a wide range of fillings. So next time you’re downtown be sure to keep your eyes peeled.

data.title: Sam Choy’s Poke To The Max
data.description: If you want some seriously tasty poke, look no further than Sam Choy’s Poke To The Max. This place knows how to make a mean bowl of poke that will have you coming back for more. They go so far as to call themselves the “Godfathers” of poke, so you know they’ve gotta have offerings that you can’t refuse.

data.title: MOMO Express
data.description: MOMO serves up a modern take on Vietnamese street food. Giving you first-hand access to some of the best eats in Seattle on wheels. Not to mention they have vegan and veggie options for those plant-based eaters out there.

data.title: Theo’s Gyros
data.description: Of course, you can also never go wrong with a super tasty gyro and Theo’s serves up just that. You can snag their gyros with their signature halal lamb or switch it up with halal beef. Whatever you’re feeling, they’ve got it.

data.title: YS Street Food Group
