data.description: And finally, we have to cap this list with some delicious authentic Chinese food. They serve up Chinese BBQ and other tasty authentic Chinese dishes that will have you coming back time and time again. Be sure to give them a try Okay folks that’s what we have for Seattle food trucks. If you want more options you can click here for a list of some of Seattle’s food trucks and where and what times you can find them. So with that, we hope you enjoy these tasty restaurants on wheels.

data.title: Bybee Farms
data.description: This farm has been in operation since the 40s and offers 6 strands of Blueberries for pickers to choose from. And they are Stanley, Dixi, Pemberton, Jersey, Blue Ray, and Blue Crop. Did you even know there were that many different kinds of Blueberries? Oh, and they use organic agricultural methods.

data.title: Larsen Lake Blueberry Farms
data.when: Tuesday-Saturday, 10 am-6 pm, Sunday, 10 am-5 pm

data.title: Mountainview Blueberry Farm
data.description: This spot is big. Mountainview has 9 acres of land and 7 different varieties of berries that you can pick. However, Mountainview’s berries are conventionally farmed using IPM. That being said, it’s still one of the more popular spots near Seattle.

data.title: Charlotte’s Blueberry Park
data.description: And for those of you situated in South Seattle, heading down to Tacoma might be your best bet. So if that’s you, you can try checking out Charlotte’s Blueberry Park which is run by Metro Parks Tacoma. And it’s huge at over 3,300 bushes!

data.title: Olalla U-Pick Blueberry Farm
data.description: Gotta love organic. Olalla is another great spot for those of you looking for specifically organic Blueberry farms. And during the pandemic, they are operating on time slots so be sure to book ahead for your preferred timeslot.

data.title: Blue Dot Farm
data.description: On the topic of appointments, Blue Dot is also running on a by appointment picking schedule during the pandemic. And while blue Dot is a small family-run farm, they have 9 primary varieties of Blueberries and 7 other varieties. Which is pretty dang good.

data.title: Bow Hill Blueberries
data.description: Bow Hill also likes to keep things organic and they happen to be one of the oldest if not the oldest family-run blueberry farm in the Skagit Valley. So you can be sure that they know their stuff. Not to mention, they’re the perfect stop on a day trip in the Skagit Valley.
data.when: Monday-Thursday 10 am-5 pm, Friday & Saturday 10 am-6 pm, Sunday 11 am-6 pm

data.title: Broers Farms Inc.
data.description: And if you want certified organic then Broers is the place for you. Not to mention they also have multiple other berry varieties. So you can snag blueberries, raspberries, blackberries, and marionberries. Because variety is key.

data.title: Bryant Blueberries
data.description: If you want more variety in berries, Bryant has you covered. Not only do they have blueberries but they also have a hybrid of raspberries and blackberries known as tayberries. And they also have boysenberries and currents. So you could say they’re one of the most unique blueberry farms near Seattle.
data.when: Tuesday-Thursday 8 am-4 pm, Saturday & Sunday 8 am-4 pm

data.title: Blue Dog Farm
data.description: Blue Dog is another farm that takes its organic practices very seriously. And they also offer a unique membership program for dedicated u-pickers. So if you want the ability to pick at any time, consider a membership. You’ll still have to pay by the pound but hey that flexibility sure sounds worth it to us. Okay, folks that should be a good start for you to find a blueberry farm near Seattle. And before you go please remember to bring your masks, hand sanitizer, and to social distance. All farms have various social distancing and mask policies so be sure to read up on those before you go. And with that enjoy all of the wonderful blueberry farms that our state has to offer.
data.when: Members can pick daily from sunrise to sundown
data.where: : 7125 W. Snoqualmie Valley Rd, Carnation, WA

data.title: Redmill Burgers
data.description: You can never go wrong with Redmill between their multiple locations they are constantly serving up quality, tasty burgers. And they’ve been at it for quite a while so if there’s anywhere we’d go first, it’s Redmill.
data.where: : Tuesday-Saturday 11 am-9 pm, Sunday 12 pm-8 pm

data.title: Dicks Drive-In
data.description: Of course, this list wouldn’t be complete without the iconic, classic, tasty, and cheap Dick’s burgers. Loved by all Seattleites alike, this burger spot serves up a small menu that never disappoints. And of course, they also make classic milkshakes.

data.title: Bateau
data.description: This restaurant by James Beard Award-winning chef Renee Erickson is all about meat. And that means Bateau just so happens to serve up one of the best burgers. Seriously you need to try the Bateau burger because it might just end up being the best burger you’ve ever had.

data.title: Mean Sandwich
data.description: This spot lives up to its name, they serve up some seriously mean sandwiches. And of course, that includes the D.A.M. Burger, which is another one of Seattle’s must-try burgers. If you couldn’t guess, it’ll probably make you say “DAM that’s a good burger”.

data.title: Lil Woody’s
data.description: This Seattle gem is back in action and ready to serve you some of the most unique burgers in the city through online ordering. So hop online and order yourself one of their delicious, high-quality burgers packed with local ingredients. You won’t regret it.

data.title: Smith
data.description: If you want a simple but guaranteed good burger that’s a bit more elevated, you need to try Smith. They make an excellent burger that can be cooked to your desire. And while we’re advocating for getting takeout right now they do have an amazing interior as well.

data.title: Two Doors Down
data.description: If you’re all about customizing your burger then Two Doors Down is a great spot for you. And they happen to have a ton of beers on tap that you can enjoy with your tasty burger. So be sure to stop by Two Doors Down next time you’re on the hill.

data.title: Rain City Burgers
data.description: Here’s another great Seattle spot that offers tasty, consistent, and unique burgers that will satisfy any craving. And at the moment they are taking online orders for you to come and pick up. So don’t overlook Rain City burgers, it might just become your new go-to spot.
data.where: : Monday-Saturday 11 am-9 pm, Sunday 11 am-8 pm

data.title: Uneeda Burger
data.description: This tasty Fremont burger spot is open for takeout orders. So if you’re going to chill in Gas Works or somewhere in North Seattle be sure to stop by and grab a burger beforehand. And Uneeda Burger has tons of options to choose from.

data.title: Harry’s Fine Foods
data.description: This Capitol Hill gem is a seriously special spot. And they have one of our favorite sneaky patio areas. So while they’re presently only open for takeout they have a very tasty burger. That being said, keep an eye on their Insta for current menu offerings. Okay, folks well now you can pass the time trying some of the best burgers in Seattle. And of course please make sure to follow all restaurant rules when dining-in or grabbing takeout. Additionally, be patient with restaurants. With all that in mind enjoy these excellent spots and we’ll catch with our next guide!

data.title: Full Tilt Ice Cream
data.description: For some of the city’s best and most original flavors, you have to stop by Full Tilt. And if you happen to be grocery shopping keep your eyes peeled because select grocers around Seattle carry their flavors in store. And trust us, they don’t disappoint.

data.title: Frankie & Jo’s
data.description: This ice cream shop has a lot of wins, it’s plant-based, gluten-free and owned by women. So by those factors alone you gotta check them out. However, their ice cream happens to be some of the best in the city. So don’t worry about the lack of milk. You won’t be able to tell the difference.

data.title: Whidbey Island Ice Cream Co.
data.description: If you’re all about quality then you need to try a pint of Whidbey Island Ice Cream Co. They source their milk from local farms and you can absolutely taste the difference in their delicious, rich ice creams. Not to mention they’re available in many local grocery stores or you can head to the scoop shop on Whidbey Island.

data.title: D’Ambrosio Gelato
data.description: And if you’re a fan of high-quality gelato, D’Ambrosio is the place for you. And while all of their flavors are amazing and worth trying. We also have to hype up their gelato cakes for special occasions. Seriously 10/10 recommend.
data.when: Monday-Thursday 2-9 pm, Friday & Saturday 2-10 pm, Sunday 2-9 pm

data.title: Fainting Goat
data.description: Funny name but amazing Gelato. Plus its all organic and you absolutely can’t go wrong with that. So be sure to stop by this North Seattle gem to try one of their many delicious flavors. And if you really love it, grab a pint! Plus you can even have it delivered.

data.title: Seattle Cookie Counter
data.description: Plant-based ice cream is back for yet another win. The Seattle Cookie Counter is an amazing vegan owned and operated bakery and ice creamery that serves up some delicious treats. And of course, you can combine them for a delicious ice cream sandwich. But be sure to order online as they are only open for pick up.

data.title: Husky Deli
data.description: For those of you trapped in West Seattle, you can’t forget Husky Deli. This Seattle classic has been at it a long time and serves up some great classic ice cream flavors. So be sure to stop by to support this great small business and get your ice cream fix.
data.when: Sunday-Thursday 7 am-7 pm, Friday-Saturday 7 am-9 pm

data.title: Bluebird Ice Cream
data.description: And if you happen to live in North Seattle and want to sit back and have the ice cream come to you, check out Bluebird Ice Cream. They are offering home delivery to select neighborhoods in North Seattle. And of course, you can also find them at their shop and at select farmer’s markets around the city.

data.title: Nutty Squirrel Gelato
data.description: And finally, we’re capping our list with another great gelato spot. Nutty Squirrel is only open for curbside pick up and delivery so be sure to hop online before going. But they are well known in the city for their quality and tasty frozen goodness. So be sure to give them a try. Okay, folks, that’s the scoop on the best places to grab an ice cream in Seattle. And of course please follow all business rules when visiting these shops or ordering. We know you’ll love all of these spots so treat yourself this weekend!

data.title: Saigon Deli
data.description: Saigon Deli is the perfect no-nonsense, takeout sandwich spot. And it’s also probably one of the most affordable sandwiches in the city at $3. So if you’re in the mood for a tasty banh mi and other delicious Vietnamese dishes, head over to Saigon Deli.

data.title: Bok a Bok Fried Chicken
data.description: If you’re in the mood for a super delicious fried chicken sandwich, look no further than Bok a Bok. They have several options to choose from and let us tell you they are all equally delicious. So be sure to give them a try next time you want to try something new.

data.title: Other Coast
data.description: This Ballard classic has been serving up mean sandwiches for what seems like forever. And let us tell you they sure are tasty. Not to mention you can choose between 7” and 14” sandwiches depending on how hungry you are.

data.title: Mean Sandwich
data.description: They truly live up to their name as in the sandwiches are really good. And the staff are very kind. So you can expect a menu chock full of tasty sandwiches and high-quality ingredients. We highly recommend that you check them out as you won’t be disappointed.

data.title: Tat’s Delicatessen
data.description: Tat’s is probably one of Seattle’s most classic sandwich shops. And also the most likely to put you in a food coma. They specialize in East Coast-style sandwiches. Which means you can find meatball subs, cheesesteaks, and more on their massive menu.

data.title: Dingfelder’s Delicatessen
data.description: If you want to take it one step further with New York inspired sandwiches, head to Dingfelder’s. And while their sandwiches are on the pricier side they are absolutely worth it. You’ll be able to taste the quality. Gotta love it.

data.title: Cafe Presse
data.description: We love Cafe Presse for a lot of reasons. And they just so happen to make some pretty great sandwiches. Not to mention, open-faced sandwiches like Croque Madame and Croque monsieur. So if you haven’t had the chance to dine here yet, now’s the time.

data.title: Mammoth
data.description: This sandwich spot has a menu full of neolithic names. You can snag items like the mastodon, saber-tooth and neanderthal sandwich. And while the names are fun, the food is really good too. Not to mention, you can also add some booze to your order.

data.title: Beecher’s
data.description: If you want to keep things super simple and classic, then we say go with a grilled cheese from Beecher’s. And they have several other sandwich options if you want to spice things up a bit. But if you need cheesy goodness then head to Beecher’s.

data.title: Valhalla Sandwiches
data.description: And finally, you can’t go wrong with Valhalla Sandwiches. They have a big menu full of delicious options. And they’re extremely accessible as they off takeout and delivery through multiple platforms. So we highly recommend that you give one of their tasty sandwiches a go. Well, folks, we guarantee that you’ll love at least one of these sandwich shops offering takeout and delivery in Seattle. So if you’re in need of a sandwich we hope that you give one of these great restaurants a shot. And if you do, let us know what you think.

data.title: Fremont Bowl
data.description: We can’t speak highly enough about this place. It’s so good it’s almost addictive. And we like that they focus on donburi bowls. Because they’re a filling and healthy lunch or dinner option. Not to mention their prices are great. So if you haven’t given them a try, now’s the time. Options: Takeout or delivery with Uber Eats & Grub Hub

data.title: Musashi’s
data.description: This Wallingford classic has been around a long time. And that’s because it’s one of Seattle’s best spots to grab sushi. In fact, they’re pretty well recognized as having one of the best Chirashi bowls in the city. So if that sounds up your alley be sure to give them a try. Options: Takeout or delivery

data.title: Fuji Sushi
data.description: This gem is tucked away in Chinatown and is an excellent place for fresh, high-quality sushi. And what’s best of all is that they’re doing both takeout and delivery at this time. Or you can also opt to dine in. Whatever you choose, you won’t regret trying Fuji Sushi. Options: Takeout, delivery, and dine-in

data.title: Sushi Kappo Tamura
data.description: And if you want a bougie sushi night, look no further than Sushi Kappo Tamura. They are the cream on the crop for a few reasons. Firstly they use local and in-season ingredients. Secondly, their chefs have been at it a long time and head chef/owner Taichi Kitamura is pretty much a legend. In other words, you have to give them a try. Options: Takeout or delivery via Uber Eats & Grub Hub

data.title: Maneki
data.description: This gem is certainly Seattle’s oldest sushi bar and also probably Seattle’s oldest continually operating restaurant. It opened in 1904 which is pretty cool that it’s still around today. And that’s because they’ve been serving up mean sushi this whole time. So until we can get back to eating in the tatami rooms, we highly recommend ordering takeout. Options: Takeout

data.title: Tamari Bar
data.description: Well, Tamarai Bar is technically an Izakaya. But they have some killer sushi and sashimi on the menu that is definitely worth ordering along with all their other tasty menu items. And their bento-style to-go lunches are very aesthetically pleasing. So not only does your food taste amazing but it’s beautiful as well. Options: Takeout

data.title: Tsukushinbo
data.description: Honestly, we don’t really know how to pronounce the name of this restaurant. But we do know it’s really really good and in normal times very hard to get into. So that’s why we’re pumped that takeout is a thing. And you honestly can’t go wrong with anything that you order here, it’s all delicious. Options: Takeout

data.title: Shiro’s
data.description: And this list wouldn’t be complete without another high end, incredible sushi spot. Shiro’s is another long-standing spot that also happens to be Seattle’s first Edomae style spot. So if you really want some of the highest quality sushi you need to order yourself some Shiro’s ASAP. Options: Takeout, delivery, dine-in

data.title: Mashiko
data.description: This well-loved Seattle sushi spot is committed to sustainability. And in these times that’s super important because we need fish to enjoy sushi! So not only is their sushi sustainable but it’s high quality, delicious, and available for takeout. And that’s what we’re talking about. Options: Takeout

data.title: Ten Sushi
data.description: And to top off our list, we have a classic, simple and tasty takeout sushi spot. Ten sushi is perfect if you want a wide menu with plenty of choices. And they offer delivery through most 3rd party services so you have options across the board. We’re into it. Options: Takeout and Delivery via DoorDash & UberEats Okay, folks, we hope that you enjoy this list of the best places to get sushi takeout and delivery in Seattle. And while dine-in is slowly becoming an option at Seattle restaurants, we still highly recommend that you grab food-to-go. Regardless, enjoy these tasty sushi restaurants.

data.title: Betsutenjin
data.description: This small spot specializes in Hakata-style tonkotsu ramen. That means an incredibly rich pork broth, served with thin noodles and some chashu for good measure. Of course, if you ever get sick of that (you won’t), you could try their special offerings instead, like miso prawn ramen.

data.title: Rondo
data.description: This relatively new Seattle restaurant has quickly become pretty well-loved. And on top of that, they have some pretty tasty ramen. You can choose from options like classic shoyu or spicy hellz ramen. Not to mention, they have a ton of tasty side dishes that you can also pick up.

data.title: Yoroshiku
data.description:
A full-service izakaya that serves up a variety of ramen, ranging from spicy miso to vegan options. Make sure you try the Fisherman Ramen, which includes clams, octopus, sockeye salmon, and scallops. Related Posts:
Guide: 15 places for great pizza takeout and delivery in Seattle
Guide: 8 of the coolest Seattle Instagrams to follow
data.when: s: Takeout and delivery through Grubhub and Uber Eats

data.title: Menya Musashi
data.description: This International Japan-based chain is known for its tsukemen style ramen. So if you’re a noodle lover, Menya is a great option. Plus they have both ramen kits and ready to eat ramen. And we love options.

data.title: Ooink
data.description: This delicious spot specializes in tonkotsu ramen, so the pork bone broth is the star of the show. We personally love the classic shoyu ramen, but those seeking heat can get the spicy ramen instead and choose a spice level of 1 to 4. And Ooink is presently offering take-home ramen kits which is fun!

data.title: Arashi
data.description: A staple spot that started in Tukwila and since expanded to the Ballard area, thank goodness. We really like the flavor profile of the Black Garlic ramen, but like every other spot on this list, you can order anything and walk away happy.

data.title: Hokkaido Ramen Santouka
data.description: This is the first free-standing outpost in America from the legendary Japanese chain. We’re going to be honest, the Kara Miso ramen here is second to none when it comes to mixing heat with incredible flavor.
data.when: s: Takeout or delivery through Doordash and Uber Eats

data.title: Ramen Danbo
data.description: A straightforward outpost in Capitol Hill. Not only is the classic miso ramen an absolute treat, the extra scallions, sesame oil and sesame seeds in the negi-goma is something else too. Grab some of the chashu pork donburi on the side too, you won’t regret it.

This hidden gem is located in the Amazon concrete forest or campus, whatever you want to call it. But it is definitely not to be missed. Teinei has 6 different flavors of Ramen to choose from and like the other restaurants on this list, you can’t go wrong with whatever you pick.

data.title: Nuna Ramen
data.description: If you are vegetarian or vegan, Nuna has you covered. Plus they include locally sourced ingredients in their menu and also do have some options for carnivores. So if you’re looking for a wide range of options, Nuna has you covered.

data.title: Samurai Noodle
data.description: This small chain is known for its Tonkotsu ramen and has locations in the ID and University district. So you can expect consistent tastiness and an array of options that will keep you coming back. And there you have it, folks! Our picks for the best ramen in Seattle. As always, we recommend opting for takeout over delivery if you can. But enjoy these tasty ramen spots, you’ll be grateful that you did.
data.where: : 4138 University Way NE and 606 5th Ave South

data.title: Breezy Town Pizza
data.description: One of two spots in the city that excel at pan pizza. Rather than doing exclusively Chicago or Detroit style, Breezy Town opts for a tongue in cheek approach, creating a pizza that transports you to the best spot in a midwestern town.
data.when: Monday to Thursday, 4 PM-12 AM, Friday, 4 PM-1: 30 AM, Saturday, 11 AM-1: 30 AM and Sunday, 11 AM-11 PM
data.where: : 4864 Beacon Ave S, inside Clok-out Lounge

data.title: Pagliacci
data.description: If you want guaranteed great pizza delivered to your home we definitely recommend Pagliacci. And they have a wide menu that includes sides and desserts like Gelato. Plus they have locations across the city.
data.where: : 25 locations across Seattle and the Eastside

data.title: Big Mario’s Pizza
data.description: A New York-style staple that has three locations around the city. Classic and straightforward, this is a great option if you’re rewatching Mariner games from home on the weekend or something.
data.when: Varies by location but open late
data.where: : Capitol Hill, Queen Anne, and Fremont locations

data.title: Veraci Pizza
data.description:
Veraci serves up a seriously mean wood-fired Neapolitan pie. And they have a wide selection of offerings or you can opt to build your own. So if you need some thin crust goodness, we definitely recommend stopping by Veraci. Related Posts:
Lonely in the city? Seattle ranks 7th in USA for single-person households
The SPL’s summer book bingo will cure your boredom
data.where: : 500 NW Market St and 7320 35th Ave NE

data.title: Dino’s Tomato Pie
data.description: From the people behind Delancey comes Dino’s. Serving up both New Jersey round pizza and Sicilian rectangular, Dino’s is the place to grab a little something if you’re in Capitol Hill. Best website by far on this list, too.
data.when: Sunday to Wednesday, 4 PM-12 AM, and Thursday to Saturday, 4 PM-2 AM

data.title: Rocco’s
data.description: Hip spot downtown that pairs contemporary flavors with tasty cocktails. And surprisingly, these guys are also offering pizza by the slice! Perfect for those of you who don’t feel comfortable tackling an XL over one weekend.

data.title: Pizzeria 22
data.description: These guys have great prices considering they are part of the prestigious VPN certified group. Italians are protective of their foods, with pizza being no different, and a VPN certification demonstrates perfection when it comes to Neopolitan style pies.
data.when: Sunday to Thursday, 4 PM-10 PM, and Friday to Saturday, 4 PM-11 PM

data.title: Delancy
data.description: This beautiful and minimal Seattle restaurant also happens to make a pretty tasty pizza. And while they have a smaller menu than some of the others on the list they are absolutely worth checking out. Because we all need artisanal pizza once and a while.
data.when: Tues-Fri 5 PM-10 PM and Sat & Sun 4:30 PM-10 PM

data.title: Proletariat
data.description: Billed as ‘the pizza that made White Centre famous’, Proletariat makes the trip out here more than worth it. Grab something simple, like maybe the REAL Hawaiian made with SPAM, or test out a pizza like White Centre White, that foregoes tomato sauce.
data.when: Monday to Thursday, 4 PM-9 PM, Friday/Saturday, 12 PM-11 PM and Sunday, 12 PM-9 PM

data.title: Slice Box Pizza
data.description: Great spot for grab and go pizza that’s only a few blocks from T-Mobile Park. Thin crust and Sicilian style pizzas are the norm, and this spot definitely wears the crown for ‘most neighborly neighborhood joint’.
data.when: Monday to Saturday, 11 AM-6 PM, Closed Sunday

data.title: Ballard Pizza Company
data.description: Tasty, simple, and high quality is what comes to mind when thinking of Ballard Pizza Company. And we’re big fans of both their pizzas and salads so be sure to get one of each! Plus they deliver and you gotta love that.
data.when: Mon-Fri 4 PM-8 PM and Fri & Sat 4 PM- 9 PM

data.title: Supreme
data.description: Now with locations in both West Seattle and the University District, Supreme offers delicious, contemporary New York pizza. Definitely a great spot for grabbing pizza takeout in Seattle, and especially if you want to keep things simple.
data.where: : 4521 California Avenue SW and 4529 University Way NE

data.title: Flying Squirrel Pizza
data.description: This pizza joint definitely gets the award for the best name. But beyond that Flying Squirrel has been known around the city for quite a while as one of the absolute best places to get a pie. And we’ll agree, they make excellent pizza and have a good range of options for you to choose from.
data.where: : 8310 5th Ave NE and 5701 Airport Way S

data.title: Windy City Pie
data.description: The other pan pizza staple in Seattle, and affiliated with Breezy Town Pizza. The OG spot for delicious Chicago-style deep dish. Their sourdough based crust and the delicious caramelized cheese makes it a winner in our minds.
data.when: Sunday/Wednesday/Thursday, 4 PM-10 PM and Friday/Saturday, 4 PM-11 PM, Closed Monday and Tuesday

data.title: World Pizza
data.description: This spot gets the nod because they do vegetarian pizzas better than any other spot in the city. Because, after all, who said that pizza can’t be healthy food? Although we have to admit that wasabi pineapple doesn’t sound super appetizing. And that’s our list of great spots for pizza takeout and delivery in Seattle! Enjoy the week, folks.
data.when: Monday to Thursday, 10 AM-9 PM, Friday, 10 AM-10 PM, Saturday, 12 PM-10 PM and Sunday, 12 PM-8 PM

data.title: Atulea
data.description: This relatively new addition to Capitol Hill has become quite the spot, because who doesn’t love tea? And to boost that, they focus on matcha tea. You can expect high-quality teas and a beautiful, summery environment at this Capitol Hill institution. Just look at those plants!

data.title: Sam Choy’s Poke to the Max
data.description:
As the name suggests, Sam Choy’s does it big or not at all. They are the kings of poke, and you can expect the best of Hawaiian cuisine and more here. Plus, they have a really cool location in Rainer Valley that will make you feel like you’re sitting at a beachside restaurant. Oh, and they also have a few food trucks. So summery! Related posts:
Guide: 5 restaurants in Seattle with breathtaking views
Guide: 6 of the best late-night dining spots in Seattle

data.title: juicebox cafe
data.description: This perfectly Instagrammable restaurant feels like an indoor greenhouse with its plethora of plants. To boot, the menu is packed with healthy and delicious snacks that make us think of the fruit trays our mom used to bring us by the pool. Ah, those were the days.

data.title: Agua Verde Cafe
data.description: Talk about an institution! Agua Verde has been around since 1998. They serve up tasty Mexican food right on Lake Union in Portage Bay. The bright colored interior and greenery surrounding the restaurant are definitely reminiscent of a tropical paradise. Also, we highly recommend coming back in the summer because they rent paddleboards.

data.title: Hula Hula
data.description: Of course, this list wouldn’t be complete without a tiki bar. Sadly, Seattle doesn’t have many, but we do have Hula Hula. You can expect a tiki vibe complete with tropical drinks & bowls, karaoke, and tasty eats. It’s the closest you’re getting to a tropical vacation in the PNW! Alright, with that, we hope our list of Seattle restaurants that feel like summer helps make the end of your winter that much better. If anything, it’ll at least be a little bit tastier. Hold on folks, that summer sun is almost here!

data.title: Canlis
data.description: Unarguably the most classic of all Seattle restaurants, Canlis has been serving Seattlites since 1950. It also happens to have a beautiful view of Lake Union. And beyond that, it’s internationally known as an excellent spot for elevated dining. Don your fancy clothes and take it all in!

data.title: Ivar’s Salmon House & Barge
data.description:
Ivar’s also happens to be a Seattle classic, and has been well-loved by people from all walks of life. You can always expect the best fish and chips, that’s for sure. Plus the restaurant is a cedar replica of a Northwest Native American longhouse and is probably one of the most unique restaurant interiors in Seattle. If you’re dining in the spring and summer, you can pull your boat up to their floating barge seating area. S’fancy! Related posts:
Guide: 6 of the best late-night dining spots in Seattle
Guide: 5 unmissable fusion restaurants in Seattle

data.title: Athenian Seafood Restaurant
data.description: The Athenian is a Pike Place Market mainstay with two levels of views of the beautiful Puget Sound. You can expect a mix of American comfort food and seafood. However, our favorite meal to dive into here is a simple breakfast before the market opens. If you do go later and the Athenian is packed, head over to Lowell’s next door for equally as good food and views.

data.title: Goldfinch Tavern
data.description: This restaurant is tucked away in the Four Seasons Hotel and is part of the well-known Ethan Stowell Restaurant Group. You can expect elevated American food with local ingredients and flavor as well as vegetarian and vegan options. On top of all that, you can also sit at a window booth and gaze over downtown and Elliot Bay. Sounds pretty nice, huh?

data.title: Westward
data.description: This well-loved restaurant is getting a very exciting makeover by the Sea Creatures group. Westward closed at the beginning of January for renovations and it’s estimated that they’ll reopen in about 12 weeks. We’re sure excited to enjoy the fire pit, oysters and Lake Union views when they reopen! So, where are we going for dinner? Time to make our date uncomfortable by staring out the window too much. Can’t help it with such beautiful views at these Seattle restaurants!

data.title: The Pink Door
data.description: This restaurant is a Seattle classic loved by both locals and tourists alike, so you really can’t go wrong here. If you just so happen to be really picky about your pasta, The Pink Door has tons of options for you to choose from, including gluten-free options. Do the sensible thing and try them all.

data.title: Willmott’s Ghost
data.description: This is undeniably one of the most unique dining experiences in Seattle, as it’s located inside the Amazon Spheres. It also just so happens to be part of the Sea Creatures group which is locally owned and operated by James Beard Foundation Award-winning chef Renee Erickson and partners. So not only is the restaurant beautiful, but the food is amazing. It might just become your go-to pasta spot!

data.title: San Fermo
data.description:
Firstly, San Fermo is beautiful. It has an old-world, intimate feel due to it being in a legit old house! It has a white wall, clean, and minimal aesthetic that fits perfectly in everyone’s Instagram feed. In fact, we’re sure you’ve seen people post pics from San Fermo before. Besides the restaurant’s aesthetics, they make great food. Just look at those parm piles! Related posts:
This app chooses what you do for your date night in Seattle
Guide: 6 delicious spots for dessert in Seattle

data.title: Pasta Casalinga
data.description: If you’re looking for a high quality, more affordable option, Pasta Casalinga should be your first choice. It’s located in the heart of the Pike Place Market and serves up authentic Italian pasta with a Pacific Northwest influence. Definitely stop by!

data.title: GH Pasta Co
data.description: Here’s another affordable option for those of you trying to make the most of your carbs budget. GH Pasta Co has tons of tasty options and is quickly rising as a pasta star in Seattle. It’s the perfect grab and go pasta if you’re looking to gracefully inhale your food on the run!

data.title: La Medusa
data.description: If you’re looking for places to check out in Columbia City, La Medusa is the place to be. La Medusa is known for its southern Italian/Sicilian menu with Northwest ingredients. It’s a sweet little spot and you’ll be able to taste the difference in La Medusa’s dedication to the craft of pasta. By this point, you should be daydreaming of bucatini. What are your favourite pasta places in Seattle! Let us know if you’ve got one we need to try!

data.title: Jade Garden
data.description: If you know, you know. Jade Garden is a Seattle dim sum OG, and they also happen to be open in the wee hours. If you’re spending time in Chinatown late at night, this will probably become your go-to place. You can’t go wrong here.
data.where: : Monday – Thursday 9 am – 2:30 am, Friday & Saturday 9 am – 3:30 am, Sunday 9 am – 1 am

data.title: Witness
data.description: If you’re heading back north on Broadway, you should definitely give Witness a try. They specialize in southern fare and comfort food. So, if you need a late-night serving of chicken and waffles, they’ve got you covered. Who doesn’t need that?
data.where: : Monday – Thursday 4 pm – 1 am, Friday 4 pm – 2 am, Saturday 9 am – 2 am, Sunday 9 am – 1 am

data.title: Ba Bar
data.description: Late-night pho? Count us in. Ba Bar is a Seattle institution and serves up some of the city’s best bowls of pho. They also have some pretty dang tasty drinks and appetizers. But if you need more convincing, it’s located in a pretty central area, making it easy to hit up.
data.where: : Monday – Thursday 10 am – 2 am, Friday & Saturday 10 am – 4 am, Sunday 10 am – 2 am

data.title: Dick’s Drive-In
data.description: It may seem like a no-brainer, but Dick’s is probably one of the quickest and cheapest options for late-night dining. They also happen to have multiple locations across Seattle, so no need to hop in an Uber to grab yourself some much needed late-night fries.

data.title: 13 Coins Restaurant
data.description: Yes, it’s a bit out of the way, but this is truly a Seattle classic when it comes to 24-hour dining. You can expect consistent American fare with an elevated atmosphere. If you’re coming or going from SeaTac, it’s definitely worth stopping in.

data.title: Pie Bar
data.description: Yes, its pretty niche, but who knows when you’re going to crave pie? We crave pie at weird times. It’s fine. It’s probably America’s best food group after all. And hey, have you ever seen a pie place that stays open until 2 am? Probably not, so you should definitely check out Pie Bar if you’re going to be out late on Capitol Hill! Also, pro tip, they have a walk-up window in case you just want the pie to go. Alrighty guys, that’s a wrap for late night dining in Seattle. We think we did a pretty good job of covering different flavors all across town. If you give any of these awesome institutions a try, let us know and save us a bite!

data.title: The Mountaineering Club
data.description: Let’s kick things off with the panoramic views provided by the 16th floor of Graduate Seattle. The Mountaineering Club boasts views of Mount Rainier, downtown Seattle, and Puget Sound. It’s so nice up here you might forget to even eat and drink.

data.title: Monkey Loft
data.description: “Surprisingly intimate and always bumping” is an easy way to describe Monkey Loft. Oh, and the rooftop is an absolute blast. Like c’ mon, just look at those patio lanterns!

data.title: Mezcaleria Oaxaca
data.description: The one and only Mezcaleria Oaxaca worth visiting in Seattle, trust us. This local gem in Capitol Hill has been providing delicious cuisine in a great setting for years, and has become a hot spot for anyone in the know.

data.title: Fog Room
data.description:
Perched above 2nd Avenue in downtown Seattle, this is more of a unique terrace than a traditional rooftop patio. That being said, it’s hard to deny Fog Room from earning a spot on this list. The modern-chic decor is gorgeous, the downtown views are stunning, and the food and drink menus are insanely good. Enjoy! Related Posts:
Black Raven Brewing has opened a massive new taproom
Acclaimed Restaurateur opening new spot in the heart of West Seattle

data.title: The Nest
data.description: Get a little boujee and hit the top-shelf of Seattle rooftop bars/patios with a visit to The Nest. Come for the views, stay for the cocktails, and leave because you’re broke (like us) or stay a little longer ‘cuz you’re flush with cash.

data.title: Captain Blacks
data.description: With two outdoor decks, some wicked deals, and an unbeatable atmosphere, it’s hard to deny that Captian Blacks is one of Seattle’s favorite spots. Heck, throw in the Southern-inspired dishes and you’ve practically encountered heaven on earth.

data.title: Frolik
data.description: Chasing the “true SOCIAL experience”, Frolik has become one of the top restaurant and bars in downtown Seattle.

data.title: MBar
data.description: Impressive views combined with a club-like ambiance make MBar one of the most impressive rooftop patios in Seattle. Obviously, the rooftop is great, but even the indoor seating provides top-notch atmosphere and sights. Now, those aren’t all of the best rooftops and patios in Seattle, but they are a great place to start! We’ll be sure to highlight even more rooftop spots soon!

data.title: RN74
data.description: This French Steakhouse has over 1,000 wines available and the food is top notch. In fact, the former RN74 in San Francisco had been called a “revolution for the wine world”. (Making this an obvious choice in our books!) By the way, 1,000 wines mean a couple hundred of them are decently affordable. Not bad!

data.title: Walla Walla Steak Company
data.description: Aptly named after its location (one of the best-named cities in America), this spot has a hefty focus on local wines and a brewery attached to the steakhouse. As well as this, Wine Enthusiast likes that you can get nearly 40 different wines by the glass.

data.title: Willows Inn
data.description: The seasonally changing wine list is entirely comprised of PNW wines. On top of that, Wine Enthusiast also recommends the Blue Clams and heirloom wheat bread as a tasty food pairing. We’ll take ten, thanks. Finally, you can check out the complete list right here. 

data.title: The Walrus and the Carpenter
data.description: In addition to being one of the best seafood spots in Seattle, these guys definitely have the best name. Head down there to talk about shoes and ships and sealing wax as you enjoy a dozen or so oysters.

data.title: RockCreek
data.description:
This Fremont mainstay is a perfect blend between fishing lodge and industrial space. Based on that alone we’re impressed. But, then they went and created a fantastic menu using everything from monkfish to grouper. Related Posts:
Seattle is getting another HQ2 from Silicon Valley
Thompson Seattle’s brand new restaurant is already a favorite

data.title: Matt’s in the Market
data.description: One of two places in Pike Place Market that have become institutions in the city. The constantly evolving menu uses the freshest seafood from the market below. As a result, it’s also one of the busiest spots in Seattle.

data.title: Bar Melusine
data.description: An adorable spot in Capitol Hill that focuses on French cuisine. Melusine is actually the Walrus’ cousin, which is as good a stamp of approval as anything. We recommend trying anything with clams in it.
data.when: Tuesday to Saturday, 5PM-10PM and Sunday/Monday, 5PM-9PM, Brunch Saturday/Sunday, 10AM-2PM

data.title: Manolin
data.description: This surprisingly affordable spot in Fremont comes from the minds of four former employees of Sea Creatures (Melusine, Walrus, and a handful of other incredible restaurants). Actually, the name is a dead giveaway- Manolin refers to the young apprentice from Hemingway’s ‘The Old Man and the Sea’.
data.when: Tuesday to Saturday, 4PM-10PM and Sunday, 4PM-9PM, Closed Monday

data.title: Taylor Shellfish Farms Oyster Bar
data.description: With three spots in Seattle, Taylor Shellfish is another must-visit in the city. These guys have been farming oysters and other seafood since the 1890s. If you survive over a century doing the same thing, you deserve success, it’s that simple.

data.title: Pike Place Chowder
data.description: This place is going to be insanely busy, and for good reason. The 3-time winner of the Great Chowder Cook-Off in New England is actually in the competition’s ‘Hall of Fame’. So, we can safely say you’re going to have one of, if not the best, chowders in the country.
data.where: : One in the market and one in Pacific Place

data.title: Duke’s Seafood
data.description: Duke’s is the perfect destination for those who want to feel good about enjoying classic seafood dishes. These guys are neck and neck with Pike Place for best chowder in the area, and they’ve got a menu that is 100% sustainably sourced. And there you have it, folks! Our top picks for Seattle’s best seafood restaurants. Next time you have friends coming in from out of town, make sure you consult this list if they want some delicious seafood.

data.title: CHATEAU STE MICHELLE
data.description: Washington’s largest and oldest winery plays host not only to wine lovers, but also musical acts and concertgoers throughout the summer. The property is stunning, and you’re more than welcome to enjoy your sips outdoors to soak up the view.

data.title: NORTHSTAR WINERY
data.description:
Starting out in the early 90s, Northstar was created to showcase the variety of Washington’s vineyards. Now, one of the best merlots out there (yes, looking at you, France) comes from this winery. Come try it for yourself, we think you might just agree that it gives the ‘authentic’ stuff a run for its money. Related Posts:
17 things to do in Seattle this June
Totokaelo Sale! Our fave high fashion pieces under $150

data.title: CAVE B ESTATE WINERY
data.description: Sitting on the same plot of land as The Gorge, Cave B was specifically chosen for its rich soil and desirable microclimates. Cave B started up in 2000 as a premium winery and has since become a destination for wine aficionados and nature lovers alike.

data.title: COL SOLARE
data.description: A collaborative effort between Washington’s Chateau Ste Michelle (see above) and the iconic Italian producer Marchesi Antinori. When a winery that started in 1385 signs off, you know you’ve got something good. The name here is Italian for “shining hill”. We’d like to know what’s Italian for “the cabernet sauvignon is legendary and we love the scenery.” Any help?

data.title: PORTTEUS VINEYARDS
data.description: Venture up to Portteus if you prefer red varietals over white. The guy who started it all chose Washington in favor of Napa, so go ahead and feel flattered while you sip. Voted as one of the best wineries to visit in Washington.

data.title: ABEJAH WINERY
data.description: You need to stay at the inn here to be able to enjoy a wine tour. Fine, twist our arm. From the moment you’re greeted with a glass of cab, the staff is trying to get to know you in order to find out exactly what’s best to offer. We wish we had more refined tastes for them to work off of.

data.title: NOVELTY HILL-JANUIK
data.description: When these two independent winemakers decided to join forces, they created a perfect storm for wine tasting. And, it’s a family affair, with the son running Novelty Hill and the parents running Januik. Pair that with one of the best-designed facilities in the state, and you’ve got a destination winery that can’t be missed.

data.title: LONG SHADOWS VINTNERS
data.description: Arguably the most prestigious name in this group, Long Shadows is an understated masterclass in Washington winemaking. The combination of five world-class winemakers and unprecedented access to premium land in the Columbia Valley has resulted in seven different top-tier labels. Makes sense that these would sell out quickly online, so head to the winery to try them all. Nice, ok, we feel more cultured already, and we haven’t been out there yet this season! Can you imagine how good it’s going to feel kicking back on one of these patios, sipping some of the country’s best wine? Us too, we’re hitting up our friends about it tonight.

data.title: Casco Antiguo
data.description: Authentic Mexican rides the line between familiar and exotic. The tamer people will be content with a couple of tacos or enchiladas. The adventurous might instead want some plantain empanadas or the pozole, which is braised pork and hominy in guajillo broth.

data.title: Damn the Weather
data.description:
One block away from Casco lies this upscale restaurant that focuses on American fare. Think progressive though, with options like smoked arctic char, roasted squash and steak frites available. Related Posts:
Seattle is getting scooter sharing… soon-ish
Guide: 10 of the coolest buildings to see in Seattle
data.when: Sunday to Wednesday, 11AM-11PM and Thursday to Saturday, 11AM-12AM

data.title: Tat’s Delicatessen
data.description: The first of two delis worthy of this list. Tat’s is a hearty spot that is famous for their Philly Cheesesteak, so keep that in mind before you head down. Of course, you can also get a hoagie or a hot sub, but know that it’s for those who are hungry.

data.title: Piroshki on 3rd
data.description: This counter-service cafe has a special place in our hearts. First, the piroshkis are like Russian calzones and are amazing. Second, they do some dang good pierogies. Third, their daily specials are to die for. We’re talking stroganoff, goulash, and cutlets. Woah, baby.

data.title: Nijo Sushi
data.description: While it’s a couple of blocks outside of Pioneer Square, we’re including Nijo. These guys do all sorts of Japanese dishes, ranging from agedashi tofu to short ribs to bento boxes. We like it because of the variety of tasty dishes.

data.title: Delicatus
data.description: Our second deli pick. Delicatus looks and sounds a little more upscale than TAT’s but the sandwiches are still reasonably priced and downright delicious. We love the Reuben, but you can’t go wrong here.
data.when: Monday to Friday, 11AM-7PM, Wednesday til 7:30 PM

data.title: Il Corvo
data.description: Obviously, we were going to include Il Corvo on this list. Quite possibly the most famous lunch spot in the city, this iconic restaurant creates pasta dishes daily and is one of the few places where we’re happy to line up. And there is our guide to the best lunch places in (and technically around) Pioneer Square. Soon you’ll be the office foodie, but don’t worry, your secret is safe with us.

data.title: Breezy Town Pizza
data.description: One of two spots in the city that excel at pan pizza. Rather than doing exclusively Chicago or Detroit style, Breezy Town opts for a tongue in cheek approach, creating a pizza that transports you to the best spot in a midwestern town.
data.when: Monday to Thursday, 4PM-12AM, Friday, 4PM-1: 30 AM, Saturday, 11AM-1: 30 AM and Sunday, 11AM-11PM
data.where: : 4864 Beacon Ave S, inside Clok-out Lounge

data.title: Big Mario’s Pizza
data.description:
A New York-style staple that has three locations around the city.The perfect place to swing by for a single slice while you’re out and about. Or, stick around a while and get a beer to wash it down. Related Posts:
An exclusive look at the prettiest vintage in Seattle
Guide: How to spend 48 hours in Seattle
data.when: Varies by location by open late
data.where: : Capitol Hill, Queen Anne, and Fremont locations

data.title: Dino’s Tomato Pie
data.description: From the people behind Delancey comes Dino’s. Serving up both New Jersey round pizza and Sicilian rectangular, Dino’s is the place to grab a little something if you’re in Capitol Hill. Best website by far on this list, too.
data.when: Sunday to Wednesday, 4PM-12AM, and Thursday to Saturday, 4PM-2AM

data.title: Rocco’s
data.description: Hip spot downtown that pairs contemporary flavors with tasty cocktails. This is the place to go if you’re looking for an extended pizza extravaganza with a few friends before going out later.

data.title: Pizzeria 22
data.description: These guys have great prices considering they are part of the prestigious VPN certified group. Italians are protective of their foods, with pizza being no different, and a VPN certification demonstrates perfection when it comes to Neopolitan style pies.
data.when: Sunday to Thursday, 4PM-10PM, and Friday to Saturday, 4PM-11PM

data.title: Proletariat
data.description: Billed as ‘the pizza that made White Centre famous’, Proletariat makes the trip out here more than worth it. Grab something simple, like maybe the REAL Hawaiian made with SPAM, or test out a pizza like White Centre White, that foregoes tomato sauce. Good space for kids, too.
data.when: Monday to Thursday, 4PM-9PM, Friday/Saturday, 12PM-11PM and Sunday, 12PM-9PM

data.title: Slice Box Pizza
data.description: Great spot for grab and go pizza that’s only a few blocks from T-Mobile Park. Thin crust and Sicilian style pizzas are the norm, with tables available if you want to save some money and grab a beer before a baseball game.

data.title: Supreme
data.description: Now with locations in both West Seattle and the University District, Supreme offers delicious, contemporary New York pizza. Like Rocco’s, it’s best to head over with a few friends and take advantage of their great bar program.
data.where: : 4521 California Avenue SW and 4529 University Way NE

data.title: Windy City Pie
data.description: The other pan pizza staple in Seattle, and affiliated with Breezy Town Pizza. The OG spot for delicious Chicago-style deep dish. They’re sourdough based crust and the delicious caramelized cheese make it a winner in our minds.
data.when: Sunday/Wednesday/Thursday, 4PM-10PM and Friday/Saturday, 4PM-11PM, Closed Monday and Tuesday

data.title: World Pizza
data.description: This spot gets the nod because they do vegetarian pizzas better than any other spot in the city. Because, after all, who said that pizza can’t be health food? Although we have to admit that wasabi pineapple doesn’t sound super appetizing. And that’s our first list for great pizza in Seattle! Stay tuned as we continue to explore the city.
data.when: Monday to Thursday, 10AM-9PM, Friday, 10AM-10PM, Saturday, 12PM-10PM and Sunday, 12PM-8PM

data.title: Bisato
data.description: Scott Carsberg spent 20 years in Belltown and earned himself a James Beard award for Best Chef in the Northwest back in 2006. Now, he has reopened Bisato after a 7-year hiatus in Pioneer Square. It’s a more casual experience in comparison to his first venture, Lampreia. Venetian cuisine dominates the menu, and Bisato is sure to become a top choice for Italian.
data.when: Tuesday to Saturday, 5PM-12AM and Sunday, 5PM-10PM, Closed Monday

data.title: Aerlume
data.description: This upscale spot is just steps away from Pike Place and is sure to become one of the hottest restaurants in the city once patio season rolls around. It is the brainchild of Jason Miller (of the Lakehouse and Miller’s Guild) and El Gaucho hospitality. Aerlume focuses on farm to table cuisine, with a seasonal menu.

data.title: Lucky Santo
data.description: When Nikki DeGidio got diagnosed with celiac disease, she thought that her time in the restaurant industry was over. Fortunately for us, her mentor and friend Jason Stoneburner helped her dream up Lucky Santo. With a focus on paleo, Lucky Santo will appeal to those who are trying to eat healthier or have dietary restrictions but still want an amazing meal.

data.title: Jack’s BBQ
data.description: Arguably the best spot for Texas BBQ in Washington, Jack’s has expanded from their original location in SoDo to South Lake Union. So now, it’s easier than ever to treat yourself to some brisket. Maybe wait a couple of weeks for the lines to die down though, we have a feeling this place will be busy for a while.
data.when: Monday to Friday, 7AM-10AM/11AM-8PM, and Saturday, 11AM-8PM, Closed Sunday

data.title: Meg’s Hamburgers
data.description: From the owners of Altstadt comes this retro-inspired burger joint. Smashed burgers and soft buns are the focus here. Like Jack’s BBQ, once the hype cools down it will become a great place to swing by for a quick lunch. Grab a simple hamburger, Meg’s Melt (a NY Bodega specialty with smash burger, swiss cheese, onions, and sauce), or keep it simple with a fried PB&J. And that’s our list of new restaurants in Seattle! Hopefully, there are a couple of spots on here that you’ve yet to try.

data.title: The Pink Door
data.description: Named after the beautiful pink door that you walk through prior to entering, this restaurant’s interior is even cooler than the exterior. With a vintage pinstripe theme across the booths, giant floor-to-ceiling windows, and antique gold mirrors hanging across the shiplap and exposed brick walls, it is clear that this Italian hotspot did not hold back on their interior vision.

data.title: The Hart & The Hunter – Palisociety Hotel
data.description: Located in the Palihotel, this restaurant is absolutely stunning. With the black and white checkered floor tieing in the pistachio green leather on the booths and rustic white painted walls together seamlessly, this space is perfect for an intimate soirée. Every detail is what makes an experience truly memorable, and it’s clear that this was carefully considered throughout the design process for The Heart and the Hunter.

data.title: Oddfellows Cafe
data.description: From the expert Seattle food and drink crew, The Derschang Group, comes this delightful cafe and bar that we can’t get enough of. The rustic, industrial restaurant is the perfect spot to settle down with some work, snap a selfie, and then scroll through Insta for 2 hours. We’re not kidding…once you’re in here, time flies and you absolutely won’t want to be leaving.

data.title: Tulio Ristorante
data.description: Sometimes there is plenty of beauty to find in simplicity, and the ultra-classy, ultra-classic Tulio Ristorante defends that notion wonderfully. Dark wooden finishes, old-school ambiance, and high-brow service and offerings round out the entire experience.

data.title: Little Neon Taco
data.description: This Mexican taco spot is as modern as it is timeless. With a custom built-in-shelving unit full of plants, vintage coke and Mexican jarritos bottles, the shelf brings artwork to the walls all on its own. The tall, rattan bar stools are tropical and bohemian, and take us back to a hot vacation day in a heartbeat. Small details like the hot pink tips on the bottoms of the dining chairs show that no element was overlooked when designing this joint.

data.title: Bar Melusine
data.description: Clean lines, white walls, and dream decor make this an Instagrammer’s dream. If you’re looking for a fresh splash of delicious food and gorgeous atmosphere, then Bar Melusine has you covered in spades. This is a perfect spot for the spring and summer, so get a move on, people!

data.title: Wilmott’s Ghost
data.description: When talking about beautiful restaurants in Seattle, it is impossible to leave off Wilmott’s Ghost. Brushed full of millennial pinks and a bright, playful atmosphere, we’re pretty sure your Instagram followers will go crazy over this one. The mid-century design of Wilmott’s Ghost is unique and oh-so visually appealing. From navy blue booths that wrap around a round marble table with a pastel green bottom to the gold light fixtures and rich mahogany seating, this resto is worth a visit and definitely a selfie or two. Oh, and it’s inside The Spheres, so that should tell you enough about how cool it is.

data.title: Tallulah’s
data.description: Oh, go figure…it’s another restaurant from The Derschang Group! We’re not complaining, though. Tallulah’s has earned a spot in the hearts of every Seattle decor-lover who has walked through its doors. From the lush hanging plants to the walls filled with eclectic paintings, pictures, and posters, every nook & cranny has a new decor surprise.

data.title: Atulea
data.description: Okay, so we might be cheating with this one. Even though it’s not quite a ‘restaurant’ in the traditional sense, this modern-day tea room is one of the most Instagrammable places we’ve seen in a while. The interior features an entire wall filled with pink walls and banana leaf wallpaper (hello selfies), coveted mid-century chairs, speckled white countertops, tiny square subway tiles, and tons of adorable details. The food and drink are just as picture perfect so be sure to order yourself a matcha latte and donut when you stop by. Gotta pump the foodiegram, after all.

data.title: One of the nations largest carnivals is happening in Washington State this weekend & here's where
data.description:
The cherry blossoms may be on their way out but the rest of the state’s blooms are on the way in. Between wildflowers and now the Washington State Apple Blossom Festival, there’s plenty to see. Here’s what to expect from one of spring’s sweetest festivals. The festival runs for over a week and is a celebration of apple blossoms, the beginning of stage one of the fruits that Washington produces the most of. It also happens to be the oldest major festival in the state of Washington, with the first festival happening in 1920. So if you love apples, state history, and spring you definitely don’t want to miss this! Recent Posts:
Here’s the tea: The first ever Seattle Boba Fest is happening in the U District this weekend
You can celebrate an authentic medieval Mayday at Camlann Village this weekend  The festival has all sorts of events for attendees to enjoy. Check out events like a food fair featuring eats from Kaleenka Piroshky, Keep it in the Valley Funnel Cakes, Ali’i Hawaiin Shave Ice, and more. There’s also a massive carnival (America’s 7th largest), live performances and even eating contests. That’s not all though, there’s seriously an event for everyone and you need to view the calendar for yourself. Best of all, there’s no main ticket to attend the festival. That being said, there are individual tickets for things like the carnival so make sure you know which events you’d like to attend. Enjoy folks and happy spring!

data.title: Maris Farms Baby Animals and Blooms Days kick off this weekend & here's what to expect
data.description:
Is there a better way to kick off spring than with some beautiful blooms and super cute farm animals? Probably not. If that sounds up your alley you’re going to want to head to Maris Farms because their Baby Animals and Blooms Days are back! This event is all about embracing the potential of spring. You’ll find a local farmer’s market, vendors, adult, and baby animal cuteness, as well as fields of beautiful blooms. It’s an event that’s great for folks of all ages with something for everyone to see, enjoy and experience. Recent Posts:
The massive Waterfront Seattle project is taking shape & here’s what’s new this year
You can celebrate an authentic medieval Mayday at Camlann Village this weekend  Your admission includes access to activities like a Wagon Ride, Cow Train Ride, Low Ropes Course, Conk the Crow, and Roller Bowler. Plus Hilltop favorites like Gaga Ball, Bee-line Ziplines, Wall Mazes, Human Foos Ball, Trike Track, Tubeslides, and Barnyard Ball Zone. That means you can either simply wander the farm or enjoy some playtime and burn off all the delicious farm foods. When it comes to the blooms you’ll be able to view them, take pictures and even purchase cut tulips if your heart desires. As always we recommend planning ahead and purchasing your tickets in advance, especially because this is a popular event that is likely to sell out and also because you get a better admission price when purchasing online. Enjoy!

data.title: See more than 80 life size dinosaurs at this new immersive exhibit in Seattle
data.description:
Let’s be honest, all of us at least once in our lives have probably wanted to see what it would have been like to take a step back in time. Especially to an era with dinosaurs. Luckily you can do that and more starting next week at Dinos Alive, a brand new immersive experience here in Seattle. Dinos Alive features more than 80 life-size animated dinosaur replicas in an immersive Jurassic venue. You’ll have the opportunity to walk alongside the massive creatures that once roamed our world millions of years ago. Plus this way you don’t have to worry about all the dangerous aspects of interacting with dinos. Recent Posts:
The Seattle International Film Festival returns next week
Did you know? You can go fossil digging in Washington State  You’ll get to see all of your favorite species including T-rex, Stegosaurus, Ankylosaurus, Velociraptors, and many more. Additionally you can dive into the depths of the seas and interact with Jurassic sea giants in a unique virtual aquarium. To make things even more immersive you can also partake in a captivating VR experience. Dinos Alive is a fun and interactive way for people of all ages to learn about the triassic, jurassic and cretaceous periods. So do something different this month, you have until June to add a little jurassic fun into your life. Tickets are on sale now and as always we recommend thinking ahead and buying beforehand.

data.title: The Freakout Weekender is a new two day music festival happening this April
data.description:
Can’t wait for music festival season? Turns out you don’t have to, between April’s concert lineup and now The Freakout Weekender, you’ll have days upon days to listen to tunes. Let’s get into some details on what to expect from this two-day music festival. The Freakout Weekender comes from the folks behind Freakout Festival. While it’s only two days long it’s bigger than you might think. “The multi-venue, multi-cultural Seattle music festival will feature over 40 artists from around the globe, including Antibalas, Austra, Molly Burch, Armand Hammer, Efterklang, Surfbort, Tunde Olaniran, Cobra Man, Public Memory, Mintfield, and many more.” Recent Posts:
April Showers: Here’s a look at the extended Seattle spring forecast
The Seattle Public Library just added 5 new partners to it’s Museum Pass program  If you’ve been wanting to see new live music, this is the festival for you. The lineup is full of names that you probably haven’t heard of before. Whether you want to hear hip hop, garage rock, punk rock, afrobeat, there’s a genre for you. Like most events and concerts around the city, we highly recommend planning ahead and purchasing your tickets ASAP. It’s also worth noting that you have the option of choosing between one day, two day, and VIP passes depending on what you’re looking for. So get out there and treat yourself to a rocking April!

data.title: The first annual U District Cherry Blossom Festival kicks off this Friday
data.description:
The best way to celebrate Seattle’s cherry blossoms is, of course, by visiting them. But it doesn’t hurt to enjoy a little bit of extra celebration, especially when it’s a new festival. The first annual U District Cherry Blossom Festival kicks off this Friday and you don’t want to miss it! The main focus here is the blossoms. But the festival also has some enticing offerings like drink specials, eats, and shopping opportunities. Some of the drink specials you can snag include a Cherry Lemon Blossom Saison from Big Time Brewery, a Vodka-Up Cherry Blossom Cocktail from Agua Verde Café, and even a Cherry Blossom Mocha from Café Allegro. Recent Posts:
April Showers: Here’s a look at the extended Seattle spring forecast
The Seattle Public Library just added 5 new partners to it’s Museum Pass program  When it comes to eats you can enjoy a Cherry Bucket Combo from BB.Q Chicken, a Pink Cherry Blossom Noodle Soup from Kai’s Thai Street Food & Bar, and Sakura Ice Cream from Sweet Alchemy Ice Creamery. The full list of drinks and eats specials for the festival is quite long so you can try a few different offerings while it’s running. When it comes to shopping you can stop into several local businesses to pick up prints, gear, and more all centered on the beautiful cherry blossoms. If you need even more from this fest you can also partake in the Cherry Blossom Run, and visit the waterfront Cantina Bloom Garden. Sounds like the perfect way to start spring!

data.title: Nordo's immersive cabaret Down The Rabbit Hole returns this April
data.description:
If you’re looking to be transported out of this world this spring you may just want to head to Nordo. Due to popular demand, they’re remounting their smash hit, multi-sensory cabaret Down The Rabbit Hole this Spring. It’s everything you loved from years past with brand new additions. Down The Rabbit Hole is centered around the themes of Lewis Carroll’s Alice In Wonderland. You’ll get to watch as your favorite tales like “The Walrus and the Carpenter” and “The Stolen Tart” are set to original music and performed by a local cast. It’s an experience designed to cater to all the senses. Recent Posts:
The Seattle-Tacoma International Airport is about to get a major facelift
5 eye-catching live performances you can watch in Seattle this month  Beyond the show, you can expect a seasonal four-course tasting menu as well as drinks for purchase, custom-designed art installations, and an unexpected, new whimsical experience. What’s more, the immersive art installations have been created by local artists to make the event more special. Another addition to this year’s performance includes super fun after-show karaoke. As this show is quite popular we highly recommend purchasing your tickets ahead of time. It’s a great event to check out with your SO, friends or experience it as part of a celebration like your birthday. You can learn more and grab tickets at Nordo’s website.

data.title: The Spring Fair returns in person to Washington this April
data.description:
Are you ready for spring? We sure are too and if you’re looking for a way to celebrate the return of brighter days, why not head to The Spring Fair? It’s taking place at the Washington State Fairground this April over the course of two weekends. So what can you expect? Like years past you’ll be able to see the main attraction, all sorts of cute fuzzy baby animals, livestock, livestock shows, and more. Additionally, you’ll be able to see shows like DockDogs,  Swifty Swine Racing Pigs, and Motorsport Mayhem. Whatever you’re hoping to watch, it’s almost a guarantee the fair has it. Recent Posts:
5 of the best food & drink festivals to look forward to in Seattle this spring
The 11 best places to see cherry blossoms in Seattle this spring  Now cute animals and shows aren’t the only things you’ll be able to check out. You can also test your bravery and enjoy some good old-fashioned fair rides. And if you’re hungry you can nosh on one of the many unique fair food offerings. Fried butter anyone? So grab your family, your friends, whoever, and plan ahead for one of Washington’s best celebrations of spring.

data.title: Thing at Fort Worden is back this year with a truly incredible venue & lineup
data.description:
Summer 2022 is jam packed with concerts and music festivals. Thing at Fort Worden is returning this year with a star studded line up of both local and international musicians and artists. Expect a distinctive mix of music, comedy, visual arts, speakers, and much more. Thing is taking place in late August on the historic grounds of Fort Worden. If you haven’t been to the fort before it is one of the most spectacular and unique settings in the PNW. The fort encompasses “434 acres with 12 miles of forested hiking trails, 2 miles of walkable saltwater beaches and commanding views of the Puget Sound.” Recent Posts:
The Capitol Hill Block Party lineup just got release & tickets are on sale now
ZooTunes returns to Woodland Park Zoo this summer with a legendary line up  As it was once an active military base, attendees will be able to see the base in a new light with 2 outdoor stages, McCurdy Pavilion a former balloon hangar converted into a theatre, and the Wheeler Theatre an intimate art deco venue. Clearly the venue is out of this world but what about the performing artists? This years lineup includes acts like Freddie Gibbs, Yves Tumor, Faye Webster, Modest Mouse, Father John Misty, Jose Gonzalez and more. So plan ahead and don’t miss out on what is sure to be one of the best music festivals in the PNW this summer. Psst tickets go on sale Friday, February 25th.

data.title: You can watch people race motorcycles on ice later this month in Washington
data.description:
Why go to a regular old sports game when you can watch people race motorcycles on ice? Trust us we’re not pulling your leg, this is a very real thing. And if you didn’t know it was a thing, don’t worry, we too just found out about it. That being said, XTreme International Ice Racing is coming to Washington this month and you don’t want to miss out. So how exactly does the race work? The main event consists of six riders for six laps riding high-speed Speedway bikes. Because these bikes are so high powered they can only withstand shorter total amounts of laps but it doesn’t make the event any less engaging. Recent Posts:
Here are the best new bakeries to check out in Seattle this February
You can rent this historic schoolhouse Airbnb right here in Washington  Keep in mind that throughout the event you’ll get to watch twenty to twenty-five races depending on how many local riders participate. And in the case of Washington’s event, the race will be going down at Angel of the Winds Arena so you’ll be able to relax indoors which the riders race laps. It’s almost guaranteed to be an event unlike any you’ve attended before. Tickets are on sale now and like other events, we’d recommend buying them ASAP. And you know, tell your friends this is happening because we can imagine it being an eve of great fun. Enjoy folks!

data.title: Here's a look at the world's first NFT Museum in Seattle & it's next show
data.description:
The NFT world keeps getting bigger each day and it’s grown by leaps and bounds right here in Seattle, especially because we now have the world’s first NFT Museum. The Seattle NFT Museum opened its door this past January as a brand new and exciting glimpse into the world of crypto art. Ready to take a look? The new NFT Museum opened with an exhibition showcasing all sorts of works, ranging from generative art to 1:1 to 3D rendering and more. Some of the featured artists were even local, like Neon Saltwater and Charles Peterson. Alongside screens showing the unique works, visitors will also find a wall that breaks down exactly what an NFT is, a gift shop, and an Ethereum mining machine. But as the crypto world evolves so rapidly, the NFT Museum is also rotating its shows to give viewers a new set of works to check out. Recent Posts:
2 Seattle spots made the Most Romantic Restaurants in America 2022 list
The 10 most popular movies set in Washington state according to IMDb The museum’s second exhibition will highlight pioneering women in the early history of NFT art. The exhibition includes seven artists, two collectors, and one collection. What’s extra cool about it is that three of the artists are from or currently live in Seattle, they include Jessica Greenwalt, Sage Sarvie, and Kelsey Johnson. The exhibition will run from February 26th through the month of March, coinciding with Women’s History Month. So take this opportunity to check out something new and get your eyes on a real NFT. Who knows, it might just become your new favorite museum.

data.title: Hales Ales has a drunken science experiment extravaganza this weekend
data.description:
Looking for an evening of scientific fun with drinks involved? Science Night is back at Hales Ales, you can enjoy a science experiment extravaganza inside of Hales beautiful Palladium Theater. It’s certainly one of the more unique and hands-on ways to enjoy a brew this weekend. Your admission covers all of your supplies for the evening meaning you can try dozens of experiments. Whether you want to blow things up with air, make metal levitate, or create unbreakable bubbles, the opportunity is there. Expect Tesla Coils, a laser tunnel, and some more indescribable things as well. Recent Posts:
10 of the best things to do in & around Seattle this weekend (January 28th-30th)
Brighter days are here: The sunset in Seattle is now happening after 5 pm  via GIPHY Beyond experimenting, you’ll also be able to watch mind-boggling performances by inventor Johnny Jetpack and Isaac Vicknair. And if you happen to have a cool science gadget or science joke, you can show it off at the show and tell and science joke contest on the main stage. No matter what you want to do, there’s something for you at this event. This event normally sells out so be sure to buy your tickets ASAP in order to avoid disappointment. Have fun and drink responsibly.

data.title: Your car will actually drive itself up this magnetic hill in Washington
data.description:
Washington is home to many wild and wacky things. Perhaps one of the most unique is Prosser’s Gravity Hill. As the name suggests, this hill appears to defy gravity as it is known to “pull” cars up a  minor incline on the road. You can make the trip east to test it out yourself, but be prepared for an inexplicable experience. So how does one use the hill? All you have to do is make the drive east and put your car into neutral at the ‘Start’ line painted on Crosby road, et voila! You’re magically pulled up the hill! According to Atlas Obscura, the grain elevator at the end of the road is haunted. And while we tend to take these things with a grain of salt, we wouldn’t expect anything less from a site that offers a seemingly impossible experience. Now before you get too spooked, people have many theories about why the hill does what it does. Some of those theories include optical illusions and of course, the ‘haunted’ grain elevator, but the real explanation might not be as exciting as the latter. Magnetic or ‘gravity’ hills exist all over the world, and one simple explanation is that these small inclines are part of larger declines that we can’t see or process, causing us to believe that we’re being pulled upwards. Related posts:
6 natural hot springs in Washington state that will melt your winter blues
6 exciting winter day trips near Seattle to try this year  With all that in mind its still a fun and truly unique day trip that you can take right here in our state. Not to mention, it’s Washington’s only gravity-defying hill. So if you live in the state, you should definitely check it out at least once. While the road is public access keep in mind that the land around it is privately owned. And of course, use your best judgment and be safe when checking out this phenomenon. As always if you give it a go be sure to let us know what happens and maybe even take a video or two because we’ll admit, we’re curious.

data.title: Cirque du Soleil returns to Seattle next week with a brand new show
data.description:
Starting next week, Cirque du Soleil’s captivating magic will return to Redmond’s Marymoor Park. The traveling circus’ newest performance is a classic Cirque du Soleil show reimagined for a new generation with intricate costumes and an array of sounds and genres. It’s a must-see experience for those of you who have missed live performances. Cirque du Soleil and Seattle actually have a long history. The traveling group has been visiting our rainy city for over three decades with all sorts of different performances, artists, and themes. While each show may vary, the one constant is the wonder that ensues. Recent Posts:
The coziest pub crawl of the year returns to Seattle later this month
30 of the absolute best things to do in & around Seattle this January  As this show is a beloved classic, its reinvention is sure to be engaging. The biggest changes include set, costumes, makeup, music, and even the plot. Think of it like the show has been stripped down to its bare bones, the essence is still there but the look is entirely different. That fact alone feels pretty relatable considering the constant state of flux and reinvention our world is in these days. So treat yourself to a world of fire breathers, acrobats, and pure artistry this month. As these shows are popular we recommend purchasing your tickets sooner rather than later. With that enjoy and have a great week.
data.where: : 6046 West Lake Sammamish Parkway NE Redmond, WA

data.title: You can watch banned films during this series from SIFF this month
data.description:
There’s a lot more to watch than just Netflix this January. Between the Sundance Film Festival and SIFF’s BANNED! Film Talks series, you’ll have no shortage of on-screen entertainment. Ready to see some of history’s most provocative films? BANNED! is for you. The five-part SIFF Film Talks series looks at films throughout time that “were deemed too dangerous by authorities for viewing.” Some of the controversial topics explored and displayed in these films include religion, indecency, and colonial legacy among others. The films are broken up into five talks and three live screenings at SIFF Film Center. All of the talks are taught by John Trafton and will also be available virtually through live streaming via Zoom. Recent Posts:
This Seattle pop-up serves a new hyper-local & organic menu every 2 weeks
Washingtonians have ranked among the best in the nation for keeping New Year’s resolutions  While the idea of banned film or content may seem like an old notion, it actually does still happen. Because of that, you’ll get to watch an array of films dating from the early 1900s all the way up until 2018. And if you want to watch some of the films in person, the three live screenings include The Battle of Algiers, In The Realm of the Senses, and Rafiki. When it comes to the talks some of the films discussed include Haxan, All Quiet on the Western Front, I am Curious (Yellow), and The Last Temptation of Christ. If you’re looking to watch something new and learn, this series is for you. Now here’s the deal, it begins tomorrow so snag your tickets.

data.title: The coziest pub crawl of the year returns to Seattle later this month
data.description:
