Remember pyjama day in elementary school? Well it turns out there’s an equally, maybe more fun adult version that you can partake in this month. The 4th annual Onesie Pub Crawl is happening in Downtown Seattle later this month and you don’t want to miss it. The crawl comes from the folks behind the uber popular SantaCon and operates in a similar manner. It’s a tad different than pyjama day, but definitely still in the same vein. After all, it doesn’t get much cozier than running around town in your favorite onesie. Recent Posts:
10 of the coolest things to do for free or cheap in Seattle this January
Washingtonians have ranked among the best in the nation for keeping New Year’s resolutions What’s cool about these crawls is that you can participate for just a few hours or up to 14, if you’re really feeling it. Once you have your wristband you’re able to check in anytime after noon. You’ll get to enjoy live entertainment throughout, no cover charges, drink specials, and a costume contest with cash prizes! Everyone is welcome and last year over 1,500 people attended so expect to make some new onesie loving friends. As always we recommend purchasing your tickets early especially because you can score $10 pre sale tickets right now.

data.title: You can enjoy a snowy sleigh ride straight from a fairytale at this WA spot
data.description:
“Dashing through the snow, In a one-horse open sleigh, O’er the fields we go, Laughing all the way.” Ready to make that a reality? You can have a magical holiday experience in the best Christmas town in the country thanks to Leavenworth Sleigh Rides. Leavenworth has a whole host of sleigh rides for you to choose from. Whether you’re looking for a more intimate experience with up to 6 people or Santa’s Sleigh with up to 16 people they have you covered. All rides come with a piping hot cup of cider to enjoy with some rides even stopping by an open fire. Recent Posts: 
5 local Seattle organizations to donate to this holiday season
Will it be a white Christmas in Seattle this year? Here’s an early look  Thanks to the pandemic your sleigh ride will actually be private so go with your SO or bestie or invite up to 16 people from your crew. It’s a great way to get outdoors during the winter and enjoy 40-50 minutes of a beautiful snowscape rarely seen in the city. And you’ll definitely snap some great insta pictures while you’re out there too. Keep in mind that for rides this year you’ll need to bring your own blankets so don’t forget them. You’ll also be required to wear a mask when indoors but again, that’s pretty standard these days. If you’d like to learn more or book your ride you can click below.

data.title: An adults-only Holiday Night Market takes place at Pike Place this week
data.description:
There are many ways to enjoy Pike Place Market during the holiday season. This week you’ll be able to enjoy an adults-only event that’s perfect for exploring the market and getting your gift shopping done. So get your tote bags and get ready to shop till you drop. Pike Place Market’s Holiday Night Market takes place this Thursday, December 16th. The MarketFront Pavilion will turn into a winter wonderland complete with seasonal cocktails, hand-made gifts, food, and music. Whether you’re having a sip at the Polar Bar or shopping from one of the 33 vendors it will be a night to remember. Recent Posts:
Pike Place Market’s Can Can is putting on a dazzling winter burlesque show this holiday season
Will it be a white Christmas in Seattle this year? Here’s an early look  Some of the featured vendors include Seattle Candle Company, Buddha Bath, Weird Woods, and more. You can feel good shopping this holiday market knowing that the items being sold are handcrafted by local artisans. And that also means you’re sure to find unique items that you both did and didn’t know you needed. Keep in mind you will need to provide proof of vaccination in order to attend but that’s pretty uniform these days. You can find more details if need be by clicking the link below. Enjoy folks!

data.title: Catch a first-of-its-kind screening of Nirvana's '91 Paramount Theatre show this weekend
data.description:
On Halloween of 1991, one of Seattle’s most iconic concerts happened at The Paramount Theatre. The band playing was Nirvana, tickets were $10 and only 2,800 people got to attend. It was the first leg of their “Nevermind” tour and if you weren’t one of the lucky few to attend, you’ll actually be able to watch it again this month. Sadly Kurt hasn’t risen but “Nirvana – Live at the Paramount” will play at the Paramount on December 12th. It’s the first time the recording has been played to an audience at the place where it was originally filmed. So if you want to be a part of the 2.0 history of this concert, you might as well purchase some tickets. Recent Posts:
A CBB analyst said the NBA should return to Seattle & folks are excited
Seattle just ranked as the most caffeinated city in the nation  Beyond watching the recording of the performance you’ll also get to watch and hear opening bands THEM and the Black Tones instead of Mudhoney and Bikini Kill. And The Black Tones set will be mixed by Craig Montgomery, Nirvana’s sound engineer who did the audio at the Paramount concert 30 years ago. So it’ll be the perfect blend of old and new to honor this iconic concert. To make things even better, the screening benefits YouthCare, which is a nonprofit that works to end youth homelessness. For the time being, tickets are still available but we recommend purchasing them ASAP. You can learn more by clicking below.

data.title: You can check out 38 life-size LEGO models at Seattle's 'Awesome Exhibition'
data.description:
Everything is awesome, especially when life-sized LEGOs are involved. The Awesome Exhibition is open in Seattle and full of awe-inspiring life-size LEGO models for folks of all ages to enjoy. Seriously, you’ll forget that you’re an adult when checking out these amazing displays of creativity and LEGO skill. The Awesome Exhibition features 38 different models made from more than two million LEGO bricks, taking over 4,800 hours to build aka 201 days. If you think you’re a skilled LEGo builder just wait until you see models like a 24.5 foot tall NASA SLS Rocket and the first life-sized LEGO Harley Davidson. Recent Posts:
Here are 5 of the best places to go indoor roller skating around Seattle
55 of the absolute best things to do in & around Seattle this December  Expect to see and interact with depictions of real-life places, vehicles, and animals. You’ll get to experience LEGO as not only an artistic medium, but also as a platform for interaction, collaboration, and education. Basically, you’ll get all the joy of LEGOs that you did when you were a kid but with a more grown-up outlook. The Awesome Exhibition is on for a limited time only so we recommend purchasing those tickets soon and while you can. If you’d like to learn more or grab tickets you can click below. Enjoy folks!

data.title: Pike Place Market's Can Can is putting on a dazzling winter burlesque show this holiday season
data.description:
Pike Place Market’s beloved Can Can is back with another world-class dinner and theatre experience blending the best of dance, cabaret, and burlesque. It’s called Wonderland and is the perfect way to celebrate the holidays in a unique and memorable way. You’ll get to watch as Can Can’s “professional performers swing from the chandeliers into a show full of classic beauty and flirtatious artistry.” Expect nostalgia, dance, laughter, and all sorts of holiday cheer. It’s a show full of mesmerizing performances that will transport you to a winter wonderland. Recent Posts:
Enter the Land of the Sweets, Seattle’s Burlesque Nutcracker returns this December
55 of the absolute best things to do in & around Seattle this December  Not only will you be wowed by the performance but you’ll also get to see Can Can’s intimate theatre transformed into a whimsical winter chalet. To make things even more special you’ll find a  variety of food, wine, and spirit menus carefully crafted with local market-fresh winter ingredients, at the Can Can’s kitchen & bar.  You’ll get to eat, drink, and be merry in a wintry Wonderland to remember. If you’d like to learn more or grab tickets you can click below. As always we recommend planning ahead and purchasing tickets ASAP. Enjoy folks and happy holidays!

data.title: A holiday light display featuring local artists opens in Freeway Park this week
data.description:
There is no shortage of unique light displays to check out in Seattle this holiday season. From Argosy Christmas Ships to WildLanterns you have so many options. But why not check out one that’s free and created by local artists? Freeway Park Illuminations 2021: “Wayfinding” selected 7 artists to create light displays with a common goal of helping people reconnect. That goal surfaced after the year and a half that all of us spent in various forms of isolation and happens to tie in well with the holiday season as it can be isolating for some folks. Each piece illuminates the stroll through Freeway Park with welcoming installations that bring light and color to the area. Recent Posts:
Seattle has a retro Christmas pop-up hidden in an auto-garage
55 of the absolute best things to do in & around Seattle this December  Each piece has its own unique meaning and you can learn about them by clicking here. If you want to be one of the first to check out this exhibition you can attend an opening tomorrow night December 2nd. There will be music, refreshments, and self-guided tours to the art pieces through the park’s twinkling pathways and lit-up groves. Don’t miss this opportunity to see one of Seattle’s most unique parks in a whole new light. You can learn more about the opening event by clicking below.

data.title: Seattle has a retro Christmas pop-up hidden in an auto-garage
data.description:
Looking for the ultimate holiday experience? A converted garage might just be your best bet. Sounds crazy right? Well Otis and Sparky Kringle and ready to helo you have the most magical holiday yet at Kringles Filling Station. These two brothers come from a “long line of tinkerers, mechanics, engineers, and craftsmen whose family history and North Pole roots date back centuries.” They also happen to work for Hotopp Creative Studio. They’re an award-winning Seattle-based entertainment design firm specializing in attractions, experiences, and live events. So you know it’s going to be good with no details spared. Recent Posts:
Here are some of the best spots to get a Christmas tree around Seattle
11 romantic date ideas you have to try in Seattle this holiday season So what can you do at Kringles Filling Station? The answer is a whole lot. You can snap a holiday photo of your entire crew with Otis and Sparky in a one-of-a-kind sleigh or play Christmas Ski-Ball and belt your heart out to Holiday Karaoke. And when you’re burnt you can kick back and relax with a cup of hot chocolate from one of their very special gas pumps. Expect to see characters decked out in classic costumes as well as a converted garage full of old-timey decorations. It’s a perfectly retro Christmas experience that you won’t soon forget. And best of all, Otis and Sparky finished up their hard work early this year which means you can visit the filling station starting today, November 26th. If you’re ready to visit you can click below to learn more.

data.title: The Yuletide Express is a stunning Christmas tradition with views of Snoqualmie Falls
data.description:
‘Tis the season of holiday trains and from model trains to the Polar Express, Washington has it all. But the holiday train fun doesn’t stop there because you can also enjoy a ride on the Snoqualmie Yuletide Express. It’s a 25-minute holiday excursion full of holiday decorations, Christmas spirit, and more. Your journey embarks from the historic Snoqualmie Depot. Upon boarding your train car you’ll find seasonally decorated, antique coaches to enjoy as you travel west to Snoqualmie Falls. To make the journey even more magical, the train will briefly pause at the crest for a view of the river valley before returning to Snoqualmie. Recent Posts:
Enter the Land of the Sweets, Seattle’s Burlesque Nutcracker returns this December
11 romantic date ideas you have to try in Seattle this holiday season  Due to the trip’s relatively short span, it’s great for younger folks who might not want to sit still for an hour-long experience. Not to mention each child will receive a small gift from Santa to make the experience even more memorable. And while it certainly has a family-friendly focus, this ride is great for folks of all ages looking to experience a unique holiday tradition. Be sure to purchase your tickets online ahead of time and keep in mind that all folks 12 and older need to provide proof of vaccination or a negative Covid test taken within the last 72-hours. You’ll also need to wear a face mask for the entirety of your experience. But that’s the norm these days and if you’d like to learn more or grab tickets you can click below.

data.title: The Bellevue Botanical Garden will have over 500k holiday lights to explore
data.description:
Washington is off the charts with holiday light experiences this winter. From drive-thru holiday lights to wild lanterns, you have so many options. But if you live on the Eastside and are looking for something close to home, then you don’t want to miss out on Garden d’Lights. Garden d’Light’s is taking over the Bellevue Botanical Garden to bring an enchanting experience to the Eastside. You’ll be able to see the botanical garden like never before as over half a million lights illuminate the beauty of the garden. With the many unique lights and scenes, there’s sure to be something for everyone. Recent Posts:
11 romantic date ideas you have to try in Seattle this holiday season
16 festive holiday markets in & around Seattle you can’t miss this winter  You’ll see the shapes of plants, birds, animals, and cascading waterfalls. Be sure to look for many of your old favorites as well as some new surprises too. Go solo, with your friends or family, it’s a holiday experience that everyone can enjoy. Best of all, the display lights up starting this weekend. So be sure to hop online and purchase your tickets ahead of time. You can click below to learn more.
data.where: : Bellevue Botanical Garden, 12001 Main Street, Bellevue, 98005

data.title: Snowflake Lane returns to the Bellevue Collection starting this week
data.description:
Christmas magic will soon be in the air in Bellevue. The 17th annual Snowflake Lane is returning nightly at the Bellevue Collection starting this Friday, November 26th. You’ll be able to watch as the sidewalks fill with people hoping to catch a glimpse of this unique PNW holiday tradition. If you’ve never attended Snowflake Lane before, it takes place nightly at 7 pm throughout the holiday season. Spectators gather on the sidewalks between Bellevue Square and Lincoln Square from NE 4th to NE 8th to watch as Bellevue slips away and is replaced with a winter wonderland. Expect to see falling snow, dazzling lights, festive music, toy drummers, and dancers. Recent Posts:
Enter the Land of the Sweets, Seattle’s Burlesque Nutcracker returns this December
Here are 3 awesome spots to go ice skating in and around Seattle  While the parade is the star of the two you can also snap pics with Santa Claus at the Snowflake Lane Factory! Folks looking to grab pics can head to the second level of Bellevue Square Center Court to pose for a contactless photo with Santa. He’ll be making his list and checking it twice at his desk so be sure to be on your best behavior. The best part about this magical Christmas tradition is that it’s free! So why not check it out if you’re looking to get in the holiday spirit? You can learn more by clicking below and you can make restorations for pics with Santa by clicking here.
data.where: : Between Bellevue Square and Lincoln Square

data.title: Enter the Land of the Sweets, Seattle's Burlesque Nutcracker returns this December
data.description:
There have been a few ways to watch the Nutcracker this holiday season. And as much as we love the classic ballet version sometimes we all need to switch it up a bit. That’s why Land of the Sweets: The Burlesque Nutcracker is a great performance to add to your list of holiday events. Lily Verlaine and Jasper McCann have been producing this show in Seattle for 14 years making it a beloved classic in its own right. The show is refined and stunning, with professional dancers performing Verlaine’s choreography. You can expect to see a blend of classical techniques with burlesque for an end result that is beautiful, funny, and certainly unique. Recent Posts:
Here are 3 awesome spots to go ice skating in and around Seattle
11 romantic date ideas you have to try in Seattle this holiday season You’ll see the return of favorite characters from the story like Babette La Fave, the Snowflakes, and Lily Verlaine’s Baroness of Bon-Bons (the Sugar Plum Fairy). Accompanying these lively characters is a live nine-piece jazz orchestra, performing renditions of the Tchaikovsky score. To top it all off you’ll be wowed by stunning scenic pieces, opulent bespoke costuming, and of course, the original choreography and talent of the dancers. The performance is taking place at the Triple Door throughout December but keep in mind, guests need to be 17+ in order to attend and some shows are 21+. So find your perfect day to attend and gather your friends for what is sure to be one of the best holiday performances of the year. If you’d like to learn more you can click below for tickets and details.

data.title: You can ride take a ride on 'The Polar Express' in Washington this holiday season
data.description:
“From outside came the sounds of hissing steam and squeaking metal. I looked through my window and saw a train standing perfectly still in front of my house.” Don’t worry, animated Tom Hanks is not coming to get you but the Chehalis Centralia Railroad is. If you’ve ever wanted to hear the classic Christmas tale, The Polar Express, read aboard the train itself, now is your chance. Get ready to enjoy a magical ride to the North Pole. It’s family-friendly fun for everyone as you listen to The Polar Express, sip cocoa and have a visit with Santa aboard Chehalis Centralia Railroad. You’ll enjoy as characters from the story come to life and you can join in on carolling during your ride. Recent Posts:
Sippin Santa returns to Seattle as a holiday pop-up bar this month
GeekCraft Expo is coming to Seattle this month with over 100 ‘nerdy’ vendors
 via GIPHY To make things even more magical, the train ride takes place on a historic 1920’s train. Expect to see it decorated and you are encouraged to wear your coziest pyjamas and bring your favourite blanket. Because you might as well get in character as the passenger you are! Now here’s the deal, tickets are extremely limited and there are long waitlists for this experience. But if you head over to the Chehalis Centralia Railroad you may be able to find folks reselling tickets. That being said you can also try your luck at tickets by clicking below. Enjoy folks and start believing.

data.title: A first-of-its-kind trapeze performance happens in Seattle this weekend
data.description:
There’s an incredibly unique performance happening in Seattle this weekend. It’s called Dances in the Sky and it’s a visual and musical collaboration between Emerald City Trapeze Arts and the Seattle Metropolitan Chamber Orchestra. Trust us, even if performing arts aren’t exactly your thing, this might just change your mind. It’s an awe-inspiring Aerial performance featuring a world-class Flying Trapeze act led by internationally acclaimed flyer, Jordan Tribble. You’ll get to watch as performers take to the air performing against compositions by Johann Strauss, Jr., Claude Debussy, and Georges Bizet. What’s more, the show also features harpist, Sophie Baird-Daniel. Recent Posts:
Hip hop or ballet? You have options for seeing The Nutcracker in Seattle
Sippin Santa returns to Seattle as a holiday pop-up bar this month  But what exactly makes this performance so special? Well the combination of talented musicians and performers is enough but according to The Seattle Times, this performance may be the very first of its kind. “No one involved in “Dances in the Sky” has ever heard of live orchestra accompanying a flying trapeze act.” So treat yourself to what may prove to be a part of trapeze and orchestra history this weekend. The performance is 21+ and guests are encouraged to dress formally for the performance. So pull out your best dresses and suits, grab your friends and snag tickets while you still can. You can learn more and grab tickets by clicking below.

data.title: You can enjoy holiday displays, FREE Santa pics and more at Magic in the Market
data.description:
Is there anything more magical than Pike Place Market during the holidays? Probably not, except for maybe a sighting of Saint Nick himself. That being said, the 26th Annual Magic in the Market is happening again this year and you’ll definitely want to attend. What makes this holiday celebration so magical? The market comes alive thanks to beautiful light displays and decorations crafted to create the ultimate holiday ambiance. One of the most memorable aspects of these decorations is the Winter Wonderland scene at the front of the market which was designed by Market Artist Graig Anderson. Recent Posts:
Hip hop or ballet? You have options for seeing The Nutcracker in Seattle
The Seattle Cinerama faces an uncertain future & you can help save it  But there’s much more to see than just the decorations. Folks who attend can also enjoy special shopping offers, live holiday music, photo ops, glass blowing demonstrations and more. If you’re feeling extra cheery you can indulge in some holiday drinks & treats while you wait to take free photos with Santa. By the way, the market encourages folks of all ages to get their Santa pics so whether you’re 5 or 100, or anywhere in between, don’t miss out on a pic with Saint Nick. The magic kicks off on November 27th but is available for you to check out throughout the holiday season. So visit it once or make it a part of your weekly market shopping. Either way you can click below to learn more.

data.title: GeekCraft Expo is coming to Seattle this month with over 100 'nerdy' vendors
data.description:
Seattle is a pretty geeky city, between Amazon and our ever-growing tech sector it only makes sense that GeekCraft Expo is making a stop in the Emerald City. And if you’re looking for the perfect gift for the geek in your life, this is going to be your one-stop-shop…err expo. Let’s check it out. GeekCraft Expo is taking over Magnuson Park’s Hangar 30 on November 27th & 28th. You’ll be able to shop from over 100 vendors selling perfectly nerdy wares and gifts. These items are unique in nature and handmade by local crafters & makers. Recent Posts:
Here are 11 places to enjoy Thanksgiving dinner in Seattle this year
Wunderground has opened its first cafe in Seattle with a full drink & eats menu  It’s a great way to snag truly unique gifts and support local makers instead of big box stores. You’ll find items from your favorite games and shows, unique clothing, jewelry, knick-knacks and so much more. Who knows you might just end up grabbing something for yourself too. If you’d like to learn more about GeekCraft Expo you can click below. Keep in mind that you need to be vaccinated and provide proof of vaccination in order to attend. And if you end up attending be sure to get in character because cosplay is highly encouraged.

data.title: The Seattle Night Market returns for one night only this weekend
data.description:
Still, looking for weekend plans? We’ve got you covered. Seattle’s largest indoor Night Market is returning once again to Magnuson Park Hangar 30 this weekend. It’s your chance to shop from Seattle’s makers, finders, and foodies all under one roof. This beloved Night Market is transforming over 30,000 sq ft of indoor and outdoor space to give you a fall night to remember. You’ll be able to shop, snack, and booze your way through Magnuson Park’s historic Hangar 30 as you enjoy live entertainment, karaoke, photo booths, food trucks, and over 85 local retailers. Recent Posts:
10 of the best things to do in Seattle this weekend (November 5-7)
The 41st Seattle International Comedy Competition is back this year with 33 comedians  What’s even more fun about this event is that it’s 21+ so you can enjoy a night of adults-only fun. Bring your family, friends or go solo and secretly shop for holiday gifts ahead of time. You might as well have a drink while you’re there because all alcohol sales are giving back. The proceeds will go to support the Seattle Farmers Market Association and help support the Farmers Relief Fund. Now keep in mind that this is a ticketed event so you need to purchase your tickets ahead of time. What’s more, you also need to provide proof of vaccination or a negative test taken 72 hours from the event date. So be sure to plan ahead to ensure that you can check out this amazing market. You can click below to learn more and grab tickets.
data.where: : Magnuson Park Hangar 30, 6310 Northeast 74th Street, Seattle, WA

data.title: Freakout Festival kicks off next weekend in Ballard & here is what to expect
data.description:
Earlier this year we wrote about a crazy concept, an in person music festival. These days concerts are back in swing and we had Day In Day Out Festival in September. But if you’ve yet to attend a concert or festival this year you’re in luck because Freakout Festival happens this month! Freakout Festival has been happening since 2013 and is produced by independent record label Freakout Records. The festival features all sorts of bands from the Pacific Northwest and beyond. It’s also a  great opportunity to support many of Ballards small venues which are getting back in the swing of things now that concerts are a thing again. Some of the venues participating include The Tractor, The Salmon Bay Eagles, and more. Recent Posts:
10 of the best concerts coming to Seattle this November
31 of the absolute best things to do in & around Seattle this November  Some of the artists performing include Cedric Burnside, Liz Cooper, The Seeds, The Mystery Lights, Matthew Dear and many more. Beyond the tons of great artists and bands playing you’ll also be able to enjoy visuals by Mad Alchemy Liquid Light Show. It’s the perfect excuse to jam out to new tunes this fall. If you’d like to learn more about the festival or snag tickets you can click below. If you end up attending be sure to tag us in any pics and vids that you snap!

data.title: WildLanterns returns to Seattle this month with giant immersive holiday displays
data.description:
We all love a good holiday light display but sometimes we want something a little more unique. And that’s why the Woodland Park Zoo’s WildLanterns are a great deviation from your everyday red and white light displays. It’s an immersive experience featuring large animal and nature lanterns representing wild places from around the globe! Kicking off on November 12, WildLanterns is a way to explore the zoo like never before. It’s a lantern festival unlike any in the Northwest and is much different than the past WildLights. No matter how old you are, you’re sure to be wowed at the size and diversity of the displays that the zoo and BECU create. Recent Posts:
Downtown Seattle’s beloved tree lighting ceremony returns later this November
Seattle’s Miracle Christmas pop-up bar is returning this year as festive as ever This year you’ll also be able to enjoy the WildLanterns Trail. It features hundreds of thousands of colorful lights that illuminate the trees and landscapes throughout Discovery Loop. It’s a brand new addition to WildLanterns and is a great spot to snap holiday pics for your socials. Best of all, it’s included with your lights admission. Another new addition this year is live traditional Chinese art performances. You’ll be able to watch Tianyu’s captivating performances which include traditional Chinese folk dances, Kung Fu, lion dances, and more. If you’d like to learn more about WildLanterns or grab tickets you can click below. Enjoy folks!

data.title: SantaCon Seattle returns this December with free admission to 15+ venues
data.description:
Have you ever wanted to watch as Santas of all shapes and sizes take over Seattle? Well, SantaCon is back this year and it’s your best chance to see just that. Over the span of two weekends, you can parade through Downtown Seattle in your best Santa fit to help spread holiday cheer. What exactly is this magical celebration? It’s much more than a pub crawl. Each year folks join a mass gathering of people dressed in Santa Claus costumes as they parade publicly on streets and in businesses in cities around the world. It’s all about spontaneity, creativity, and of course having a good old festive time. Recent Posts:
Seattle’s Miracle Christmas pop-up bar is returning this year as festive as ever
Downtown Seattle’s beloved tree lighting ceremony returns later this November   On December 11th and 18th, you’re invited to paint the town red and white. You can expect live entertainment all day, free admission to 15+ venues, drink specials, a costume contest, professional photographers, and more! Best of all, you can hop in on the fun pretty much anytime between noon and midnight to pick up your wristband. That being said, we recommend doing the whole day if you can so that you can really enjoy all the festive fun. If you’d like to learn more about this year’s SantaCon or snag tickets you can click below. Psst you can score some pretty cheap tickets if you buy them now instead of waiting until the event

data.title: Partake in the ultimate holiday experience aboard Argosy Cruises Christmas Ship
data.description:
During November and December, you’ve probably heard music coming from Puget Sound. You’re not crazy and it’s not sirens trying to lure you into the water. Rather, it’s Argosy Cruises Christmas Ship Festival. The unique festival is back for its 72nd year and it’s looking better than ever. Watch as hundreds of shimmery white lights light up the darkness of the Puget Sound while sailing to different Puget Sound waterfront communities. Just how many? Around 40 in all. It’s a celebration truly heard around the sound as onboard choirs sing the tunes of Christmas to guests aboard, to follow boats, and to communities gathered onshore. Recent posts:
Seattle’s Miracle Christmas pop-up bar is returning this year as festive as ever
31 of the absolute best things to do in & around Seattle this November  Best of all there are three different ways to enjoy this timeless Christmas tradition. Here’s what’s included with each option. Christmas Ship Follow Boat (follows Christmas Ship) Onshore Event “Welcome the Christmas Ship™ and Follow Boats from a community event on shore and enjoy a 20-minute choir performance broadcast from the Christmas Ship™. Join us for the 6th Annual Parade of Boats Viewing Party Dec. 10th at Evanston Plaza on the Fremont Cut!” So if you’re looking to take your Christmas traditions to the next level, a ride on the Argosy Cruises Christmas Ship might just be your best bet. You can click below to learn more and grab tickets.

data.title: Wander through designer Christmas trees at The Festival of Trees this month
data.description:
One of Seattle’s most iconic Christmas events is returning this year grander than ever. The Festival of Trees will return to dazzle visitors of the Fairmont Olympic Hotel and give back in a big way to Seattle Children’s. Best of all, there are multiple ways to enjoy the festival. Starting November 18th you’ll be able to visit the lobby of the Fairmont Olympic Hotel in Seattle’s Downtown core to see all of the gorgeous designer holiday trees. Expect to see trees decked out in ornaments, bows, flocking, and more. While visiting the trees you’ll also be able to read some of the inspiring stories of Seattle Children’s patients. Recent Posts:
Drive through over 1 million Christmas lights at this display an hour north of Seattle
Seattle’s Miracle Christmas pop-up bar is returning this year as festive as ever  Now if you feel like giving back in a big way you can also participate in the Seattle Festival of Trees Gala Auction on November 20th. If you choose to attend you’ll be able to enjoy drinks, passed hors d’oeuvres, entertainment, live and silent auctions, and a scrumptious dinner. Of course, proceeds go to support Seattle Children’s. And if you fall in love with a tree when visiting you can purchase it as another form of giving back but keep in mind trees are $3.8k and few are left. Whether you’re giving back or simply checking out the trees, this holiday event is a great excuse to wander Downtown Seattle. Grab a holiday beverage, do some shopping and end your day with a stroll through the Fairmont Olympic Hotel. If you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: Downtown Seattle's beloved tree lighting ceremony returns later this November
data.description:
A classic Seattle tradition will be illuminating Westlake Center once again this year. You’ll be able to join over 10,000 people for the annual post-Thanksgiving tree lighting celebration to kick off the holiday season. It’s an age-old Seattle tradition that you don’t want to miss. Well, ‘age-old’ is relative but tree lighting ceremonies have been happening around the city for decades. From the world’s tallest Christmas tree to Green Lake’s own tree lighting celebration, Seattle knows how to raise a tree. And Westlake’s celebration is modern-day proof of that. Recent Posts:
Drive through over 1 million Christmas lights at this display an hour north of Seattle
Seattle’s Miracle Christmas pop-up bar is returning this year as festive as ever   Rain or shine you’ll be able to watch as the tree turns on and fills Westlake Center with a brilliant display of light and color. Then you’ll be able to watch as the iconic Macy’s star comes to life with its eye-popping, fireworks-framed sparkle. Bellow all the holiday lights you’ll find the DSA’s beloved carousel. It’s a tradition that you don’t want to miss. If you’d like to learn more about it you can click below.

data.title: Drive through over 1 million Christmas lights at this display an hour north of Seattle
data.description:
Halloween is over and Thanksgiving is just a few weeks away and that means it’s time to fill the holiday limbo time. Ready to get into the holiday spirit? Take a drive an hour north and check out The Lights of Christmas illuminating Stanwood. It’s a drive-thru Christmas experience that you won’t soon forget. From November 26th until January 8th, 2022, you can hop in your car and check out this holiday outing for everyone. You’ll get to see over a million spectacular lights, dazzling displays, all while you wave to Santa and Mrs. Claus and listen to Christmas music in the warmth and comfort of your own car. It’s 30 minutes of Christmas fun that you can check out with your friends, family, or even solo. Recent Posts:
Seattle’s Miracle Christmas pop-up bar is returning this year as festive as ever
Seattle Center’s Winterfest is back next month with its classic train, ice sculpting & more  This year’s event will feature new lights as well as old favorites like the light tunnel, Cascade Splendor mountain scene, the larger-than-life Nativity, Santa, and his reindeer. You’ll be wowed by the displays and we’re sure you’ll snap some great pics as well.  And if you happen to feel peckish while you’re enjoying the lights you can purchase fresh-hot mini donuts along with other snacks, hot beverages, and espresso all with drive-thru convenience. It’s pretty hard to say no to mini donuts so we’d recommend picking some up to make your experience complete. You still have time to plan ahead and pick your perfect dates for attending. If you’d like to learn more or grab tickets you can click below.

data.title: The 41st Seattle International Comedy Competition is back this year with 33 comedians
data.description:
Do you think you’re funny? Well, you’re probably not as funny as the folks participating in the 41st Seattle International Comedy Competition which kicks off this week. Get ready to laugh as the competition begins a 17-performance tour throughout the Puget Sound this Thursday. It’s probably been a while since you’ve watched live comedy so attending this well-loved gathering of funny folks is a great way to get back into it. After all, the competition took 2020 off due to the pandemic. And that being said, things will look pretty similar to years past but there will be some changes, most notably the lack of Comedy Underground. The venue unfortunately did not survive the pandemic. Recent Posts:  
Seattle is being scouted by FIFA as a potential host for the 2026 World Cup
10 of the best things to do in & around Seattle this week (November 1-5)
 via GIPHY While it’s a big loss, the good news is that you’ll get to experience some other and maybe new-to-you venues from Tacoma to Bellingham and everywhere in between. The competition kicks off at Unexpected Productions near Pike Place Market and you’ll also be able to see shows at the Broadway Performance Hall on Capitol Hill, as well as the finals at Laughs Comedy Club in the University District. You’ll get to watch as 33 comedians from around the globe compete to be the funniest person in the room. The Seattle International Comedy Competition is a big deal in the comedy world and it’s a great way to see some of the best comics working today. So treat yourself to some laughs this month. You’ll probably leave with some inspo to apply next year and a few jokes that you can try on friends and fam. If you’d like to learn more you can click below.
data.where: : Multiple venues around Seattle and Washington

data.title: This unique haunted house explores the horrors of climate change & it's happening this weekend
data.description:
We’ve said it before and we’ll say it again, horror is subjective. Because the world around us can be just as scary as what horror directors depict on the big screen. And that’s why the Fremont Abbey Arts Center’s haunted house is worth checking out, it’s a multi-arts experience looking at just how scary our changing world is. By ‘changing world’, we mean climate change. Something we’ve all seen this year in our own country between the fires across North America and Hurricane Ida. If you want to see the scary realities of climate change come to life as you wander through a dark maze haunted by the shadows of our time, this is the spot for you. Come face to face with the “Fossil Fool” business executives and try to avoid the desperate pleas of the hungry ghosts of consumerism. Recent Posts:
A terrifying haunted house returns to the site of Seattle’s most gruesome unsolved crime
This site lists all the homes in Seattle with haunted & downright terrible histories  Now we know that many of you are overwhelmed by climate change and because of that, a haunted house with such a real topic can be, well, overwhelming. But what makes this event so unique is that its purpose is to bring artists together to create a space where people can move through those emotions and grief. So think of it almost like a therapeutic haunted house if you will. And after you experience navigating through the haunted house you can head upstairs for live music to lighten the mood and start your Halloweekend off right. If you’re looking for a different way to get spooked this year, this is probably as unique as it gets. Need more convincing? The proceeds from the haunted house will go towards supporting artists and frontline climate actions. So feel good, get spooked, and click below to learn more.

data.title: Seattle Center's Winterfest is back next month with its classic train, ice sculpting & more
data.description:
In some exciting news, it looks like one of Seattle’s OG and most classic celebrations of the holiday season is back this year. Winterfest at Seattle Center kicks off on November 26th and is happening both virtually and also in-person. It’s your chance to watch performances, see ice sculptures, winter trains, and much more. If you grew up in Seattle you probably have fond memories of attending this festival. The winter trains are hard to forget with their perfectly placed villages and scenery lighting up the Armory. It’s a tradition that’s been going on for over 40 years and is being made even more fun this year with the addition of a scavenger hunt. All you have to do to participate is pick up your entry sheet at the Train Station, and see how many clues you can spot. Recent posts:
31 of the absolute best things to do in & around Seattle this November
A boozy Alice in Wonderland-style tea party is coming to Seattle this winter  While the train is the main attraction for many, you can also watch master carvers Chan Kitburi and Janson Iwakami carve seasonal and holiday-themed sculptures. They’re both beautiful to look at and a perfect backdrop for your holiday photos. Or pop outside and check out all of the dazzling lights which will provide an equally beautiful photo backdrop. Additionally you’ll be able to watch live performances on the Armory Stage while you check out the Winterfest Train & Village, or wander the Armory’s food merchants. Some of those performers include the Garfield Jazz Band, Bailadores de Bronce, Khu.éex’ and more. There’s something for folks of all ages and at this festival and you can’t miss it considering it’s a true and tried Seattle tradition. What’s more is that this festival is free and you can combine it with other nearby activities like the Chihuly Garden & Glass or The Nutcracker at McCaw Hall. Click below to learn more.

data.title: MoPOP's newest exhibit gives you a behind the scenes look at the history of hip hop
data.description:
There’s so much to see at MoPOP these days from Disney costumes to your favorite horror movie props. But it doesn’t stop there, now you have a brand new exhibit to check out detailing the history of one of music’s most language-conscious genres: hip-hop. Contact High: A Visual History of Hip-Hop is a can’t miss show full of images of your favorite hip hop stars. The new exhibition looks at hip-hop throughout the United States from the 1970s to the present day. It looks at the stars themselves and the regional cultures that flourished in different parts of the US that influenced the genre. You’ll be able to see 170 iconic images and the contact sheets behind the creative process that went into the photos themselves. Recent posts:
A massive expo of all things weird arrives in Seattle this weekend
A Nightmare Before Christmas cabaret show will dazzle Seattle this Halloween  Photographs aren’t the only thing you’ll see, you’ll also be able to check out artifacts from MoPOP’s permanent collection like “early rap battle fliers, Tupac Shakur manuscripts, Flavor magazines, and costumes from Sha-Rock, The Notorious B.I.G., and MF DOOM.” It’s pretty safe to say you’ll be able to see at least one photo or object from your favorite hip-hop artist. So treat yourself this week or when you have the time and see the behind-the-scenes world of artists like Missy Elliott, Jay-Z, Queen Latifah, Tupac, and more. The exhibition is open with MoPOP’s current hours and you can purchase your tickets ahead of time online. If you check it out be sure to snap some pics and tag us in them. Enjoy folks and you can click below to learn more.

data.title: A massive expo of all things weird arrives in Seattle this weekend
data.description:
Something rather curious is coming to the Washington State Convention Center this weekend. It’s a convention unlike any you’ve attended before. The Seattle Oddities & Curiosities expo is for lovers of the strange, unusual & bizarre and you don’t want to miss it. While it might sound a bit like a sideshow circus, it’s not. Rather, the Oddities & Curiosities Expo showcases almost 50 unique vendors, dealers, artists, and small businesses from all over the country. As the name suggests, you’ll find all sorts of weird items, things you’d expect, and also the unexpected. Recent posts:
A Nightmare Before Christmas cabaret show will dazzle Seattle this Halloween
10 places with haunted history you can visit in and around Seattle   Expect taxidermy, preserved specimens, original artwork, horror/Halloween-inspired pieces, antiques, handcrafted oddities, quack medical devices, clothing, jewelry, skulls/bones, funeral collectibles, and much more. There’s truly something for everyone who is into all things weird. And in case you were wondering, all items you see at the expo are legal to own and sustainably sourced. Whether you’re looking to purchase or simply window shop, the Seattle Curiosities & Oddities Expo is a great way to spend Halloweekend. It’s a safe place to discover new artists, meet new friends, and be surrounded by an amazing community of like-minded people. If you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: You can watch the next generation of horror films at SLAY! Film Festival starting today
data.description:
Horror is a genre with a whole lot of wiggle room, after all, what’s scary to you might not be as freaky to others. That’s why – even if you’re set in your ways and prefer one direction over another it’s worth checking out the second annual SLAY! Film Festival. The festival asked filmmakers to submit films of 8 minutes or less with a subject that scared them the most. What was submitted in the end included everything from ghost stories, slasher films, cults, and of course, some very scary political nightmares? Because let’s face it, life, as it is, can be pretty dang scary these days. Recent Posts:
10 places with haunted history you can visit in and around Seattle
This interactive Seattle 2021 Trick or Treat map gives the safest & best spots  The final cut of the festival includes 17 films created by folks just like us. You’ll probably see at least a few of your own fears reflected in these films as they have topics of self, what lurks in the dark and of course good old death. So face your fears and watch a horror film with a fresh take. Who knows, it might just inspire you to make your own for next year’s festival. To make things easier, the festival has three formats, a live Seattle and Portland showing and a live stream showing. So whether you want to be spooked at home or in theatre, you have the option to choose. You’ll be able to watch the live stream on select dates between October 22nd-31st and the in-person showings will take place on October 29th & 30th. So grab your friends, some snacks and find your new fave movie. You can click below to learn more.

data.title: Coldplay plays the first Climate Pledge Arena concert tmrw & here are 3 ways to watch
data.description:
Something big, very big is taking place in Seattle tomorrow. Coldplay is hitting the stage as Climate Pledge Arena’s first official event and you can still snag tickets. But if you can’t make it in person, it turns out there’s more than one way to check out the concert. The band is going on tour for their new “Music Of The Spheres” album which officially dropped on October 15th. That means fans lucky enough to snag tickets will get to hear this album played live just days after it drops. So get ready to jam to your new favorite tunes. Recent posts:
The ghost of the inventor of pot brownies reportedly haunts this Seattle hotel
This new Seattle building will have a repurposed Boeing 747 as a lounge inside of it  Now if you can’t attend in person you can watch a live stream on October 22nd at 7 pm on Amazon Prime, Amazon Music, or Twitch. But if you can’t catch the live stream you’ll also be able to watch the show on Prime Video beginning on November 5th. What’s more, you’ll also be able to listen to an exclusive Amazon Original EP featuring tracks from the performance on Amazon Music. Basically, there are so many ways to view it that there’s no reason not to check out this concert. If you plan on going in person you should keep in mind that you must be fully vaccinated in order to attend events at Climate Pledge Arena. So with that, make sure you have your proof of vaccination and get ready to enjoy an amazing concert in our city’s newest and coolest venue. You can click above or below to learn more.
data.when: Concert October 22nd, Recording goes live November 5th

data.title: This Washington drive-in theater is using live actors to brings horror flicks to life this month
data.description:
Sometimes when you’re watching a horror movie it feels like the characters might just crawl through your screen. It’s a terrifying notion that might just come true at The Cinema of Horrors. Watch as your drive-in movie watching experience comes to life before your very eyes. The Cinema of Horrors offers lovers of all things spooky a unique movie watching experience that will take any movies jump scares to the next level. Fill your car up with your friends and grab tickets for your favorite scary movie on the big screen. It’ll feel pretty normal until you realize that there’s something lurking outside your car. Recent Posts:
You can race through a corn maze just outside of Seattle this month
A terrifying haunted house returns to the site of Seattle’s most gruesome unsolved crime Keep your doors locked because the monsters that are roaming the grounds might just come in. And with how scary they look you’ll feel just like you’re in a horror movie of your very own. It’s two hours of terrifying fun that you don’t want to miss out on if you’re both a movie junkie and horror lover. You can pick from the remaining titles including Child’s Play, It Chapter 2, Halloween and more. Just be sure to buy those tickets ASAP as many screenings have sold out. And if you want to bring the kids you can actually choose from select family night screenings of less spooky films like Hocus Pocus, Halloweentown, and Beetlejuice. With that, enjoy and don’t scare yourself too silly.
data.where: : Clark County Fairgrounds, 17402 NE Delfel Rd Ridgefield, WA 98642

data.title: You can see over 50 terrifying props from your favorite horror movies at MoPOP
data.description:
There’s nothing quite like a good horror movie this time of year. All those dark color schemes, soundtracks, and scenes really help us get in the mood for spooky season. But did you know that Seattle’s MoPOP has an exhibition that celebrates all things horror year-round? Yep, horror fans this one is for you. MoPOP’s Scared to Death: The Thrill of Horror Film is a permanent exhibition and is included in your ticket each time you visit. So no need to pay extra to see more than 50 props and costumes from your film and television horror favorites. Recent Posts:
10 of the best things to do in & around Seattle this week (October 18-22)
Seattle just got the nation’s first Hokkaido-style soft-serve spot & it’s time to try it Just which movies can you see props from? Expect to see items from A Nightmare on Elm Street, Friday the 13th, The Walking Dead, Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Bride of Frankenstein, Dawn of the Dead, Hostel, Jeepers Creepers, Pet Sematary, and more. And if that’s not enough for you, MoPOP let Curiocity in on a little secret and that is the addition of the “Candyman” hook from 1992 and Sutter Cane books from “In the Mouth of Madness.” While seeing the objects is cool, the exhibit is just about as cinematic as the films themselves. See if you can survive a vampire’s lair dripping with blood and try not to scream when you see suspended corpses framing a killer’s den. But if you do make it through all that you’ll also be able to see extensive exhibit films, oral history interviews with the genre’s top directors, and also some interactive photo ops. It’s a seriously star-studded exhibit and if you’ve never seen it before now is the perfect time to check it out. Not to mention, it might give you some Halloween costume inspo. If you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: The 26th annual Seattle Queer Film Festival returns this week with over 40 films
data.description:
Now that October is here we’ll bet that at least a few of you have been going hard on streaming. After all, with so many new Netflix additions this month, it’s hard not to. While we all love a good Netflix sesh, why not check out something a little more unique like the 26th annual Seattle Queer Film Festival which kicks off this week. The Seattle Queer Film Festival is operating in a hybrid format this year to ensure that everyone who wants to experience it, can. Festival attendees can watch all screened films at home virtually unless otherwise noted. Alternatively, attendees can opt for a true movie-watching experience and enjoy a film or two in person. Recent Posts:
10 of the best things to do in & around Seattle this week (October 11-15)
This interactive Seattle 2021 Trick or Treat map gives the safest & best spots Attendees will have the chance to watch 30 feature films, 11 short films, and/or participate in 11 workshops. Films come from near and far with both American and International films being shown. And if there’s a particular topic you’re looking for like trans, QTBIPOC, lesbian, etc, the festival’s website has you covered with a handy film guide. If you’re ready to watch the festival, keep in mind that you have a few options. You can purchase a film pack, festival pass, or individual tickets depending on how many films you want to watch. Now if you plan on watching in person you will need to provide proof of vaccination and also wear a mask inside the theatre. With that, enjoy and if you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: Get spooked at a massive Halloween rave happening at WaMu theatre this month
data.description:
It still feels crazy that October is here and also that Halloween this year is a thing. Well, the holiday still happened last year obviously but not quite at the same level, we’re used to. So why not get back into the swing of Seattle Halloween celebrations with a rave? BOO! Halloween is a rave unlike any that you’ve attended before. BOO has 3 themed realms full of audiovisual trickery to captivate & steal your soul while you listen to your favorite artists and watch performers work their magic. You’ll get to dance among skeletons, ghouls, goblins, and other frightfully fun characters as WaMu Theatre transforms into a haunted wonderland. Recent Posts: 
A boozy Alice in Wonderland-style tea party is coming to Seattle this winter
Seattle Restaurant Week returns with over 200 participating spots later this month   What’s even better about this event is that it has a massive lineup that’s spread over two days! So you can pick a day to see your favorite artists or go all-in for 2 nights of dancing fun. As you can see by the lineup above, this festival has some pretty major names so if it’s been a while since you’ve been to a rave this might just be the perfect one to get back into it. Tickets are still on sale but keep in mind that you need to provide proof of vaccination or a negative COVID-19 test to attend. You will also need to wear a mask but these are all things that we are used to at this point. So be sure to purchase tickets ASAP as an event this fun is sure to sell out quickly.

data.title: Seattle largest indoor night market returns one night only this month
data.description:
Summer nights may be over but that doesn’t mean that it’s time to start turning in early. Not yet at least because Seattle’s largest indoor Night Market is finally returning to Magnuson Park Hangar 30 this October. It’s your chance to shop from Seattle’s makers, finders and foodies all under one roof. This beloved Night Market is transforming over 30,000 sq ft of indoor and outdoor space to give you a fall night to remember. You’ll be able to shop, snack and booze your way through Magnsuon Park’s historic Hangar 30 as you enjoy live entertainment, karaoke, photo booths, food trucks and over 75 local retailers. Recent Posts:
The Seattle Mariners are opening a brand new venue in the old Pyramid Brewing space
10 of the scariest haunted attractions in and around Seattle 
What’s even more fun about this event is that it’s 21+ so you can enjoy a night of adults only fun. Bring your family, friends or go solo and secretly shop for holiday gifts ahead of time. You might as well have a drink while you’re there because all alcohol sales are giving back. The proceeds will go to support the Seattle Farmers Market Association and help support the Farmers Relief Fund. Now keep in mind that this is a ticketed event so you need purchase your tickets ahead of time. What’s more you also need to provide proof of vaccination or a negative test taken 72 hours from the event date. So be sure to plan ahead to ensure that you can check out this amazing market. You can click below to learn more and grab tickets.
data.where: : Magnuson Park Hangar 30, 6310 Northeast 74th Street, Seattle, WA

data.title: Meet master glass blowers & more at this annual Glass Festival returning this month
data.description:
Seattle has long been known as a hub for the arts, most notably music. But did you know that the PNW region is actually the leading regional hub for glass art in the United States? Our very own state of Washington has over 700 glass artists, Pilchuck Glass School, and over 100 glass art studios. That’s why it’s the perfect spot for Refract, the ultimate Seattle glass experience which is happening next weekend October 14th-17th. Refract is a celebration of the region’s rich glassblowing history and scene. It gives you the opportunity to attend special events, epic exhibitions, parties, studio tours, intriguing demos, and even connect with artists working in this eye catching medium. No matter your glass-blowing knowledge, there’s something for everyone at this festival. Recent Posts:
Want to be an astronaut? Seattle is one of the best cities in America for space jobs
This tiny Georgetown wedding chapel you can rent is one of Seattle’s most unique venues  What’s even cooler about this festival is that it’s happening across the state. Some of the event venues include Pilchuk Glass School, The Museum of Glass, Chihuly Boat House, and many more. You can visit studios and showrooms of masters like Dale Chihuly, Lino Tagliapietra, Preston Singletary, and more. Of course, you’ll also be able to see works of up-and-coming local glass artists as well. Whether you want to create your own piece of glass art, watch the masters do their work, or simply view exhibitions, this festival is for you. Keep in mind that masks are required and that proof of vaccination may be required by individual venues.
data.where: : Venues in Seattle and across Washington state

data.title: A terrifying haunted house returns to the site of Seattle's most gruesome unsolved crime
data.description:
Ready to get seriously spooked? If you’re looking for something other than a haunted corn maze, you’re in luck. It turns out that you can visit Seattle’s favorite haunted house starting this week! That’s right folks, the Georgetown Morgue is back for another year of terrifying haunts that you won’t soon forget. The Georgetown Morgue is a unique building aside from hosting one of Seattle’s best and most iconic haunted houses. It of course has a history of death and also as the site of one of Seattle’s most gruesome crimes on record. Just what happened you may ask? October 25th, 1968, the entire facility staff of Broughton Brothers Funeral Services were bound and forced into the crematorium chamber. There were no surviving witnesses and no suspects were ever identified. It’s believed that the motive had something to do with less-than-legitimate business practices at the funeral home. Yikes! Recent Posts:
10 of the coolest and craziest ghost towns that you can visit in Washington
This spooky abandoned tunnel hike takes you 2.3 miles through a Washington mountain  With a history like that, it will be hard for you to tell whether you’re seeing actors or vengeful ghosts as you navigate the halls of this haunted house. Especially because word on the street is that a new owner has taken over and unearthed a decrepit Catacomb for you to discover. Be wary of Dr. Simons and his trusted goons Rigor and Mortis as you try to survive a night of frights. Now if you really can’t handle being chased around the morgue you can still check out a slightly less scary option. The morgue also offers a self-guided tour which allows you to navigate the haunted house without actors but beware because there still are some animatronics. With either option, you’re sure to leave seriously spooked. Keep in mind that this haunted house is intended for folks 12 and older and please don’t attend if you think that being seriously scared might harm you. It’s also worth mentioning that if you want to avoid the long lines you can pay between $25-$100 to advance your spot in line or just be admitted entry as soon as you arrive. If you’d like to snag tickets or learn more you can click below. Enjoy and don’t scare yourself too silly.
data.when: Weekends and select additional days September 24th-November 6th

data.title: Stalker Farms is back with 8 new terrifying Halloween experiences & tix are on sale now
data.description:
October is just 10 days away and that means it’s time to start getting ready for some spooky experiences. If you don’t want to make the drive to Halloweentown then you need to head to Snohomish to check out Stalker Farms. It’s Washington’s original haunted, immersive horror experience that’s sure to give you the scare of the year. Even scarier than COVID-19, we promise. Stalker Farms has been voted Washington’s #1 must-see haunted attraction by The Scare Factor for three years in a row and this year it’s back and better than ever. You can experience an in-person and up close and personal production with 8 attractions that will leave you with memories you won’t soon forget. And because this year’s production has so many options we’re going to give you a little preview of each. Recent Posts:
This spooky abandoned tunnel hike takes you 2.3 miles through a Washington mountain
10 stunning Airbnbs around Washington that you should stay at this fall  Slasher Family Homestead This is one of three cornfield experiences you can enjoy at Stalker Farms this year. Explore a new and much larger cornfield as you try to navigate the twists and turns without running into the blood-hungry Suzie Slasher and family. Take a few steps into the corn and you’ll quickly see what all the screaming is all about. Pogo’s Funny Farm In a separate cornfield, you’ll find POGO the Clown. This year he and his free-range clowns have their own space and are ready to feed off of the smell of your fear and eat your laughter. Be careful, you never know where they’ll pop out next. The Scarecrow’s Challenge   If you want to let your competitive side out then you need to try the Scarecrow’s Challenge. In a third cornfield, you can test your reflexes in one of the most terrifying games of red light green light you’ve ever played. You need to avoid the semi-sentient Wedigourd monster inside the maze that can only sense movement through the ground and the corn. Can you make it through the corn labyrinth and past the Wendigourd, or will you become its next meal? Clown Shot Paintball As there’s an abundance of clowns at Stalker Farms, you might just have to protect yourself from them. Clown Shot Paintball invites you to take a seat, load 100 paintballs, and take shots at static and moving interactive targets. Be careful though because the clowns will come out to see what the ruckus is all about! Camp Fire Rentals Want to have a slightly more wholesome or story-based spooky night? Rent your very own campfire and tell ghost stories while warming up before or after visiting the haunts or corn maze! Psst, you can bring outside food and drinks (non-alcoholic) to your rented campfire but nowhere else on the farm.  Nightime Corn Maze Want to wander the corn in peace? You can do that as well. The nighttime corn maze is a no scare opportunity to walk amongst the corn and see just how lost you can get in all the twists and turns. Cool down after some scares or enjoy as is if you don’t want any scares at all. Beer Garden We get it, you might need some liquid courage to endure the farm. Or maybe you need to chill after being scared silly. You’re in luck because you can sip on a selection of craft beer and wine from the Pacific NW. Plus, partial proceeds from the sales will benefit NW Honey Bee Habitat Restoration. Obviously, you have to be 21+. The Midway Overwhelmed with the options yet? Well, The Midway is the final one. It’s where you can enjoy the Beer Garden as well as unique onsite food vendors, a giant jumping pillow (weather permitting), skill-based carnival-style gaming, and live entertainment on busy nights. It’s not hard to tell why this haunted corn maze is so popular and with so many options it’s definitely your best bet for getting your money’s worth when it comes to spooky events. To ensure that’s the case, Stalker Farms has several ticket pricing options so you can experience as much or as little as you’d like. Each ticket is for one-time use and all visitors must have a ticket. Double Dare tickets give you access to the Slasher Family Homestead & Pogo’s Funny Farm, unlimited use of the Jumping Pillow and other games, and access to the Midway and Beer Garden. Double Dare VIP tickets give you access to everything and No Scare Night tickets give you access to the giant, non-haunted Corn Maze in the dark, 100 paintballs to shoot at the Clown Shot Paintball Shooting Gallery, and unlimited use of the Jumping Pillow and other games and also access to the Midway and Beer Garden! We know that’s a whole lot of info but as always, we recommend buying your tickets ASAP especially because you can score $9-$11 off full-price tickets right now. If you’d like to learn more or snag tickets you can click below. Have fun and don’t scare yourself too silly!

data.title: The Skagit Valley Giant Pumpkin Festival is happening tomorrow and you can't miss it
data.description:
Now that fall is officially just days away it’s time to start thinking about pumpkins. That being said, Skagit Valley’s farmers and hobbyists have been thinking about pumpkins for months already. And you know what that means? The Skagit Valley Giant Pumpkin Festival, it’s happening tomorrow and you don’t want to miss it. Honestly, who can resist seeing a massive pumpkin? They’re the fruits of farmers and hobbyist’s hard labor and they’re just fun to look at. If you agree then a trip to the in-person festival is in order. You’ll get to watch as pumpkin and oversized veggie-growing hobbyists exhibit their hard work and compete in a weigh-off. Recent Posts:
Enjoy some of Seattle’s most diverse eats at this food festival happening now
9 German restaurants in Seattle where you can celebrate Oktoberfest anytime  The winners of various pumpkin competitions can win between $25-$1500 so expect people to go big, literally. Obviously, the main attraction is seeing these massive veggies but you’ll also be able to enjoy some family-friendly activities like a hay maze, face painting, eats, and even some bluegrass music. There’s something for everyone making it the perfect Saturday activity. Oh, and did we mention it’s free? You have no excuse not to check it out so get yourself up to the Skagit Valley this Saturday. If you’d like to learn more about the festival you can click below. Enjoy folks!

data.title: You can race through a corn maze just outside of Seattle this month
data.description:
Running through a corn maze is kind of synonymous with horror movies. You know, you’re the main character being chased by the killer, constantly tripping and screaming in horror. Well, it doesn’t have to be that way because you can actually run through a corn maze for fun this month during the Corn Maze Craze 5k & 7k. Bob’s Corn & Pumpkin Farm is hosting the Corn Maze Craze run this year on September 25th and runners will be able to enjoy an unforgettable fall run on the farm. Just imagine a crisp morning run with all the fragrances of autumn foliage as you pass through mist-covered lowland fields. Best of all, you can just focus on running without any scary horror movie killer after you. Recent Posts:
This spooky abandoned tunnel hike takes you 2.3 miles through a Washington mountain
10 of the best autumn hikes with amazing views you can find near Seattle  You’ll race through a tunnel and over dirt farm road and of course through a corn maze where you’ll really have to get in the competitive spirit. You’ll be jostled left, right, and around through the corn as you weave your way through. Really, what’s a better way to ring in fall than this? While you’re there you can purchase admission to the farm if you want to make a fun day of it. You’ll be able to enter the corn maze again, a smaller kids’ maze, pumpkin patches, hayrides, a kid’s area, a cow train, food booths, a play barn, and a corn crib. So bring your friends and family and enjoy fun for folks of all ages. If you’d like to learn more about the run you can click below. You have until 11:59 pm on September 23rd to pre-register online. But if you miss out, you can also register at the event day of.

data.title: Volunteer Park Conservatory is hosting a  massive indoor plant sale this weekend
data.description:
With a new season come changes around the home. Maybe you’ve realized that you’re in need of some new decor, namely some new plants. If that’s the case you’re going to want to head over to the Volunteer Park Conservatory this weekend because their fall plant sale is on! The fall plant sale is the conservatory’s biggest fundraiser of the year. And unlike last year, this awesome sale is back in person. So you can browse plants to your heart’s content all while supporting the city’s stunning historical greenhouse. Recent Posts:
You can get a sneak peek at the Kraken Community Iceplex this weekend
This delicious $29 sandwich from a local spot has Seattleites obsessed  At this sale, you’ll be able to purchase houseplants and tropicals for any home or apartment—small. You can also browse an assortment of rare and exotic cacti and succulents from The Cascade Cactus and Succulent Society. And if you happen to be a member of the conservatory you’ll receive 15% off and a free gift with any plant purchase. Now maybe you’re a bit hesitant about bringing a new plant into your life because you have a tendency to kill them. Have no fear because the Volunteer Park Conservatory experts will help you find the perfect plant for your home’s conditions and your maintenance level. Or if you have a green thumb in your life, you can always snag a sweet gift for them. If you’d like to learn more about the sale or check it out you can click below. Remember this is only happening this weekend so don’t miss out!

data.title: Coldplay will be first act to perform at Climate Pledge Arena & here's how to get tix
data.description:
At this point, you probably know that the Seattle Kraken will be dropping the first puck of its inaugural game on October 23rd. But did you know that there’s an equally iconic act hitting the same spot the day before? Get ready to sing your heart out because Coldplay is coming to Seattle. The band is going on tour for their new “Music Of The Spheres” album which drops officially on October 15th. That means fans lucky enough to snag tickets will get to hear this album played live just days after it drops. Of course, we’re sure you’ll be able to hear some of your other favorite hits as well. Recent Posts:
Fremont Oktoberfest returns this month as Seattle’s largest beer fest & tix are on sale now
Here’s how Climate Pledge Arena is preparing for the Seattle Kraken  Now you’re probably wondering, how do I get tickets? Good questions. Basically, you’ll want to register for the ticket presale which is happening on Tuesday, September 14th from 10 a.m. PT through 10 p.m. PT. You have until Sunday, September 12th at 9 am PT to register and you don’t want to miss out because normal ticket prices will probably get pretty expensive. You should also keep in mind that you must be fully vaccinated in order to attend events at Climate Pledge Arena. So with that, get vaccinated and get ready to enjoy an amazing concert in our city’s newest and coolest venue. You can learn more by clicking below.

data.title: You can sail like a buccaneer thanks to this local pirate cruise on Lake Union
data.description:
Ahoy matey, have you ever wished that you could live the pirate life? Well, it turns out you kind of can thanks to Emerald City Pirates. This local pirate ship can take you and your family or friends on an unforgettable sail if you’re up for the adventure. With International Talk Like a Pirate Day coming up on September 19th there’s no better time than the present to take a sail with Emerald City Pirates. The ship offers a few different sailings including a Family Treasure Cruise, an Adult Pirate Party Cruise, and a Private Brews Cruise. Of course, if you want to go really big you can also charter the whole ship. Recent Posts:
You can ride a rare and historic steam-powered train on this Washington railroad
There’s an island full of affectionate wolves you can visit right here in Washington   Scheduled cruises leave Thursday-Sunday depending on the cruise and if you choose one of the adult or boozy cruises you must be 21+ to attend. Cruises last 1.5-2 hours with 15 minutes of boarding activities, and 10-15 minutes to disembark. You can purchase drinks, snacks, and pirate swag in the ship’s store as well. And you can even bring your pup with you if they’re under 25 pounds and willing to sit on your lap during the sail. A cruise with Emerald City Pirates is sure to be fun for folks of all ages and is a great venue option to keep in mind if you’re planning an event. Who knows, you might just find that the pirate life is for you. If you’d like to learn more or grab cruise tickets you can click below.

data.title: Another "Welcome Back Week" kicks off with a roller rink & free events this weekend
data.description:
Even though COVID-19 still has its grasp on Seattle, folks are looking forward to a more open and bright future. Part of that open future has been Mayor Jenny Durkan’s “Welcome Back Weeks”, which aims to promote local arts, culture, and small businesses. Cool right? Even better, the second round of Welcome Back Weeks arrives this weekend. The second round of free events and unique offerings is taking place from September 4th to 19th at participating venues and businesses in Seattle’s core neighborhoods. Some of the main attractions include free live music, welcome back booths and a rollerskating rink at Westlake Park. Recent Posts:
The Seattle Cider Summit is now offering three delicious DIY tasting kits
37 of the absolute best things to do in & around Seattle this September Join us for FREE Sept. #WelcomeBackSeattle celebrations of arts & culture w/ @downtownseattle. Vax + mask reqd. at all events
• 9/10 @BorealisSeattle light + sound event
• 9/18 Celebrate #BlackLivesMatter fest.
• 9/19 Finale concert at @seattlecenter https://t.co/kj63Xfn8VN — Mayor Jenny Durkan (@MayorJenny) August 30, 2021  When it comes to events, this Welcome Back Week has a free immersive light and sound experience happening at the historic Paramount Theatre. It’s called Borealis, A Festival of Light, and was designed specifically for the Paramount. Throughout the evening of September 10th, guests can enjoy four 35-minute presentations. Psst, the people behind this did the Space Needle’s virtual New Year’s Eve show. That’s not all for events though. Guests can also enjoy the Beers & Bites happy hour at Occidental Square from September 16th to 18th and a Celebrate Black Lives Matter festival at City Hall Plaza on September 18th. This festival will showcase performances curated by queer artist collective Legendary Children and also local Black-owned culinary artists and retailers. There’s a lot to see and experience at these events and we highly recommend attending them. Now keep in mind that masks and a full vaccination are required for all events so be sure to come prepared with masks and your vaccination card to avoid disappointment. With that, enjoy, and if you’d like to learn more you can click below.
