data.title: Here's what to expect at the Walla Walla Fair & Frontier Days returning next week
data.description:
You know all about the Washington State Fair but do you know about the Walla Walla Fair & Frontier Days? This tradition has been bringing joy to Washingtonians since 1866 and is a must for ending your summer right. Best of all, it’s actually happening this September! The Walla Walla Fair & Frontier Days takes place this September 1st-5th and has a huge lineup of entertainment. You can experience a hypnotist, a battle of the bands, wood carving, dock dogs, demolition derby, a rodeo, and more. Like other fairs around the state, you can also check out all sorts of livestock and tasty fair food. Recent Posts:
Here’s what to know about the historic Evergreen State Fair returning this weekend
Did you know that Alki Beach was once home to Seattle’s very own Coney Island (PHOTOS)  Beyond the general wonders of what the fair has to offer, you’ll also be able to hear Chicago perform live on September 1st. So if you were hoping to end your summer with some Western-themed fun it’s absolutely worth heading to Walla Walla to enjoy this age-old tradition. Not to mention, if you had purchased tickets for the 2020 fair, they’re still valid so you might as well check it out. Now we will say that the fair does not have any mentions of COVID systems or precautions in place. So bring your own hand sanitizer and keep in mind that it’s probably safest to mask up. With that, enjoy the fair and if you’d like to snag tickets and learn more you can click below.

data.title: Here's what to know about the historic Evergreen State Fair returning this weekend
data.description:
Need a pick me up this Monday? Well, get excited because one of Washington’s oldest and best traditions returns this weekend. We’re talking about the Evergreen State Fair. The fair returns this year on August 26th with the theme “Back in the Saddle Again” and is sure to be a classic Washington experience. The Evergreen State Fair has been happening since 1949 and has been bringing Washingtonians end-of-summer joy ever since. This year’s fair will be no different and possibly even better since we all missed it last year. You can enjoy classic fair carnival rides, fair foods, and live entertainment. Some of the performers this year include Foghat, Chris Janson, Zach Williams, and more. Related posts:
10 of the best things to do in & around Seattle this week (August 23-27)
The 2021-2022 Seattle Arts & Lectures lineup just went live and you don’t want to miss out  Of course, you’ll also be able to get up close and personal with some super cute farm animals and enjoy various equestrian shows like 4H, the Western Regional Clydesdale Show, and more. If you want some more fast-paced entertainment you can also watch Monster Trucks and even ride on one! There’s plenty of fun for everyone. As Washington has recently been cracking down with COVID-19 cases rising, the fair will be tweeting any updates that they have throughout the 12 days it’s running. For now, everything is good to go and you can purchase your tickets by clicking below.

data.title: You can ride a rare and historic steam-powered train on this Washington railroad
data.description:
Have you ever dreamed of having an uber-romantic cross country trip on a steam train? Well sadly, steam trains are a rarity in this day and age but don’t totally dash your hopes. Because one of the best ways to see Washington’s stunning landscape is via a visit to the Chehalis Centralia Railroad & Museum. The Chehalis Centralia Railroad is one of the only steam-powered railroads in the state. And to make things even more special, you can only ride the train seasonally. On weekends you can choose between two different train excursions. The first being the Chehalis Valley Coach Ride Excursion, a  13-mile round trip ride to Milburn. You’ll pass by views of wooded forests, old farmsteads, country homes, and tranquil nature sites. Related posts:
This beloved Washington lake once turned a woman into soap
The 2021-2022 Seattle Arts & Lectures lineup just went live and you don’t want to miss out The second option is the Riverview Coach Ride Excursion, an 18-mile round trip ride to a former rail stop at Ruth. On this extended run, you’ll follow alongside the Chehalis River and see its lush riverbanks, forests, and farmlands. Both rides are a great way to spend a day on a weekend and are only happening until September 25th. So run, don’t walk folks because you don’t want to miss out on riding a historic train. Now we will say the steam locomotive is currently being repaired but your train trip will still be just as spectacular as these locomotives and cars are historic. It’s certainly not a regular Amtrak trip and it’s also a great way to support an organization that is working to preserve Washington State history. Now if you still need a little nudge, the railroad also runs themed trains throughout the year and even wine tastings on specific weekend nights. So get your friends, your SO, your family, whoever you like, and head over to Chelis for the historic ride of a lifetime. You can learn more by clicking below and please tag us in any pics if you end up taking a ride. Enjoy folks!

data.title: You can explore Da Vinci's inventions brought to life at this new immersive exhibit in Seattle
data.description:
The past year has been full of a global boom of immersive exhibitions as folks return to both museums and events. The common theme of these events? Old masters from Van Gogh to Monet and more. If that happens to be up your alley you’re going to want to check out the MOHAI’s newest Da Vinci-centered exhibit that quietly opened last weekend. Da Vinci-Inventions is unlike other immersive exhibits in that you’re not going to enter a room with a bunch of projections. Rather, Grande Experiences curated the event to bring Da Vinci’s inventions to life in scale. That mean’s you can see a good chunk of the ultimate Renaissance man’s classic sketchbook drawings as real objects. Related posts:
Catch films from across the PNW at this 24th annual festival returning to Seattle
You can score a free bouquet from Pike Place Market if you have a Seattle staycation this month  In case you didn’t know, some of Da Vinci’s most notable inventions include things like the helicopter, the airplane, the automobile, the submarine, parachute, and bicycle. Obviously, Da Vinci laid the groundwork for these things rather than create the actual technology but being able to see the earliest version of these objects is going to be pretty dang cool. Beyond inventions, you’ll be able to check out some of Leonardo’s most famous codices, anatomical studies, and the Battle of Anghiari drawings. To really get into the details there’s an animated presentation of the Vitruvian Man and the Sforza horse sculpture. Best of all you have until January to check it out. The exhibition is great for folks of all ages and sure to spark some curiosity. So get out there and learn a thing or two, you won’t regret it. You can learn more and grab tickets by clicking below.

data.title: Sip craft beer from over 45 breweries at the zoo's boozy adults-only event this October
data.description:
Have you ever wanted to have an adult-only experience at the Woodland Park Zoo? Well, you can do that, enjoy local beer and get up close with the zoo’s ambassador animals. Sounds too good to be true right? It’s not! Brew at the Zoo is back this October and tickets are on sale now. Here’s what you can expect. Brew at the Zoo gives you a unique opportunity to explore the zoo while sipping on beers from over 45 of the finest local breweries. You can also enjoy imports, domestics, microbrews, ciders, and more. Seriously this event has it all and even more. But what’s best about this event is that proceeds go to support the over 900 animals at the Woodland Park Zoo. Related posts:
You can score a free bouquet from Pike Place Market if you have a Seattle staycation this month
Catch films from across the PNW at this 24th annual festival returning to Seattle  If you’re ready to buy tickets you have two options. The first is general admission which includes admission, 7 tasting tickets for beer/cider, ambassador animal experiences, and access to some award-winning exhibits. The second option is premium admission which includes a commemorative tasting glass, an exclusive ambassador animal experience, early entry to the event at 5 pm, and 5 additional tasting tickets. Now keep in mind you will be able to purchase additional drinks and also snacks regardless of which admission you pick. Now, this event pretty much always sells out in advance. So we highly recommend that you purchase your tickets ASAP as they went on sale today. If you’d like to learn more about the event or grab tickets you can click below.

data.title: Travel back in time at this magical Washington Renaissance Faire kicking off this weekend
data.description:
Are you a fan of all things medieval, magical, and Renaissance-themed? Well, you’re in luck because the Washington Midsummer Renaissance Faire kicks off this weekend! This August you can enjoy 3 themed weekends that are sure to give you the renaissance experience of your wildest dreams. This weekend on August 7th & 8th visitors will be able to watch as Merriwick is invaded by Pirates and the Great Horde during “Barbarians at the Gates”. If you’re visiting this weekend you’re encouraged to wear your best leathers, furs, hats, & boots to channel your inner Pirate. After all, you kind of need the full fit if you’re going to munch on massive turkey legs. Related posts:
You can score a free bouquet from Pike Place Market if you have a Seattle staycation this month
A brand new Topgolf venue just broke ground in the Seattle area  Then on August 14th & 15th, you’ll be able to step into a world of fantasy as Merriwick is taken over by faeries, witches, wizards, goblins, elves, dragons, and everything in between during “Myths & Magic”. It’s time to get out your wings and elf ears if you have them. You’ll be able to celebrate as the fairground becomes a world of lore and enchantment. Finally, on August 21st & 22nd you’ll be able to step forward or back in time during “Wandering Thru Time”. The last weekend is focused on celebrating all things science fiction. So be sure to come dressed in a costume from any time period or as your favorite character from any sci-fi book, movie, TV show, story, or comic. During each weekend you’ll be able to enjoy different live acts by the townspeople and royals of Merriwick. You’ll also be able to enjoy all sorts of eats from the food market and take home medieval-inspired wares from The Artisan Marketplace. Oh, and you can even camp at the fairground in case you have a little bit too much fun at the medieval pub. There are all sorts of options here and if you need a little escape from reality it’s well worth checking out. You can learn more and snag tickets you can click below.
data.where: : 19401 Sumner Buckley Hwy, Bonney Lake, WA

data.title: The Seattle Deconstructed Art Fair returns for a second year this August
data.description:
If you’re into the arts then chances are that you know about the Seattle Art Fair. Obviously, because of the pandemic, it hasn’t happened in a year and won’t be happening again until 2022. So in its place, art lovers can enjoy an even cooler fair known as Seattle Deconstructed Art Fair for the second year in a row. The Deconstructed Art Fair is the substitute for the larger fair which draws local, national, and international galleries. But what makes it extra cool is that it allows for smaller and local galleries to get a larger audience. In fact, this year there are over 50 galleries participating and you can visit them all on your own time online and in-person from August 5th-31st. Related posts:
Here are 10 of the most incredible times that Seattle went viral
You can’t miss this new larger than life pop art museum in Pioneer Square  To kick things off you’ll be able to enjoy the official return of the First Thursday Artwalk on August 5th from 6 pm-8 pm in Pioneer Square and Downtown. During that walk, you’ll be able to check out tons of galleries in the area and who knows, you might just end up taking a piece home. But if you’d rather wait and check it out on your own you can go as near or as far as Pioneer Square, Georgetown, Capitol Hill, Kirkland, Whidbey Island, and even Edison, WA. Because you have a month to check out this art fair you have plenty of time to see as much or as little art as you want. Keep in mind if you are visiting galleries in person that each gallery will have its own COVID-19 protocols. So with that in mind, keep your masks with you. Get out there and see some art and if you want to check out all of the participating galleries you can click below.
data.when: August 5th-31st, Starts with First Thursday Artwalk August 5th

data.title: A huge 7-acre sunflower festival is just weeks away and tickets are on sale now
data.description:
Now that we’re past the days of tulip festivals and in between the days of pumpkin patches you might as well see some sunflowers. This August and September you can head to Maris Farms to walk among acres of sunflowers and even take home your own bloom. But that’s not all, the farm’s Sunflower Days have all sorts of fun for folks of all ages. Maris Farms is opening its 7 acres of sunflowers to visitors each weekend between August 14th and September 19th. The farm has over a dozen different colors and varieties of sunflowers for you to enjoy and as part of admission, you can choose one bloom to cut! But if you want more flowers you can choose from the many other U-Cut blooms that the farm has to offer. Related posts:
You can stay at an Airbnb where Lewis and Clark once camped right here in Washington
36 of the absolute best things to do in & around Seattle this August  Also included in admission are all sorts of photo ops, the opportunity to play at the chalk truck, jump pillow, zip lines, human foosball, low ropes course, trike track, and barnyard ball zone. Additionally, you can check out the somewhat ominous-sounding gaga ball, conk the crow, and the roller bowler. You’ll have to visit and see for yourself! There’s something for folks of all ages between flowers, a farmer’s market, and the opportunity to sip some wine! We recommend purchasing tickets sooner rather than later as sunflowers only bloom once a year and there’s going to be a whole lot of people looking to get new Insta pics. Keep in mind that when you purchase tickets you get to choose both a date and time. With that, you can learn more and snag tickets by clicking below.

data.title: You can still get tickets to Washington's country-loving Watershed Festival this weekend
data.description:
If you’re in the mood to see some live music this weekend you’re in luck because you can go big. That’s right folks, Washington’s country-loving Watershed festival is back for 2021 and it’s happening in just 3 days! So get your camp on and see some of the nation’s favorite country artists right here in our state. Watershed is taking place at its usual venue, the scenic Gorge Amphitheater which overlooks the Columbia River. Like years past, you can indeed camp for all three days of the festival but keep in mind camping passes must be purchased separately. Unlike years past, you cannot buy single-day tickets so it’s all or nothing this year folks. Related post:
This southern Washington city is the fastest growing city in the state
You can stay at an Airbnb where Lewis and Clark once camped right here in Washington  As for COVID safety? Well, the festival simply states that they’d like to “provide as close to a normal Watershed Festival experience as possible, while also maintaining everyone’s safety”. But there are no mentions of what said safety is other than following state guidelines. So be sure to bring masks, hand sanitizer, and don’t go if you’re not vaccinated. You’re probably also wondering who all is playing this year. There are 16 different artists playing with big names like Tim McGraw, Kelsea Ballerini, Thomas Rhett, and more. Beyond the musicians, a big draw of the festival is obviously all that partying that happens at the campsites. So listen to the music, party or simply take in the views, there are multiple ways to enjoy this festival. Tickets are still available but who knows, they could go quickly so we recommend hopping on them ASAP if you’d like to hit the festival this weekend. With that stay safe and enjoy folks!

data.title: You can check out welcome back celebration in Seattle's CID this weekend
data.description:
Remember a few weeks back when we mentioned the Seattle “Welcome Back Weeks”? Well, they’re finally here with a new name, “Welcome Back Seattle and the first one is happening this weekend in the Chinatown International District. Let’s get into the deets. This celebration is the first of many to help welcome people back into Seattle’s downtown which has been sort of like a ghost town throughout the pandemic. To do this, the Seattle Office of Arts & Culture is holding a two-day celebration of local food and culture at Hing Hay Park. That means you’ll be able to enjoy cultural performances, live music, and performances from artists like Hollis, Chong the Nomad, and more! Related posts:
10 of the best things to do in Seattle this weekend (July 16-July 18)
There are a few tickets left to catch Seattle’s own Kenny G at shows this week Summer is here, downtown is reopening, & we’re celebrating with #WelcomeBackSeattle events! Join us at #HingHayPark 7/17 & 7/18 from 11am-7pm for performances, activities, & tasty #CID treats. We’ll have live local music, cultural celebrations, and more! https://t.co/6WDOGtdtbA pic.twitter.com/LbwUDCIBY5 — Mayor Jenny Durkan (@MayorJenny) July 12, 2021  And if you haven’t gotten your vaccine yet, there will also be a vaccination pop-up. You can really do it all this weekend and if you’re busy that’s no worries because you also have the Pioneer Square and Westlake welcome back events to check out. If you can we absolutely recommend checking them all out. With that be sure to get down to Hing Hay Park this weekend. Consider also shopping at local stores or treating yourself to a meal at a local restaurant. After all, these businesses need our help and we might as well make it a part of the celebration! data.title: Here's everything to expect at this weekend's King County Fair
data.description:
Yet another beloved Washington tradition is returning after a pandemic hiatus. The King County Fair is returning to the Enumclaw Expo Center this weekend! Now as times are changing, you can expect a few things to be a bit different this year. But we promise it will be just as good as years past. Despite Washington being fully open again, fair organizers still want to be cautious and keep the King County Fair as safe as possible. That means you can expect to see increased handwashing stations and of course, it’s always best to keep up with the social distancing. But the good news is that pretty much all your faves from past years will be there. Related posts:
Seattle just ranked as one of the best US cities to live in
The best retro drive-in theatres you can find in Washington  That means this year you’ll be able to enjoy four whole days of food, rides, animal displays, and more. Now keep in mind this fair is quite short and is only happening from Thursday-Sunday so you’ll definitely want to get on buying those tickets. After all, it’s probably been a bit since you’ve been to the fair and this one happens to be the oldest fair west of the Mississippi. Betcha didn’t know that! If you’d like to learn more or grab tickets you can click below. We hope that you guys get out there and enjoy the fair this weekend, it’s one of the state’s most beloved traditions and we’re so happy to see it back in person this year. Enjoy folks!

data.title: You can't miss this new larger than life pop art museum in Pioneer Square
data.description:
There’s a pretty unique art gallery hidden in Seattle that you probably don’t know about. It’s a “Black-Owned, artist-led art gallery and neighborhood cultural institution” and trust us, you’re going to want to visit. Ready to check out a real piece of Seattle? Let’s take a look at Martyr Sauce. Martyr Sauce was founded in 2012 by artist and curator Tariqa Waters and is located in the historic arts district of Pioneer Square. Now there’s a new part of this iconic space that you need to see because it’s truly larger than life. And that is the Martyr Sauce Pop Art Museum. Right now, it’s been transformed into a bubble gum pink space filled with massive handmade reproductions of objects from the ’60s TV show Julia. Related posts:
10 of the best things to do in Seattle this weekend (July 9-July 11)
A brand new two day music festival is happening in Seattle this September  Now the space’s future will most likely be very multi-use. Waters wants to commission and encourage artists to use the space. The beginning of that is a collaboration with Tacoma artist Kenji Hamai Stoll and Clyde Petersen. Both artists have work currently in one of the space’s galleries. And both shows are eye-catching and immersive experiences that you should definitely check out. If you plan on visiting you can book your tickets ahead of time by clicking below. You’ll need to wear a mask and will be asked to put on protective booties when you arrive. Also, keep in mind that no more than 4 people are allowed in per 30-minute time slot. So book those tickets now because they’re pretty much sold out until August.

data.title: Washington's oldest winery has amazing summer concert series you can't miss
data.description:
We’ve all greatly missed attending concerts and it’s looking like there will be plenty to enjoy this summer. But not all concerts are created equal and that’s why we think you should know about the Chateau Ste Michelle concert series. It looks pretty dang spectacular and they have. aline up of artists that might have not even known were in town! The winery’s summer concert series takes place outdoors at the Chateau Amphitheater. Between proof of full COVID-19 vaccination or a negative COVID-19 test within 48 hours, social distancing, and the outdoors, you can feel pretty dang safe when it comes to attending these concerts. Not to mention, the winery is closely following WA State COVID-19 health protocols so you’ll be in good hands. Related posts:

Here are Washington’s most famous filming locations that Hollywood loves  With all that out of the way, let’s get into the fun stuff. Throughout August and September, you can attend 12 different concerts. Some of the performing musicians include Fitz & The Tantrums, Train, and Chris Isaak. Just imagine getting to sing along to some of your favorite songs with a glass or bottle of some amazing local wine. Sounds pretty dreamy right? Well, you’ll be able to do all that this summer. Some tickets are currently on sale while others will go on sale later in the month. Prices are determined by the artist and the event so you’ll see a slight fluctuation between each artist. We have to say this seems like one of the cooler concert series that you can attend this summer so you might just see us out there. Are you planning on going? Be sure to let us know down below. data.title: The lineup of Ballard's first in-person music fest was just announced!
data.description:
In April we found out that you’ll be able to attend a music festival with live music this fall. It’s called Freakout Festival and while that seemed a little crazier last month it’s still kinda hard to believe. After all, none of us are used to normal concertgoing times at this point. But if you plan on attending you should be excited because the lineup was just announced. If you’re unfamiliar with Freakout Festival, it’s been around since 2013 and is produced by independent record label Freakout Records. The festival features all sorts of bands from the Pacific Northwest and beyond. Plus it’s a great opportunity to support many of Ballard’s small venues which have been closed for well over a year now. Some of the venues participating include The Tractor, Sunset Tavern, and more. Related posts:
Here’s how you can get a Discover Pass for FREE in Seattle
Seattle may want to decriminalize psychedelics — Here’s what to know  Now the wait for the lineup is over and you can go ahead and start purchasing festival passes. You’ll be able to see artists like Cedric Burnside, Liz Cooper, The Seeds, and many many more. You can opt for a two or four-day pass with VIP or GA options. Honestly, with how long it’s been since we’ve all been able to attend a music festival, the four-day pass is probably in order. If you’d like to learn more about Freakout Festival or snag tickets, you can click below. Normally we’d warn that things could change but we’re feeling pretty optimistic about this one happening. So get out there and treat yourself to some live music this fall.

data.title: You can see over 70 Disney costumes at MoPOP's new immersive exhibition
data.description:
We’ll bet that at least a few of you are Disney fans and if that’s the case then you need to head over to MoPOP. Heroes and Villains is the newest show at the museum and it’s all about the art of the Disney costume. You’ll be immersed in the world of Disney, “through the artistry and creativity of its costumes”. The exhibition features more than 70 original pieces, including items like ball gowns, sorcerers’ capes, tiaras, and even some glass slippers. While the items themselves are obviously amazing, the exhibition explores just how some of these iconic costumes came to exist. You’ll get to see costumes worn by Disney’s loving heroes and evil villains and everyone in between. Related posts:
30 of the best things to do in Seattle this June
14 of the best FREE or cheap things to do in Seattle this June  If you want more than the exhibition you can also check out some special virtual programs. These programs feature panel discussions, movie watch along, and more! In our opinion, it’s worth it to check out both the in-person show and the digital events for a full experience. What’s best of all is that Heroes and Villains is opening this weekend so be sure to hop online and grab a ticket. Whether you like Disney or are simply interested in set and costume design, this exhibition is definitely worth checking out. In fact, we might just see you out there. If you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: A live concert is taking off at the Museum of Flight this Saturday
data.description:
If you still scrambling to make plans this weekend there’s something pretty dang cool happening tomorrow that you might want to check out. The concerts take place at the Museum of Flight’s outdoor pavilion making it a safe and extremely unique venue. data.title: Northwest Folklife is celebrating it's 50th anniversary with a massive virtual festival
data.description:
We’ve all greatly missed Seattle’s festivals. And while we were hoping for an in-person return in 2021 clearly that’s not going to be the case. But the good news is that Northwest Folklife is happening this month and is celebrating its 50th anniversary in a brand new online and digital format. Get ready to enjoy Folklife like never before! As always, the festival is free for you to enjoy. And this year it will be as full of events as ever. You’ll be able to take a look at 50 years of Folklife celebrated through dance, performance, panel presentations, and much more. You’ll also be able to see a curated livestream of performance, music, and dance works from Pacific Northwest artists. It will certainly be a lot to see and well worth checking out. Related posts:
10 local vintage clothing shops in Seattle you don’t want to miss
You can stay in one of 29 vintage travel trailers at this unique Washington resort  Another huge part of the festival is the diverse group of vendors that come to sell their wares. And like past festivals, you’ll still be able to purchase all sorts of items thanks to the virtual marketplace. Honestly, we have a feeling that this is going to be one of the more successful major virtual festivals that our city has done. So we’re quite excited to attend! We highly recommend that you hop online and check out the schedule of artists as we can guarantee there are at least a few performances that you’ll want to check out. If you’d like to learn more or check out the lineup and marketplace you can click below. Have fun and happy folklife!

data.title: Shop flowers galore at the Pike Place Market Flower Festival this weekend

If you happen to like fresh flowers then you absolutely need to visit Pike Place Market this weekend. Because it just so happens to be the 13th Annual Flower Festival. You’ll be able to shop all of your favorite spring blooms and support both local farmers and the market. On Saturday and Sunday, the market will fill with over 40 tents all offering their blooming wares. You can expect to see spring favorites like tulips, daffodils, irises, and peonies. 12 unique day trips you can take near Seattle
12 great Seattle shops to check out for Mother’s Day gifts  If you end up spending over $50 you’ll also be able to snag a mesh shopping bag and sunglasses while supplies last. Plus your visit to the festival is also a great opportunity to see what some of the other craft sellers have to offer. And in case you forgot about Mother’s Day, this festival might just come in handy with a gift or two. If you’d like to learn more about the Pike Place Market Flower Festival you can click here. And if you end up snagging some beautiful blooms be sure to tag us in your pics. We’d love to see what you all end up taking home. With that have a great weekend and enjoy the festival!

data.title: You can dine at a 14th-century feast at this medieval village in Washington
data.description:
Have you ever been curious about what life was like during the dark ages? Well, it turns out that you can actually get a pretty good idea of it at Camlann Medieval Village in Washington. This extremely unique village is dedicated to educating people about what life was like in the 14th century at their living and breathing museum. And part of that education includes food! Several times a year, Camlann puts on grand feasts at its Bors Hede Inne. These feasts are prepared from recipes enjoyed by the noble classes because you are, of course, royalty. And trust us, don’t be scared about the food because it actually sounds pretty dang good. Some menu items include things like Blaunch Porre which is sweet leeks and quail. See? It’s not nearly as barbaric as you thought. Related posts:
12 unique day trips you can take near Seattle
You can stay in one of Seattle’s most iconic homes on Millionaire’s Row  In our books, this is probably one of the most unique dining experiences that you can get in Washington. And if you’re interested in trying it out, you’re in luck because there are several feasts happening this summer. On June 19th and 20th, you can enjoy a delicious Midsomer Feast (without all the scariness of an Ari Aster film). And if you can’t make those dates you can enjoy St James Feasts on July 24th and 25th. So treat yourself to a new and truly unique dining experience that will transport you back centuries. Who knows, maybe 14th-century cuisine will end up being your new fave thing. Because you can’t knock it till you try it right? If you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: You can stay in one of Seattle's most iconic homes on Millionaire's Row
data.description:
If you’ve walked Capitol hill before then you probably know about Millionaire’s Row. This stretch of 14th Ave E holds the past homes of some of Seattle’s most iconic founders. And one of those homes actually happens to be a stunning bed and breakfast that you can stay in. Let’s take a look at the Shafer Baillie Mansion. The Shafer Baillie Mansion is a 14,000 square-foot Tudor Revival home built in 1914. The mansion’s name references two of its earliest owners, Alexander Baillie and Julius Shafer. And what’s extra cool is that Alexander Baillie was responsible for introducing golf to the western United States. Who knew? Related posts:
This Seattle business will help you create your dream picnic
Here’s how the world is reacting to Seattle’s latest billionaire divorce  Photo via Shafer Baille Mansion When it comes to staying at the mansion you can expect a stay with old-world charm and modern amenities. And you can choose between eight different rooms with nightly prices ranging from $159-$269 a night. Many rooms have unique features like antique furniture or bathrooms with fixtures original to the home. And as each room is unique it means you have a reason to come back time and time again.  Photo via Shafer Baille Mansion As this is a bed and breakfast you also expect a delicious continental-style breakfast in the morning. So what are you waiting for? Book yourself a staycation and take a step back into a bygone Seattle era, you won’t regret it. If you’d like to learn more about the Shafer Baillie Mansion you can click below.

data.title: You can explore an abandoned army base at this Washington State Park
data.description:
Alright, adventurers, if you’re in need of something a little different, then a trip to Whidbey Island is in order. Once there, you can explore an abandoned army base at Fort Casey Historical State Park. You can run through old bunkers, batteries, tunnels, and more! It’s unlike anything else in the state and visiting this park is sure to give you an unforgettable experience. Now before we get any flack, we use the term ‘abandoned’ lightly. Because the forts here are actually maintained by the park, however, they are no longer in use by the military. In fact, they’ve been empty since the 1940s and actually date all the way back to the 1800s. So a visit to Fort Casey will definitely take you back in time. Related posts:
Your car will actually drive itself up this magnetic hill in Washington
This WWII coast watcher’s shack in Washington is now a beachfront Airbnb with a pool  Photo via Shutterstock Don’t worry, the forts are perfectly safe and while they may feel like a maze, you probably won’t get lost. But if you’re afraid of the dark, you’ll definitely want to bring a flashlight. That being said the only thing you’re likely to encounter in the tunnels is other curious explorers. And if running in the dark isn’t really your thing you can check out the rest of the 999-acre marine camping park. You can catch amazing views of Puget Sound or bring a kite and fly it in one of the large fields. Plus you can also check out the early 1900s lighthouse and interpretive center if you’re in the mood to learn. Because trust us, there’s a lot more to this park than meets the eye. It’s hard to put into words just how cool this local historic site is and trust us, it never really gets old. So whether you’ve been before or this is your first time hearing about Fort Casey, it’s time to take a trip. Now keep in mind that park closures may happen so be sure to read the park website before leaving. And of course, bring a mask and hand sanitizer with you. With all that out of the way, get out there and enjoy this piece of Washington history.

data.title: The Seattle Asian Art Museum is returning after nearly a year long closure
data.description:
We don’t know about you guys but we’ve really enjoyed visiting our local museums since they’ve reopened. However, you might have noticed that one museum still hasn’t reopened. And that’s the brand spanking new Seattle Asian Art Museum. But get excited because it’s coming back this month. You probably remember but this museum went under an extensive two-year renovation and had just reopened when the pandemic started. In fact, it was only open again for a little over a month before it was forced to shutter its doors. And that means many of us missed out on the opportunity to see just how cool the new and improved museum is. Related posts:10 of the coolest things that were invented in Seattle
10 socially distant things to do in Seattle this week (April 26-30) If you happen to be a Seattle Art Museum member you’re in luck because the museum will be opening to you on May 7th. But if you’re not, don’t worry, you’ll be able to check out the museum on May 28th. And like the main Seattle Art Museum, tickets will be sold only online in timed slots. These will probably go quickly so plan ahead and book your tickets now. We hope that you’re able to get out there and check out this truly unique museum and the amazing art pieces it has to offer. If you’d like to learn more about the Seattle Asian Art Museum you can click below. And as always if you check it out, let us know what you think. Have a great May folks!

Goodbye Pier 58, here’s a peek at Seattle’s upcoming Waterfront Park  So while you’ll have to wait a while for a lineup, you can get a head start by purchasing festival passes. data.title: You can explore a fully illuminated cave system right here in Washington
data.description:
If all the time at home during the pandemic has really awakened the inner explorer in you, then you’re going to want to keep reading. Because it turns out that there’s a fully illuminated cave system that you can explore right here in Washington. And best of all, it’s free! The cave system in question is Gardener Cave which is located within Crawford State Park in Metaline Falls, Washington. It also happens to be the third-longest limestone cavern in Washington at just over 2,000 feet. Meaning you can walk among stalactites, stalagmites, rimstone pools, and flowstone that were 500 million years in the making. Pretty dang cool right?  Photo via Washington State Parks Foundation A long metal staircase and series of platforms guide you safely along the cave pathways with lights illuminating the unique formations. You’ll want to keep your eyes peeled because trust us, these rocks are anything but ordinary. Related posts:
10 socially distant things to do in Seattle this weekend (April 23-25)
You can now pay with your hand at Whole Foods stores in Seattle  
Photo via Washington State Parks Foundation In fact, the unique formations that you see in the caves were actually created by dead sea creatures decomposing over time which created an ooze that eventually became limestone. Among these formations is the caves 7.8-ton column which happens to be the largest in the Pacific Northwest. And if you really want to get a closer look be sure to bring a flashlight with you when you visit. But be sure not to touch the formations.  Photo via Washington State Parks Foundation Now we know you’re probably already packing your bag to give Gardner Cave a visit. But hold your horses because the cave reopens in May and if you want one of the parks free tours you have to schedule ahead of time. Don’t worry you can find all those details by clicking below. And if you do decide to go, be sure to bring layers because the cave is around 39 to 42 degrees Fahrenheit.
data.when: May-September, Cave tours daily 10 am, 12 pm, 2 pm, and 4 pm
data.where: : Crawford State Park Heritage Site, 10381 Boundary Road, Metaline Falls, WA 99152

data.title: You'll soon be to able walk among life-sized dinos in Seattle
data.description:
It’s been a while since dinosaurs walked the Earth in Washington state. We’re talking over 65 million years ago. But if you’ve ever wanted to see what dinosaurs are like up close and personal you can do just that at the Woodland Park Zoo. The zoo’s brand new, immersive Dinosaur Discovery exhibit opens this May and lets you walk among dozens of life-sized dinos. The Dinosaur Discovery exhibit is presented by T-Mobile and features dinosaurs from renowned animatronics maker Dino Don Inc. Trust us, these hand-made dinos will probably blow your expectations out of the park. In fact, you might just be convinced that you’re in Jurassic Park. So don’t scare yourself too silly, especially when it comes to the dinos that are over 30 feet tall. Related posts:
Here are the best Seattle concerts scheduled to come to town this year
Seattle Independent Bookstore Day is back this month with a few differences  Now, this exhibit is technically aimed at younger folks. But as full-grown adults, we’re definitely going to check this out. Because it really isn’t every day that you get to experience roaring and breathing prehistoric giants. And it’s just one more excuse to check out our favorite zoo ever. Plus it’s worth mentioning that all ticket proceeds from the exhibit go back to helping care for the animals at the Woodland Park Zoo. That’s a win-win if you ask us. The Dinosaur Discovery exhibit will only be on for a limited time so we highly recommend that you purchase zoo tickets in advance. Because we have an inkling that this is going to be super popular. And you definitely don’t want to miss out. So if you’d like to learn more or snag a ticket or two, you can click below.

data.title: Seattle Independent Bookstore Day is back this month with a few differences
data.description:
If you’re a local bookworm then you probably need no introduction to Seattle Independent Bookstore Day. Or maybe you do. Whatever the case may be, this beloved race to shop at 21 local bookstores is back but with a few differences to make it COVID-19 safe. Keep on reading to find out more. If you’ve participated in the event before then you know normally you have to visit 21 bookstores in one day to snag that amazing discount card. Well, this year there will be no day-long race but there will be a 10-day long one. That’s right folks, this year you have to make 1 purchase from 10 different participating bookstores in the course of 10 days. All you really have to do is remember the number 10. Related posts:
The 12 best places to see cherry blossoms in Seattle this spring  And to make things even more accessible you can either visit the stores in person or online. So from April 24th-May 3rd be sure to spend your money at one of the stores below. Ada’s Technical Books, Arundel Books, Book Larder, BookTree, Brick & Mortar Books, Eagle Harbor Book Co., Edmonds Bookshop, Elliott Bay Book Co., Fantagraphics Bookstore, Island Books, Liberty Bay Books, Magnolia’s Bookstore, Neverending Bookshop, Open Books: A Poetry Emporium, Paper Boat Booksellers, Page 2 Books, Phinney Books/Madison Books, Queen Anne Book Co., Secret Garden Books, Third Place Books, and University Bookstore. Because when you get through 10and show your receipts, you’ll get a limited edition 2021 Seattle Independent Bookstore Day tote bag. So while it’s not the same as years past we’re happy to see that nearly every single bookstore in 2019’s competition is still in business. And we’ll keep our fingers crossed for a full return to book crazy fun in 2022. If you’d like to learn more you can click below.

data.title: Music
data.description: Feist 1, 2, 3, 4 Feist is knocking at your door… everyone who was alive in the early 2000s remembers the vice hold that Feist’s poppy tunes had on the world. So why not hear them again? The Flaming Lips Do You Realize?? The opportunity you have here to see one of America’s fave psychedelic rock bands? Yes, this is a show you should definitely go see. Due to their popularity most available tickets are resale so expect to pay a little extra if you’re planning on going. Jam out to your old faves and some newer songs as well. TLC No Scrubs, Waterfalls, Creep… how could you not go see some of the most iconic songs of the 90s performed live. Molchat Doma If you’ve been on TikTok in the past year then you’ve definitely heard Molchat Doma. The Belarusian darkwave/post-punk band has blown up in the past few years and is probably worth attending.

data.title: Arts & Culture
data.description: Karaoke with Baby Ketten Ready to sing to your heart’s content in front of a bunch of strangers or your friends? It might just be time to head to karaoke at Cafe Racer. You’ll find a professional sound system, lights, a real stage, and an impressive library of music. A Festival for May at Camlann Village Watch garland weaving, textiles, blacksmithing, basket making, leatherworking, and pottery. You’ll also be able to view longbow archery demonstrations, village dancing, and even tune into the harmonious medieval music of Mynstrels. And yes, you’ll also be able to celebrate Mayday with a great pole, decked with flowers, streamers, and greens complete with a traditional maypole ceremony. Cat Tower! Cat towers are a necessary accessory for cat owners but they aren’t exactly the best looking. This unique group show focuses on Frank Crow’s invention of the cat tower. Yes, the works are inspired by the thing your cat dulls its nails on. Ooh La La! Now that the new year has come and gone, folks are looking towards the next big holiday, Valentine’s Day. Can Can’s newest show is a rose-colored soirée to remember, an original Parisian-inspired production. Like their other shows, you’ll also be able to sip on lavish libations and nosh on delectable delicacies while watching the performers work their magic. Green Book Tour The Green Book Tour is a new self-guided history tour created by the soon-to-open Black & Tan Hall. It’s available both online and as an app depending on your needs. When taking the tour you’ll be transported back in time to the 1920s and 30s as you learn all about the Black-owned and Black-friendly businesses that operated along Seattle’s Jackson Street. Inland Empire In need of a weird movie to watch? Instead of seeing something new, watch something a tad bit older. David Lynch’s Inland Empire is taking over The Beacon for multiple showings throughout May. It’s the perfect amount of freaky and funky. SIN at Kremwerk Each first Saturday Kremwerk puts on SIN, a fetish, EBM, and industrial night. You can expect fetish performances, drinks, and dancing. Additionally, you can see features by Seattle Shibari and professional photography by Jason Renek. If you’re looking for something new, this might just be worth checking out. MARY! A Drag Happy Hour Each week on Tuesday you can attend a drag happy hour at Chop Suey. You’ll be able to watch drag icon Jane Don’t and three of Seattle’s other premiere drag beauties do their thing. It’s sure to be the most fun you’ve had at a happy hour in a while. Contact High: A Visual History of Hip-Hop If you’ve ever wanted to see behind-the-scenes images of your favorite hip-hop artists, this exhibit is for you. MoPOP’s newest exhibit, Contact High allows visitors to see over 170 images of hip hop’s most influential artists like Missy Elliott, Jay-Z, Queen Latifah, Tupac, and more. See four decades of photography, from the late 70s to today, documenting a revolution across different aspects of life. Silent Reading Party: In-Person The beloved Silent Reading Party is back in person if you’d like to have the experience of reading amongst strangers inside of the beautiful Hotel Sorrento. Keep in mind there is a $20 food and drink minimum on top of your ticket price. Northwest Folklife This year’s festival is back in person! It’s all about celebrating “people’s natural propensity for change.” And while this year’s festival focuses on change you’ll still have old mainstays like live performances, vendors, food, and more. Lauren Halsey: 2021 Knight Lauren Halsey’s show is the Seattle Art Museums’ next upcoming exhibition. Her work “spans sculpture, installation, and architecture, including site-specific projects, particularly in the South Central neighborhood of Los Angeles.” Further, “her work maintains a sense of civic urgency and free-flowing imagination, reflecting the lives of the people and places around her and addressing the crucial issues confronting people of color, queer populations, and the working class.” Recent Acquisitions: Jeffry Mitchell The Frye is showcasing work from local “gay folk artist” Jeffry Mitchell. This show highlights his work with lotus bulbs and is sure to be one of the better shows that you see this year. Think bright bright, happy and fun pieces.

data.title: Food & Drink
data.description: Hit up a waterfront patio Ready for patio season? We’re right behind ya and that’s why we made a list of some of our favorite waterfront patios around the city. Because what’s better than a patio on the water? Try a wine subscription Local natural wine shop and bar La Dive actually offers a monthyl wine subscription! When you sign up you can choose between three different subscription options. The first option is two bottles a month for $42, then four bottles a month for $84, or six bottles a month for $120. Catch a view on a rooftop patio If you’re looking to eat out this month, why not take in some beautiful Seattle spring views? We’ve compiled a list of our favorite restaurants with rooftop patios perfect for taking in the sights of the city. Whether you’re looking for eats, drinks or both, these spots have you covered.

data.title: At Home
data.description: See what’s new on Netflix A new month means tons of new additions. May’s Netflix additions are a mix of new originals and some old favorites. While it may not be as big as January’s additions it’s still well worth checking out. You can also see what’s leaving Netflix in May as well. Virtual Silent Reading Party For those of you that love the Silent Reading Party but are more comfortable at home, you can still enjoy the virtual version. You’ll also get to hear piano tunes from pianist Paul Matthew Moore as you read amongst strangers over zoom.

data.title: Misc
data.description: Washington State Apple Blossom Festival The festival has all sorts of events for attendees to enjoy. Check out events like a food fair featuring eats from Kaleenka Piroshky, Keep it in the Valley Funnel Cakes, Ali’i Hawaiin Shave Ice, and more. There’s also a massive carnival (America’s 7th largest), live performances and even eating contests. That’s not all though, there’s seriously an event for everyone and you need to view the calendar for yourself. Baby Animals and Blooms Days at Maris Farms This event is all about embracing the potential of spring. You’ll find a local farmer’s market, vendors, adult, and baby animal cuteness, as well as fields of beautiful blooms. It’s an event that’s great for folks of all ages with something for everyone to see, enjoy and experience. Check out a plant sale If you’re looking to get your spring garden started you might as well check out some of the amazing plant sales happening around the city this month. Whether you want indoor or outdoor plants, seeds or tools, these sales have you covered. As always we’ve created a list detailing when and where to go. Take a road trip to a themed hotel Have you been wanting to drive down the West Coast? Why not make your trip a little more lively by staying at a themed hotel? From romantic suites to pirate-themed bedrooms, we’ve found several hotels worth checking out. Take a tour over the city Walking tours are cool and all but why not experience Seattle from a birds-eye view? Don’t worry, you don’t have to have a pilot’s license, instead, you can choose from one of several plane tours offered in and around the Seattle area. Of course Get some work done in a new space Next, a trio of some “regular”, but still fun, options around the city. If working from home is getting a little old, then maybe check out our roundup of some of the best cafes in the city to get some work done. Brews ‘n Board Games Snapshot Brewing offers an all-day happy hour for casual tabletop gamers! You can either borrow theirs or bring your own; fill up our punch card and win cool stuff. And get sweet deals like $9 house growler fills every Sunday. Pop up plant sales at Rhododendron Species Botanical Garden Throughout spring, the Rhododendron Species Botanical Garden will host featured vendor weekends in partnership with local nurseries. In April you’ll be able to shop from Puget Sound Daylily Club on May 1st, Courting Frogs on May 14th & 15th, and Botanica on May 28th & 29th. With that, have a great May and we’ll see you back here in June!

data.title: A Festival for May at Camlann Village
data.description: Watch garland weaving, textiles, blacksmithing, basket making, leatherworking, and pottery. You’ll also be able to view longbow archery demonstrations, village dancing, and even tune into the harmonious medieval music of Mynstrels. And yes, you’ll also be able to celebrate Mayday with a great pole, decked with flowers, streamers, and greens complete with a traditional maypole ceremony.

data.title: Karaoke with Baby Ketten
data.description: Ready to sing to your heart’s content in front of a bunch of strangers or your friends? It might just be time to head to karaoke at Cafe Racer. You’ll find a professional sound system, lights, a real stage, and an impressive library of music.

data.title: Check out one of Capitol Hill’s newest restos
data.description: Money Frog is the newest spot from the folks behind Taurus Ox and Hangry Panda. They serve up pan-Asian cuisine in the former location of Capitol Hill’s Vios. You can dine on items like condensed milk peanut prawns, soft shell chili crab, and green beans. You’ll also find menu items like fried frog legs, cacio e pepe with yakisoba noodles, and curry ketchup fried rice. Our mouths are already watering.

data.description: Hear from a panel of artists whose works deeply reflect concerns for the environment and the planet. Artists include Suze Woolf, Beverly Naidus, and Shu-Ju Wang. Not only is the event going to be interesting and informative but it’s also an excuse to head to Bainbridge Island.

data.title: Deftones
data.description:
Nothing like nu-metal for spring right folks? Well, no matter what you think about Deftones you really can’t go wrong with them. Dare we say this will be the best concert in April? You’ll also be able to catch opener Gojira. Recent posts:

data.title: The Brian Jonestown Massacre
data.description: At one point or another, we’ve probably all had the cords to Pish stuck in our heads. Might as well get them out by seeing The Brian Jonestown Massacre live and in person. Plus their opener is Mercury Rev, double whammy.

data.title: Boren Banner Series: Sadie Wechsler
data.description: This piece is outside, it’s free to visit and you can do so at pretty much any time of day. Plus Wechsler’s new piece explores the history of Seattle’s own First Hill. The artist consulted the Burke Museum and members of the Duwamish Tribe in order to create a photograph that represents the ecological history of the area.

You can watch films from nearly any genre you can think of as there are over 160 films being shown. Why not make it a challenge and see how many you can watch?

data.description: As the La Conner Daffodil Festival wraps up, the Skagit Valley Tulip Festival is beginning. See all of your favorite blooms at your preferred festival farm and of course, grab some blooms to take home. Best of all, you have all month to check it out. Have a great weekend, Seattle!

data.title: Sugarloaf
data.description: The Anacortes Community Forest Lands are a great place to spend a day exploring. Because there you’ll be able to summit Sugarloaf Mountain and check out a beautiful array of wildflowers as well as water views. Plus it’s a beautiful drive up north.

data.title: Paradise at Mount Rainier
data.description: There’s a reason this side of Rainier has its name. Paradise is pretty much exactly as its name suggests. Expect to see the mountain up close and personal with amazing views of fields of wildflowers. It’s seriously a bucket list view, don’t sleep on this one, folks.

data.title: Sunrise at Mount Rainier
data.description: If you’re going to make the trek out to the mountain then it’s well worth your time to head to the other side of the mountain. At Sunrise you’ll be 1000 feet higher and will have the opportunity to see a real alpine ecosystem. Plus if you want to stretch your legs you can check out an easy 2 ½ mile hike full of views. Trust us, it’s well worth your time.

data.title: Tiffany Mountain
data.description: Walking Freezeout Ridge at Tiffany Mountain is a great way to see some of Washington’s most unique landscapes. You get to walk through summer grazing country and as you work your way up you’ll also pass through the remnants of a fire zone. But the real winner here is the beautiful blooms you’ll see the higher you get.

data.title: Ancient Lakes
data.description: Just because eastern Washington is a desert climate doesn’t mean that the area is lacking foliage. In fact, these areas are some of the best places to see the unique blooms and plants that grow in the driest parts of the state. So take a hike and play a little game of eye spy to see what blooms you can see.

data.title: Mount Sawyer
data.description:
You can have your cake and eat it too at Mount Sawyer’s Tonga Ridge. A wander along this beautiful trail will reward you with several miles of huckleberry fields later on in the season. That means you can eat as you walk and also enjoy the wildflower blooms along the trail. Sounds pretty idyllic, doesn’t it? Related posts:
6 popular movie stars that you may not know are from Washington
Washington state just ranked as one of the best places to camp in 2022

data.title: Kendall Katwalk
data.description: This trail isn’t for the faint of heart. Kendall Katwalk is known for its narrow path which is along a rocky cliffside. But we’re including it because the walk to this part of the trail is full of alpine wildflowers. So go all the way and live a little bit or just meander and check out the flowers before the trail gets too real.

data.title: Sauk Mountain
data.description: We love this wildflower hike because you get to see blooms as low as the parking lot and as high up as the peak. What’s extra cool is that you can see how the blooms change as you gain a higher elevation. Sauk Mountain is well worth the hike for both the blooms and stunning views.

data.title: Hurricane Hill
data.description: If you’re headed to Olympic National Park then this hike should absolutely be on your itinerary. Hurricane Hill is known for its insane views but you’ll stay for the beautiful array of wildflower blooms. The trail is also pretty wide and paved making it easier on the feet than some of the other hikes on this list.

data.title: Dog Mountain
data.description: Dog Mountain is so popular in spring and summer that a permit is required for all hikers. That being said, the hike is absolutely worth the permit due to the amazing array of blooms and the bird’s eye view of Mount Hood and the Columbia River.

data.title: Lower Mad River Valley
data.description: On this hike you’ll find rocky canyons, fragrant ponderosa pine forests and an abundance of wildflowers. If you’re really feeling it you can even do the 17-mile thru-hike on the nearby Chelan Lakeshore Trail.

data.title: Mima Mounds
data.description: Visiting the Mima Mounds is a bit of a double whammy. The mounds are considered one of Washington’s most unique natural formations and also happen to be a great place to see wildflowers. Visit them for yourself to see what the mysterious mounds are about. That’s what we have when it comes to the best places to see wildflowers in Washington this spring. We hope that you get out there and see some blooms.

You’ll get to watch as your favorite tales like “The Walrus and the Carpenter” and “The Stolen Tart” are set to original music and performed by a local cast. It’s an experience designed to cater to all the senses.

data.title: Interbay Golf Course
data.description: This one is probably somewhat obvious as it’s smack dab in the heart of Seattle and a popular spot for both mini-golf fans and players looking for a 9 hole course. The mini-golf course is cute and suitable for players of all ages and is easily accessible for people not wanting to go far from the city.

data.title: Green Lake Pitch and Putt
data.description: This small golf course is a Seattle located along the beloved and scenic Green Lake. It’s not the biggest but it’s a great spot to enjoy with friends if you’re in North Seattle and of course, you can also go for a walk around the lake after.

data.title: Flat Stick Pub
data.description:
This unique pub is a great spot to grab drinks and play some mini-golf. There aren’t many places where you can do that and to make things better, the pub has multiple locations. You can check them out in Pike Place Market, South Lake Union, Kirkland, Bellingham, Spokane, and Tacoma. Related posts:
5 hidden bars & speakeasies that you can visit in Seattle
12 amazing Seattle patios with great views of the city
data.when: Six different locations across the state

data.title: Willows Run
data.description: Willows Run Golf Complex has everything and more when it comes to golf. You can put the 45-hole layout but the crown jewel for the purpose of this article is Rainbow Run. It’s a great mini-putt course with a nature theme that will appeal to folks of all ages.

data.title: Columbia Super Range
data.description: If you really just want putt you can check out the Columbia Super Range chip and putt course. Beyond the 9 hole mini-course, you can also check out a putting green and practice bunker. It’s a great option for those of you that are further north.

data.title: Parkland Putters
data.description: This Tacoma spot is the furthest on the list but they only do mini-golf and have been in the game since the 1960’s so they know a thing or two. Not to mention they have 4 different courses of varying levels of difficulty so that players of all ages can have fun. Time to tee up.
data.where: : Friday 4 pm-7 pm, Saturday 12 pm- 7 pm, Sunday 12 pm-5 pm, Monday 4 pm-9 pm

data.title: Kent Valley Ice Center
data.description: Expect the unexpected at Kent Valley Ice Center. The mini-golf course has multiple water features and challenging jumps that will test your aim, making it a true battle to the end. It’s sure to be a hit with folks of all ages. Enjoy folks!
data.where: : Monday, Wednesday, Thursday 9:30 am-6 pm, Tuesday 9:30 am-7 pm, Friday & Saturday 9:30 am-9 pm, Sunday 11 am-4 pm

data.title: Check out a plant sale
data.description: Now that April is here, gardening season is just around the corner. Whether you’re in need of indoor or outdoor plants, fruit bearers, or simply beautiful blooms, there are some sales you’ll want to check out this month. Expect to find plants in all price ranges so you can take something home that works for your budget.

data.title: Visit a new museum for free
data.description:
The SPL Museum Pass program gives you access to the Burke Museum, MoPop Museum of Pop Culture, Museum of Flight, Nordic Heritage Museum, Seattle Aquarium, and Wing Luke Museum of the Asian Pacific American Experience all for free. Pretty cool right? Well get this, now you can also visit, the Center for Wooden Boats, the Henry Art Gallery, the Museum of History & Industry, the Seattle Art Museum, and the Seattle Asian Art Museum. Recent Posts:
5 hidden bars & speakeasies that you can visit in Seattle
You can fly from Seattle to Las Vegas for under $35 this spring

data.title: The Spring Fair
data.description: You can see all sorts of cute fuzzy baby animals, livestock, livestock shows, and more at The Spring Fair. Additionally, you’ll be able to see shows like DockDogs,  Swifty Swine Racing Pigs, and Motorsport Mayhem. Whatever you’re hoping to watch, it’s almost a guarantee the fair has it.

data.title: BAM Biennial 2022: Architecture & Urban Design
data.description: Explore BAM’s juried exhibition which focuses on the work of established and emerging Northwest artists, craftspeople, and designers, with an emphasis on new work. This year’s biennial focuses on specific fields and areas of studies within the realm of art, craft, and design.

data.title: Watch the Lyrid Meteor Shower
data.description: The Lyrids are known for being solidly reliable, producing at least 10-15 meteors an hour. That being said, sometimes they like to show off meaning that if you get lucky you might catch a burst with closer to 100 meteors, no guarantees though. Worth a look right? When: April 15th-29th

data.title: Go find some cherry blossoms
data.description: Cherry blossoms have started to bloom all around the city, and we rounded up our absolute favorite spots to go see them. If you’re already blossomed out, why not take the time to learn about the bloom’s history?
data.when: Click the link above for our picks

data.title: Recent Acquisitions: Jeffry Mitchell
data.description: The Frye is showcasing work from local “gay folk artist” Jeffry Mitchell. This show highlights his work with lotus bulbs and is sure to be one of the better shows that you see this year. Think bright bright, happy, and fun pieces. There are plenty of free or semi-cheap things to do in Seattle this month so get out there and have some fun! We’ll catch you back here in May.

data.title: The Freakout Weekender
data.description: The Freakout Weekender comes from the folks behind Freakout Festival. While it’s only two days long it’s bigger than you might think. “The multi-venue, multi-cultural Seattle music festival will feature over 40 artists from around the globe, including Antibalas, Austra, Molly Burch, Armand Hammer, Efterklang, Surfbort, Tunde Olaniran, Cobra Man, Public Memory, Mintfield, and many more.”

data.title: Down The Rabbit Hole at Nordo
data.description: Down The Rabbit Hole is centered around the themes of Lewis Carroll’s Alice In Wonderland. You’ll get to watch as your favorite tales like “The Walrus and the Carpenter” and “The Stolen Tart” are set to original music and performed by a local cast. It’s an experience designed to cater to all the senses.

data.title: Rainier Beach Community Seed Swap
data.description: If you’re a fan of starting your garden from seed this event is for you! “Bring your garden-saved seeds, excess seeds you have from opened packets, or just yourself if you’re just getting started. We’ll have some seeds to share too.”

data.title: Puget Sound Gesneriad Society Show & Sale
data.description: House plant enthusiasts this sale is for you! You’ll be able to see “show-quality gesneriads including African Violets, Streptocarpus, Sinningias, Columneas, Aeschynanthus, Episcias, and Kohlerias.” You’ll also be able to purchase a few of said beautiful blooms for your own collection.

data.title: Music
data.description: The Freakout Weekender The Freakout Weekender comes from the folks behind Freakout Festival. While it’s only two days long it’s bigger than you might think. “The multi-venue, multi-cultural Seattle music festival will feature over 40 artists from around the globe, including Antibalas, Austra, Molly Burch, Armand Hammer, Efterklang, Surfbort, Tunde Olaniran, Cobra Man, Public Memory, Mintfield, and many more.” Beach House Indie rock gods Beach House are helping Seattleites start April with some smooth tunes and old favorites. You’ll also be able to hear from special guest Ami Dang. Denzel Curry Next up is Denzel Curry who is arriving in Seattle with a whole crew. You’ll be able to hear from him as well as Kenny Mason, Mike Dimes, Playthatboizay. girl in red Intimate rock/pop sensation girl in red aka Marie Ulven is making the trek from Oslo to Seattle. Enjoy her tunes and get the chance to hear from Holly Humberstone as well. Disclosure Want to hear the sounds of your 2014 Tumblr playlist again? Good news, Disclosure is coming to town accompanied by opener DJ Boring. Hopefully, that’s not a foreshadowing name. Deftones Nothing like nu-metal for spring right folks? Well, no matter what you think about Deftones you really can’t go wrong with them. Dare we say this will be the best concert in April? You’ll also be able to catch opener Gojira. The Brian Jonestown Massacre At one point or another, we’ve probably all had the cords to Pish stuck in our heads. Might as well get them out by seeing The Brian Jonestown Massacre live and in person. Plus their opener is Mercury Rev, double whammy. The Magnetic Fields Indie-rock legends The Magnetic Fields will be taking over the Moore Theatre with their croony tunes. This is one of those concerts you really don’t want to miss. Tech N9ne The early 2000s are calling and they want you to go to the Tech N9ne show. We know deep down you have the desire to scream the lyrics to Caribou Lou at a live concert so don’t stop yourself. J Balvin Haven’t had the chance to check out Climate Pledge Arena yet? Reggaeton artist J Balvin will be raising the energy in CPA with his lively tunes. Feist 1, 2, 3, 4 Feist is knocking at your door… everyone who was alive in the early 2000s remembers the vice hold that Feist’s poppy tunes had on the world. So why not hear them again?

data.title: Arts & Culture
data.description: Down The Rabbit Hole at Nordo Down The Rabbit Hole is centered around the themes of Lewis Carroll’s Alice In Wonderland. You’ll get to watch as your favorite tales like “The Walrus and the Carpenter” and “The Stolen Tart” are set to original music and performed by a local cast. It’s an experience designed to cater to all the senses. Green Book Tour The Green Book Tour is a new self-guided history tour created by the soon-to-open Black & Tan Hall. It’s available both online and as an app depending on your needs. When taking the tour you’ll be transported back in time to the 1920s and 30s as you learn all about the Black-owned and Black-friendly businesses that operated along Seattle’s Jackson Street. U District Cherry Blossom Festival The best way to celebrate Seattle’s cherry blossoms is, of course, by visiting them. But it doesn’t hurt to enjoy a little bit of extra celebration, especially when it’s a new festival. The first annual U District Cherry Blossom Festival is happening now complete with blooms, food & drink specials, and shopping. Seattle Moisture Festival This festival is actually the world’s largest Comedy/Varieté festival.  It enters around 3-15 minute acts performed by artists accompanied by a live show band. To make things even more interesting, you never know what you’ll see on stage. Generally you can expect aerialists, jugglers, magicians, comedians and more. Boren Banner Series: Sadie Wechsler This piece is outside, it’s free to visit and you can do so at pretty much any time of day. Plus Wechsler’s new piece explores the history of Seattle’s own First Hill. The artist consulted the Burke Museum and members of the Duwamish Tribe in order to create a photograph that represents the ecological history of the area. BAM Biennial 2022: Architecture & Urban Design Explore BAM’s juried exhibition which focuses on the work of established and emerging Northwest artists, craftspeople, and designers, with an emphasis on new work. This year’s biennial focuses on specific fields and areas of studies within the realm of art, craft, and design. SIN at Kremwerk Each first Saturday Kremwerk puts on SIN, a fetish, EBM, and industrial night. You can expect fetish performances, drinks, and dancing. Additionally, you can see features by Seattle Shibari and professional photography by Jason Renek. If you’re looking for something new, this might just be worth checking out. MARY! A Drag Happy Hour Each week on Tuesday you can attend a drag happy hour at Chop Suey. You’ll be able to watch drag icon Jane Don’t and three of Seattle’s other premiere drag beauties do their thing. It’s sure to be the most fun you’ve had at a happy hour in a while. Contact High: A Visual History of Hip-Hop If you’ve ever wanted to see behind-the-scenes images of your favorite hip-hop artists, this exhibit is for you. MoPOP’s newest exhibit, Contact High allows visitors to see over 170 images of hip hop’s most influential artists like Missy Elliott, Jay-Z, Queen Latifah, Tupac, and more. See four decades of photography, from the late 70s to today, documenting a revolution across different aspects of life. Silent Reading Party: In-Person The beloved Silent Reading Party is back in person if you’d like to have the experience of reading amongst strangers inside of the beautiful Hotel Sorrento. Keep in mind there is a $20 food and drink minimum on top of your ticket price. Cat Tower! Cat towers are a necessary accessory for cat owners but they aren’t exactly the best looking. This unique group show focuses on Frank Crow’s invention of the cat tower. Yes, the works are inspired by the thing your cat dulls its nails on. Ooh La La! Now that the new year has come and gone, folks are looking towards the next big holiday, Valentine’s Day. Can Can’s newest show is a rose-colored soirée to remember, an original Parisian-inspired production. Like their other shows, you’ll also be able to sip on lavish libations and nosh on delectable delicacies while watching the performers work their magic. Lauren Halsey: 2021 Knight Lauren Halsey’s show is the Seattle Art Museums’ next upcoming exhibition. Her work “spans sculpture, installation, and architecture, including site-specific projects, particularly in the South Central neighborhood of Los Angeles.” Further, “her work maintains a sense of civic urgency and free-flowing imagination, reflecting the lives of the people and places around her and addressing the crucial issues confronting people of color, queer populations, and the working class.” Recent Acquisitions: Jeffry Mitchell The Frye is showcasing work from local “gay folk artist” Jeffry Mitchell. This show highlights his work with lotus bulbs and is sure to be one of the better shows that you see this year. Think bright bright, happy and fun pieces.

data.description: High energy, catchy and fun seem like the best way to describe an Amine concert. The rapper will be taking over the Showbox SODO for a performance that’s sure to help you end your March on a high note. Don’t miss out!

data.title: Enjoy one last brew at Hale’s Ales
data.description: One of Seattle’s OG independently owned breweries is closing early next month. If you’re looking to have a brew with some friends you might as well get out there and show them some love. Cheers to the weekend right?
data.where: : Monday-Friday 3 pm-9 pm and Saturdays 12 pm-9 pm, Closing April 9th

data.title: The Big Taste
data.description: This festival is truly big, guests can choose what they want to taste from over 100 wines, beers, ciders, and spirits from the Pacific Northwest. You’ll also be able to nosh on eats from Carolina Smoke for an additional cost.

data.title: Treat yourself to some sushi
data.description:
Haven’t eaten out in a while? Why not treat yourself to some sushi? After all, it’s one of the foods the PNW does best. Not only that but we went ahead and created a list of spots that you should check out in Seattle. Recent Posts:

data.title: Hit up a waterfront patio
data.description: Ready for patio season? We’re right behind ya and that’s why we made a list of some of our favorite waterfront patios around the city. Because what’s better than a patio on the water?

Whether you need planting containers, tools, seeds, or more, there are several great places worth visiting around the city. We’ve compiled a list of spots for you that are sure to have plenty of seeds to keep your garden costs low. Enjoy your weekend, Seattle!

data.title: Beach House
data.description: Indie rock gods Beach House are helping Seattleites start April with some smooth tunes and old favorites. You’ll also be able to hear from special guest Ami Dang.

data.title: Denzel Curry
data.description: Next up is Denzel Curry who is arriving in Seattle with a whole crew. You’ll be able to hear from him as well as Kenny Mason, Mike Dimes, Playthatboizay.

data.title: girl in red
data.description: Intimate rock/pop sensation girl in red aka Marie Ulven is making the trek from Oslo to Seattle. Enjoy her tunes and get the chance to hear from Holly Humberstone as well.

data.title: Disclosure
data.description: Want to hear the sounds of your 2014 Tumblr playlist again? Good news, Disclosure is coming to town accompanied by opener DJ Boring. Hopefully, that’s not a foreshadowing name.

data.title: Deftones
data.description:
Nothing like nu-metal for spring right folks? Well, no matter what you think about Deftones you really can’t go wrong with them. Dare we say this will be the best concert in April? You’ll also be able to catch opener Gojira. Recent Posts:
Sky High: Scenic flight tours you can take in & around Seattle this spring

data.title: The Brian Jonestown Massacre
data.description: At one point or another, we’ve probably all had the cords to Pish stuck in our heads. Might as well get them out by seeing The Brian Jonestown Massacre live and in person. Plus their opener is Mercury Rev, double whammy.

data.title: The Magnetic Fields
data.description: Indie-rock legends The Magnetic Fields will be taking over the Moore Theatre with their croony tunes. This is one of those concerts you really don’t want to miss.

data.title: Tech N9ne
data.description: The early 2000s are calling and they want you to go to the Tech N9ne show. We know deep down you have the desire to scream the lyrics to Caribou Lou at a live concert so don’t stop yourself.

data.title: J Balvin
data.description: Haven’t had the chance to check out Climate Pledge Arena yet? Reggaeton artist J Balvin will be raising the energy in CPA with his lively tunes.

data.title: Feist
data.description: 1, 2, 3, 4 Feist is knocking at your door… everyone who was alive in the early 2000s remembers the vice hold that Feist’s poppy tunes had on the world. So why not hear them again? There you have it, enjoy Seattle!

data.title: Bonobo
data.description: We’ve got three concerts to recommend this week, and they’re all worth checking out. Expect an evening of chill, jazzy songs from Simon Green’s 6 albums. It’s the perfect excuse to end your March on an absolutely blissed-out note.

data.title: The Sling Tour: Clairo with Arlo Parks
data.description: Clairo’s music has grown considerably since her quick rise to fame. Frome bedroom pop to more folky tunes you’ll be able to hear your faves at this concert with both her and Arlo Parks.

data.title: Billie Eilish: Happier Than Ever World Tour

data.title: Field Guides: A Walking Meditation
data.description: Seattle’s Freeway Park has a brand new way to interact with it. data.where: : Freeway Park, Sixth Ave and Seneca St

data.title: Cat Tower!
data.description: Cat towers are a necessary accessory for cat owners but they aren’t exactly the best looking. This unique group show focuses on Frank Crow’s invention of the cat tower. Yes, the works are inspired by the thing your cat dulls its nails on.

data.title: Lauren Halsey: 2021 Knight
data.description: Lauren Halsey’s show is the Seattle Art Museums’ next upcoming exhibition. Her work “spans sculpture, installation, and architecture, including site-specific projects, particularly in the South Central neighborhood of Los Angeles.” Further, “her work maintains a sense of civic urgency and free-flowing imagination, reflecting the lives of the people and places around her and addressing the crucial issues confronting people of color, queer populations, and the working class.” Have a great weekend, Seattle!

data.title: Go on a day trip adventure
